webTitle: Fiji hostage drama has violent twist

fields.headline: Fiji hostage drama has violent twist
fields.standfirst: Clashes in Suva as President sacks captive PM and grants immunity to leader of the coup
fields.trailText: The international theatre of the absurd has a new act.
fields.body:
The international theatre of the absurd has a new act.

The South Pacific islands of Fiji have taken centre stage thanks to a coup that has the audience scratching its head and wondering whether to laugh out loud or walk out in protest during the interval.

The indigenous Fijian businessman George Speight and his small band of armed rebels stormed the parliament building in the capital, Suva, 10 days ago, taking hostage the Indian Fijian Prime Minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, and his cabinet.

Chaudhry has reportedly been beaten and mentally tortured and yesterday was said to be in urgent need of medical attention for internal injuries.

The West was quick to respond with outrage, calling Speight a terrorist and condemning his thuggery. Australia, the closest major power, initially treated the coup as a short-lived affair that would be put down in days. Speight was rated as power-crazy but not dangerous.

But yesterday, to the amazement of many - possibly even Speight himself - Fiji's President, Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara, sacked Prime Minister Chaudhry and his government as they sat helpless in captivity. He suspended parliament and announced that he will appoint a caretaker administration today or tomorrow.

Mara also said Speight and his followers would probably be granted immunity from prosecution for their roles in the coup. He expected the world would react 'very badly' to the decision.

Shortly before the announcement the situation threatened to get ugly when shots were fired as rebels and Fijian soldiers clashed at a roadblock outside the parliament complex - the first visible violence since the coup began. Rebels tried to grab soldiers' weapons and pushed one of them to the ground. Soldiers fired warning shots and at least three people were injured.

Until now the politics and threats of violence have almost become sideshows in favour of Speight's star performance. At first he banned the media from the environs of the parliament complex. Then one night, with a couple of henchmen, he gave a dramatic after-dark press conference from behind the locked front gates.

Next he changed tack, conscious possibly of overacting the bogeyman. He invited the cameras and reporters into the complex with open arms. Was he taking hostages, we wondered? Far from it. He gave them access to film and a feed.

More significantly, some were offered kava, the traditional Fijian narcotic drink which is made from roots mashed in water. Fijians drink kava only with good friends, relatives and honoured guests.

As this coup has progressed, it has been easy to get distracted by this colourful action down at the footlights. Off stage in the wings, a real tragedy is unfolding. There sit a group of democratically elected politicians including the nation's Prime Minister - possibly with life-threatening injuries - with gun barrels being held to their temples.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: The tale of a relationship that bloomed in mutual melodrama, plus April Rising, All the Names, The Penguin Book of Twentieth-Century Essays, Timbuktu and Persian Brides
fields.body:
Love is Where it Falls
Simon Callow
Penguin £7.99, pp214
Buy it at BOL

Callow's memoir of his friendship with the famed literary agent Peggy Ramsay details a relationship that seems to have flourished in the rich mulch of mutual melodrama despite the obvious obstacles of age - she was 70 to his 30 when they met - and sexuality. Ramsay was besotted from their first encounter, and initially made a forlorn attempt at seduction. Later their relationship settled into a mind-bogglingly dedicated exchange of confidences, letters and gifts (not least an entire flat for Callow), a rather touching romance that was to last until her death. 'Dear, dear, dear Simon,' one of Peggy's letters breathes, 'you have a temperament that vibrates at the fall of a leaf.' Ironically, perhaps, those of a sterner temperament may find it all a bit much.

April Rising
Corene Lemaître
HarperCollins £5.99, pp276
Buy it at BOL

Spoilt, sharp-tongued Ellen returns to her sleepy home town after a two-year holiday to find - not an entirely original plot twist, this one - that Someone's Been Sleeping in Her Bed. The someone turns out to be April, her brother's new white-trash-with-a-heart-of-gold girlfriend. April's real home is the kind of place where 'near relations mount each other', as our heroine delicately puts it, and Ellen would like nothing better than for her to return there. What follows is almost the pure Lite romantic comedy implied by the book's repulsively Chic-Lit jacket, but not quite. Ms Lema&icric;tre's confident handling of startling words like 'oubliette' joins a positively depilatory turn of phrase to inject a redeeming shot of acid into her fairy story.

All the Names
José Saramago
Harvill Panther £6.99, pp244
Buy it at BOL

Senhor José labours as a clerk in the frightening labyrinth of the Central Registry, ordering and transcribing the city's records of the living and the dead. The terrible simplicity of his existence is one day halted when he chances upon the index card of an ordinary woman. Inexplicably, inexorably, Senhor José's quest to find this woman in the flesh begins to eclipse everything else in his life. The allegorical implications of Saramago's astonishing novel are legion; but as his battered, diffident hero recognises, 'nothing so tires a person as having to struggle, not with himself but with an abstraction'. And we needn't, for the novel's metaphoric resonances are never obvious or obtrusive, but are quietly meshed in prose of great humanity and gentleness.

The Penguin Book of Twentieth-Century Essays
edited by Ian Hamilton
Penguin £8.99, pp555
Buy it at BOL In his preface to this brilliant collection, Ian Hamilton confesses that he still has unhappy memories of having to write an essay 'On Pianos' for his Oxford entrance exam. If he'd edited this book then, he could have turned to James Thurber's masterful exposé of his secret life for guidance, although as Thurber is the first to modestly admit, 'the naked truth about me is to the naked truth about Salvador Dali as an old ukulele in the attic is to a piano in a tree, and I mean a piano with breasts'. Superb writing on more serious subjects features in equal abundance.

Timbuktu
Paul Auster
Faber £6.99, pp186
Buy it at BOL

'If you can't eat it or screw it, piss on it.' Such is the philosophy of life according to dogs, as confided to Mr Bones, the canine hero of Auster's inventive novel. But Mr Bones's world view is altogether more complex than the motto quoted above would seem to suggest. As sole companion and confidante to his damaged, brilliant master Willy G. Christmas, Mr Bones has acquired an understanding of life that frequently transcends that of his human counterparts. Auster has great fun with his mongrel protagonist, but it's Timbuktu 's investigation of the terrible potency of loyalty that really makes sense of its hero.

 Sophie Harrison

Persian Brides
Dorit Rabinyan
Canongate, £6.99, pp200
Buy it at BOL

This centres on the love-lives of Flora and Nazie, Jewish girls in Persia at the turn of the century; Flora's husband abandons her, Nazie is impatient to marry the man promised her. The characters and setting are skilfully evoked. The book is based on incidents from Rabinyan's family history, which she brings to life without sentimentality, although the earthiness of the characters occasionally results in a little too much anatomical detail. Nonetheless, an assured vision of a beautiful, if brutal world.

 Tony Wood

webTitle: BBC set to turn debut novel into £5m serial

fields.headline: BBC set to turn debut novel into £5m serial
fields.trailText: White Teeth, the acclaimed first novel by 24-year-old Zadie Smith, is to be made into a £5 million television serial for BBC 1.
fields.body:
White Teeth, the acclaimed first novel by 24-year-old Zadie Smith, is to be made into a £5 million television serial for BBC 1.

Her deal is thought to be the only time the work of such a young writer has been bought for a major British television adaptation. White Teeth is tipped to win the £30,000 Orange Prize for Fiction on 6 June. Last year Smith, a Cambridge graduate, won a £250,000 advance from publishers Hamish Hamilton for the novel.

The book is set in Britain during the 1970s and the present and tells the story of three multicultural families and how they came to live as neighbours in the suburbs of north London. After its publication in January, the book quickly attracted praise from many established literary figures, including Salman Rushdie.

The BBC and the independent production group Company Television have grabbed the rights from under the noses of Hollywood. Some of the biggest film-makers in the United States - including Miramax, the makers of Shakespeare in Love - had made approaches to Smith, but she was determined to see her book on British television.

'Money was not a big issue. I love TV, so I thought this would be a lot of fun,' she said. 'It suits TV too. You would have lost a lot of the story and some of the characters in a film.'

The author, who has taken up a post as writer in residence at London's Institute of Contemporary Art since graduating, told The Observer that she wants White Teeth to reach a television audience, rather than a cinema audience.

Smith is in the middle of a book tour of America, but she will return to London at the end of this week for the announcement of the Orange Prize. The anonymously endowed prize is open to women authors only and has been running for five years. Previous winners include Helen Dunmore and Anne Michaels. This year the competition has been judged by a panel that includes Ffion Hague and is headed by the journalist Polly Toynbee.

Smith's book has been the favourite ever since the short list was released.

The television adaptation will be made by the production team behind the current serialisation of Anna Karenina. Company Television also made The Lakes and A Young Person's Guide to Becoming a Rock Star .

The full cast for the serial has not yet been discussed, but Smith is keen to approach Penelope Wilton, who recently played Michael Gambon's wife in the BBC's production of Elizabeth Gaskell's Wives and Daughters, for the role of Joyce, the white, middle-class mother figure of the novel.

Smith, who is half-Jamaican, would like a female writer to adapt the book for television.


Vanessa Thorpe

webTitle: Sontag pleads poetic licence in using uncredited 'scraps of history'

fields.headline: Sontag pleads poetic licence in using uncredited 'scraps of history'
fields.trailText: A debate between history and literature has opened in New York over Susan Sontag's acclaimed new novel  In America, published here next week. Sontag is accused by amateur historian Ellen Lee of failing to credit sources.
fields.body:
A debate between history and literature has opened in New York over Susan Sontag's acclaimed new novel In America, published here next week. Sontag is accused by amateur historian Ellen Lee of failing to credit sources.

Sontag's historical fiction is about a Polish actress, Maryna Zalezowska, who ventures from Poland to an experimental Californian farming community. Instead of staying there she returns to acting and becomes a star. The book explores themes of emigration, exile, belonging and self-regeneration.

The plot echoes the career of real-life actress Helena Modjeska, the particular interest of Lee, who helped found the Modjeska foundation in California. Now, Lee has told the New York Times that passages in the novel resembling parts of books about Modjeska, and her diaries, should be credited.

The debate invokes the non-existence of attribution rules governing historical fiction and the question of how rules of acknowledgement that govern academic work can apply to fiction when it creates characters by using what author Thomas Mallon - supporting Sontag - calls 'scraps and traces of history'.

Among the sources Lee believes should have been credited are books about the actress, Polish verse, old newspaper articles, and Modjeska's own Memories and Impressions . Lee says borrowing references is unacceptable. Sontag, however, is surprised by such a reaction.

Sontag's eclectic oeuvre encompasses fiction, essays, films and plays, and has been important in developing the historical novel genre.

Debating Lee in the New York Times, Sontag did not contest similarities between texts; rather, she posits counter-rules for historical fiction whereby a novelist is not required to annotate everything. Many are whimsical literary references, she says. 'The sources themselves are working with other sources, and they are using quotations from actual words,' says Sontag. Much of the other work mentioned by Lee, for instance, is from newspapers that Sontag traced.

'All of us who deal with real characters in history,' she says, 'transcribe and adopt original sources in the original domain. I've used these sources and completely transformed them.

'There's a larger argument to be made that all of literature is a series of references and allusions.'

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: Few poets can have attracted as many biographers, but Brenda Maddox's brilliant account of Yeats is an essential text.
fields.body:
George's Ghosts: A New Life of WB Yeats
Brenda Maddox
Picador £8.99
Buy it at BOL

Few poets can have attracted as many biographers, but Brenda Maddox's brilliant account of Yeats is an essential text. It has clarity and elegance and is an unfailingly entertaining read. But its real power flows from its insights into the emotional baggage this strange genius carried through his life and, in particular, the influence of women on the man and his art.

First, there was his mother, who denied him either demonstrative love or overt approval but richly endowed him with the power and imagery of Irish folk myth. Then there was Maud Gonne, with whom Yeats was for many years obsessed, who briefly gave him her sexual favours but eventually rejected him. He transferred his passion to her daughter, Iseult, with incestuous undertones since Maud had conceived the notion that she was Yeats's child. By 1917, he was determined to marry, to reproduce himself, and he wed Georgie Hyde-Lees on the rebound from Iseult's rejection.

Yeats was a very odd fish indeed, yet his frailties were necessary to his art. His finest work flowed from sorrows, failures and inadequacies over which he agonised. Towards the end of his life, he became an increasingly ludicrous figure. He had a genital operation to restore his potency so that he could live, as he wished, like an old goat. Dublin, which had laughed at him as a masturbator in the old days, now laughed at what it thought of as a new folie de grandeur.

Comic figure, yes; fool, often. His poetry, its technique honed to perfection, sometimes outstripped his intellect. Yet Yeats left a giant footprint on literature and, not least, helped to invent the mythology of modern Ireland.

webTitle: Bronson's blonde is belle of the underworld

fields.headline: Bronson's blonde is belle of the underworld
fields.trailText: At a gathering of the underworld's favourite sons the talk was not of gangland hits or post office jobs, but book sales, counted by the thousand.
fields.body:
Tony Lambrionou, former henchman to the Kray twins, has done 40-odd. Ex-armed robber Roy 'Pretty Boy' Shaw, who once killed a man in prison with his bare hands, has done more than 50, while 'Dodgy' Dave Courtney, killer turned columnist, just topped 55. 'Big' Joey Pyle, another Kray associate, hasn't done any but points out that the others are a long way behind the late Lenny Maclean, aka The Guvnor, who did more than 150.

At a gathering of the underworld's favourite sons the talk was not of gangland hits or post office jobs, but book sales, counted by the thousand.

The party, at the Million Hare pub in Woolwich, South-east London, had been in full swing since 7.30pm with 'real men' in the back room swapping war stories and chomping cigars as they waited for the guest of honour. Three hours later a white stretch limo pulled into the car park alongside the Rolls- Royces and Mercedes, and a bemused blonde in a beret and 'Born To Be Wild' t-shirt stepped out.

After six years' jail for trying to smuggle tens of thousands of pounds worth of cocaine into Heathrow, 34-year-old Joyce Connor, a one-time sculptor, was welcomed into the bosom of London's criminal elite.

The event was set up by Charles Bronson, Britain's most violent prison inmate. Bronson (whose autobiography has sold more than 25,000 copies) has carried out three armed robberies and has six convictions for violence against fellow inmates. He has led eight jail rooftop protests. The hardman is now serving 15 years for possession of a gun and hostage-taking. He recently received a further seven years for holding fellow prisoners in his cell and threatening to eat them.

As soon as the authorities allow it, Joyce Connor will become his wife.

They have never met but fell in love after swapping letters. Speaking in a strong Canadian accent - she emigrated there as a child - she explained: 'I was always interested in working in the field of art therapy, using it as a way of gaining an insight into people with difficult personalities and I began writing to Bronson after seeing some of his drawings in a newspaper. I was going through a very difficult time, and through it all, Charlie has been the only one who has really supported me and helped me get through it. I have never been happier.'

Lack of physical contact does not concern her. 'You see people who have only just met going off and screwing each other. They don't really know each other at all. With Charlie and me it's not like that. We can't fall back into having sex. A real relationship is about more than that. It's about honour, trust and respect. I see a side of him that no one else does.' The odd couple plan to co-write their love story in a series of books and comics.

Bronson, 45, was born Michael Peterson but changed his name to that of the Death Wish star. He does 2,000 press-ups every day. In a letter from his cell he wrote: 'Joyce has lit up my life. I am obviously a very volatile man. She understands my strangeness. She is my princess.'

They have never met but fell in love after swapping letters. Speaking in a strong Canadian accent - she emigrated there as a child - she explained: 'I was always interested in working in the field of art therapy, using it as a way of gaining an insight into people with difficult personalities and I began writing to Bronson after seeing some of his drawings in a newspaper. I was going through a very difficult time, and through it all, Charlie has been the only one who has really supported me and helped me get through it. I have never been happier.' Lack of physical contact does not concern her. 'You see people who have only just met going off and screwing each other. They don't really know each other at all. With Charlie and me it's not like that. We can't fall back into having sex. A real relationship is about more than that. It's about honour, trust and respect. I see a side of him that no one else does.' The odd couple plan to co-write their love story in a series of books and comics. Bronson, 45, was born Michael Peterson but changed his name to that of the Death Wish star. He does 2,000 press-ups every day. In a letter from his cell he wrote: 'Joyce has lit up my life. I am obviously a very volatile man. She understands my strangeness. She is my princess.'

webTitle: Welcome to Florida, home of Noah's Ark

fields.headline: Welcome to Florida, home of Noah's Ark
fields.standfirst: Rory Maclean's Next Exit to Magic Kingdom makes you pleased that he saved you the trouble of going to Florida
fields.trailText: Rory Maclean's Next Exit to Magic Kingdom makes you pleased that he saved you the trouble of going to Florida
fields.body:
Next Exit Magic Kingdom
Rory Maclean
HarperCollins £16.99, pp224

Rory Maclean, an award-winning travel writer, had spent four months researching for another award-winning trip. But instead, he 'went to Florida because the Daily Mail was delivered to my door by mistake. If my usual paper had turned up I'd be in Germany now'.

The Mail was full of adverts for Florida and devoid of any for sunsational fun in Bavaria or fly-drive bargains in Schleswig-Holstein. So the next day, MacLean flies to the state that dangles off the bottom of the US, armed with shorts and sunscreen but no itinerary. He seeks to apply some of his hard-won Teutonic insights to his new destination but soon becomes intrigued by his own intuition and seemingly random choices to stop here or there or turn this way or that.

There are plenty of opportunities to examine such profundities as he encounters Cassadaga Spiritualist Camp ('a Historical District since 1992'), the Liberty Correctional Institute and a mermaid in Weeki Wachee. He is propositioned by a hot chick in late-night Miami. He is punched by a German dad in the Believe It Or Not Museum because he refuses to confirm to a German brat the authenticity of the human unicorn (maybe a bit more research on Germans was needed).

He helps move an alligator that was squatting in a suburban swimming-pool to the swamps that are disappearing under retirement homes. (It has to be caught again and released three times for the benefit of the local TV crew.) He visits the alleged site of the Garden of Eden (it seems Noah's Ark had been carried by the 'atmospheric drift' from Florida to Mount Ararat).

Wherever he goes, he engages with local characters, often adopting tactics that could lead to nasty scrapes if used by someone with less charm. 'I wonder if you can help me. I'm looking for the best person in town. Who's Palatka's good samaritan?' he asks through the bulletproof glass of the police station of the town where he's been told there is 'nothin' and no one good'.

Some travel books make you want to 'go there' with the writer. This one makes you pleased he's done it for you. For a month, he spent his time in his own company or that of strangers. Maybe it's easier to be yourself that way. As he returns to Gatwick, MacLean reflects that 'a journey is not a linear thread, as the Cruel Fates would have it, with cause and effect tumbling over each other along its measured length. Rather, it is a spiral, fluid and unfixed, elegant and ephemeral'. Sometimes, the journey is not just about travel.

webTitle: Reader, I had sex with just about everybody...

fields.headline: Reader, I had sex with just about everybody...
fields.standfirst: DM Thomas's reworking of Jane Eyre, Charlotte,  forsakes Brontë's characters for his own obsessions
fields.trailText: DM Thomas's reworking of Jane Eyre, Charlotte, forsakes Brontë's characters for his own obsessions
fields.body:
Charlotte: Brontë Revelations
DM Thomas
Duck Editions £14.99, pp173

'My Edward and I, then, are happy...' Not so, Jane Eyre, not so. In DM Thomas's radical reworking of Jane Eyre, the Rochesters find that married life does not run quite as smoothly as Charlotte Brontë had led us to believe it would. This alternative ending is, we learn, a personal fantasy jotted down by Miranda, a lecturer in women's studies who has been invited to Martinique to deliver a talk on Brontë. It is, Miranda muses, a way of exploring 'some of the repressed issues' in this much-loved novel. Naturally, 'repressed issues' means sex. 'Reader, you will expect me to draw a veil over the intimacies which transpire between a man and his wife. I am sorry to disappoint and offend you...'

According to Miranda's imaginings, the Rochesters' marriage is never consummated. (We have strayed from the Brontë narrative immediately after the wedding - long before the birth of their son.) It takes two years for Jane to realise that something is wrong, but during a frank exchange with the former Miss Temple, her mentor at Lowood, Jane discovers that her relations with Rochester are, indeed, rather unconventional. After Jane has confronted her husband gingerly about this, he rides off in a fury and is thrown from his horse. At his funeral, she loses her faith and, discovering that there is in fact a Rochester heir, a boy who was left behind with Bertha's family (which comes, puzzlingly, from Martinique, rather than Jamaica, as in the source novel), sets off to find him for financial as well as personal reasons.

This narrative is entwined with the sexual questings of Miranda, mistakenly addressed as 'Madame Brontë' by a Martinique official who misreads her details on arrival. Far away from her husband David, who is designing the Faith Zone in the Dome - as if it didn't have enough problems - Miranda sees the island as a happy hunting ground, and sweatily seduces a bartender, a cane-cutter and a transvestite. The Literary Review 's 'Bad Sex' judges will find a wealth of material here.

Though Miranda professes to be madly political ('Columbus. Cortez. Nato. Bastards') and is deeply affected by the tale of Carib chiefs throwing themselves off cliffs in order to escape the white invaders, she is oblivious to the politics of her own situation: a bored Caucasian woman on holiday, industriously seducing the local population.

If these chaps misunderstand, get too involved, then she loses her temper: 'Reader, I told him to piss off.' It's impossible to empathise with this hardboiled creature who, as the novel gets going, makes so much noise that she almost entirely drowns out poor old Jane. Miranda, whether abroad or at home playing up to her sicko dad, Ben, is a badly drawn satire; a clumsy poke in the eye of women's studies, which has celebrated the mad woman in the attic.

There are some truly disturbing bits in the novel, but they're usually the bits that show how very wonky Thomas's horizon is, how skewwhiff his moral perspective. On Martinique, one of Miranda's more obliging conquests tells her that his girlfriend was delighted to hear about their encounter: 'She feel proud of me. Her man could get a lovely white woman.'

Miranda makes it clear that her notebooks began as a lie, a forgery, to distract her father Ben from 'this Brooklyn Jewish harridan' who was threatening their intimacy. There's more than a nod in the direction of The Tempest: a bibliophile like Prospero, Ben has been abandoned - cast adrift! - by the rest of the family, for reasons which he finds a bit rich. 'What is this fucking puritan, politically correct modern world, where it's fine to fuck a dozen men up the bum in a bathhouse, but you can't make your own granddaughter giggle with a tickle of her little patate?' he fulminates.

Jane Eyre has proved repeatedly that it's robust enough to endure - occasionally be enriched by - endless reworkings, of which Jean Rhys's Wide Sargasso Sea has been the most effective. Charlotte, on the other hand, sheds no light on the original, being embarrassingly self-indulgent. At heart, it fails because it does not engage with the characters drawn by Brontë, being far more interested in the rapacious cyphers who populate the contemporary part of the novel. DM Thomas, once fêted for The White Hotel, bangs on so relentlessly about sex that before long you're desperate to treat him as you would an embarrassing party drunk, and order him a taxi, sharpish. But no matter. Charlotte Brontë can take whatever DM Thomas chooses to throw at her. Too much of the time, he is firing blanks.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: The best of the Poet Laureate's poems from the last twenty years read in his own measured tones
fields.body:
Selected Poems 1976-1997
Andrew Motion

Read by the author
Running time 2 hours 30 minutes
Faber - Penguin audiobooks

When the Poet Laureate was first appointed, unkind souls went about conducting straw polls to see what, if anything, the man in the street could quote of Professor Motion's verse. Here, then, is the perfect antidote to the humming and blank deliberation that appeared to follow this question. Though he may have entered the wider public consciousness with his recent verse tributes to the Wessex marriage and the Millennium, this collection presents the best of Motion's poetry over the past 20 years, read in his familiar, calm, carefully measured tones.

There are the early, moving poems about his mother's last illness and death; the narrative verse about his grandfather's experiences in the First World War; his own elliptical reminiscences on younger days - 'Hull', the 'fish-smelling pastoral' where he lived in Larkin's footsteps, or a journey around England's cathedral cities. There are longer narrative poems like 'Lines of Desire', a reflection on his father's experiences in the Second World War and his own memories of his father, its rhythms plunging the listener deep into the poet's intimate imaginings and visions.

Here, just as in his 'live' readings, Motion introduces many of the poems with a short précis - a background that fixes the poem in a particular time and place. While not strictly necessary - there is a clarity to Motion's verse that makes it often self-explanatory - they give the readings a more personal flavour, as if the poet has taken you into his confidence.

fields.headline: The reluctant author
fields.standfirst: Stephanie Merritt meets Canada's leading writer who was accused of insulting the royals and whose ninth novel is tipped as a Booker contender
fields.trailText: Stephanie Merritt meets Timothy Findley, Canada's leading writer, who was accused of insulting the royals and whose ninth novel is tipped as a Booker contender
fields.body:
'I'm as happy as a lark,' says Timothy Findley, squinting into the sunshine, lighting another cigarette and beaming, before tucking into possibly the largest glass of wine I have seen anyone wielding at 11 o'clock in the morning. You can tell that Findley is enjoying life; he radiates contentment, the kind of happiness that comes from knowing you are in exactly the right place, doing exactly what you love most. Canada's leading writer is 70 now, and he's worked hard for this; nine novels, three short-story collections, two volumes of memoir and three plays.

His ninth novel, Pilgrim (Faber, £10.99), has just been published here, and he's greatly excited because, despite his importance in the United States and Canada and a raft of honorary degrees and awards (including the prestigious Chevalier de l'Ordre des Arts et des Lettres), he hasn't been published in the UK for nearly 15 years and has never been here to promote a book before.

We're on the terrace of his hotel in Bloomsbury, and on the next table Bill Whitehead, Findley's partner of more than 30 years, is also contentedly chain-smoking and cradling a glass of wine, looking out over the gardens. 'Sometimes he needs my memory,' Bill confides in a stage whisper; Findley ('Tiff', as he is known to everyone) pretends to be annoyed. Sometimes they finish each other's sentences. They are both neatly dressed, charming, kindly, funny and with a slight whiff of the theatre about them, a vestige of their previous career. They are, in short, lovely; they make you want to spend all day with them, be a part of their world.

That Findley should be so little known in this country is extraordinary, when the others of his generation (which he describes without a trace of self-importance as 'the golden age of Canadian literature') are internationally feted: Margaret Atwood, Alice Munroe, Mordecai Richler, Michael Ondaatje. Findley is convinced that he fell from grace with the British literary world because of our fierce loyalty to the royal family. In 1986, his fourth novel, Famous Last Words, which features the Duke and Duchess of Windsor as fictional characters, was published here to surprisingly hostile reviews, though it had been well received by US critics.

'I've never read anything so cruel,' he says, looking sad, and you immediately want to beat up anyone who would be mean to him. 'Their attitude was really, "How dare this upstart colonial insult our royals?". But the papers were very unkind about the book, so I think publishers were wary of taking me on after that.'

Their caution meant that British readers missed out on two of Findley's finest novels, Headhunter and The Pianoman's Daughter. But he is delighted that it is Pilgrim - already a bestseller in Canada, heaped with critical acclaim in the US press and tipped as a likely Booker contender - that marks his return to the British literary arena.

Pilgrim is a daring novel, one which broaches hefty and complex questions about the 'big themes' - art, death, consciousness, humanity. It's also impossible to put down, serious and funny with deep resonances and a cast of wonderful characters. Pilgrim is a man who has lived for ever; like the prophet Tiresias, he cannot die and has been both male and female.

In 1912, after another fruitless suicide attempt, he is taken to the Burgholzi Clinic in Zurich, where he becomes a patient of an ambitious, unorthodox young doctor named Carl Gustav Jung. Through Pilgrim, Jung begins to understand the collective unconscious; Pilgrim, meanwhile, being prescient, can see the approaching horror of the First World War and in response, sets out on a journey of destruction, obliterating the landmarks of European art which, he feels, can have no place or meaning to a humanity bent on destroying itself. Findley's prose is beautifully poised, his sentences carefully weighed and precise. Each evening, he asks Bill to read aloud the pages he has written that day, wanting to hear their rhythm, feeling that if the tongue trips on the words, the mind will too.

Findley's great strength is his feel for dialogue, a talent nurtured during the 15 years he spent working as a professional actor. He had his first acting job at 17, but his break came when he was cast with Alec Guinness and Irene Worth at the inaugural Shakespeare Festival at Stratford, Ontario in 1953. 'For a young actor it was wonderful,' he says, blue eyes shining with pleasure as he remembers. 'Good God, here I was at 22 and I was working with these people - I even had a whole scene with Guinness! Well, he thought very highly of me as a young actor, so he and Tyrone Guthrie put together some money for me to come and study in London.'

He trained at the Central School of Speech and Drama and was ambitious in his stage career until, at the age of 32, he wrote a short story in order to win an argument with the actress Ruth Gordon. 'I thought, there's only one way I can win this argument, and that's by being the only voice. So I went home and I wrote a story, which I had never done before, and when she read it she put her arms around me and said, "Oh, Tiffy, you must give up acting just as fast as you can!" And I thought, I beg your bloody pardon - I want to be Laurence Olivier, I want to be Alec Guinness, I'm not giving up! But she said, "Because you are a born writer, and there are so few that we can't afford to lose one." Isn't that lovely?'

Life hasn't always been so happy for Findley. He cared for his brother who died slowly of alcoholism, and Findley has had his own battles on that front. 'But through therapy, and through Bill, I've managed to solve it. I now drink nothing but wine.' He twinkles, lifting his glass. 'I think you can give up so easily and say, oh, the suffering is beyond me - well, if you didn't have some suffering, how would you ever grow up? And the how the hell would you know how to write? It doesn't mean you provoke it, or wallow in it, but I do believe that you couldn't write if there wasn't an awareness of suffering. It's one of the ingredients of all good writers.' But he does admit that 'if I didn't have a foot truly anchored on the ground, and a man to live with who saves my sanity every day, I don't know why I wouldn't just sink into alcoholism and get out of here.'

For now, though, there is a lot to look forward to. His new play, Elizabeth Rex, is about to open in Stratford, Ontario, then he and Bill leave for their house in Provence. 'We're going on a special dispensation,' he says. 'Usually you can't leave Canada for more than six months at a time or you lose your pension and your benefits. But if you're near the end of your life, they let you make a special trip, just once, to stay longer.'

It's odd to hear him say that, as if a cloud has suddenly passed over. But he's hard at work on another novel, and there are other ideas, possible titles scribbled on the backs of cigarette packets, other characters waiting to appear. Tiff is still in the sun.

For now, though, there is a lot to look forward to. His new play, Elizabeth Rex, is about to open in Stratford, Ontario, then he and Bill leave for their house in Provence. 'We're going on a special dispensation,' he says. 'Usually you can't leave Canada for more than six months at a time or you lose your pension and your benefits. But if you're near the end of your life, they let you make a special trip, just once, to stay longer.' It's odd to hear him say that, as if a cloud has suddenly passed over. But he's hard at work on another novel, and there are other ideas, possible titles scribbled on the backs of cigarette packets, other characters waiting to appear. Tiff is still in the sun.

fields.headline: Tales from the cryptic
fields.standfirst: The Complete Poems of William Empson is short on poetry and long on notes
fields.trailText: The Complete Poems of William Empson is short on poetry and long on notes
fields.body:
The Complete Poems of William Empsonedited by John Haffenden
Allen Lane £30, pp512
Buy it at BOL

The poet and critic William Empson, who died in 1984, was the newly risen star of Cambridge English in its heyday of the late Twenties, and seemed, with his probing, scientific cast of mind, to exemplify the spirit of the place then. He came to literature via mathematics. In September 1930, at the age of 24, he published Seven Types of Ambiguity, the classic statement of the techniques of close reading championed by his tutor, I.A. Richards.

Before this moment of triumph, however, he had been banished from his fellowship at Magdalene, after contraceptives had been discovered among his possessions by a porter; he spent the rest of his life as an itinerant university teacher, mostly in Japan and China, latterly in Sheffield, where his marvellously dedicated editor, John Haffenden, has since inherited his chair.

As he had already, before his expulsion, written half the poems he was ever to publish, many commentators, including F.R. Leavis, have characterised Empson's career as a falling away from these brilliant beginnings. He was certainly not prolific. Of this monumental volume's 500 pages, an almost comically small proportion - barely 100 - have poems on them. The rest is annotation.

Empson's two collections of verse had as much explicatory prose in them as they had poetry; not, as is said of the notes to The Waste Land, to bring small books up to size, but from a conviction that the writer might be able to explain the whole meaning of his poem. These notes are supplemented here, sometimes repetitively, by information volunteered by the author in letters and interviews, and then again by the panoply of Haffenden's work on the poems; so that this is a complete edition of the poems and an exhaustive companion to them.

But should any poems need to be buttressed by so much apparatus? Leavis regretted what he judged to be Empson's 'unprofitable obscurity', and not all the notes in the world could make easy going of a poem like 'Bacchus', Empson's longest exercise in the cryptic mode, impressive and exasperating alike to Peter Porter, who called it 'the most difficult poem in the world'. Empson wanted his poems to be complicated in the way that life is, and since he thought that 'life involves maintaining oneself between contradictions that can't be solved by analysis', it's little wonder if they sometimes seem to close themselves off from the reader.

When Empson's verse has been in favour, notably in the early Fifties, it was for qualities that might be summarised as sanity: intelligence, formal assurance, the charm of his eccentric perceptions (a juggler whose apples are rotten, etc); qualities resembling those of the metaphysical poets of the early seventeenth century. Yet Haffenden's labours encourage us now to a different reading of the poems' reserve and obscurity.

Empson acknowledged in retrospect that his poems were attempts to objectify and so to control what he called 'neurotic [uncaused] fear'. His sufferings from nervous illness will, no doubt, be detailed in Haffenden's forthcoming biography. Meanwhile, it is evidently no coincidence that he wrote (or preserved) hardly a line of verse after his marriage in 1941, when he was 35. His first poems, so exacting in their allusiveness, are revealed as those of a boy afraid of a girl; the second crop, collected in The Gathering Storm in 1940, are those of a world in fear of war.

Empson's poems have always seemed deeply felt at the same time as they are extravagantly imagined or intricately argued. We have his sanction here to categorise them as 'Despair Poetry'; and he excelled at forms like the villanelle, where single lines repeat with numbing or imprisoning effect: 'It is the pain, it is the pain endures', or 'Slowly the poison the whole blood stream fills', or 'The heart of standing is you cannot fly'. A poem called 'This Last Pain' seems to define Empson's motive and method, his setting of wit against terror, his narrow but unique achievement, when it concludes: 'Imagine.../ What could not possibly be there,/ And learn a style from a despair.'

fields.headline: The elegy and the ecstasy
fields.standfirst: Helen Dunmore hails a sweeping naval narrative, and examines a preoccupation with death and, oddly, flies
fields.trailText: Helen Dunmore discovers a sweeping naval narrative, and examines a preoccupation with death and flies in her roundup of new poetry
fields.body:
How many buyers of Heaney's Beowulf translation have yet got as far as the funeral pyre? Long poems, although honoured on the bookshelf, are felt to be hard going for the contemporary reader. Now Douglas Dunn steps out to dare his audience with The Donkey's Ears (Faber £8.99), 172 pages of abba-rhymed quatrains about the Russian navy's voyage from the Baltic to its destruction by the Japanese navy at the battle of Tsushima in 1905.

Dunn's narrator is Flag-Engineer Politovsky, who is caught up in an imperial adventure that dramatises the decay of Tsarist Russia. On a voyage of this kind nothing can be hidden. Politovsky's letters to his wife Sophie reveal his anguish at their separation, the texture of their love, his fears for this ramshackle navy, the inadequacies of the ship, the hopelessness of their captains, and the brutalities of conscript life.

He conjures up the claustrophobia of the ships, and the bizarreness of their landfalls. It's a journey towards death, and against that backdrop each scene has the clarity of a lightning-strike. The Donkey's Ears is a wonderful story, told in poetry that fuses driving narrative, politics, choice imagery and the passionate inner life of a man who knows that no engineering talent can patch up the obsolete fleet of Imperial Russia.

C.K. Williams has the courage to take his time and allow his characteristic long line to unfold the inner lives of his subjects. Repair, (Bloodaxe £7.99, pp70) his latest collection, won the Pulitzer Prize. He has a searching, humane imagination, and his anecdotes burn deep, starting from such places as the 'cheap, printed, pulpy, seemingly purposefully shapeless light cotton shifts' that women wore as housedresses in his childhood, and the curlers which they '...seemed constantly to have in their hair,/ in preparation for some great event, a ball, one would think, that never came to pass.' ('The Dress') Williams is the laureate of those whose great events don't come to pass, but who keep on getting ready for them anyway. Like Dunn, he is essentially a political poet in the richest sense of that word.

Thom Gunn's America is also a place of loss and elegy. Like Catullus, a poet whom in some ways he resembles, Gunn is engaged in an erotic, undercover war against time and death. Each poem in Boss Cupid (Faber, £7.99, pp115) makes its report from the latest battleground, where Aids has multiplied the attritions of sexual love:

He seemed all body, such

As normally you couldn't touch,

Reckless and rough,

One of Boss Cupid's red-haired errand boys

Who couldn't get there fast enough.' ('The Problem')

In Gunn's poems, death closes everything, and is close at hand. Some poets aren't happy until they have made something redemptive out of this, but Gunn sees what he sees, and makes it visible. His lovers aren't on their way to any epiphany. They're just caught in the sexiness of being alive:

Peter Redgrove is Laurentian in his hunger for the natural world, and his ability to lay it down in words. Redgrove has been pouring poetry into the world for more than 40 years, with a recklessness that cares no more about the odd bad poem than a river cares about the flotsam it shoulders into backwaters. The poet melts into the landscape, all his senses alert:

He gripped the fruit

And it buzzed like a gong stilled with his fingers

And a wasp flew out with its note

From the gong of sugar and scented rain ('Orchard with Wasps')

Redgrove's Selected Poems (Cape Poetry, £8.99, pp136) are an excellent fix on this very prolific poet. The compression of his life's work emphasises the power of the poetry. He is considered a visionary, but this selection highlights his fineness of touch, and his humour.

All the flies are reading microscopic books:

They hold themselves quite tense and silent

With shoulders hunched, legs splayed out

On the white formica table-top, reading.

Jamie McKendrick's marble fly in Sky Nails: Selected Poems (Faber £8.9, pp115) neither moves nor reads. It is 'perfectly preserved and just / a shade larger than life-size / and much stiller than life and harder'. This fly is part of a wall relief, which records and preserves everything of the animal kingdom. Except, of course, its life. McKendrick's poems tease thought. The fly will never be caught, because it has already been caught by its sculptor. It has been overwhelmed by stone much as the creatures of Pompeii will be overwhelmed by molten rock, or, as McKendrick observes:

It can't have been long after

that much the same idea

occurred to Vesuvius. ('The Marble Fly')

McKendrick is a prize-winning and highly regarded poet but a lot of readers are still missing out on his work. The best of his poems, like the marble fly, are sculpted to last.

Poets stay young for a long time. It's one of the best bits of the business, the way a poet can be so described at 40 or at 45. But Matthew Sweeney, in his latest collection A Smell of Fish (Cape £8.00, pp64), is having none of it. The poet's daughter may be off to the pub in red velvet hipsters with the bass guitarist boyfriend, but it's no good Sweeney thinking he can join in. In Prague, he feels the same:

I need that blue train

to spirit me south, away from

Prague and its appetites,

the young in one another's laps,

clothes in disarray ('The Blue Train')

Sweeney's poems are like shards of mirror. As you bend to look more closely, they cut. His version from Dante's Inferno, a passage which deals with the damned locked in ice on the floor of Hell, is chilling and possesses a near-demonic energy. It seems that for Sweeney, as for Douglas Dunn, a long poem releases new force in the poet.

webTitle: Global warming? He doesn't give a fig

fields.headline: Global warming? He doesn't give a fig
fields.standfirst: Variable quality mars Tony Harrison's new collection, Laureate's Block and Other Poems
fields.trailText: Variable quality mars Tony Harrison's new collection, Laureate's Block and Other Poems
fields.body:
Laureate's Block and Other Poems
Tony Harrison
Penguin £7.99, pp99
Buy it at BOL

The notion of royal patronage is offensive to the republican sensitivities of Tony Harrison, as it is to this Australian republican. When the idea of him being considered for the poet laureateship, vacated by the death of Ted Hughes, was broached in the British press, Harrison responded with a public poem of rebuke for those who might even consider him a possibility, a poem his publishers declare has gained 'notoriety'. Blurb-making is the most political of affairs.

However, Harrison certainly doesn't eschew the notion of the poet as cultural spokesperson, and seems to advocate a de facto laureateship by public proclamation in many of the works in Laureate's Block and Other Occasional Poems. At its best, the collection is a defence of the primacy of the poet, at worst a claim for non-institutional recognition of himself as the legitimate pretender, but one who wouldn't soil his hands.

This is a work that varies immensely in quality, from the unbelievably egotistical and structurally impoverished title poem and the tonally unstable 'Two Poems for My Son in His Sickness' - where pathos becomes bathos (at best):

Other poets' sons and daughters, Joyce's

Frost's and Victor Hugo's, all heard voices.

Is what tears our offsprings' minds apart

the shaping spirit of poetic art?

and the poet seems to be giving the 'tragedy and sacrifice of art' a centre stage it can't sustain - to the brilliant, amusing, wry and fiendishly clever ode to global warming that finishes the book, 'Fig On The Tyne'.

This last poem epitomises the best and worst of Harrison's present work, though pulls off what many of the other poems fail to do - an effective distance between the Dionysian aims and Apollonian urges of this 'people's laureate'.

Rhyming couplets suit the tone of the piece perfectly, and the irregularities of rhythm superbly undermine the canonical expectations the reader may impose on a poem that works within the (satirical) classical register. There's a kind of gentle self-effacement and flippancy at work that isn't evident enough elsewhere:

Such flavour, sweetness! Half's a feast

though ripened in the chill North-East

ripened through gales and CFCs

fields.headline: The Letter
fields.standfirst: Or poem beginning with a line by Keats
fields.trailText:
Before he went to feed with owls and bats
he wrote a letter to his grandmother,
asking who could stand this new stepfather...
fields.body:
Before he went to feed with owls and bats
he wrote a letter to his grandmother,
asking who could stand this new stepfather
whose first act had been to kill the pets
he'd kept inside - the half-blind vole
that lived in his schoolbag, the white moth
he'd replaced once a week, the sloth
his poor Dad had brought him from Brazil,
the green Indian parrot that couldn't speak,
the hedgehog he'd saved, the scorpion
he'd smuggled from Morocco on the plane -
all dead, except the banded rattlesnake
he told his gran was hidden in the shed
waiting to be slipped into that bed.

fields.headline: Beyond bestsellers?
fields.trailText: According to the latest Prospect magazine, that essential guide to life, the universe and everything, of all the British novels published in the nineteenth century, some 99.5 per cent are now forgotten and out of print. fields.body:
According to the latest Prospect magazine, that essential guide to life, the universe and everything, of all the British novels published in the nineteenth century, some 99.5 per cent are now forgotten and out of print. What's more, it's a fair guess that the 0.5 per cent which are still remembered, and are still in print, were not, as Macaulay once put it, 'the last fashionable novel on the tables of young ladies'.

Publishers, however, are like the Bourbons. They forget nothing and they learn nothing. Their quest for the latest talent is as hot now as it was then. Hardly a week goes by without Messrs Snipcock & Tweed (or Hodder & Stoughton) ponying up a 'six-figure advance' for the magnificently incomplete manuscript of a young unknown, ideally from Ireland or the Commonwealth, and preferably photogenic.

Within the world of books, there has always been an unvoiced disquiet about this cycle. Much of the hostility to the book with the big advance can be put down to our old friends Envy, Spite and Malice, but recently, after a decade and more of extravagant bestseller hunting (and nearly a generation of merger and acquisition within the imprints themselves), we have begun to hear a more coherent note of alarm.

In a speech entitled 'Beyond the bestseller culture', at the recent Booksellers Association Conference, Terence Blacker, a seasoned book-trade commentator, argued that 'the increasing giantism of the trade - mega-agents selling mega-authors to mega-conglomerate publishers to tie up with mega-bookselling chains - is dangerous. The spark of true, as opposed to manufactured, talent, is very often to be found in the small, the independent, the bloody-minded'.

Blacker has a good point, and it's one shared by the beetroot-jowled veterans for whom things ain't what they used to be. I've also expressed sympathy for this argument in the past, but I'm not sure now that I agree with him any more. Book publishing has always had both a commercial and a cultural raison d'être often dynamically at odds with each other.

It is also fiercely Darwinian. Publishers who pay telephone-number advances, without commensurate sales, go to the wall. Authors whose talents are unequal to their publisher's expectations get remaindered. And, generally speaking, but not wanting too sound like Dr Pangloss, I believe that good books and good writers find appropriate audiences.

It's perfectly true, as Blacker puts it, that 'the good books, the ones that have lasted, have tended not to be blockbusters, but the work of precisely the kind of authors who risk losing out in today's publishing climate', but it's also true that none of us has the faintest idea who, in a hundred years time, is going to be contributing to the corporate bottom line of Harper-Random or Transworld-Fourth Estate.

The 'increased giantism' of book publishing is simply a reflection of the extraordinary media boom we're living through, and if it seems extravagant and unruly, then that's probably the evidence of teenage vigour, not thin-blooded antiquarianism.

Book publishing has always had both a commercial and a cultural raison d'être often dynamically at odds with each other. It is also fiercely Darwinian. Publishers who pay telephone-number advances, without commensurate sales, go to the wall. Authors whose talents are unequal to their publisher's expectations get remaindered. And, generally speaking, but not wanting too sound like Dr Pangloss, I believe that good books and good writers find appropriate audiences. It's perfectly true, as Blacker puts it, that 'the good books, the ones that have lasted, have tended not to be blockbusters, but the work of precisely the kind of authors who risk losing out in today's publishing climate', but it's also true that none of us has the faintest idea who, in a hundred years time, is going to be contributing to the corporate bottom line of Harper-Random or Transworld-Fourth Estate. The 'increased giantism' of book publishing is simply a reflection of the extraordinary media boom we're living through, and if it seems extravagant and unruly, then that's probably the evidence of teenage vigour, not thin-blooded antiquarianism. robert.mccrum@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Just get a life...
fields.standfirst: Have you read as widely as A.S. Byatt? If not, her new novel, The Biographer's Tale, will soon find you out
fields.trailText: Have you read as widely as A.S. Byatt? If not, her new novel, The Biographer's Tale, will soon find you out
fields.body:
The Biographer's Tale
A.S. Byatt
Chatto & Windus £14.99, pp265

A.S. Byatt's marvellous novel, Possession, is prefaced by a bit of Browning: 'How did you contrive to grasp/ The thread which led you through this labyrinth?/ How build such solid fabric out of air?/ How on so slight foundation found this tale?/ Biography, narrative?' The Biographer's Tale, like Possession, a story of intellectual obsession and questing, also inspires such questions, not least the question of whether 'biography' is the same as 'narrative', as in 'imaginary tale'. But this time we can't get out of the labyrinth.

As the knowingly literary title suggests, this is the most self-conscious of fictions. On the first two pages alone, there are references to Empedocles, Lacan, Frankenstein, Freud, Foucault, Heraclitus, Tolkien, T.S. Eliot, Donne and Marvell. Readers may at once have an anxious sense of not having read as much as the author and this never quite goes away. The novel's quest-story takes us into a mosaic of texts, parodies, translations, allusions and fragmentary quotations. This is an addict's book about the dangers of literary addiction.

Our narrator, Phineas G. Nanson, a small - Hobbit-sized? - mental explorer, decides to give up his poststructural thesis in a thwarted desire for facts and things. (Some fun is had throughout with critical theory.) He is advised by his large, Magus-like professor, Ormerod Goode, to read a brilliant Fifties biography by an obscure Yorkshireman called Scholes Destry-Scholes. This is the life of Elmer Bole, a Victorian explorer, historian, diplomat, poet, translator, natural historian and sexual adventurer.

Phineas, who has thought of biography as a 'bastard form, a dilettante pursuit', gets possessed by Scholes on Bole, and decides to write a biography of the biographer. But he can't find out anything about him, except that he is a magical story-teller and is supposed to have drowned in the Maelstrom off Norway.

In his 'quest for Scholes', Phineas comes upon the following items: Scholes's lecture notes on biography, wonderfully dry and very much to the point: 'First find your facts. Select your facts. Arrange your facts. Consider missing facts. Explain your facts.' Then, three lengthy fragments of 'life-writing' by Scholes, one on Linnaeus, the eighteenth-century scientific writer and traveller, one on Galton, the nineteenth-century mental researcher, now damned for his views on eugenics, and one on Ibsen. 'A taxonomist, a statistician, a dramatist: students in their own ways of the connectedness of things and people.' Then, a shoebox of Scholes's leavings, including file cards of quotations by or about his three figures. Last, a report of his presumed drowning, with a photograph, not of his face, which Phineas has never seen, but of an empty boat.

Phineas's quest takes him from a quiet, solitary existence into a network of emotional and erotic adventures: with two apparently charming gay travel agents in a highly specialised travel agency called Puck's Girdle; with a Swedish pollination ecologist called Fulla Biefeld, encountered at the Linnaean Society, and with Scholes's palely beautiful niece, Vera Alfrage, a radiographer. Gradually, Phineas's attempt to write a clinical account of his biographical pursuit mutates into a passionate autobiography. His changed life, with his two loves, his travels and new interest in nature, begins rather to resemble that of - Elmer Bole.

The novel's meditation on the art of biography stacks up whole shoeboxes full of metaphors for biography's attempt to embody the life of another, its negotiation between generalisations and particulars, its remembering of the dismembered. So we have images of metamorphosis, plagiarism, mosaics, radiology, Rubik cubes, marbles, hybrids, mutations, onions, and, most ingeniously, 'those very large advertising installations, which show you an image, made up of a series of vertical stripes, for a calculated number of minutes, and then... revolve the stripes, to reveal a quite other image'. Perhaps the biographer lurks behind the stripes.

As always in Byatt, there is something dark and ominous going on. Is biography a sympathetic magic or is it a ghoulish kind of stalking and haunting, a voyeuristic form of necrophiliac pornography, the biography as snuff movie? Phineas is conscious of mortality - his mother has just died - and all his discoveries lead him to the horror of encountering your double or of losing your own self in the maelstrom.

Phineas gives up literature for nature; he goes from words to things, books to bees, abstractions to entities. As a result, the book is crawling with bugs and bones and closely studied creatures. In taking leave, he moralises: 'As long as we don't destroy and diminish it irrevocably, the too-much-loved earth will always exceed our power to describe, or imagine, or understand it. It's all we have.' Here and throughout, I felt a bit got at. I wanted to like this book much more than I did. It's very suggestive about biography, at a time when imaginative novelists are under threat from the inroads of confessional life-writing, and biographers are questioning all the Destry-Scholes-like simple rules ('First find your facts' etc.)

And the biographical musings did interest me very much. But I found the book's playfulness laborious, its knowing erudition airless and its characters whimsical and unappetising. Perhaps I just got irritated from trying to make all the bits fit together and find the thread through the labyrinth.

webTitle: BT forced to free up the net

fields.headline: BT forced to free up the net
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Consumers will soon enjoy free, unlimited internet access without having to pay for extra services such as cable TV or commit to making a certain number of voice calls each month.
fields.body:
Consumers will soon enjoy free, unlimited internet access without having to pay for extra services such as cable TV or commit to making a certain number of voice calls each month.

Oftel, the telecommunications watchdog, has ordered BT from this Thursday to provide unlimited Internet access to other telecoms firms and Internet Service Providers (ISPs) at wholesale rates.

Matt Peacock, spokesman for AOL Europe, Europe's biggest ISP, said: 'This is the most important ruling in the internet sector for many years.

'This ruling means internet users in the UK will have the most affordable internet access in the world. It has ended BT's role as the gatekeeper to the internet.'

The ruling followed a complaint to the watchdog by US telecom firm MCI Worldcom after BT refused a request to supply it with an unmetered access service at a wholesale price.

Before the ruling, BT would have had to offer only its own Surftime unmetered package to other telecoms firms and ISPs. Telecoms analysts say this meant the monthly cost per user for unmetered access was around a minimum of £25 a month, compared with $20 in the US.

Recently a number of operators have looked to offer their own versions of unmetered access, absorbing the costs of Surftime themselves, in a rush to build a large customer base to whom they could then sell other products and services - such as cable TV or telephony. The move was viewed as largely unsustainable in the long term.

Analysts predict that as the costs of taking a BT wholesale package fall by anything between 50 and 75 per cent, telecom firms and ISPs will concentrate on ploughing their money into more and better quality services.

Others urged caution. One telecoms source said: 'We welcome this in principle but it's still not exactly clear what BT will be allowed to charge.'

webTitle: Climbing out of the valley of debt

fields.headline: Climbing out of the valley of debt
fields.standfirst: The road to ruin can start with divorce, the sack or the death of someone close.  Alexander Garrett  offers a seven-step return to solvency
fields.trailText: The rich and famous usually create their own financial crises - by wild extravagance or fighting rash libel actions. Disgraced former Tory MP Jonathan Aitken was driven to bankruptcy by the costs of a libel suit, as was Coronation Street star William Roache. The Duchess of York's debts mounted because of an expensive wanderlust that would have shamed Jules Verne.
fields.body:
The rich and famous usually create their own financial crises - by wild extravagance or fighting rash libel actions. Disgraced former Tory MP Jonathan Aitken was driven to bankruptcy by the costs of a libel suit, as was Coronation Street star William Roache. The Duchess of York's debts mounted because of an expensive wanderlust that would have shamed Jules Verne.

For the rest of us, crises usually have more mundane causes, such as a business failure, accepting too much of the credit thrown at us, or a life-changing event such as redundancy, divorce, the birth of children or the death of a spouse. Bizarrely, education is now a major debt-maker: more and more students leave university owing £15,000 or more.

Survival means either repaying your debt, reducing it to manageable proportions or, if all else fails, accepting bankruptcy so that what you owe is eventually discharged.

Debt generally is currently rising to levels not seen since the late Eighties. The National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux (Nacab) dealt with 268,000 consumer debt problems in the six months to last September, 7 per cent more than a year earlier. Researcher Mintel says the country's personal debt total, including mortgages, is £600 billion - or £10,000 per head of the population. And the number of individual insolvencies last year, 28,806, was the highest since 1994. Sue Edwards, money advice officer at Nacab, says problems are brought to a head by something like a notice of eviction, the imminent arrival of bailiffs, or a house or car being repossessed. 'It takes an awful lot for most people to seek help.'

Many try to borrow their way out of debt by simply taking on more loans - and then see their problems escalate. Others fall for offers of debt 'consolidation'. This is not a bad idea in itself, but the new loan must be cheaper than the debt it replaces; and beware of replacing unsecured debt, such as credit card bills, with a loan secured on your house.

There is usually no easy answer to a crisis, but the right steps will help you to cope:

Step One Assess the situation calmly. 'Take a good long, hard look at your finances,' says Edwards. 'Then look at your income and your necessary outgoings, and work out a budget that doesn't include any debts unless they are essential.'

That may mean drastic cuts in your spending - from cancelling holidays or removing your children from private schools, to spending less on food and nights out.

Step Two Prioritise your debts. Most unsecured creditors will not make you bankrupt. Nacab's Edwards says: 'A high-priority creditor is anyone who has a serious sanction against you.'

These include your mortgage lender, who can repossess your house, your landlord, who may evict you, or your local authority - failure to pay council tax can lead to prison. The Inland Revenue and Customs & Excise are top priority for self-employed people. They can have your property seized and instigate bankruptcy proceedings. The Child Support Agency can have you jailed for failing to pay maintenance. Utility debts are urgent, too: your water, fuel and telephone can be cut off.

Non-priority debts for most people include credit cards, bank overdrafts and loans, store cards and other traders' bills. You may prefer to pay some of these people before the taxman, but it's best to recognise who will compromise and who will not.

Hire-purchase payments vary in priority, says Edwards. If your car is essential for work, it may be a disaster to lose it. But if the washing machine goes, you can always use a launderette.

Step Three Seek advice. There are several reputable sources of help. Apart from citizens advice bureaux, there is National Debtline, and specialists such as the Bankruptcy Advisory Service and the Bankruptcy Association.

Solicitors or accountants may also be helpful. Beware of 'ambulance chasers', though. Some firms exploit people in trouble for their own gain.

'You need advice from somebody who has no vested interest in the advice they give, and whose charges are low,' says Gill Hankey of the Bankruptcy Advisory Service.

An experienced adviser will help you to prioritise your debts; will know your legal rights; may help you to negotiate with creditors; and may point you to any additional sources of support such as state benefits.

Step Four Talk to your creditors. 'Most will do their best to accommodate you,' says Gill Hankey. 'But if you don't contact them for months, they're likely to lose patience.'

Try for a gradual repayment of your debt - for example, monthly payments to Customs & Excise to sort out a VAT bill - or a partial repayment. Unsecured creditors know that if you go bankrupt they will probably get nothing.

Edwards says: 'A mortgage lender will expect you to be able to meet your existing monthly repayment, and to repay all arrears over the remaining period of the mortgage. If you are a local authority tenant, the authority may accept as little as £2.60 a week if you are on benefits.'

Work out how much income is left after essential living costs and priority debts, then offer the other creditors a pro-rata distribution of your remaining income. For example, if you have £100 a month left after paying your mortgage and utility bills; and you have other debt repayments of £300 a month, you should offer each creditor a third of the amount due.

This process can be formalised in an Individual Voluntary Agreement. However, IVAs can be expensive to set up, and a high proportion fail, usually because the debtor ends up agreeing to a higher level of repayments than they can realistically meet.

Step Five Think about whether you have any assets that could be used to help repay your debts. It would make little sense to risk bankruptcy over £30,000 of debt if you have an endowment policy that could be cashed in early for a similar amount. If your creditors refuse to compromise, they could ultimately send in bailiffs, seize your possessions, and auction them. You are likely to get a far better price for valuables if you sell them yourself.

Step Six If your debts are truly overwhelming, consider making yourself bankrupt. 'Once you are in bankruptcy, your creditors can't pursue you any further, and can't take any further action such as sending round bailiffs,' points out Hankey of the Bankruptcy Advisor Service.

As a bankrupt, you are not allowed to hold credit cards or raise credit, but if you were in severe debt, you would have little chance of doing this anyway, she points out.

However, bankruptcy can mean the permanent loss of your professional status if you are a solicitor, an accountant or a surveyor. And if you have a personal pension, that money can be seized along with your other assets.

John McQueen, founder and chief executive of the Bankruptcy Association, says: 'Whether you opt to go bankrupt should depend to a large extent on whether you are under direct pressure - if you have bailiffs knocking at your door, for example.'

Those who have least to lose from bankruptcy are people with few assets or little disposable income. If you are young, espe cially, you may eventually be able to put your bankruptcy behind you and start afresh.

Step seven. Even in the depths of a crisis, don't take your eye off the ball. 'I've just had a guy come to see me who's 64 years old, and the Official Receiver has told him they are going to sell his house,' says McQueen. 'Five years ago, when he was made bankrupt, the house was in negative equity, and he could have bought it back from the Receiver for £1, but now it has risen in value and he's going to lose it.'

Some people eventually pull through simply by taking stock of their situation, talking to creditors, and reordering their lives to reflect their new circumstances. Others go through the pain of bankruptcy, with the knowledge that at the end of three years - or two if the amount owed is less than £20,000 - their debt will be discharged. Within another five years the record of the bankruptcy should be expunged from credit reference agencies' records.

Still other people manage to just keep their head above water for years, with no prospect of the cloud of debt lifting. This is arguably the worst course.

Hankey says: 'I always like to see a solution to the problem. I had a lady who came to see me who's just 24 years old. She owes £13,000 but only earns £600 a month, and she had been advised to pay off her debt at £1 a month. I would question the validity of that advice, because this lady will never be free of the debt.'

Victim of 'vindictiveness'

John Yate's bankruptcy was triggered by the failure of his business, which was in turn the result of a six-week postal strike in Birmingham during 1998. Yates's company, a sort of mail order version of Ann Summers, had been trading successfully since 1973. He had 25 people on the payroll when the business was brought to a standstill by the postal workers' dispute.

Ironically, the Post Office was among the first to withdraw credit, and the business went into receivership with debts estimated by the Official Receiver at £1 million. For Yates, now 53, that spelt much more than the loss of his livelihood; he had signed personal guarantees to a finance company to obtain loans for refinancing company equipment. Now they wanted their money back.

'When I signed the guarantees, the agent for the finance company told me: "Don't worry, they never act on these guarantees",' says John, who now concedes he was naive. He tried to strike a deal with this creditor, proposing a Company Voluntary Agreement, then an Individual Voluntary Agreement. But, he says, they refused to discuss it, and seemed determined to make him bankrupt, even though that meant they would probably get nothing. 'I just couldn't get over the uncommercial vindictiveness of it,' he says.

One of the greatest shocks, he says, was realising how little there was available in the way of help. His bank was unsympathetic, and the only support he found was from his doctor and a couple of suppliers, as well as the Bankruptcy Association. 'But there was no agency that I could go to to broker a deal with creditors.'

Yates says he was hit 'really hard' by bankruptcy when it came in January 1999. 'People were shocked when they saw me - my self-esteem disappeared and I really lost the will to live.' He believes that bankruptcy is the lowest status society can bestow on an individual. 'I feel useless; sometimes I feel dirty.'

Nearly 18 months into bankruptcy, John is still confused about its implications. The family home was safe: it had always been in his wife's name. He has also found work with the company that bought most of the assets. But he is not sure whether his pension is safe, and it remains to be seen whether creditors will accept his settlement offer.

The main lessons he has learnt are not to sign personal guarantees, and not to trust 'the system'. 'I went to business school but I was never taught how easy it is to bankrupt someone. Bankruptcy is the only situation where you don't get a second chance.'

Help on way for the honestly unlucky

A Government consultation paper published earlier this year has proposed that the laws on bankruptcy be significantly relaxed, as part of a drive towards encouraging entrepreneurial activity in the UK.

Introducing the paper, Trade Secretary Stephen Byers said: 'Bankruptcy law currently makes no distinction between those who are honest but unlucky or undercapitalised, and the reckless or fraudulent.'

The paper proposes that 'honest' bankrupts be discharged much more quickly - in six months rather than the current norm of three years. It points out that in the UK, the proportion of bankruptcies relating to business failure - 65 per cent - is far higher than in countries such as the US, where more than 90 per cent of bankruptcies involve consumer debt. In the US there is no fixed period before you are discharged: in most cases it takes only three to four months.

Another proposal is that those declared bankrupt be entitled to keep a part of the equity in their home, without it being seized by the Official Receiver. In parts of the US, this is called a 'homestead allowance', and the idea is that it would lower the risk of borrowing money for a business, and consequently reduce the widespread problem of under-capitalisation.

For those deemed to have acted fraudulently or irresponsibly, however, the Green Paper proposes a harsher regime. The Official Receiver would be able to seek an order which would prolong the restrictions on bankrupts obtaining credit, trading under another name, or directing a company, for a period of up to 15 years.

Retired, but still in fear of the last stubborn creditors

Financial difficulties began for Gwen Marshall and her husband, Jim, when Gwen lost her job as a secretary at a City bank. It was 1990 and mortgage rates had rocketed; the repayments on their Home Counties bungalow had risen from £500 to over £1,000, and they had the additional cost of an endowment policy to meet.

Gwen found a job, but her pay fell from £16,000 to £9,000, and the couple were soon struggling. 'I was in poor health with arthritis and asthma, so I wasn't up to commuting to London every day,' Gwen explains. 'And local pay was much lower.'

By 1993, the Marshalls were three months behind with their repayments; then a repossession letter arrived from their lender. They sold the house themselves, but having borrowed less than £70,000 initially, they found they now owed the mortgage company more than £110,000. Once they had paid it off, they had exactly £75 left.

The council helped them find private accommodation, but in 1994 Gwen was made redundant again, and other creditors were making urgent demands. 'We were getting demanding letters, people knocking on the door threatening to take our things, and even talking to our neighbours,' says Gwen. They went to their local citizen's advice bureau in desperation. Here a financial adviser wrote to the creditors - 15 in all - asking for details of the sums owed. Their debts amounted to £32,000.

The CAB helped draw up a financial statement of incomings and outgoings, and an offer was made to repay creditors monthly with no further interest accruing. All 15 accepted. 'We were so happy, because we had never thought there could be a way out,' says Gwen. 'The amounts were not too bad.'

The couple continued with their repayments until this year, when Jim retired. He opted to take a lump sum as part of his pension in the hope of a final settlement with creditors. So far, most have accepted, but a handful have declined. Gwen says: 'We're still a bit frightened, but we hope they will come round so we can enjoy our retirement.'

She believes the onerous conditions attached to their mortgage made their problems much worse and advises anybody taking a home loan to check the details very carefully.

She adds: 'I don't know what would have happened without the citizen's advice bureau. Without them, we'd have been on the streets.'

 Names have been changed
