There is usually no easy answer to a crisis, but the right steps will help you to cope: Step One Assess the situation calmly. 'Take a good long, hard look at your finances,' says Edwards. 'Then look at your income and your necessary outgoings, and work out a budget that doesn't include any debts unless they are essential.' That may mean drastic cuts in your spending - from cancelling holidays or removing your children from private schools, to spending less on food and nights out. Step Two Prioritise your debts. Most unsecured creditors will not make you bankrupt. Nacab's Edwards says: 'A high-priority creditor is anyone who has a serious sanction against you.' These include your mortgage lender, who can repossess your house, your landlord, who may evict you, or your local authority - failure to pay council tax can lead to prison. The Inland Revenue and Customs & Excise are top priority for self-employed people. They can have your property seized and instigate bankruptcy proceedings. The Child Support Agency can have you jailed for failing to pay maintenance. Utility debts are urgent, too: your water, fuel and telephone can be cut off. Non-priority debts for most people include credit cards, bank overdrafts and loans, store cards and other traders' bills. You may prefer to pay some of these people before the taxman, but it's best to recognise who will compromise and who will not. Hire-purchase payments vary in priority, says Edwards. If your car is essential for work, it may be a disaster to lose it. But if the washing machine goes, you can always use a launderette. Step Three Seek advice. There are several reputable sources of help. Apart from citizens advice bureaux, there is National Debtline, and specialists such as the Bankruptcy Advisory Service and the Bankruptcy Association. Solicitors or accountants may also be helpful. Beware of 'ambulance chasers', though. Some firms exploit people in trouble for their own gain. 'You need advice from somebody who has no vested interest in the advice they give, and whose charges are low,' says Gill Hankey of the Bankruptcy Advisory Service. An experienced adviser will help you to prioritise your debts; will know your legal rights; may help you to negotiate with creditors; and may point you to any additional sources of support such as state benefits. Step Four Talk to your creditors. 'Most will do their best to accommodate you,' says Gill Hankey. 'But if you don't contact them for months, they're likely to lose patience.' Try for a gradual repayment of your debt - for example, monthly payments to Customs & Excise to sort out a VAT bill - or a partial repayment. Unsecured creditors know that if you go bankrupt they will probably get nothing. Edwards says: 'A mortgage lender will expect you to be able to meet your existing monthly repayment, and to repay all arrears over the remaining period of the mortgage. If you are a local authority tenant, the authority may accept as little as £2.60 a week if you are on benefits.' Work out how much income is left after essential living costs and priority debts, then offer the other creditors a pro-rata distribution of your remaining income. For example, if you have £100 a month left after paying your mortgage and utility bills; and you have other debt repayments of £300 a month, you should offer each creditor a third of the amount due. This process can be formalised in an Individual Voluntary Agreement. However, IVAs can be expensive to set up, and a high proportion fail, usually because the debtor ends up agreeing to a higher level of repayments than they can realistically meet. Step Five Think about whether you have any assets that could be used to help repay your debts. It would make little sense to risk bankruptcy over £30,000 of debt if you have an endowment policy that could be cashed in early for a similar amount. If your creditors refuse to compromise, they could ultimately send in bailiffs, seize your possessions, and auction them. You are likely to get a far better price for valuables if you sell them yourself. Step Six If your debts are truly overwhelming, consider making yourself bankrupt. 'Once you are in bankruptcy, your creditors can't pursue you any further, and can't take any further action such as sending round bailiffs,' points out Hankey of the Bankruptcy Advisor Service. As a bankrupt, you are not allowed to hold credit cards or raise credit, but if you were in severe debt, you would have little chance of doing this anyway, she points out. However, bankruptcy can mean the permanent loss of your professional status if you are a solicitor, an accountant or a surveyor. And if you have a personal pension, that money can be seized along with your other assets. John McQueen, founder and chief executive of the Bankruptcy Association, says: 'Whether you opt to go bankrupt should depend to a large extent on whether you are under direct pressure - if you have bailiffs knocking at your door, for example.' Those who have least to lose from bankruptcy are people with few assets or little disposable income. If you are young, espe cially, you may eventually be able to put your bankruptcy behind you and start afresh. Step seven. Even in the depths of a crisis, don't take your eye off the ball. 'I've just had a guy come to see me who's 64 years old, and the Official Receiver has told him they are going to sell his house,' says McQueen. 'Five years ago, when he was made bankrupt, the house was in negative equity, and he could have bought it back from the Receiver for £1, but now it has risen in value and he's going to lose it.' Some people eventually pull through simply by taking stock of their situation, talking to creditors, and reordering their lives to reflect their new circumstances. Others go through the pain of bankruptcy, with the knowledge that at the end of three years - or two if the amount owed is less than £20,000 - their debt will be discharged. Within another five years the record of the bankruptcy should be expunged from credit reference agencies' records. Still other people manage to just keep their head above water for years, with no prospect of the cloud of debt lifting. This is arguably the worst course. Hankey says: 'I always like to see a solution to the problem. I had a lady who came to see me who's just 24 years old. She owes £13,000 but only earns £600 a month, and she had been advised to pay off her debt at £1 a month. I would question the validity of that advice, because this lady will never be free of the debt.' Victim of 'vindictiveness' John Yate's bankruptcy was triggered by the failure of his business, which was in turn the result of a six-week postal strike in Birmingham during 1998. Yates's company, a sort of mail order version of Ann Summers, had been trading successfully since 1973. He had 25 people on the payroll when the business was brought to a standstill by the postal workers' dispute. Ironically, the Post Office was among the first to withdraw credit, and the business went into receivership with debts estimated by the Official Receiver at £1 million. For Yates, now 53, that spelt much more than the loss of his livelihood; he had signed personal guarantees to a finance company to obtain loans for refinancing company equipment. Now they wanted their money back. 'When I signed the guarantees, the agent for the finance company told me: "Don't worry, they never act on these guarantees",' says John, who now concedes he was naive. He tried to strike a deal with this creditor, proposing a Company Voluntary Agreement, then an Individual Voluntary Agreement. But, he says, they refused to discuss it, and seemed determined to make him bankrupt, even though that meant they would probably get nothing. 'I just couldn't get over the uncommercial vindictiveness of it,' he says. One of the greatest shocks, he says, was realising how little there was available in the way of help. His bank was unsympathetic, and the only support he found was from his doctor and a couple of suppliers, as well as the Bankruptcy Association. 'But there was no agency that I could go to to broker a deal with creditors.' Yates says he was hit 'really hard' by bankruptcy when it came in January 1999. 'People were shocked when they saw me - my self-esteem disappeared and I really lost the will to live.' He believes that bankruptcy is the lowest status society can bestow on an individual. 'I feel useless; sometimes I feel dirty.' Nearly 18 months into bankruptcy, John is still confused about its implications. The family home was safe: it had always been in his wife's name. He has also found work with the company that bought most of the assets. But he is not sure whether his pension is safe, and it remains to be seen whether creditors will accept his settlement offer. The main lessons he has learnt are not to sign personal guarantees, and not to trust 'the system'. 'I went to business school but I was never taught how easy it is to bankrupt someone. Bankruptcy is the only situation where you don't get a second chance.' Help on way for the honestly unlucky A Government consultation paper published earlier this year has proposed that the laws on bankruptcy be significantly relaxed, as part of a drive towards encouraging entrepreneurial activity in the UK. Introducing the paper, Trade Secretary Stephen Byers said: 'Bankruptcy law currently makes no distinction between those who are honest but unlucky or undercapitalised, and the reckless or fraudulent.' The paper proposes that 'honest' bankrupts be discharged much more quickly - in six months rather than the current norm of three years. It points out that in the UK, the proportion of bankruptcies relating to business failure - 65 per cent - is far higher than in countries such as the US, where more than 90 per cent of bankruptcies involve consumer debt. In the US there is no fixed period before you are discharged: in most cases it takes only three to four months. Another proposal is that those declared bankrupt be entitled to keep a part of the equity in their home, without it being seized by the Official Receiver. In parts of the US, this is called a 'homestead allowance', and the idea is that it would lower the risk of borrowing money for a business, and consequently reduce the widespread problem of under-capitalisation. For those deemed to have acted fraudulently or irresponsibly, however, the Green Paper proposes a harsher regime. The Official Receiver would be able to seek an order which would prolong the restrictions on bankrupts obtaining credit, trading under another name, or directing a company, for a period of up to 15 years. Retired, but still in fear of the last stubborn creditors Financial difficulties began for Gwen Marshall and her husband, Jim, when Gwen lost her job as a secretary at a City bank. It was 1990 and mortgage rates had rocketed; the repayments on their Home Counties bungalow had risen from £500 to over £1,000, and they had the additional cost of an endowment policy to meet. Gwen found a job, but her pay fell from £16,000 to £9,000, and the couple were soon struggling. 'I was in poor health with arthritis and asthma, so I wasn't up to commuting to London every day,' Gwen explains. 'And local pay was much lower.' By 1993, the Marshalls were three months behind with their repayments; then a repossession letter arrived from their lender. They sold the house themselves, but having borrowed less than £70,000 initially, they found they now owed the mortgage company more than £110,000. Once they had paid it off, they had exactly £75 left. The council helped them find private accommodation, but in 1994 Gwen was made redundant again, and other creditors were making urgent demands. 'We were getting demanding letters, people knocking on the door threatening to take our things, and even talking to our neighbours,' says Gwen. They went to their local citizen's advice bureau in desperation. Here a financial adviser wrote to the creditors - 15 in all - asking for details of the sums owed. Their debts amounted to £32,000. The CAB helped draw up a financial statement of incomings and outgoings, and an offer was made to repay creditors monthly with no further interest accruing. All 15 accepted. 'We were so happy, because we had never thought there could be a way out,' says Gwen. 'The amounts were not too bad.' The couple continued with their repayments until this year, when Jim retired. He opted to take a lump sum as part of his pension in the hope of a final settlement with creditors. So far, most have accepted, but a handful have declined. Gwen says: 'We're still a bit frightened, but we hope they will come round so we can enjoy our retirement.' She believes the onerous conditions attached to their mortgage made their problems much worse and advises anybody taking a home loan to check the details very carefully. She adds: 'I don't know what would have happened without the citizen's advice bureau. Without them, we'd have been on the streets.'  Names have been changed

webTitle: Bidding war rages for vital 'grey vote'

fields.headline: Bidding war rages for vital 'grey vote'
fields.standfirst: Pensioners want more than old cash reshuffled, writes  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Pensioners' incomes are likely to be a major issue in the next general election. That is the safest conclusion you can draw from last week's political battles.
fields.body:
Pensioners' incomes are likely to be a major issue in the next general election. That is the safest conclusion you can draw from last week's political battles.

Conservative leader Will-iam Hague started the debate when he announced plans for an extra weekly increase in the Basic State Pension - of between £5.50 and £10 - for each pensioner or pensioner couple. This payment would start from April next year, if there were an election before then and a Conservative victory.

Labour counterclaimed that pensioners would be only a tiny amount better off under these plans - 42p a week for a single pensioner under 75. What is the truth?

Most commentators - including the Conservative spokespeople - now accept that there is very little new money in the Tory plans for pensioners. The Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS) calculates that, on average, the 11 million pensioners would get an extra £30 a year each.

This is because money for the £2 billion increase would come from stopping benefits pensioners already get - the £10 Christmas bonus, for instance, the £150 Winter Fuel Payment, the extra 25p-a-week for the over-85s and the free TV licence for the over-75s. The only new money proposed for pensioners is another £320 million - which would be taken by scrapping the New Deal scheme for lone parents, slashing emergency help for people on Income Support and by denying a newly won right of Winter Fuel Payments to men aged 60 to 64.

But there would be winners and losers in the Tory proposals, according to the IFS. 'The people with most to win would be couples who have both built up Basic State Pension rights,' says spokeswoman Sarah Smith. This is because they would both, if under 75, get a £5.50 increase, worth £572 a year together, and would lose £170 (their £10 Christmas bonuses and the £150 Winter Fuel Payment paid per household, not per person). They would end up about £4 a week better off each. The Tories are also proposing to raise tax thresholds for pensioners, so that they do not immediately lose some of this gain in tax.

Obvious losers are men aged 60 to 64. They have recently won the right to Winter Fuel Payments in a sex equality case with women who officially become pensioners five years earlier than men, at 60. But these men are not yet entitled to the Basic State Pension and would simply lose their £150 Winter Fuel Payment: they would be about £3 a week worse off.

But Labour appears to be correct in its statements that the benefits to pensioners of the Tory plans would be marginal. After some wrangling, the Conservatives admitted that the £5.50-£10 increases would include the £2-£3 uprating for Retail Price Inflation that pensioners will get anyway in April.

Chancellor Gordon Brown is now being strongly urged to give at least the level of increase that the Tories are mooting. 'Grey power' could send a lot of new Labour MPs onto dole queues if Labour does not pull something out of the bag. Recognising that pensioners are about a fifth of the electorate, Brown is thought to be seriously considering the issue.

With the Social Security Select Committee about to look into the subject of pensioner poverty, the topic will not go away. And even if its figures are not so impressive after scrutiny, the Conservatives have hit on important themes: pensioners want more money; they want a simpler system; they want to decide how to spend it themselves rather than getting small concessions and bonuses here and there which they find demeaning.

'This does represent an important challenge to the way we've seen policy developing under Labour,' says Mervyn Kohler of Help the Aged. 'And I hope this is the beginning of a bidding round between the different parties for the older vote.'

Both main parties still have a lot of explaining to do to the elderly. A crucial element of the Tory plans is their attitude to the Minimum Income Guarantee (MIG). At the moment, while the single person's maximum Basic State Pension is £67.50, he or she is entitled to a total minimum income (through the MIG mechanism) of £78.45 a week. The MIG protects the lowest-paid pensioners. While Labour is committed to increasing MIG to match wage inflation, the Conserv ative leadership has not made its stand clear. It is quite possible Labour would give a higher MIG rise than the Conservatives. Poor pensioners would therefore be better off under Labour.

The Tory attack on the Social Fund - proposing to take £90m of its £600m budget to fund the pension rises - also shows a ruthless approach to benefits claimants. The Fund - which pays for larger purchases for claimants, such as a new cookers or pair of shoes - is already on its knees.

Labour, meanwhile, is working on a new 'Pensioners Credit', which is aimed at improving the position of retired people whose income is just above the MIG level. A consultation paper is due 'later in the year', according to the Department of Social Security. But the Chancellor has already made it clear that this new scheme will not be in operation until after the next general election.

Another crucial issue facing politicians is the low take-up of benefits by poor pensioners. Age Concern estimates that 800,000 of the elderly are not getting their due . This Tuesday the DSS launches a TV advertising campaign to encourage people to claim. They can also apply over the telephone rather than face queues in benefits offices.

Both parties are set to clash again in the summer when the Government publishes its long-awaited White Paper on long-term care for the elderly. Both Labour and the Tories will want to be seen to be doing most to help people retain their own homes if they need to pay for long-term care.

DSS freephone for the elderly to make benefit claims: 0800 028 1111.

webTitle: 'We've been at the crossroads. We must choose the right road'

fields.headline: 'We've been at the crossroads. We must choose the right road'
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Mark Neale remembers Guy Fawkes' night 1983. He was a volunteer with the St John's Ambulance service at a fireworks display at Ballymoney Riada Centre.
fields.body:
Mark Neale remembers Guy Fawkes' night 1983. He was a volunteer with the St John's Ambulance service at a fireworks display at Ballymoney Riada Centre.

Then just 17, he was chatting to an old friend. But moments later Johnny McFadden, 50, was dead. He was shot as he arrived home in Rasharkin in County Antrim. He bled to death.

Mr Neale recalls Tracey Doak, a childhood friend who was 21 when a bomb claimed her life and that of three workmates. He was studying in England then, and somehow that brought home the futility of it all.

Now 34, Mr Neale reels off other victims he knew: Bob Buchanan, 50, a guest at his wedding to Hazel, now 35, 13 years ago; Sam McKane, 33; Johnny Moore, 57; Harry Cobb, 38; and Colin Carson, 31. The list goes on.

The IRA killed them all. Each was an RUC officer, like Mr Neale's parents, Richard and Maevee, who has 60 years' service between them. His pride in the force is overwhelming.

Mr Neale, a quality manager at a food company in Portadown, Co Armagh, is one of the 860 people who will gather this morning at the Waterfront Hall in Belfast to determine Northern Ireland's destiny.

They are delegates to the Ulster Unionist council, all but a handful Protestant and the majority past late middle-age. There have been momentous times since the sealing of the Good Friday agreement two years ago, but all know this is the defining moment.

They must decide whether to back their leader, David Trimble, and return to government with Sinn Fein on the back of the IRA's offer to put arms beyond use.

Mr Neale appears to be the identikit Ulster Unionist. He is a Presbyterian and Orangeman. Even his neatly clipped moustache, he admits, is something of a giveaway.

He voted in November to enter government with Sinn Fein before the IRA began decommissioning. He is seen as progressive, and alarm bells were ringing at party HQ when he said last week he was adamant he could not support a quick return to the power-sharing executive.

"We were losing on everything, decommissioning, policing and even flags. I felt we should drawn a line in the sand and stay there.

"But I began to think again when Peter Mandelson said in the Commons there was to be no disbandment of the RUC and that it was to live on in the new service. The RUC wasn't to disappear as somehow an illegitimate and disgraced force.

"Anyone who plays down the IRA's statement this month knows nothing about how republicanism works. There is a huge shift.

"Ulster Unionists were at the crossroads before, in 1968 and 1974, when we turned our backs on reforms and power-sharing. We are there again, and we must choose the right road this time.

"Our task is to change politics, to get away from religion so that Catholics can be unionists and Protestants can be nationalists. And we must make sure republicans no longer have any grievances.

"We must be pragmatic and go forward with confidence in ourselves. So I will be voting Yes to restored devolution."

Democratic Unionists party
Sinn Fein

webTitle: Upbeat Trimble set for final showdown

fields.headline: Upbeat Trimble set for final showdown
fields.standfirst:
Unionist leader's gruelling week will end in triumph - or finish his career
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Unionist leader's gruelling week will end in triumph - or finish his career
fields.body:
For a man under the most intense pressure, he at first appears remarkably upbeat as he snaps a chocolate digestive. He is relaxed, he explains, simply because he knows that he is doing the right thing. Yet his hands tell a different tale. When he lifts them to remove his glasses and wipe his eyes, they are shaking uncontrollably.

David Trimble, Ulster Unionist leader, will never admit it. But he knows the stakes today on so many fronts will never be higher. He says: "This process is much more robust than many people think, but there is no doubt Saturday is important. I refuse to discuss what happens if we lose, because I know what the headlines will be. I am not going to get into the back-me-or-sack me approach.

"They are grown people in the Ulster Unionist Council. They don't like to be manipulated with emotional blackmail, as the anti-agreement camp will find out. Its literature has been a turn-off."

It has been a gruelling week. He is near hoarse after a whirlwind round of meetings, with the aim personally to address all 860 delegates attending today's meeting of his party's ruling council.

None of the locations were revealed in advance, apparently for fear of tipping off protesters. On at least one night this week his family's unprepossessing home in the Co Down village of Lambeg, which gives its name to the booming drum beloved of Orangemen, has been picketed until the early hours. An aide revealed hardliners were even shining laser guns into the living room of the house, home to Trimble, his wife Daphne, and four young children. Police finally arrived to disperse them.

Worst of all, Trimble half jokes, was having to give away the pair of tickets he had secured weeks ago for last Monday's Royal Opera House staging of Die Meistersinger von Nurnberg. Richard Wagner is his favourite, and his only extravagance is a most expensive music system on which to play his huge, eclectic collection.

So, instead of five hours and 40 minutes exhilaration and escape, he was addressing party members near Antrim on the merits of the IRA's unprecedented offer to put arms beyond use. He was then off to go head to head on television with his would-be nemesis, Jeffrey Donaldson, the ambitious anti-agreement MP.

As he breakfasts this morning he will be pondering whether it might be the last meal of a condemned politician. Three hours or so later, he will have his answer.

Lose today and Trimble, 55, can kiss his five-year leadership of the 95-year-old majority party of Unionism goodbye. He has hinted it might come as a relief, a thought that somehow rings hollow.

More, though, is at stake: the Ulster Unionists would be split as never before, possibly irrevocably, sparking a potentially regressive realignment; while the two-year-old Good Friday agreement could be considered deceased. What impact that would have on the IRA is anyone's guess.

Blame

He will be blamed for each consequence. Many Ulster Unionists will blame him for destroying their party, and for disappointing their early faith in him as a hardliner, while republicans will bemoan his lack of leadership, and say he missed an opportunity to move on when the agreement was in its infancy. But win and he will have carried off a triumph against all odds, defeating a back-biting campaign which would have destroyed robust British politicians long ago. He will have lanced several boils, including the intractable decommissioning impasse, and he will have done it, a handful of lieutenants aside, pretty much on his own.

He bounds into the office of first minister more than an hour late. He appears in good form and is sporting a red badge, the Legion D'Honneur, which he won with SDLP leader John Hume. Left casually in one corner are his Nobel peace prize medal and certificate.

Only one question has left him stumped since he belatedly announced on May 18 that he was supporting, on the back of the IRA's offer, the British and Irish government's proposals for a return to the power-sharing executive with Sinn Fein. What was the best thing devolved government achieved in its 72-day existence?

He appears gobsmacked, stares, both amused and confused, and then whisks off his oh-so-trendy glasses, rubs his eyes, and starts to laugh, or, rather, wheeze. This all takes what seems like minutes.

His answer, when it eventually comes, seems that of the pernickety lawyer he was before winning the Upper Bann constituency in 1990 to start a new career relatively late. He was 45 and becalmed in academia when he left Queen's University, Belfast, for Westminster.

Change

Trimble mumbles about foisting off Sinn Fein attempts to win one of the junior ministers posts through forging an alliance with the SDLP, and, warming to the theme, calls it an example of how the centre-ground must seize the initiative. He believes politics will be changed radically in the next decade, and wants to reform the Ulster Unionists and the party's link with the Orange Order to make it a more attractive proposition for Catholics.

"I have enjoyed the meetings with delegates. They have been very civilised and very calm. The decommissioning issue is, of course, uppermost, but people are also focusing on the behaviour of Sinn Fein during the executive. They believe Sinn Fein ministers, in their attitude towards the union flag, didn't quite play it fair.

"As far as democratic politics is concerned, it's perfectly obvious Sinn Fein are not quite house-trained yet. But you don't train them any other way than through democracy."

He rejects his opponents' charges that he brought the executive down in February because the IRA had failed to begin arms decommissioning and is going back when there has been no change in that.

He points out the May 6 initiative, which provides for arms dumps to be inspected, comes direct from the IRA, a crucial distinction to the vagueness arising out of ex-US senator George Mitchell's review last November. It breaks new ground, and it is time to put them to the test.

He says he has secured the RUC's name living on in the title deeds of the new ser vice. He believes he has also outmanoeuvred Sinn Fein on the union flag issue.

So what is his canvassing telling him? He refuses to say. "You have to take all that with a huge pinch of salt. But it is clear matters have been stabilising since we went on to the front foot and said we were backing a return to government."

Just as well. According to some returns, Trimble may have lost had the council met as initially planned last Saturday by as much as 70 to 30. In postponing the meeting, he has been able to say he pushed the government as far as he could on the RUC and flags, while putting distance between his own expressed doubts and the vote.

Tonight opera takes centre stage at the Waterfront Hall. It is Verdi's Aida, a tale of jealously, treachery and divided loyalties. It will be hard pushed to match the drama of the matinee.

April 18 1998 Trimble's proposal to accept the Good Friday agreement won 72% of the vote in UUP's ruling council

May 22 1998 Good Friday agreement won 71% endorsement in referendum - 1% more than Trimble said he needed

June 29 1998 Elected first minister designate of the assembly

webTitle: Fry high as Clarke lifts Posh

fields.headline: Fry high as Clarke lifts Posh
fields.standfirst:
Darlington 0
Peterborough United 1
Clarke 74
fields.trailText: Darlington 0 - 1 Peterborough
fields.body:
It had to be more splish-splosh than style and strategy, but having ridden their luck through a first half when they were decidedly second best, Peterborough were able to turn the tide of an epic struggle and make their return to the Second Division.

The winner had Barry Fry risking the wrath of officialdom, not to mention dangerous exertion on his famously overworked ticker, with a characteristic sprint and whoop of delight along the touch-line. For a manager whose own supporters wanted him out of office at Christmas, there was pleasure to be had from Andy Clarke's marksmanship in the 74th minute.

Darlington had contributed so much to a game that started with Wembley refusing to absorb any more rain water and yielding large puddles over this hallowed piece of turf. You feared at that stage for the well-being of the Brazilian maestros the following day, but fortunately the heavens relented and in the circumstances permitted a decent spectacle.

Darlington made the best of the difficult conditions and looked the most likely to come through and confirm their position as the team closest to the automatic promotion places at the climax to the Third Division campaign. But Fry's team hung on desperately, put their faith in some resolute defending and after a few choice words from their ebullient manager at half-time, they at last began to give their followers something to shout about.

At the heart of the over-worked defence, Andy Edwards and Simon Rea were totems of reliability. And amid all the pressure that their opponents exerted, Peterborough knew that if only they could give Clarke possession, his ability to turn a marker could pay dividends.

His goal arrived 60 seconds after another incisive break in which he had skipped around Andy Collett, only to be denied by a remarkable recovery tackle from Craig Liddle. Darlington were still expressing relief at that escape when Ritchie Hanlon headed the ball forward and found Clarke fractionally onside. His first attempt was repelled splendidly by the goalkeeper, but the rebound was a formality for a front-runner who once was close to a move to Manchester United.

Early on Darlington's Marco Gabbiadini strode powerfully in from the left and saw his shot deflected wide. Shortly after Neil Heaney drove hard and a rebound off a defender's legs spared Mark Tyler the ordeal of making a difficult save.

Peterborough were frantically trying to plug the holes and use Clarke's pace on the counter whenever possible. The former Wimbledon winger laid on an opening for David Oldfield and a despairing tackle from Liddle risked a penalty award. However the referee decided to look kindly on him.

That rare flurry in the Darlington area preceded another good spell from the north-east visitors in which Peter Duffield skilfully cushioned a header before unleashing a volley which came off the outside of the upright after Simon Rea had first altered the direction of the attempt.

When Duffield then played a give and go with Michael Oliver he again found the target an elusive objective. A far- post thrust from Heaney flashed across the face of goal and so Peterborough were able to survive to the interval on level terms.

webTitle: Underdogs aim to dodge history and the showers

fields.headline: Underdogs aim to dodge history and the showers
fields.trailText: Pluvius will probably have other ideas, but this weekend's Benson & Hedges Cup semi-finals are more likely to whet appetites than wet them. For one thing, both underdogs are at home.
fields.body:
Pluvius will probably have other ideas, but this weekend's Benson & Hedges Cup semi-finals are more likely to whet appetites than wet them. For one thing, both underdogs are at home.

History and Met Office alike, though, are ranged against Glamorgan who today face Surrey, winners in 1974 and 1997. The only previous time the Welshmen reached this stage they and Derbyshire waited three days to complete a 1988 tie which was settled when Michael Holding bowled Matthew Maynard with a little help from a tumbling helmet.

Maynard, now captain and sole survivor, will be praying that the notorious Sophia Gardens square, trampled by rugger buggers during the World Cup, behaves itself, at least when the hosts are batting. Chasing a modest 153 in the quarter-final, Hampshire were felled for 69 after sagging to 38 for eight.

Gloucestershire too may dread precedent. Though they and tomorrow's opposition in Bristol, those perennial Lord's lodgers Lancashire, have locked horns for some of the finest scraps in one-day annals - most famously the twilight classic at Old Trafford in 1971 that delayed the Nine O'Clock News - the west countrymen have had only one win in 11 ties. At least they do have home advantage for a change.

Conveniently enough, not one of the semi-finalists managed more than a couple of hours' labour yesterday, though Keith Medlycott, the Surrey coach, was not about to admit this was a good thing. "It's very frustrating, not the ideal preparation," he lamented. "We went to the indoor school at Canterbury but that's not the same, is it?"

Surrey will welcome back England's Alec Stewart and are likely to opt for the all-rounder Jason Ratcliffe ahead of Carl Greenidge, whose father enjoyed so many triumphs at HQ. The deceptively languid Ratcliffe has been the joker of this year's B&H, claiming six wickets at 8.83 with his dandy dobbers.

In a campaign dominated by ball and covers - no batsman bar the decidedly non-mortal Australian Michael Bevan has made 200 runs - Glamorgan's Steve Watkin (economy rate 2.09 runs per over) and Lancashire's Chris Schofield (seven wickets at 9.57) are sound bets to pick the crucial locks.

webTitle: On a mission to seek and destroy

fields.headline: On a mission to seek and destroy
fields.standfirst: Courtney Walsh arrives here with the West Indies next week aiming for 500 wickets
fields.trailText: Courtney Walsh's hair is flecked with white these days, as if he has just been blessed by Methuselah or perhaps been painting the ceiling. He also arrives here with the West Indies next week aiming for 500 test wickets.
fields.body:
Courtney Walsh's hair is flecked with white these days, as if he has just been blessed by Methuselah or perhaps been painting the ceiling. He plays dominoes, too. But he wants to assure everyone that he is not ready to be fitted for his pipe and slippers yet.

There have been more frightening bowlers than this, even from Jamaica. Michael Holding was faster and more penetrating. And the rather chilling Roy Gilchrist was sent home from a tour of India for bowling beamers.

But no fast bowler, from Jamaica or anywhere else, has matched Walsh's remarkable fitness and consistency over such a length of time. He first played test cricket in Australia in 1984-85.

The most successful bowler in test history will be 38 this year and, as the West Indians prepare to fly in to Gatwick on Wednesday, England's batsmen are desperately looking for signs that anno domini has done its worst.

They may be disappointed. Having recently broken Kapil Dev's record of 434 test wickets "Cuddy's" large brown eyes are now set on 500. "I've never played in a losing series against England, and I've been playing them for 15 years," he says. "I still look after myself, I'm still able to compete."

This will be his last tour of England, possibly his last anywhere. "I think 500 wickets is a possibility but I will need luck, consistency and a few more test matches.

"I plan to reassess my body and my mind at the end of this tour. But this could certainly be my last tour, particularly if the new string of youngsters come through and does well."

Since the bad days of the 80s England have been competitive in their five most recent series against West Indies. The scores, England first, have been: 1-2, 2-2, 1-3, 2-2 and 1-3.

"England have had us on the ropes recently but we have always been able to find something extra to beat them, even if we don't seem to win 4-0 and 5-0 these days.

"Because we haven't toured that well in recent years some people are saying we might struggle. But in the past, whenever the West Indies have been down, they have always rebounded.

"We have always come back with a vengeance. And since our disappointing tour of New Zealand we have played well. Both England and ourselves will be determined to prove that we are not bottom of the barrel.

"Brian Lara will be with us and that makes a huge difference. When I spoke to him in Trinidad I told him to relax and get ready for this tour, because it's no good him coming along if his mind is somewhere else.

"England is home from home for so many of us. And under Jimmy Adams we have beaten Zimbabwe 2-0 and feel there is some confidence coming back. The great thing about Jimmy is that he is not afraid to ask advice. He is always seeking more information."

We all thought we had said goodbye to Courtney and Curtly when they toured England in 1995. "Curtly Ambrose is still a silent assassin. He's got this 'Don't get close to me' expression but he's a very close friend and deep down he's a very good team man.

"When we were in England last he waved goodbye at the Oval. He did so again in Australia but he's still around. As the younger players come through, we will go but I don't think it's a very good thing that we should go at the same time."

But, as he looks forward to his fourth test tour of England, there is a niggling bitterness in the Walsh pysche. It concerns his unhappy split with Gloucestershire, for whom he played between 1984 and 1998 and whose progress in tomorrow's Benson & Hedges Cup semi-final against Lancashire he will follow closely.

Walsh was one of the most successful of all overseas signings. But the parting was not amicable and the resentment festers.

"I think I deserved more than a phone call after all that I had done. They tried to blame me but the people there know the truth.

"I'm still close to Mark Alleyne and the rest of the players," he says. "But when I go to Bristol now I go to the far side of the ground. I don't go near the committee room or the executive area.

"I'm not one of those people who can put on a smile and shake hands when I don't mean it. Mark is always telling me to come over but I just wouldn't feel comfortable over there. It's very sad after such a long time. I made a lot of friends at Gloucestershire and it could have been a much better end."

His last hurrah for the county was a memorable one. He took 106 wickets in the summer of 1998, more than any other bowler since the County Championship was reduced to 17 matches in 1993. In 1998 Gloucestershire won as many matches, 11, as the champions Leicestershire, and finished a close-up fourth.

"When they offered me a [new] two-year contract it was on the basis that I would not be available for the World Cup. Then, in South Africa, I heard that the offer had been withdrawn. From that day to this no one in authority at the club has thought to speak to me personally. It's as though a huge and happy part of my life suddenly doesn't exist any more."

When it is all over, Walsh will feel relieved. His tired body must go on and on because, once he stops, he will stop for good.

And then he will relax over dominoes down at his Melbourne club in Jamaica, where Holding also played and where his mother still serves up stewed peas. In his young club days he really wanted to be a leg-spinner, a fact batsmen today receive with a wry smile.

webTitle: Hamilton sheds demons as Zimbabwe hit rock bottom

fields.headline: Hamilton sheds demons as Zimbabwe hit rock bottom
fields.trailText: If the Zimbabweans are approaching next week's second test with anything other than resignation, they are not making a terribly good fist of disguising it.
fields.body:
If the Zimbabweans are approaching next week's second test with anything other than resignation, they are not making a terribly good fist of disguising it.

Wintry conditions at Headingley should enable them to claim a draw today, but they did not help their chances by being shot out for 68 by Yorkshire yesterday. The wrecker was Gavin Hamilton, the chap currently mounting a serious bid for the title of Unluckiest Cricketer in History.

For Hamilton, who took five for 22 in 45 balls as the tourists lost their last seven wickets for 29, the 20th century ended in the mother of all anti-climaxes. During the World Cup last year he had been Scotland's one braveheart, averaging 54 with the bat to outdo the likes of Sachin Tendulkar and Sourav Ganguly, whereupon England nabbed him for South Africa. Then things went distinctly pear-shaped.

Despite copping fearful flak for his leanings during the European football championship play-off, Hamilton was chosen for the first test but drew a complete blank - no runs, no wickets, no catches, no mas.

As he tuned into the Regus Office Systems show on Talksport from that lonely cloud of his, JCW MacBryan, the only fellow to endure an entirely fruitless test career, will have permitted himself at least a bit of schadenfreude.

"Gavin's a very buoyant character but that knocked his confidence a little," sympathises Martyn Moxon, the Yorkshire coach and unabashed admirer.

"He had, what, two games after that test on the tour? That was the disappointing thing. He fell off his bike but wasn't given the chance to get back on. I watched that game at Jo'burg from New Zealand. It wasn't exactly an easy pitch, was it? Donald had his tail up - that's good enough for most.

"But that's cricket, and that's history. Gavin's never down for long and he's back to near his best. His control impressed me today. Sometimes, as with his batting, he can lose control. But every ball was in the business area; nice shape, hit the seam. He always takes the ball away from the right-hander.

"I really think he could become a genuine all-rounder. He's not the finished article but the potential is there. He needs to work on his shot selection and staying focused, but he played extremely well for his hundred against Hampshire. We were in a difficult position when Gavin came in but he took the game out of their hands.

"It wasn't the first time, either. He often does that. He's gutsy, full of energy, wants to do well - all the attributes. He's just got to keep control of his emotions."

What, then, of the Zimbabweans? "You do have some sympathy for them," admitted Moxon. "We had a reception for them on Thursday night and they're smashing lads. We've all been in that position when you can't see the wood for the trees.

"It's not been easy for them, especially given the way the weather and pitches have helped the bowlers. But, from a purely biased point of view, we, England, need to beat them well, for our own sake. People aren't going to want to watch test matches if we're not beating teams like this, are they?"

In the championship yesterday the West Australian left-hander Simon Katich pounded his maiden century for Durham against Leicestershire, sharing an unbeaten 140-run stand with the 20-year-old debutant Ian Hunter.

But all told, the total number of overs bowled at all eight matches was barely sufficient to extend a single game to tea. At Chelmsford there were 12.4, at Canterbury 15, at Riverside 40.2 and not a sausage at Northampton, Southampton, Taunton, Cardiff or Bristol. Divisional cricket? Does somebody up there not like that?

webTitle: Campbell cameo fails to ignite West Indies

fields.headline: Campbell cameo fails to ignite West Indies
fields.standfirst:
Pakistan 269
West Indies 122-3
fields.trailText: There have been no allegations of match-fixing against West Indies, which is unsurprising since, while all men have their price, it is difficult to imagine a West Indian who would be willing to pay the going rate for betrayal of Caribbean cricket.
fields.byline: BC Pires in St John's, Antigua
fields.body:
There have been no allegations of match-fixing against West Indies, which is unsurprising since, while all men have their price, it is difficult to imagine a West Indian who would be willing to pay the going rate for betrayal of Caribbean cricket.

Of the rebel West Indian teams that toured apartheid South Africa in the early 1980s only one member, Ezra Moseley of Barbados, ever played for West Indies again. Most were forced into exile, whether it was playing in England, coaching in Africa or ostracised as in the case of Bernard Julien of Trinidad and Tobago. One Jamaican, Richard Austin, is now reportedly wandering the streets. West Indies cricket is too valuable to West Indians for someone who has finally made it to the top of the pile to throw it away for filthy lucre.

Still, anyone watching the second day of the third and final test between Pakistan and West Indies at the Antigua Recreation Ground might be forgiven for thinking that a West Indian equivalent of the Qayyam report into match-fixing was hanging over their heads - at least those of the nervous top-of-the-order batsmen. A score of 122 for three at the tea interval reflected the steadying of the ship but not its rocking.

Courtney Walsh finished the Pakistanis off in the only West Indian over bowled in the morning, taking the wickets of Waqar Younis and Mushaq Ahmed and taking his test wicket tally to 448 in the process, with only two runs added to their overnight score of 267. The Pakistan innings lasted 91 overs with Yousuf Youhana unbeaten on 103. Walsh, whose Indian summer continues, finished with an impressive five for 83.

Sherwin Campbell began the innings with a confidence that reminded West Indian fans of the golden days of Gordon Greenidge and Desmond Haynes, when opening stands of three figures were not uncommon.

He took three consecutive fours off the last three balls of Wasim Akram's second over but, at 31, his concentration lapsed and he picked out the Pakistan hero Youhana for a practice catch.

If Campbell brought back thoughts of Haynes and Greenidge, Adrian Griffith at the other end prompted memories of Campbell and Stuart Williams, when opening West Indian stands of one were considered high.

Griffith, a solid batsman under pressure, never looked comfortable under none and was dropped twice, on one and again on 10, before being bowled behind his back by Mushtaq Ahmed for 22, a fitting end to a 65-ball innings he is unlikely to remember fondly.

Wavell Hinds, a century-maker in the second test, was unnecessarily run out for 26 while Shivnarine Chanderpaul survived an appeal on seven for a catch that appeared to come off his behind before settling down with his captain Jimmy Adams to steady a West Indian ship that they began to steer towards the shore.

Any stands, whether heroic or helpless, were not witnessed by a packed house. Judged by the numbers of the crowd, the second day of a test match that could go either way looked more like the last day of a match set for an unavoidable draw.

The Antigua Recreation Ground remained almost stubbornly empty up to tea time. The West Indian players may still care passionately but on this island their supporters, judging by the gaps in the stands, may be less than entranced by the game.

 South Africa's players have started making statements in preparation for the King inquiry into match-fixing allegations which will hold its first hearing in Cape Town on June 7. The former wicketkeeper Dave Richardson, a qualified lawyer and the team's agent, has appointed the attorney Peter Whelan and advocate Mike Fitzgerald to act on behalf of the players during the inquiry.

Of the rebel West Indian teams that toured apartheid South Africa in the early 1980s only one member, Ezra Moseley of Barbados, ever played for West Indies again. Most were forced into exile, whether it was playing in England, coaching in Africa or ostracised as in the case of Bernard Julien of Trinidad and Tobago. One Jamaican, Richard Austin, is now reportedly wandering the streets. West Indies cricket is too valuable to West Indians for someone who has finally made it to the top of the pile to throw it away for filthy lucre. Still, anyone watching the second day of the third and final test between Pakistan and West Indies at the Antigua Recreation Ground might be forgiven for thinking that a West Indian equivalent of the Qayyam report into match-fixing was hanging over their heads - at least those of the nervous top-of-the-order batsmen. A score of 122 for three at the tea interval reflected the steadying of the ship but not its rocking. Courtney Walsh finished the Pakistanis off in the only West Indian over bowled in the morning, taking the wickets of Waqar Younis and Mushaq Ahmed and taking his test wicket tally to 448 in the process, with only two runs added to their overnight score of 267. The Pakistan innings lasted 91 overs with Yousuf Youhana unbeaten on 103. Walsh, whose Indian summer continues, finished with an impressive five for 83. Sherwin Campbell began the innings with a confidence that reminded West Indian fans of the golden days of Gordon Greenidge and Desmond Haynes, when opening stands of three figures were not uncommon. He took three consecutive fours off the last three balls of Wasim Akram's second over but, at 31, his concentration lapsed and he picked out the Pakistan hero Youhana for a practice catch. If Campbell brought back thoughts of Haynes and Greenidge, Adrian Griffith at the other end prompted memories of Campbell and Stuart Williams, when opening West Indian stands of one were considered high. Griffith, a solid batsman under pressure, never looked comfortable under none and was dropped twice, on one and again on 10, before being bowled behind his back by Mushtaq Ahmed for 22, a fitting end to a 65-ball innings he is unlikely to remember fondly. Wavell Hinds, a century-maker in the second test, was unnecessarily run out for 26 while Shivnarine Chanderpaul survived an appeal on seven for a catch that appeared to come off his behind before settling down with his captain Jimmy Adams to steady a West Indian ship that they began to steer towards the shore. Any stands, whether heroic or helpless, were not witnessed by a packed house. Judged by the numbers of the crowd, the second day of a test match that could go either way looked more like the last day of a match set for an unavoidable draw. The Antigua Recreation Ground remained almost stubbornly empty up to tea time. The West Indian players may still care passionately but on this island their supporters, judging by the gaps in the stands, may be less than entranced by the game.  South Africa's players have started making statements in preparation for the King inquiry into match-fixing allegations which will hold its first hearing in Cape Town on June 7. The former wicketkeeper Dave Richardson, a qualified lawyer and the team's agent, has appointed the attorney Peter Whelan and advocate Mike Fitzgerald to act on behalf of the players during the inquiry.

webTitle: Please, dear Waz, say it ain't so

fields.headline: Please, dear Waz, say it ain't so
fields.trailText: Wasim Akram, who has led Pakistan on 25 occasions since first he was given the job in the Caribbean in 1993, will never do so again if he plays until he is 50.
fields.body:
These are sad times in the Selvey household and this is written with a heart so heavy it could counterbalance Andy Flintoff on a seesaw with a bit to spare for Darren Gough. So you'll forgive me if the office choose to surround the piece with a deep dark border, and insert perhaps a few appropriate lines in the in memoriam columns. I might even dress in black for an official period of one month until the next Lord's test is finished. No flowers please, though, they could not be viewed through a veil of tears and with the weeping the sense of smell has gone.

It's Waz, you see. On Wednesday, in Pakistan, Justice Malik Mohammad Qayyum's long-awaited report into match-fixing allegations in his country was published and among the recommendations was that Wasim Akram should be fined £3,700, kept under strict surveillance and have his assets investigated further.

On specific charges made against Wasim, Qayyum said that he had found insufficient proof. A more general charge of match-fixing, however, brought the message that "all is not well and Wasim Akram is not above board". Wasim, who has led Pakistan on 25 occasions since first he was given the job in the Caribbean in 1993, will never do so again if he plays until he is 50.

Waz is not only the greatest left-arm pace bowler ever to play the game, he is unquestionably my favourite cricketer of all time. For sheer exhilaration the sight of him pattering in with his dander up, the wind in the right quarter and the force with him, and making the ball not just talk but gabble, cannot be bettered in my experience.

I still maintain - and sorry if you have heard this before - that the most remarkable delivery I have witnessed in more than 40 years of playing and watching cricket was bowled to Robert Croft in the final test of the summer of 1996 at the Oval.

From around the wicket the ball, a low full toss, was angling way down the leg side, swinging down there even, and Croft shaped to play a legitimate leg glance. In the last 10 feet or so, however (and only the close-up in super-slow motion shows it) the ball changed direction as if by beacon and struck Croft's pad shin-high in front of middle stump.

It was sleight of hand, utterly mesmeric and as such far too quick for the umpire. It deserved all 10 wickets at once and did not even get one.

We'd even named our first labrador Wasim (the next was Zinzan but that is another story) and the previous summer, during Lancashire's match with Sussex at Lytham, Waz met Waz and the two posed together for posterity by the pavilion. The photograph is up there on a chest of drawers in our living room. Oh and my wife fancies him rotten. Need I go on about his standing in our family?

Aside from the match-fixing allegations, Waz's wonderful career has often courted controversy: the ball-tampering saga, for example, which was never concluded satisfactorily (and which failed anyway to explain how Waz could do things with these scuffed up Hush Puppy balls that others could only dream about), and the beamer that he fizzed at Chris Adams in a Lord's final, precipitating a dining-room altercation during an interval.

There was the odd injury too which sometimes appeared just a little too convenient. Once, on a previous occasion when Lancashire were in Lytham, this time playing Kent, he left the field during the afternoon complaining of a severe stomach ailment. A doctor was summoned - my mother-in-law, as it happened, who was a general practitioner in the town - who, after examining him, apparently told him that she certainly was not going to certify him unfit and to get back out there. Waz, it emerged, was itching to get to London (by helicopter, if memory serves) for a Pakistan team-mate's benefit match. He didn't make it.

But this is something different, for Waz is now a man tainted with the smell of scandal. The International Cricket Council may seek further punishment and Channel 4, which has him contracted to commentate on England's forthcoming series against West Indies, may yet dump him, although it is holding fire to see what emerges.

And so probably ought the Selveys. We want him to say it ain't so... but the dog has already gone in any case and I'm steeling myself for the day when the picture has to follow. Might even buy a rabbit for the kids and call it Mullally. And if Waz really is as guilty as sin then let the ignominy of that be a lesson to him.

webTitle: Keegan goes back to the future

fields.headline: Keegan goes back to the future
fields.standfirst: Hoddle's team lives again as England put faith in old guard
fields.trailText: Hoddle's team lives again - eight of the England side who went out of the 1998 World Cup on penalties to Argentina in St Etienne will start this afternoon's friendly against Brazil at Wembley.
fields.body:
It seems that England are about to go into the European Championship with a team that will strongly endorse Glenn Hoddle's belief in reincarnation. And, if their success or failure is based on past deeds, Kevin Keegan's side may do better than is generally anticipated.

Eight of Hoddle's England team who went out of the 1998 World Cup on penalties to Argentina in St Etienne will start this afternoon's friendly against Brazil at Wembley. When Keegan brings back Tony Adams, who is resting a slight back injury, there will be nine for the opening match against Portugal in Eindhoven a fortnight on Monday.

The exceptions today are Dennis Wise, who will almost certainly have given way to Steve McManaman by the time England face Portugal, and Phil Neville, who has appeared in every one of Keegan's matches so far. Unless injuries dictate otherwise, therefore, England will start Euro 2000 with a team rich in tournament experience as well as enjoying a healthy balance of youth and wisdom.

"I did not realise eight of the team had started in St Etienne," Keegan admitted after announcing the side yesterday, "but I do know it's an experienced side. It is not totally new, most of these players started in the play-off games against Scotland, but it is another opportunity to look at it."

Against Brazil England will use the 4-4-2 formation largely abandoned by Hoddle, who preferred 3-5-2 with wing-backs. Though Keegan is not fully committed to any one system and could bring Gareth Southgate or Martin Keown into a back three, his limited options at full-back, especially on the left, may well see England sticking with the format that, under Terry Venables, took them to the semi-finals of the last European Championship.

For England today's encounter with Rivaldo, Cafu, Aldair and the rest will be more a matter for revision than experiment. Keegan will want to see if Paul Ince can still be the midfield force he was in Euro 96 and France 98, if David Beckham can bring the additional qualities to his game that the England coach knows he has and if the attacking partnership of Alan Shearer and Michael Owen can recapture the initial impact that stunned the Argentine defence in St Etienne.

In some ways, largely because of niggling injuries, the Brazil game will be a lost opportunity for the England coach. He really needed confirmation of Emile Heskey's ability to complement Shearer up front after the promise the partnership showed against Argentina in February. Heskey, however, is not being risked because, like Adams, he needs to rest an aching back.

This, too, would have been the ideal moment to introduce Steven Gerrard to the England midfield, if only as a substitute for Ince, but the Liverpool youngster will need to shake off a thigh problem if he is to win his first cap against Ukraine on Wednesday. Andy Cole reported fit yesterday after taking his bruised toe to a specialist but, unless Robbie Fowler fails to get fit, the Manchester United striker's chance of making Keegan's squad of 22 may already have gone.

England are not short of strikers and for the moment Keegan will be seeking the best partner for Shearer while hoping that his retiring captain's presence in the team does not become an issue. Certainly the combination of Shearer and Owen has so far not lived up to its spectacular beginning in St Etienne. Since then the pair have between them scored only three times in the seven international matches they have started together. From what he said yesterday Shearer is plainly leaning towards Heskey.

"I thought the partnership worked well against Argentina in February," Shearer said. "When Emile went down the channels he got past people and caused them problems. He also had a big, strong, physical presence about him and they did not like that. That night looked very promising for him and it is unfortunate he cannot play against Brazil."

Shearer was more guarded about being reunited with Owen. "At times the partnership has looked very good but at others not so good," he said. "We've worked on things over the last couple of days. We both like scoring goals but maybe a small problem has been that we both want to be in the box and in the same place.

"Hopefully we can sort that out. There's no harm in us both wanting to score, that is a great knack to have, but we have to help take the weight off each other, ie by running into channels. There is not many better than Michael when he gets the ball at his feet and runs against defenders. He showed that against Argentina in the last World Cup. If he gets the ball a little short I'm sure he will cause problems. But each of us has the instinct to hang on a defender's shoulder and I think we will have to rectify that."

The build-up to today's match has become dominated by images of Steve McManaman as the player most likely to inspire England in Euro 2000. He, however, will not be joining Keegan until tomorrow night after Real Madrid's celebrations over Wednesday's European Cup final triumph in Paris, in which McManaman played a significant part.

No doubt attention will still be on the former Liverpool player in the Ukraine game but for now the England form of David Beckham will come under closer scrutiny. "He can get more involved in games and we have to be sure we give him enough service. We can't ask him to be influential when we play like we did against Scotland and he spends so much time chasing people back. If we can get him doing the things he is good at he will be a massive, massive plus for us. We have to demand more of him. And he has to look at it himself."

It all comes back to basics. If England can play the ball more constructively from defence and not needlessly give it away the creative talents of Beckham, McManaman and Paul Scholes will be more likely to prosper. Passing is where Keegan's team need to improve most and a game with Brazil, who have lost only three times to England in 19 meetings, is not a bad place to start.

fields.headline: The Odds Fellow
fields.standfirst: Rely on Rangers to go all the way
fields.trailText: Get down the cashpoint, take out all your money, go to the bookies and put it all on Rivaldo, Gillingham and Rangers.
fields.body:
Real Madrid, tipped to win the Champions League final at 5-6, and Chelsea, tipped to win the FA Cup at 5-4, have been short-odds winners for us in the past week. And favourite-backers should be in the money once again if they stick with Rangers in this afternoon's Scottish Cup final against Aberdeen at Hampden Park.

Dick Advocaat's team are a best-priced 4-11 with the Tote to win outright. But they can be backed at a more attractive 8-11 with Coral to be ahead at half- and full-time.

A 3-0 scoreline in Rangers' favour is on offer at 8-1 with Coral. Aberdeen are a top-priced 15-2 to win the match with Chandler, and Stan James is quoting 7-2 about a draw after 90 minutes.

England, currently a best-priced 11-1 with Surrey to win Euro 2000, face a stern test in today's friendly against Brazil. The hosts are available at 9-4 with Heathorns, which is offering 11-5 about a draw. But Brazil's three goals in 10 minutes against Wales on Tuesday were a reminder of their thrilling ability to raise their game. A win for Brazil looks the most likely outcome at 7-5 with Eurobet or 6-5 with Chandler.

Rivaldo is worth buying at 7 points with Sporting on its First-Last Blast market. The spread awards 25 points to the scorer of the first and/or last goal. Punters who want to stick with more straightforward markets should buy Brazilian supremacy at 0.3 with Sporting and sell total goals at 2.4 with the same firm.

Gillingham are capable of winning tomorrow's Second Division play-off against Wigan at Wembley at evens with Coral and Heathorns. And those of us who have backed Ipswich to win the First Division play-offs will be hoping they can beat Barnsley in 90 minutes on Monday at 11-8 with Stanley.

Betting has begun on next season's Champions League. Barcelona, overpriced at 10-1 with Surrey, are Chandler's 5-1 joint favourites with Lazio. Chandler has Manchester United, Juventus and Real Madrid on 6-1, and Real are 9-1 with Hills. Chandler has Arsenal at 20-1 and Leeds at 50-1.

webTitle: Five to miss out on Euro 2000

fields.headline: Five to miss out on Euro 2000
fields.trailText: On Wednesday evening Kevin Keegan will break six hearts by cutting his 28-man squad to 22 ready for the Euro 2000 finals. Here we name five of them.
fields.body:
On Wednesday evening Kevin Keegan will break six hearts by cutting his 28-man squad to 22 ready for the Euro 2000 finals. The five players below seem pretty certain to miss out. The sixth casualty is harder to forecast. Depending on injuries it looks a toss-up between Nick Barmby, Kieron Dyer and Gareth Barry.

David James

Age 29, 1 cap, 0 goals

Handed a surprise call-up in recognition of a generally impressive season with Aston Villa, he might have stood a better chance of making the final 22 ahead of Ipswich's Richard Wright had he not ruined a good season's image-rebuilding with the FA Cup final error that gifted Chelsea their winning goal. So unless Wright is injured in Monday's First Division play-off final it will be home James for the bleach blond.

Ray Parlour

Age 27, 6 caps, 0 goals

Largely seen as cover for David Beckham wide on the right but nowhere near the same class. England have others who could fill in and, anyway, the Arsenal winger has hardly helped his cause with unconvincing contributions when given an England chance. The feeling persists that his forward runs too often end up blind alleys or in the loss of possession.

Jamie Redknapp

Age 26, 17 caps, 1 goal

Injured for much of the season and struggling for fitness still, the Liverpool midfielder is feeling his way back and will have a hard time putting the case for his inclusion ahead of the likes of Steve McManaman, Paul Scholes and Dennis Wise. He scored a cracking 25-yard winner in last October's friendly against Belgium but that memory was quickly erased by a more characteristically tepid performance in the Scotland defeat.

Rio Ferdinand

Age 21, 9 caps, 0 goals

Once touted as a future England regular, Ferdinand's progress has slowed in the last year. When playing in the Premiership he still looks cool on the ball and can ping a long ball to feet with the best of them, but overelaboration in defensive situations has led to some high-profile mistakes this season. At his age he has time to mature.

Andy Cole

Age 28, 7 caps, 0 goals

There seems to be a bit of history between Cole and Kevin Keegan, who did, after all, sell him at Newcastle. Despite the striker's impressive contribution to Manchester United's stirring deeds he never seems uppermost in the England coach's thoughts. With six strikers chasing five spots, the writing appears to be on the wall for Cole.

With six strikers chasing five spots, the writing appears to be on the wall for Cole.

webTitle: Bristling Bond wages war to the end

fields.headline: Bristling Bond wages war to the end
fields.trailText: His hair may have gone a whiter shade of grey, but John Bond remains an unmistakable figure. As he saunters back to Wembley tomorrow for the first time in 19 years he will doubtless reflect that he is back where he belongs.
fields.body:
His hair may have gone a whiter shade of grey, his belt loosened a notch or two and his old swagger curtailed by time, but John Bond remains an unmistakable figure. As he saunters back to Wembley tomorrow for the first time in 19 years he will doubtless reflect that he is back where he belongs.

Bond, if your memory needs jogging, was Manchester City's larger-than-life manager in the 1981 FA Cup final. He was a prominent member of the furry coat brigade, complete with garish jewellery and foot-long cigars, that was courted by City around that time. But if he was ahead of his time then, he is now considered a relic of a bygone era.

Bond was once linked with the top jobs at Manchester United and Benfica, but somehow it never quite worked out for him. After an acrimonious departure from Maine Road in 1983 he took in Burnley and Shrewsbury Town before a spell at Witton Albion during what he calls his "five years in the wilderness", whither he will reluctantly return after tomorrow's play-off final against Gillingham.

The most refreshing thing about him is his frankness. Even at the age of 67 he clearly believes he deserves better than to be a peripheral member of the coaching staff at Wigan Athletic.

"I think it's very sad when people like me are out of the game," he says, with no attempt to hide his bitterness. "When you go to clubs these days you realise they need people like me. Hardly any good coaching, what I call proper coaching, goes on. You look at these young coaches and you wouldn't believe some of the mistakes they make.

"I know I'm older and that the movements aren't the same now, but I can still coach. For what it's worth, Ron Atkinson reckoned I was the best coach he had ever seen apart from Dave Sexton. When you're talked about in those terms, it's sad when people won't use you. I think managers are frightened to death of me. They think I'm after their job, but I've never gone after anyone else's job in my life."

The one person who did offer him a job last summer was John Benson, his assistant at Norwich City and Manchester City all those years ago. No spring chicken himself, Benson will stand aside as Wigan's manager after the play-off final, with the former Sheffield Wednesday manager Danny Wilson his likely replacement.

With Benson moving "upstairs" Bond will be surplus to requirements, and he recognises why he again faces the prospect of unemployment.

"I antagonise people," he says. "I've always antagonised a fair amount of people. They don't like people who speak the truth. I just say what I think is the truth and if that's being outspoken then, yes, I was outspoken.

"It seems these days they are more interested in appointing someone they can rub shoulders with. They'll appoint someone because he was a good player. What nonsense. What utter, utter nonsense."

His anger threatens to boil over as he laments his exile from the big time, only mellowing once his mind is turned to his final fling in the arena he once thought was his own.

"I thought my days of that had gone and passed with the centenary Cup final," he says. "I've not been back since but I'm looking forward to it. It's going to be massive, massive, massive, as big as Manchester United against Real Madrid."

The Wigan public, who have bought only 8,500 tickets, would appear to disagree, but Bond is entitled to hyperbole. It is his last shot at the big time and he is determined to milk it.

webTitle: All bets off as Wembley beckons Gills again

fields.headline: All bets off as Wembley beckons Gills again
fields.trailText: The Gillingham chairman Paul Scally would like to make two things clear before tomorrow's play-off final: yes, he is delighted to be back and no, he wouldn't dream of betting on his side to win.
fields.body:
The Gillingham chairman Paul Scally would like to make two things clear before tomorrow's play-off final: yes, he is delighted to be back and no, he wouldn't dream of betting on his side to win.

A year ago Scally watched in shock as Gillingham threw away a two-goal lead against Manchester City to miss out on promotion. Then he was charged (11 months later) by the Football Association with betting on that match. The case has still to be heard.

He denies misconduct ("It's a charge brought about by a mischievous allegation in a local newspaper who were banned from our stadium over a year ago," he insists) and although it took him a month to recover from losing to City on penalties he is excited at taking on Wigan. Never have Gillingham escaped the league's bottom two tiers.

"There can be no better way to get promoted than to win at Wembley," he says. "Last year was a harsh lesson in not counting your chickens. But it's prepared us well because no one wants to suffer that torment again."

Maybe not, but Gillingham lost the final game of the season when a win would have sealed promotion. With that kind of record, it's no wonder Scally won't be betting on this one.

Probable team (4-4-2): Bartram; Pennock, Ashby, Butters, Edge; Southall, Hessenthaler, Lewis, Gooden; Onuora, Asaba.

webTitle: 'I know how bad we have been'

fields.headline: 'I know how bad we have been'
fields.standfirst: Aberdeen's Jim Leighton wants to hang up his gloves on a high
fields.trailText: The roller-coaster ride is almost over. Jim Leighton's colourful career between the sticks will finally end after today's Scottish Cup final against Rangers at Hampden Park.
fields.body:
The roller-coaster ride is almost over. Jim Leighton's colourful career between the sticks will finally end after today's Scottish Cup final against Rangers at Hampden Park. Earlier this week the 41-year-old Aberdeen and former Scotland keeper decided to hang up his gloves and become the club's first full-time goalkeeping coach.

"I had mulled over retirement for a while and decided this would be the ideal time. Mind you," he adds, "I could have been forgiven had I taken the decision during the course of the season. To say it has been turbulent would be an understatement."

It is appropriate that Scotland's national stadium will be the venue for Leighton's final game. Next to his club's Pittodrie ground, where he has spent 16 years in all, it has been his most regular haunt for most of his career.

Those who thought that his initial return to Dundee and then Hibernian after an unhappy time at Manchester United heralded the demise of his career were wrong. He confounded everyone by re-establishing himself in the Scotland team.

Yet for someone who made 91 appearances for Scotland - second only to Kenny Dalglish - Leighton has been bewildered by Aberdeen's ventures this season. From being one of the best teams in Europe, and far and away the best in Scotland, during the bulk of the 1980s under Alex Ferguson's managership, their deterioration has been witnessed at first hand by Leighton. He, after all, has had to collect the ball from the back of the net 83 times this season in the league.

That is a record for the club, who finished bottom with 33 points - 57 behind today's championship-winning opponents. It was the worst defensive record of any senior team in Britain and, lucky that the Premier League is expanding by two clubs next season, they avoided possible relegation via play-offs with two First Division sides only when it was deemed that the ground of one of them, Falkirk, who finished third, did not meet Premier League standards.

On the face of it Aberdeen, would be better off facing Rothwell Town from the Dr Martens Premier or Winsford from the Unibond Premier, teams who conceded 85 and 119 goals respectively. Leighton smiles at the suggestion.

"I know only too well how bad we have been," he says. "The decline probably began in the early 90s and reached its nadir this season.

"What has made it more absurd is that we have reached the finals of the League Cup and Scottish Cup and are guaranteed a place in Europe next season irrespective of the outcome against Rangers."

Leighton has taken small comfort from this. "I'm a realist. Our ventures in the cup competitions have only papered over the cracks. Had we played in the cups as badly as we did in our earlier league matches we wouldn't have reached the final."

But though he can understand the logic behind the bookmakers offering odds of 11-2 against Aberdeen - the longest ever for a finalist - and 4-11 for a Rangers victory, he honestly believes he can collect a fifth winner's medal.

"While for the most part we have been awful there have been matches in which everything gelled and we looked more like champions than a side propping up the table," he said. "Morale is better, especially after winning our last two matches."

Leighton's morale certainly is. The 2-0 win over Dundee last Sunday gave him his first league shut-out of the season - a far cry from the Ferguson days when he had 22 clean sheets in one season in which he conceded only 17 goals.

"I know it is a cliche to say that we have everything to gain and nothing to lose but that really is the situation. If ever a club was under pressure it is Rangers. After all, one of their most expensive players probably cost more than our entire staff."

For obvious reasons Leighton is looking forward to this match more than anyone. Along with the centre-half and captain Derek Whyte, who won two Scottish Cup medals with Celtic, he has been using his vast experience to help the younger Aberdeen players during the week's preparation.

"They are really up for this one," he says. "I just hope they have a real go. This is the best Rangers team I can recall and it would be a long afternoon for me if we were to sit back and hope to catch them on the break.

"It's there to be won and we did, after all, beat them in the quarter-finals of the League Cup. I'm not normally an emotional person but I think I will be shedding a few tears at the end of the match. Hopefully they will be tears of joy."
