webTitle: Charleroi lobby yet to learn lessons of Heysel

fields.headline: Charleroi lobby yet to learn lessons of Heysel
fields.trailText: Three weeks from now England will meet Germany in the tiny, steep-sided Stade Communal in Charleroi amid fears that this is another tragedy waiting to happen. Such sentiments are not alarmist; the ingredients for a disaster are already there.
fields.body:
Today England's match with Brazil will hold centre stage. Yet even as Kevin Keegan gets close to sorting out the probables from the improbables before announcing his squad for Euro 2000, the anvil-shaped cloud that has loomed on the horizon ever since the draw was made grows darker still.

Three weeks from now England will meet Germany in the tiny, steep-sided Stade Communal in Charleroi amid fears that this is another tragedy waiting to happen. Such sentiments are not alarmist; the ingredients for a disaster are already there.

The ground holds only 30,000 and at least three times that number of English and German supporters want to see the game, so a lot will arrive without tickets.

The seating is rudimentary: backless plastic perches which invite spectators to stand up, as many will, increasing the danger of an avalanche of bodies should someone fall. And since the ground has perimeter fences the pitch will not offer a ready route to safety, a situation unthinkable in England since Hillsborough.

The stadium is set amid a maze of narrow streets which would make it difficult for the emergency services to reach the ground quickly and impede the efforts of the police to keep order should trouble break out.

The possibility of crowd trouble has hardly been diminished by Belgian refusals to impose an alcohol ban on match days. True, the mayor of Charleroi has ordered bars near the stadium to be closed but beer will be available in other parts of this small town.

Already Belgian politicians have expressed misgivings about playing the England-Germany match in Charleroi. This week members of the country's interior affairs committee visited the Stade Communal and immediately expressed fears about the precipitous tiers of seats which, according to some reports, would necessitate mountain-rescue teams being mobilised to remove injured spectators. One member admitted he had "the feeling of being in an extremely dangerous position".

The case for switching this game to a larger ground, even at such a late stage, would appear unanswerable. The King Baudouin stadium in Brussels, which holds 50,000 in safety and comfort, is barely half an hour away.

Uefa, however, remains adamant that the match will go on in Charleroi come what may. And to judge from the comments of its chief executive Gerhard Aigner this week on the trouble that broke out in Copenhagen before the Uefa Cup final between Arsenal and Galatasaray, nothing will prompt a change of heart.

Aigner continues to propound the now defunct view that football authorites cannot be held responsible for what happens outside grounds. In Copenhagen, he said, there was no trouble at the Parken stadium, as indeed there was not. What went on in the city centre a few hours before "had nothing to do with our sport".

This is a dangerously complacent attitude. Should violence break out in Charleroi it could raise tensions inside the stadium before kick-off.

Then again, there might be no trouble inside the ground. The behaviour of football crowds is difficult to predict. The street rioting in Marseille that preceded England's opening game against Tunisia in the 1998 World Cup was not reflected in the mood of the English fans inside the Stade Velodrome.

The point about Charleroi is that any crowd problems would be exacerbated by the stadium's limitations. Before the 1985 European Cup final in Brussels Uefa's cursory inspection of the delapidated venue did not take into account what might happen in the event of a disturbance. Then Heysel happened and the ground was rebuilt as the King Baudouin Stadium, to which Uefa should now take the England-Germany game.

It will not, of course, so one trusts that widespread predictions of the match becoming football's armageddon turn out to be a case of reality contradicting hype. Aigner touched a raw nerve when he declared that parts of the media were responsible for what happened in Copenhagen; although no reporter or cameraman could be blamed for starting the trouble, the way it was represented gave an exaggerated impression of what actually occurred.

Overnight press pictures of an Arsenal supporter bleeding from a stab wound followed by 24 hours of repeated TV pictures showing rampaging mobs and tear gas suggested that the Danish capital had suffered two days of violence. In fact the trouble lasted no more than 45 minutes and the worst scenes little more than 15.

Television has a particular responsibility here. A close-up shot of half a dozen football fans pushing and shouting can leave viewers believing that a full-scale riot has broken out. In its keenness to get good pictures TV can be as guilty of sensationalism as the most strident tabloid.

It is to be hoped that on June 17 an outbreak of peace in Charleroi finds us all guilty of being at least a little sensationalist in advance.

fields.headline: Larsson fit enough for Sweden
fields.trailText: Henrik Larsson, whose career was in doubt after he broke his leg last October, has convinced Sweden's coach Tommy Soderberg he is fit for Euro 2000.
fields.body:
Henrik Larsson, whose career was in doubt after he broke his leg last October, has convinced Sweden's coach Tommy Soderberg he is fit for Euro 2000.

Larsson was named in Sweden's 22-man squad yesterday, although he has not completed a full competitive game for Celtic since the injury.

"Henrik is in better condition now than he was before his knee injury," Soderberg said. "I have really never seen such quick feet as Larsson's during training. After a severe injury a player is always hot and inspired for five or six games. That sounds good to me."

Larsson's recovery is a huge boost to a squad weakened by the loss through injury of Andreas Andersson, Pontus Kamark, Stefan Schwarz and Jesper Blomqvist.

Dennis Bergkamp and Marc Overmars may get the chance to exorcise their Uefa Cup final demons when Holland meet Romania in Amsterdam today.

Galatasaray's Gheorghe Hagi and Gheorghe Popescu, who tormented Arsenal in Copenhagen last week, are expected to line up for Romania in what will be both sides' last friendly before the Euro 2000 squads are announced.

The Dutch are desperate for a win after 11 draws in 15 matches under Frank Rijkaard, who may take the opportunity to have a look at Roy Makaay or Pierre van Hooijdonk as cover in attack for the out-of-form Bergkamp and Patrick Kluivert.

Romania, who have drafted in the 36-year-old defender Miodrag Belodedici, have never scored against Holland and would be happy to come away with a draw after defeats against Greece and Cyprus in previous warm-up matches.

Norway's coach Nils Johan Semb is also looking for clues from today's friendly against Slovakia in Oslo. Semb has delayed naming his squad as he waits for news on several injured players, among them Steffen Iversen (toe) and Eirik Bakke (thigh). Ole Gunnar Solskjaer has recovered from a knee problem. In goal Thomas Myhre, put on the transfer list by Everton this week, and Frode Olsen are each hopeful of a run-out tomorrow and in the final warm-up game against Italy.

Everton's Abel Xavier is the only English-based player in an uncontroversial Portugal squad announced by the coach Humberto Coelho.

The Ireland coach Mick McCarthy has recalled Fulham's Terry Phelan for Tuesday's friendly against Scotland.

Portugal squad:
Goalkeepers: Baia (Porto), Espinha (Vitoria Guimaraes), Silva (Braga). Defenders: Xavier (Everton), Couto (Lazio), Dimas (Standard Liege), Secretario (Porto), J Costa (Porto), Beto (Sporting Lisbon), Jorge (Sporting Lisbon). Midfield: Sousa (Parma), Bento (Oviedo), R Costa (Fiorentina), Figo (Barcelona), Conceicao (Lazio), F Costa (Monaco), Vidigal (Sporting Lisbon). Forwards: J Pinto (Benfica), Gomes (Benfica), S Pinto (Real Sociedad) Pauleta (Deportivo La Coruna), Capucho (Porto).

Sweden squad:
Goalkeepers: Hedman (Coventry City), Asper (AIK Solna), Kihlstedt (SK Brann). Defenders: Nilsson (Helsingborgs), P Andersson (Bayern Munich), Bjorklund (Valencia), Lucic (AIK Solna), Sundgren (Real Zaragoza), Gustafsson (Coventry City). Midfield: Mellberg (Santander), Alexandersson (Sheffield Wednesday), D Andersson (Bari), Mjallby (Celtic), Ljungberg (Arsenal), Svensson (Brondby) Anders Andersson (Aalborg). Forwards: Mild (Gothenburg), K Andersson (Bologna), Pettersson (Kaiserslautern), Osmanovski (Bari), Allback (Orgryte), Larsson (Celtic).

fields.headline: Lampard joins diplomatic corps
fields.trailText: The England Under-21 team launch their own European championship finals campaign tonight when they play Italy here in the Slovakian capital. But already Monday night's match against Turkey is the focus of attention.
fields.body:
The England Under-21 team launch their own European championship finals campaign tonight when they play Italy here in the Slovakian capital. But already Monday night's match against Turkey is the focus of attention.

Ever since two Leeds United supporters were killed in Istanbul before the Uefa Cup semi-final against Galatasaray last month a bitter mood has simmered between supporters of the two countries.

The problems continued when Arsenal met Galatasaray in the Uefa Cup final last week, and yesterday the respective under-21 captains were quick to address the issue before Monday night's game.

England's Frank Lampard swapped pennants with his Turkish counterpart Erhan Albayrak and each attempted to put the matter to one side.

Lampard said: "This is a great chance to restore relations between the two countries. We've said hello and it's an opportunity to make friends. They feel the same as we do and we just want to go out and be competitive. This was an important exercise to show there is no ill-feeling between Turkey and England."

Albayrak hoped there would be no repeat of the fighting that took place before the Uefa Cup final. "I would urge all the fans to behave before the game," he said. "We don't want anyone to get hurt. It's only a football match."

Tonight in the stadion Tehlene England face an Italy team boasting 10 players from Serie A, managed by the 1982 World Cup winner Marco Tardelli. England's manager Howard Wilkinson admitted to slight injury worries over Andy Campbell, Carl Cort and Luke Young, although all are likely to start.

England round off their group games next Thursday by playing the hosts, but Wilkinson expressed annoyance yesterday at having to play their three games in such a short space of time. "I don't agree with the spacing of the games," he said. "The way it is I would have wanted a bigger squad."

The two group winners - the second group features Spain, Croatia, Holland and the Czech Republic - will face each other in the final in eight days' time but those finishing in the top four will qualify for the Olympics this autumn, except England who are not eligible to field a team for Sydney.

webTitle: Hull back at Boothferry as Lloyd's lock-out ends

fields.headline: Hull back at Boothferry as Lloyd's lock-out ends
fields.trailText: Staff at Hull City will be able to return to Boothferry Park this morning after a High Court judge overturned an eviction order obtained by the former owner David Lloyd.
fields.body:
Staff at Hull City will be able to return to Boothferry Park this morning after a High Court judge overturned an eviction order obtained by the former owner David Lloyd.

Nick Buchanan, the club's chairman, and his fellow directors have made a counter-claim against Lloyd's allegation that he is owed £103,000 in rent and yesterday they secured an injunction to allow them to return to their offices. On Wednesday the locks were changed and bailiffs barred staff entry.

"All along we believed that we would win the battle to get back into Boothferry Park," Buchanan said. "The unfortunate point about all of this is that both sides will incur hefty legal fees, and all of that could have been avoided."

Bradford City will compete in Europe for the first time after accepting a late entry into next season's Intertoto Cup. Paul Jewell's side, who avoided relegation on the final day of the season, were the only Premiership club to apply for entry into the second round of the competition and were put on a waiting list. The withdrawal yesterday of an unnamed Italian club meant that Bradford stepped up.

Aston Villa will join the cup in the third round, when Bradford will play Waalwijk of the Netherlands should they beat the winners of a first-round game between an unnamed Turkish side and Atlantis of Lithuania at the beginning of July.

Bradford's players will be asked to begin their pre-season early, although those who are committed to family holidays will not have to return.

Manchester United's goalkeeper Mark Bosnich will not play for Australia in the Olympic Games in Sydney in September after deciding to take a break from international football.

webTitle: Superstar on the verge of greatness

fields.headline: Superstar on the verge of greatness
fields.standfirst: He is the second best player in the world. Today, against Brazil, David Beckham starts his quest to be better
fields.trailText: He is the second best player in the world. Today, against Brazil, David Beckham starts his quest to be better.
fields.body:
Sorry to add to the slush pile of recent stuff about footballers and babies, but there's just one more image that might be worth sharing. It goes back five weeks, to the night Manchester United's hopes of retaining the European Cup were ended by Real Madrid at Old Trafford.

An hour and a half after the end of the match, there was hardly anyone left in the stadium. A few stewards were checking the grandstands. The last television crews were moving their equipment out. In the press box, a couple of journalists were wearily packing up their laptops. Out of the players' tunnel, in the south-west corner, came three figures: the Beckham family.

Down the touchline they strolled. No security men, no courtiers, no photographers. Posh, presumably to preserve her Manolo heels, kept to the track. David, wearing his grey club suit, lifted one-year-old Brooklyn by the hands and carried him on to the pitch, encouraging the infant to toddle across the grass. You could see the smiles from 200 feet away. After a couple of minutes they disappeared through a gate at the south-east corner, on their way to the players' car park, where David had left one of his cars. The Ferrari, perhaps, or the TVR, or the Lincoln, or the Mercedes.

But for that minute or two, questions of wealth and conspicuous consumption didn't intrude at all. The nice shoes and the expensive suit and the flash car were beside the point. Kidnap attempts and bullets in the post seemed a long way away. The appeal of the moment resided in its banality. The point was the lack of self-consciousness, the ability when unobserved to behave just like normal people.

Two hours earlier, David Beckham had done something not normal at all. Raul had just scored his second goal, Madrid's third, and United's fate was clear. What he did next said a lot about his character and his talent.

This is a player who, whatever his technical virtues, is popularly supposed to be incapable of beating a man with the ball, a flaw which, in some eyes, denies him a claim to greatness. But when he took a short pass from Paul Scholes just outside the penalty area, Beckham shattered the myth. Faced by a Madrid defence good enough to have shut out Valencia's raiders in Paris this week, he put his head down and took them on. A player believed to have no pace weaved past one opponent from a standing start, past another, and past a third, all in the space of 10 yards, as if in a single swaying movement. And then, without breaking stride, he smashed a right-foot drive across Iker Casillas and into the roof of the net.

It was anything but a typical Beckham goal. Perhaps its special nature was born out of anger and frustration, out of the knowledge that he and his team were about to lose their precious crown. Perhaps something in him, some self-denying ordinance rooted in an ingrained desire to put the interests of the team first, was momentarily liberated by that knowledge. Had it occurred in happier circumstances, they would still be showing it on television. As it was, it changed nothing. Except, perhaps, the perception of David Beckham's talent.

"He's a fantastic player, a very special and respected player," Rivaldo said yesterday, looking ahead to this afternoon's match at Wembley. "His crosses are always dangerous." That's the conventional analysis, and it pays tribute to the way in which, thanks to some special alignment of the bones of ankle and foot, Beckham can whip the ball in from the right wing with an unprecedented degree of late curl and dip. Brazil's left-back - Silvinho of Arsenal - will be expecting a busy afternoon, with Beckham supported by Gary Neville, his club colleague, on England's right flank.

"I think David Beckham can have a bigger influence on the England set-up than he's had already," Kevin Keegan said yesterday. "There's much more in him, and we've got to find a better way of getting it out. We have to demand more of him." It sounded promising, although he also talked about the value of Beckham's crosses. And that's the way England will probably operate today, using him as a conventional winger.

But if he can score a goal like the one he registered against Real, which had nothing to do with his specialised ability to cross the ball, he can do practically anything. He could even find a way to use the example of Steve McManaman's display in Paris on Wednesday night to prove that, in the right setting and with the right colleagues around him, a player does not need to abandon his gift for wing play in order to exploit his vision of the game from the central areas. The time to do this is during the next five weeks, when Euro 2000 will provide him with the opportunity to measure his development since France 98, when he scored his first - and so far only - international goal with a wonderful free-kick against Colombia but then in the next game responded to Diego Simeone's trivial provocation and found himself being burned in effigy in his own country and forced to listen to obscene chants aimed at his wife.

This week, two years and half a lifetime later, the silver Ferrari could be seen parked outside the Buckinghamshire hotel where England are preparing for their campaign, lined up amid the Jags and the Mercs and the Porsches of his team-mates. Its owner no longer stands out as readily he once did among the company on the training pitch at Bisham Abbey, thanks to the removal of his streaked-blond locks. Beckham could never be accused of shunning publicity, but the decision to shave his head has had the side-effect of allowing him to blend in among the likes of Steven Gerrard, Kevin Phillips and Rio Ferdinand, which may or may not have been the intention.

But one quality continues to distinguish Beckham from the rest. For all his cars and his mansions and his pop star wife, his sheer love of the ball remains that of a football-struck nine-year-old. Throughout a training session he is never at rest, and never happy when a ball is not either in his possession or doing something he has just commanded it to do.

"Great ball, Becks," Kevin Keegan shouts during a full-scale practice game as Beckham ignores several simpler options to find Phillips with a bullet of a crossfield pass that opens up an entire flank of the opposing defence. That's what he is there to do. But while the squad is gathered round listening to Derek Fazackerley, the assistant coach, Beckham is loitering on the fringe and waiting for the moment when he can play a little game with David Seaman. It goes like this: Beckham chips the ball hard over Seaman's head while the goalkeeper throws up a second ball to try to divert it; a little test of accuracy and reflexes. When the players are lying on the grass as Keegan talks to them, Beckham is sitting on a ball, as if he can't bear to be without it. While his team-mates are trooping off the pitch and heading for the team coach at the end of the session, he is adding a coda by playing another little game of skill with one of the physios. He's the last off the pitch.

The last, too, to complete the business of signing autographs, a task he performs quietly, with a small smile for each recipient. A 12-year-old girl whose golf ball had landed among the players half an hour earlier, hooked off the adjacent fairway, gets a photo opportunity of her own, granted with a complete absence of fuss.

Since the departure of Paul Gascoigne, Beckham has become the current squad's focal point, its most compelling individual, the one to whom the eye is naturally drawn. Whatever the merits and the implications of McManaman's performance for Real on Wednesday, and in the absence of conclusive proof of Michael Owen's return to full fitness, Beckham remains the one England player capable of a game-changing feat of unimaginable virtuosity. With the ball at his feet, he is just as watchable as Gascoigne. But in every other way he could hardly be more different.

When Gascoigne performed a light-footed trick in an England training session, the point was to astonish and amuse those who were observing him. Sadly, he was long past the point at which what mattered was the simple pleasure of kicking the ball with more guile and technique than anyone else. His altruism had been distorted by the need to entertain an audience, to put on an exhibition. Beckham is not like that at all. Whatever he may get up to in a fashion photographer's studio, posing moodily for a magazine spreads in a transparent Gucci blouse, once he pulls on a football jersey he never, ever shows off.

Away from football he lives the life of his own choice, and pays a price for it. Gary Neville, his best friend and as unpretentious a man as exists in English football, laughed incredulously at the idea that Beckham's example might have been useful when it came to coping with the criticism resulting from his expensive gaffes during the World Club Championship in Rio. "I got a couple of comments here and there, and it was difficult for me, but the situation for David is something else," he said. "By comparison, I wouldn't say I had anything to deal with at all."

This is the time to put all of that aside. No player in Euro 2000 has a better opportunity to assert his presence than Beckham, potentially the principal creative influence in a team which has yet to discover itself. If Keegan has the courage and imagination to allow the side to create its own shape once the tournament is under way, Beckham could show us that his development into the finished article need not involve the trading of one set of techniques for another, but the judicious use of them all. Or, to put it another way, the world's No2 player now has the chance to live up to his billing.

fields.headline: A nemesis named Rivaldo
fields.standfirst: The world's most complete footballer is the ultimate test for England
fields.trailText: Asked who the world player of the year should be, Rivaldo's answer was simple. "Rivaldo," he said, "because I'm the best."
fields.body:
Asked who the world player of the year should be, Rivaldo's answer was simple. "Rivaldo," he said, "because I'm the best." England will hardly need reminding that the holder of sport's most coveted shirt - Brazil's No10 - is not backwards in coming forwards on the pitch either.

Which is why Kevin Keegan might learn more about his team's defensive capabilities today than from any number of training sessions or VIP seats. Bow-legged and skinny Rivaldo may be, but his genius makes the Rolex of football teams tick. For England this is the ultimate test.

"He has just about everything you can want in an attacker," Sir Alex Ferguson says. And just about everything a defender could wish to avoid: skill, speed, strength. His goal from Denilson's cross in Cardiff on Tuesday was a reminder that his head is for more than scheming.

And of course the 28-year-old forward was right. He is world player of the year, and has the European award to go with it. If many of his free-kicks and passes are remarkable for execution rather than imagination, he is also capable of flashes few others would see, let alone carry out.

"I remember in Brasilia he nearly lobbed the keeper Andy Marriott from the halfway line when he was shaping as if he was going to hit the left winger," says Robert Page, part of the Wales team beaten 3-0 this week and in 1997. "Now and again he'll do something extra special but almost everything Brazil do revolves around him."

Brazil's fluid 2-4-2-2 formation makes Rivaldo harder still to tame. Operating behind the front pair but often ahead of a four-strong line comprising the full-backs (Cafu and Silvinho) and the more grafting midfielders (Cesar Sampaio and Emerson), he seeks space to weave his magic.

Unless England's midfielders track him, the defence will be exposed to his surging runs and pinpoint passes. Twice against Wales he found room on the edge of the box and shot wide. Eventually he headed his 25th goal from 46 caps.

"You need someone to step on to him as soon as he gets the ball," Page says, "and be fierce with him." Rivaldo acknowledged that Wales' physical approach made it hard for Brazil to find space to play. Even so he once clipped the ball dismissively over Matthew Jones - an act best avoided on Dennis Wise or Paul Ince by anyone who values their ankles - and occasionally breezed past opponents as if they were training cones.

"Some players you can show on to their weaker foot and they won't do a lot," Page says, "but he's got two good feet and the strength to go with it." Indeed, Rivaldo's technique and movement are complemented by assets vital to the modern game: power, athleticism, stamina and hard work.

"His mastery of the football is brilliant but what makes him special is also the way he plays for the team," Denilson explains. "In today's game you see a lot of players who can't dribble or don't have very good control but in the box they are kings and they score a lot of goals. Rivaldo has it all."

How England counter him should offer an insight into their Euro 2000 chances. In Charleroi they will have to deal with the similar threat of Gheorghe Hagi. The Romanian may no longer have the pace or mobility of Rivaldo but he too is quick-witted, left-footed and frightening at set-pieces.

And before that comes another formidable No10, Portugal's Rui Costa. The Fiorentina player can also beat opponents at close quarters, spray passes and make runs from deep. His midfield link-up with Luis Figo is dangerous.

webTitle: Kev's a decent man - but that won't save him

fields.headline: Kev's a decent man - but that won't save him
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan was invited recently to a charity auction of sporting memorabilia. Scanning the lots on offer before the event, Keegan thought they could do with sprucing up a bit. So he donated three of his own.
fields.body:
Intriguing news from the private life of our England coach.

Kevin Keegan was invited recently to a charity auction, at which sporting memorabilia was flogged off to an audience of the loaded on behalf of a good cause. Scanning the lots on offer before the event, Keegan thought they could do with sprucing up a bit. So he donated three of his own.

There was a VIP trip for four to the next international at Wembley, the opportunity to watch the England squad train behind closed doors and, best of all, he volunteered a day to coach anybody's team, anywhere in the country. This last lot was particularly popular (though rumours of Elton John buying it for his Watford side are greatly exaggerated) and helped push the total raised in the evening near £50,000.

In a week when the head of the Belgian police trade union expressed doubts about being able to control the England v Germany collision in Charleroi, a venue apparently tailor-made for trouble, it is good to learn there is at least one decent man left connected with the English game.

Hard as he tries, however, the feeling grows that Keegan's one-man campaign may not be enough to ameliorate the shame if, as expected by almost everyone, we retreat in ignominy once more from the continent next month, almost 60 years to the day after Dunkirk.

fields.headline: Driving to Catalonia via France
fields.standfirst:
We will be travelling to a destination in Catalonia by car (heading for the French/Spanish border at La Jonquera), via Dover to Calais, taking two days to arrive at our destination. Having never driven through France before, does anyone have any tips and also recommendations for two nights' reasonable accommodation en route?
Allison Davies
fields.trailText: We will be travelling to a destination in Catalonia by car (heading for the French/Spanish border at La Jonquera), via Dover to Calais, taking two days to arrive at our destination. Having never driven through France before, does anyone have any tips and also recommendations for two nights' reasonable accommodation en route?
fields.body:
 We made the same journey last year. Two days is ambitious - allow three if possible. Best driving tip - in smaller towns, overhead traffic lights are easily missed - so look out for them at junctions. Best value accommodation - look for (often very small) "Chambre d'hote" signs in rural areas. These are often akin to chateaux with fabulous accommodation and in gorgeous locations. No need to book - you're often the only people there.
Janet Conroy

 For a very cheap, clean, place to stay, I recommend Formule 1 - there's at least one of this chain of hotels on the outskirts of most towns and cities. You get bed and breakfast with shared toilet and shower; payment is automatic (if you've pre-booked) by credit card - and instructions are in English. With regard to driving, I advise always having in mind the next town you're heading towards as French road numbers aren't as well signposted as British ones and often just "change" for no apparent reason.
Ian Andrews

 If you have kids, I would get a fly-drive package to say Barcelona - skip the overnight stops, the long and, for the kids, boring journey and spend more time enjoying things. Mind you, driving in Spain is a bit hairy at times.
David Hall, Horley

 Whenever travelling through France we always use the Gites De France Bed & Breakfast Guide (English title French Country Welcome). We've stayed in a huge variety of places, usually rooms in a private house that have been converted to provide en suite accommodation. They are nearly all in small villages. Some of them will do an evening meal. Around £25pp a night for bed breakfast and evening meal would be on the expensive side.

If you can't find a current guide, the address to get one from is: Maison des Gites de France, 35 rue Godot-de- Mauroy, 75439, Parish Cedex 09. Tel: (1) 49 70 75 75.
David and Hilary Thomas, Stretford

fields.headline: Somewhere in Britain
fields.trailText:
Norse rage
The war-like traits of Britain's Viking invaders are explored in Skullsplitter, a permanent exhibition using real warrior skeletons which opens today.
fields.body:
Norse rage
The war-like traits of Britain's Viking invaders are explored in Skullsplitter, a permanent exhibition using real warrior skeletons which opens today.

Open daily 9am-6pm. £5.65/£4.25 child. Jorvik Viking Centre, Coppergate, York (01904 643211).

Lowry dowry
The Lowry, the North's new visual and performing arts centre, contains the world's biggest collection by "the matchstick-men painter".

Open Mon-Wed 11am-5pm; Thurs-Sun 11am-8pm (Fri 10pm). Free. Harbour City, Salford Quays (0161-876 2000).

Bath Fringe
Edinburgh, eat your heart out. England's largest Fringe Festival roams the Georgian streets of Bath until June 11. Theatre, music, dance and comedy, much of it free.

Box Office: 01225 463362.

Simply bootiful
Combine the beauty of Holkham Hall, an 18th-century Palladian-style mansion set in a 3,000-acre deer park, with a barefoot walk along the pine-backed sands of Holkham Beach, Norfolk's finest.

Opens May 28, Sun-Thurs 1pm-5pm. £4/£2. Wells-next-the-Sea, Norfolk (01328 710227).

Whisky galore
A new visitor centre at Dewar's Aberfeldy Distillery focuses on the history of the brand in a fun, interactive way.

Open daily 10am-5pm (Sun noon-4pm). £3.95/£2.50 child, family £10. Aberfeldy Distillery, Aberfeldy, Perthshire (01887 822010).

Wey to go
Family fun begins at Dapdune Wharf on the River Wey, with its picnic area, wildlife sanctuary and riverside trail, followed by a half-hour boat journey through Guildford to see newly-restored Millmead Lock in action.

Sat-Mon (plus June 1,3 and 4), 11am-5am. Wharf £2.50/£1 child, family £6. River bus £2 o/w. Wharf Road, Guildford, Surrey (01483-561389).

Wet and wild
London's new Wetland Centre is a mosaic of lakes, ponds and marshes over 105 acres on the site of four disused reservoirs in Barnes. Peter Scott Visitor Centre includes observatory discovery centre, art gallery, restaurant and shop.

Open daily 9.30am-6pm (Sun members only). £6.50/£4 child, family £17. Queen Elizabeth Walk, Barnes, London SW13 (020-8409 4400).

Animal farm
Lying side by side in a line on the grass as birds of prey swoop low over your head is all part of the display at Folly Farm. Adventure playgrounds, too, and as much petting and patting as possible.

Open daily 10am-5.30pm. £3.75/ £2.75 child. Birds of prey display twice daily except Sat. Kilgetty, Pembrokeshire (01834 812731).

fields.headline: Speed demon?
fields.standfirst: www.travelocity.co.uk
fields.trailText: www.travelocity.co.uk
fields.body:
What is it?
A straightforward travel portal run by Sabre, which manages flight databases for travel agents. Travelocity has been around for a long time in net terms, and has no truck with pop-up windows, bright colours or the excessive use of exclamation marks. Flights make up most of its business, but you can also hire a car and book a hotel, as long as it's near an airport.

What about holidays?
Go to bargainholidays.co.uk instead.

So should I bother looking for a flight here?
Yes. Just as you would ring round a few agencies to find the cheapest flight, searching on Travelocity.com,expedia.co.uk and ebookers.com will usually be worthwhile.

Any distinguishing features?
It allows you to search for flights in a relatively intelligent fashion. Other advantages include baggage guidelines for each airline, flight tracking and the facility to check whether tickets have been posted.

On the other hand...
It needs a redesign and special deals are aimed at US users.

This site is for...
Travellers who want a couple of weeks somewhere uncrowded, own three-season sleeping bags, loathe travel agents and are capable of finding a flight in their own time.

webTitle: Where to stay and what to do in Johannesburg

fields.headline: Where to stay and what to do in Johannesburg
fields.standfirst:
I am a 21-year-old woman and I will be travelling to Africa this summer for a seven-day safari to the Vic Falls. However, the first two days of my holiday will be spent in Johannesburg. I have heard a lot about the safety problem there and I would like to get some information from other people who have been there about where I should stay, what I should and should not do etc.
M Gerritsen
fields.trailText: I am a 21-year-old woman and I will be travelling to Africa this summer for a seven-day safari to the Vic Falls. However, the first two days of my holiday will be spent in Johannesburg. I have heard a lot about the safety problem there and I would like to get some information from other people who have been there about where I should stay, what I should and should not do etc.
fields.body:
 I live in and love Johannesburg. Unfortunately, it has little for the tourist - the locals might suggest one of the huge shopping malls like Sandton or Eastgate where things will seem cheap compared with English prices. Go on one of the "township tours" to Soweto and try to get one that includes an evening in a shebeen (bar - often run from a family home).

Johannesburg is a good place for partying with cheap, good food and booze. There are numerous options - look in the Star newspaper on Thursday or Saturday or in the weekly Mail & Guardian. 206 is a well known club with a relaxed atmosphere. The rave, trance and techno scene is fairly big. The Baseline and Kippies are two good jazz clubs. The Gold Reef Casino has a good showcase of African dance.

For accommodation, avoid hotels and go for a guest house (there are two good ones on 4th Ave) in the slightly bohemian suburb of Melville.

Don't look like a tourist - don't carry a camera around your neck or wear a moneybelt. It's easiest to get around with a called taxi.
Andrew B

 Do not be tempted to go "downtown" at all - it is unsafe, and charmless. Spend extra money for a decent hotel in Sandton. The Holiday Inn Garden Court was £50 a night for a double room. The hotel also organises excursions. Don't miss the Soweto/Mandela trip.
Laura McNeill

 The Portfolio Collection, e-mail places@aztec.co.za has B&Bs, country places, and retreats. My friend Sonia McKenna is part of the scheme with a collection of bungalows on a small hill not far from the airport (email:mckenna@iafrica.com). Tours are a good, safe way of seeing the sights. It is winter in July and August and cold at night. No rain though, so a fleece and jumper should do.
Eira Makepeace

fields.headline: Silva compass
fields.trailText: Big base plate, bezel you can turn with gloves on, luminous needle. Good damping, so the needle settles fast.
fields.body:
Must I have one?
Yes: if you leave it behind, you'll hit a whiteout on the Cairngorms.

How do I use it?
Read the instructions and practise carefully in the park. Or go on a navigation course somewhere like the Plas y Brenin National Mountain Centre in Wales.

Common mistakes?
Using it back to front, then walking the wrong way: with luck you'll see the cliff before you're airborne.

Important features?
Big base plate, bezel you can turn with gloves on, luminous needle. Good damping, so the needle settles fast.

Why Silva?
That's the Swedish company that invented it in 1932. Some call them protractor or flatbed compasses, because Suunto makes them, too.

Suunto? Swedish again?
Finnish. Navigation's very important to the Scandinavians.

Ah, the trackless tundra?
More like Major Ernst Killander, who took Stockholm's deprived youth into the forests in the 1920s.

Do I want to hear this?
The healthy new game was finding your way from A to B, aka orienteering. And it's hard to use a compass, map and protractor when you're running.

So Silva built the compass on to the protractor?
That's it. For pinpoint stuff, you still need a traditional prismatic compass and separate protractor, but the Silva is used by most walkers and explorers these days.

An arm and a leg?
Between £11 and £60: the widely-used Silva Type 4 is £29. Prismatic pocket compasses cost £40 to £60.

Do say:
Allowing for magnetic variation, a bearing of 230 degrees will take us straight to the Dog and Duck.

Don't say:
Please, sir, why does this red needle keep moving about?

My friend Sonia McKenna is part of the scheme with a collection of bungalows on a small hill not far from the airport (email:mckenna @iafrica.com). Tours are a good, safe way of seeing the sights. fields.headline: Bargain basements
fields.standfirst: Ros Taylor seeks out the cheapest and latest holiday deals that the net has to offer
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor seeks out the cheapest holiday deals that the net has to offer
fields.body:
We all know that dirt-cheap holidays are usually a false economy. You can expect the flight to be purgatorial, the accommodation unfinished and the beach a horrific swell of towels, jellyfish and sweating bodies. But sometimes a last-minute bargain is the only choice available, and this week - regardless of place, climate, facilities or any other consideration - I set out to find the very cheapest discounted packages on the web.

Flight-only deals and short breaks didn't count, and the departures had to be within a fortnight. The results appear in order of rank, with the cheapest first.

1 Expedia

· 14 nights' self-catering in Costa Almeria, Spain for £49 (from Manchester).
· 7 nights' self-catering in Rhodes, Greece for £89 (Belfast).

At £25 a week, Costa Almeria is never going to fulfill all your hopes, but somehow that hardly matters. Although Teletext came up with this deal, too, Expedia highlighted it on the front page of its site, while on Teletext it was buried among semi-legible screenshots.

2 Teletext holidays

· 14 nights' self-catering in Costa Almeria for £49 (Manchester).

Teletext, one feels, has not quite got to grips with the internet and the effort involved in searching for a holiday here is only justified if you have no access to a television.

3 Bargainholidays

· 7 nights in a one/two-star hotel in Heraklion, Crete for £79 (Gatwick).

· 14 nights' self-catering in Corfu for £99 (Newcastle).

The sheer number of packages in the Bargainholidays database is impressive, especially if you can leave within two days. The notes at the bottom of each page explain that occasionally airport taxes and other charges are not included in the headline price.

4 UTravel

· 7 nights' self-catering camping in the Loire for £75 with Eurocamp (Dover).

A gaudy newcomer to the web, UTravel's "empowering" slogans are an irritation, and the site needs time to settle down. Nonetheless, the definition of "package" is wider than on most of its competitors and more likely to appeal to the discerning, independently-minded Guardian reader.

5 Holidaydeals

· 7 nights in a two-star hotel (half-board) in Heraklion for £79 (Gatwick).

In most respects indistinguishable from Bargainholidays.com, Holidaydeals is an efficient online bucket-shop: fast, unimaginative and impersonal.

6 Lastminute.com

· 7 nights in Ibiza for £99 (Gatwick)

A persistent error on Lastminute's server meant that I could see this offer, but requests for further information and other searches proved fruitless.

Site of the week: Lastminute.com

Haven't we heard enough about lastminute.com?
Well, you've doubtless heard about the sought-after Martha Lane Fox. And you've probably gloated over the sharp fall in the company's stockmarket valuation, unless you bought some of the shares.

Is it only for last-minute deals?
No, although they tend to be better value. Lastminute is by no means the cheapest place to go for bucket-shop deals. The site can also be infuriatingly slow. And, like a number of regular visitors, I once used lastminute.com to find a hotel, rang directory enquiries for the number, and negotiated a better deal myself over the phone.

What could I have done this weekend?
Tried to solve a murder on the Orient Express (£420 for two); taken a gourmet break in Cornwall (£175); flown Concorde on a tour of Paris and the Riviera (£599); visited Athens (£259); or bought a flight to Dublin (£83).

Package holidays with an edge?
Yes. Lastminute doesn't use charter airlines. It makes liberal use of pastels and pink, and only rarely do sentences escape a daubing of exclamation marks. It certainly wins no prizes for web design, but holidays are easy to search for and find.

fields.headline: Travelogue
fields.trailText:
Independent vote
By next year, more people will be travelling independently than taking package holidays, according to Mintel research for Michelin Travel Publications. But independent travel is far from dominated by the young because the backpacker of the 80s and 90s has now left higher education with large debts and a desire to get into the working world as soon as possible.
fields.body:
Independent vote
By next year, more people will be travelling independently than taking package holidays, according to Mintel research for Michelin Travel Publications. But independent travel is far from dominated by the young because the backpacker of the 80s and 90s has now left higher education with large debts and a desire to get into the working world as soon as possible.

The research identifies two emerging groups of travellers - young executive thrill seekers and golden-age travellers. Mintel forecasts that demand for long-haul "exotic" holidays will be spearheaded by these two groups.

Passage of poetry
P&O Portsmouth have been awarded a plaque from the Poetry Society, which they have put on the Pride of Bilbao, in recognition of their support of poet Jenni Meredith who travelled on their ships to France and Spain last year bringing "poetry to the masses".

Free upgrade
British Airways Holidays (0870 24 24 243) is offering customers a free upgrade to Club Europe, one way for departures between July and September to selected cities in Europe. Benefits of Club Europe include the use of the BA lounges and fast-track airport facilities, priority check-in and upgrade meals. Cities include Athens, Florence, Barcelona, Amsterdam, Madrid, Milan, Rome, Verona and Venice.

Simple cuisine
Nearly 70% of people surveyed by Simply Travel (020-8541 1222) said that a major factor in their holiday choice was the cuisine of their destination. The company has produced a small recipe book as a result, which is available free.

Fairway to heaven
The travel agency that has chartered the QE2 to act as a floating hotel during the Open at St Andrews from July 18-25 has come up with a package for the golf fan with money to spare - seven nights all in for £5,899pp, based on double occupancy in the best cabins. Details from Scotia Travel 0141-305 5050.

Hard succour
Two-thirds of 500 travellers crossing the Channel told Halfords that boiled sweets were still the key to surviving long summer car journeys. Nine out of 10 motorists knew they should carry a warning triangle but only just over half had one.

webTitle: I lost my heart in... West Cork

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... West Cork
fields.standfirst: Pete McCarthy
fields.trailText: Pete McCarthy
fields.body:
Why:
I went there last year to live by my guiding principal never to pass a bar that has your name in it. In south-west Ireland, there are many McCarthy's bars but I made a detour to find this one. I walked into MacCarthy's Bar and Grocery in Castletownbere on Grand National Day and had the instant feeling that this was one of the greatest bars in the world. You are confronted by a fridge full of milk and orange juice and shelves with tins of custard powder and tuna and, among it all, you see a Guinness pump. As you go in you see a tiny snug, where farmers would come in from the country to arrange marriages. The whole pub has remained unaltered since the last century.

What's the best thing:
The day I turned up also happened to be the owner's birthday and she invited me to the party. I came back at 8pm and had to plead to be allowed out at 5am the next morning. I was taken on as one of the family. That level of hospitality is virtually unknown now in this country. Then there is the Beara peninsula, which is a truly magical place. Being on the edge of the Atlantic, there is something elemental about Beara and you can see 5,000 years of human habitation in the landscape.

What triggers the memory:
I live on the Sussex Downs and here the landscape is also dotted with early human habitation. I love that feeling of being part of a continuous line of humanity.

My advice:
You should leave the Anglo-Saxon part of you behind, with all your ideas of an organised trip and a definite timetable, and just leave yourself open to happy accidents.

How do I get there?
Fly to Cork and within half an hour , you can be sitting by the water, or you can be in Beara in two and half hours.

McCarthy's Bar by Pete McCarthy is published by Hodder & Stoughton at £12.99.

fields.headline: Wight knuckle rides
fields.standfirst: You don't have to go to exotic locations to indulge your extreme sports fantasies.  Andrew Gilchrist enjoys an action-packed weekend closer to home
fields.trailText: You don't have to go to exotic locations to indulge your extreme sports fantasies. Andrew Gilchrist enjoys an action-packed weekend closer to home
fields.body:
'You're not a hen," says Mike, a wiry no-nonsense Yorkshireman who has been given the task of getting me airborne."So, this time, I want you to try to do it without flapping your arms."

We're standing on a hillside at Compton Bay, a tranquil spot on the western edge of the Isle of Wight. The sun's beating down, there's a light breeze coming in from the sea - perfect for learning to paraglide - and we've all just been taught the "parachute landing fall" in the unlikely event of anything going wrong; make the mistake of landing with the wind behind you, we're told, and you can hit the ground at 40mph.

Mike stands in front of me as I pull on the straps attached to the 27 square metres of canopy rustling about on the slope behind me. The leading edge lifts up, catches the wind and suddenly the entire canopy swells into life. The next thing I know he's pulling me down the hill yelling: "Run! Run! Run!" With all the grace of a duck-billed platypus, I perform a sort of slow motion dash down the hill and then the impossible happens: I take off. I fly.

Okay, I might only have stayed up for a couple of minutes, but two hours earlier I was floundering about this hillside thinking the cows in the neighbouring field had more chance of getting airborne. There were eight in our group, every one a beginner and none of us particularly fit, but soon we were taking off shakily from the top of the slope and landing at the bottom stunned and exhilarated by what we had achieved. All it seemed to need was a little nerve - and a fair bit of sweat.

Paragliding

Paragliding, a cross between parachuting and hang-gliding, began in the Alps in the mid-80s. "It was invented by French hillclimbers who wanted a quick way of getting down the mountains in time for the all-important dinner ," says Phil Keen, of High Adventure, the Isle of Wight's paragliding and hang-gliding centre.

With no less than 12 flying sites catering for all wind directions, the Isle of Wight is used as a training ground by many of the UK's top paragliders. British champion Barney Barnes and world record holder Sarah Fenwick both live here.

We took a breather over lunch then it was time for the big one - a flight over the brilliant white cliffs that stretch from Compton Bay down to the Needles, the famous narrow chalk rocks stretching out into the sea. This is advanced stuff, so we flew with an instructor in a tandem paraglider sporting an enormous canopy - it felt like Sydney Opera House had unfurled above our heads.

With the right conditions, paragliders can rise at 10m a second, which is almost like being catapulted into the clouds. We couldn't quite manage that but we did get up to about 600ft, high enough to look right over to the other side of the island, at the countless yachts nodding lazily through the Solent.

As I sat back in the harness watching the shadows of clouds drifting across the island, a seagull appeared to our left, rising with us in the updraught. Below us was the beach where a dinosaur footprint was discovered. A little further up the coast, ramblers walking along the coastline stopped to wave up at us and cars slowed down for a better look at these two human beings hanging in the air. When we touched down bumpily about 30 minutes later, I'd already decided to come back and have a go at the two-day introductory course (£125, or £150 at weekends).

Extreme sports

The Isle of Wight is often seen as a sleepy mecca for senior citizens ("Loos to stay open after OAP power wins the day," was a front page story in the Isle of Wight County Press while we were there), but now it's seeking to reinvent itself as an extreme sports paradise. It already has the full-on sailing and partying mayhem of Cowes Week (which actually lasts a fortnight) at the beginning of August. But now companies such as First Contact are gathering together the other adrenaline-pumping attractions of the island - paragliding, mountain biking, jetskiing, canoeing, shooting, paintballing, sailing, horseriding, ribbing - and putting them into tailor-made packages for thrill-seekers who have neither the time nor the money to travel abroad for their fun.

Ribbing

One of the biggest new Isle of Wight crazes is ribbing. Ribs are Rigid Inflatable Boats with seriously powerful engines at the back and seriously deranged skippers at the front. It's fairly simple. You step in, sit down and cling on for dear life. The engine whines like it's about to explode and you go thundering across the waves, pounding into the breakers like a big rubber mallet. You don't stop screaming till you're back on dry land.

Shooting

After that, when they said they'd booked us in for clay-pigeon shooting, I wouldn't have been surprised if they'd given us machine-guns and told us the pigeons would be shooting back.

David and Gerry, a charming pair of country gents in cravats and wellies, met us at the top of a gully with the words: "Right, into the jungle then!" Two 12-bore, double-barrelled shotguns were produced and we did four different kinds of shoot - grouse, pheasant, duck and partridge - the size, speed and flight pattern of the clay disks varying to imitate each type of bird (partridge is the smallest and the fastest).

The trick is to follow the target through the sights then, just when it's in range, aim a little ahead - or, according to the Shooting Times, imagine the bird is wearing a top hat and aim for that.

Getting there

The train from London to Portsmouth took about 90 minutes, and the Wightlink ferry crossing another 35 - but by the time you're on the Isle of Wight, the mainland bustle and rush seems much further away. We stayed in the sedate village of Ventnor on the south coast, where the microclimate of moist air and plenty of sunshine has resulted in a semi-tropical landscape.

The four-star Royal Hotel, perched at the top of the bay, proved the perfect place to unwind after a hard day's high-octane fun. But even in this peaceful place, the new extreme-sports face of the Isle of Wight seems to be emerging: I took a stroll down to Ventnor beach and saw a couple of surfers riding the waves. And, on the way back up, I passed a granny wearing a pair of Nike Air Max trainers.

webTitle: A Naturalist's Guide to the Tropics

fields.headline: Book of the week
fields.standfirst:
A Naturalist's Guide to the Tropics, by Marco Lambertini
(University of Chicago Press, £17.50)
fields.trailText:
A Naturalist's Guide to the Tropics, by Marco Lambertini
(University of Chicago Press, £17.50)
fields.body:
If I read in the small print that the pages of this book had been impregnated with chemicals to protect them from fungal and insect invasion, then I wouldn't be at all surprised.

Colourful as coral, yet dense as what we used to call jungle, this compact volume is designed for the rucksack rather than the coffee table. Which makes it doubly appealing to the armchair traveller.

Why? Because like all field guides, this book exudes authority.

When it tells me that the combined weight of the termites and ants in Malaysia is greater than that of all the hoofed animals added together, I am inclined to believe it. And when it explains how mangrove swamps work, what makes an atoll and why the savanna is burning, I am all ears.

It matters little that I have no practical use for this information at present. Simply reading about it fills me with wonder, and encourages me in the belief that, one day, I might find myself in the back of a 4x4, swatting mosquitoes and excavating larvae from my legs.

Are there snakes in this grass? Should we feed these elephants? What will happen if we take a swim and meet an electric ray? "Hang on," I shall say. "I brought this little book along. Now, run those questions past me again."

fields.body:
Six top destinations
