This sprig of a tale grew into a mighty tree over the centuries, with subsequent chroniclers claiming that Joseph was Jesus' uncle, that he buried the Holy Grail at Glastonbury, that he brought his nephew over on a business trip one time (whence William Blake's Jerusalem, with its reference to Christ on England's mountains green). True or not, Glastonbury did become the site of one of England's largest and richest abbeys, which flourished until Henry VIII's commissioners seized and plundered it. As if the Holy Grail was not a big enough draw for New Agers and imaginative pilgrims, a site within the grounds purports to be the grave of King Arthur and Queen Guinevere. But whether you take it as the genuine Arthurian tomb or a monument to one of the earliest (1191) English marketing ploys, the antiquity impresses. It's an easy walk to the top of the pudding-bowl-shaped Tor. On sunny summer days, from dawn to dusk, the lush daisy-speckled grass of the slopes are scattered with girls in halter tops and boys with no tops lounging, tanning, snogging and discussing the meaning of life. From the summit, you can see red-roofed Glastonbury slung neatly in the saddle between the Tor and Wearyall Hill, and the patterns of lines on the levels around. There are so many lines - hedgerows, ditches, dykes, roads - you could make almost any pattern you chose: ley lines, or the signs of the Zodiac which, an inventive sculptor in the 1920s claimed were to be found etched in the lie of the land in a circle round the town. Roy, a local spiritual healer and dowser acting as our guide, was determined to convince me of the special energies that thrummed beneath the earth of Glastonbury. Roy was no hippy. Dressed in blazer and grey flannels, he slipped out his pendulum to demonstrate some energy-field action. After some swinging and shuffling across the grass, Roy settled on a couple of spots. "Stand there, and hold your arms out straight," he said. "Now I want you to resist me as hard as you can." He laid his hand on my arm and pushed it down, fairly gently. I resisted; my arm remained straight. "Now stand over there and hold your arms out again." This time, he pushed down with unexpected ferocity, forcing my arm down to my side. "Do you see?" he said. "Here, you're weaker. The energy is different." "But you pushed down harder the second time." "No I didn't!" My word against his. The choice is there. You can go on a spiritual pilgrimage to Glastonbury, find meaning in the lines and the hills and the energy fields, and dream ghostly dreams. But you don't have to do that to appreciate the beauty of the place, or to browse as an outsider through the full cultural outpouring of the New Age.

webTitle: Days out for kids in London

fields.headline: Family favourites
fields.standfirst: Stuck in town with the kids for half-term or bringing the brood in tow?  Louise Nicholson, author of a new children's guide to London, recommends 12 tried and tested capital days out
fields.trailText: Stuck in town with the kids for half-term or bringing the brood in tow? Louise Nicholson, author of a new children's guide to London, recommends 12 tried and tested capital days out
fields.body:
London has never been so much fun for kids. This year, more than 30 million people will flood in from abroad and around Britain to enjoy the capital, often travelling as families. Nothing deters them - the unreliable weather, derided public transport nor the super-high prices. So, how come so many parents living in or near London equate family time off with avoiding the city?

Once you give a child the power of choice, you might be surprised at how much fun they - and their parents - can have in London. And not necessarily at a high cost. My sons, London born and raised, consider public transport an essential part of a day out. It suits me, too. A family travelcard is good value, and it is hard to beat riding upstairs in double-decker buses (front row, of course), zipping over east London on the Docklands Light Railway or painlessly slicing through the jammed-up city by Underground.

Parents might presume that kids want to see the new and the gimmicky. Indeed, in London's recent revival, children have not been forgotten. The big museums create new rooms with ever more hands-on gadgets. The newly-expanded National Maritime Museum has two excellent interactive galleries for children; the Natural History Museum lets the child become the scientist. Among the new landmarks, the BA London Eye looms above the skyline with expensive temptation - a justifiable one, for once.

But when the choice is theirs, children often demand the old favourites - watching the Changing of the Guard, clambering up and down HMS Belfast's ladders, peering down on London from the top of St Paul's Cathedral, rowing in Regent's Park and experiencing the Blitz at the Imperial War Museum.

When an American family stayed with us last summer, the top vote after three hectic London days went to the simple bus trip to see Big Ben and hear it strike the hour.

The secret of success for a family London outing seems to be to let the children take the lead. Simply provide them with all the information and options. If the pyramids were last week's history lesson, you might find yourself at the British Museum; if it was King John and the Magna Carta, you could soon be gazing at one of several versions in the British Library (where kids can also create their own book).

Here are a dozen top London outings:

1 London Aquarium Queen's Walk SE1

A subterranean aquatic wonderland of floor-to-ceiling tanks. Its centrepiece is the three-storey-high Atlantic Tank, where divers give the appearance of risking their lives each day at noon to feed the fierce-looking dogfish sharks, conger eels and seabass. We especially like stroking the rays in the Discovery Zone and watching the newly-arrived octopuses untangle their legs. Activity, quiz and trail sheets from the ticket desk.

Tel: 020-7967 8000. Nearest tube: Westminster/ Waterloo. Open: 10am- 6pm. Adults: £8.50, kids 3-14: £5.

2 Imperial War Museum Lambeth Road SE1

A surprising favourite to some. Less about fighting, more about survival during war. We like going through the first world war trench experience, complete with smells, and the second world war blitz experience in a recreated London street. Half-term specials include re-enactments of Operation Dynamo Rescue from Dunkirk, and a chance to crack the codes in the display Enigma: The Code Breakers. Activity sheets from reception; permanent poetry hunt through the museum.

Tel: 020-7416 5000. Nearest tube: Lambeth North. Open: 10am-6pm. Adults: £5.50, kids under 16: free.

3 HMS Belfast Morgan's Lane SE1

It is amazing how much fun a stationary ship can be. This huge warship built for the British Navy and now moored opposite the Tower of London, was almost destroyed by a German mine in 1939. Small children love scrambling up and down the ladders, exploring its warren of rooms, inspecting the guns and engines, and defending their captain on the bridge. Quiz sheets from ticket kiosk.

Tel: 020-7940 6328. Nearest tube: London Bridge/Tower Hill. Open: 10am-6pm. Adults £5; kids under 16: free.

4 National Maritime Museum Greenwich

Perhaps go down by boat and come back by Docklands Light Railway. Up at the Observatory, part of the museum, you can stand over the Meridian Line and attend an excellent live planetarium show (Madame Tussaud's one is automated). Among the 16 new galleries of the main museum, try sending Morse code signals in the All Hands Gallery or steering a Viking ship in The Bridge Gallery. The Story of Time told in the Queen's House includes a family trail. Lots of activities.

Tel: 020-8858 4422. Nearest station: Cutty Sark DLR; Greenwich, Connex. Open: 10am-5pm. Adults: National Maritime Museum £7.50, Royal Observatory £6, Story of Time £7.50; kids under 16: free.

5 Regent's Park

If the sun shines, take a picnic, bat and ball and get settled in somewhere on the north side of the lake. For on-site entertainment, there are the ducks nearby (with useful identification board); boating on the lake, life jackets supplied; the Open-Air Theatre (from June 7, the children's play is Alice: An Adventure in Wonderland, tel: 020-7486 2431); and the Zoo.

Tel: 020-7486 7905. Nearest tube: Baker Street/Regent's Park. Open: 5am-dusk. Free.

6 National Portrait Gallery St Martin's Place, WC2

What we like best is finding pictures of people we know something about. A good way to start is to take Britain's longest overland escalator (23m) to the Tudor Gallery in the new wing; stairs from here lead up to a rooftop restaurant and bar. Lower down in the same wing, you can put a face to more recent names in the 20th Century Gallery, or visit the IT Gallery to call up your favourite Brits and then print off a map that plots where to find their portraits.

Tel: 020-7306 0055. Nearest tube: Trafalgar Square. Open: Mon-Sat 10am-6pm, Sun noon-6pm. Free.

7 Natural History Museum Cromwell Road SW7

You need to be selective in this huge museum, or the visit falls flat. In the Life Galleries, we like the Dinosaur room best; in the Earth Galleries, it is the model volcano and earthquake simulation. Investigate, a new project in the Clore Education Centre (sometimes only open to school parties), lets children study real specimens ranging from meteorites to animal skins.

Tel: 020-7942 5000. Open: Mon-Sat 10am-5.30pm. Sun 11am-5.30pm. Nearest tube: South Kensington. Adults: £7.50, kids under 18: free.

8 London Zoo Outer Circle NW1

Not cheap, but it occupies the day and you can have a picnic on the lawns (perhaps watching the impressive predatory birds display). The Web of Life gallery has 65 different kinds of animals doing intriguing things: watching the leaf-cutter ants march mindlessly along their rope is slightly spooky. Check out the events: penguins are often fed at 2.30pm, elephants weighed at 3pm and bathed at 3.30pm, and keepers give talks in the amphitheatre. The roars of hungry lions are wonderfully frightening.

Tel: 020-7722 3333. Nearest tube: Camden Town. Open: 10am-5.30pm. Adults £9, kids 3-14: £7.

9 Tate Modern and Millennium Bridge Bankside SE1

Already very popular. But everyone will enjoy the building and its riverside café and shops. And if the art is unfamiliar - or unfathomable - for parents, try the new family trails called Explorers (starts June 1), each focusing on one suite of rooms; they include Time Capsule to inspire you to make your own piece of history.

Tel:020-7887 8000. Nearest tube: Southwark/London Bridge. Open: Sun-Thurs 10am-6pm; Fri-Sat 10am-10pm. Free.

10 Museum of London London Wall EC2

With all the rebuilding in London, this collection gets better all the time. We pour over the models of Roman London and always wish we could go to more events than we do. Weekend family ones include handling objects washed up beside the Thames, while workshops might involve making coins or shoes, or working with the archaeologists.

Tel: 020-7600 3699. Nearest tube: Barbican/St Paul's. Open: Mon-Sat 10am-5.50pm, Sun noon-5.50pm. Adults £5, kids under 16 free.

11 The BBC Experience Portland Place, W1

A mixture of information, performance and participation makes this a great outing, best booked in advance. It lasts about two hours. Your guide gives a speedy history of the Beeb, then it is your turn to perform. Everyone gets a part and, within a few minutes, you have recorded a radio programme and had a laugh listening to the result. Among the interactive games that follow, try reading a weather forecast on TV (kids usually perform better than adults) or commentating on a football game.

Tel: 0870 6030304. Nearest tube: Regent's Park. Open: Mon 11am-4.30pm, Tues-Sun noon-4.30pm. Adults £7.50, kids: £4.95.

12 The BA London Eye Jubilee Gardens SE1

If you can master the automatic booking system and its endless instructions, plus collect the tickets from County Hall as there is no postal service, this is a truly memorable ride. (Very patient people could queue up on the day.) It lasts 30 minutes during which you are gradually lifted up above London and have time to enjoy the spectacular views - bad weather only makes it more dramatic, even if you cannot see so far.

Tel: 0870 5000600. Nearest tube: Waterloo/Westminster. Open: 10am-9.30pm. Adults: £7.45, kids: £4.95.

 Louise Nicholson's Look Out London, A Children's Guide, with illustrations by Paul Cox, is published this month by Red Fox at £4.99.

fields.headline: Shrinking prophets
fields.standfirst: Hollywood never could resist a self-help guru with a learn-to-love-yourself therapy. But lately its stars are wising up - and more's the pity, says Chris Tayler
fields.trailText: Hollywood never could resist a self-help guru with a learn-to-love-yourself therapy. But lately its stars are wising up - and more's the pity, says Chris Tayler
fields.body:
Last year, the Washington Post investigated the shooting of John Travolta's new sci-fi flick, Battlefield Earth, and revealed that the secrecy surrounding it was the handiwork of a cult: "a paranoid, insular group that refuses to answer further questions from the press because it hopes to wring as much money from the public as possible... a hierarchy that hopes to dominate the world with its propaganda and turn us all into robotic supplicants."

That's the public relations industry for you. However, the Post moved into more controversial territory when it went on to speculate that the film might have something to do with Scientology as well - Battlefield Earth is based on a novel by its founder, L Ron Hubbard, while Travolta is Scientology's most enthusiastic talk-show apologist. Travolta has been quick to deny any connection between the film and his beliefs. And he's got a point: while Scientology critics have had hours of fun untangling a few scraps of ham-fisted allegory left over from the novel, the uninitiated are likely to be underwhelmed by the film's cult content. In fact, the whole controversy has done little more than highlight a profoundly depressing fact: these days, when Hollywood people decide to make fools of themselves, the neighbourhood guru is no longer the first port of call.

This is a great shame, because the movie business has a long and glorious history of trying to combine the search for enlightenment and the quest for boffo box-office. It goes back at least as far as 1924, when Samuel Goldwyn set sail for Europe with the intention of offering Sigmund Freud $100,000 to help him create "a really great love story". (Alas, Freud passed on the offer.) But the greatest age of all, in terms of Hollywood consciousness-raising, was the 70s - the Me Decade, when the growth of a lucrative mass market for psychobabble meant that skip-loads of gurus came out of the woodwork to cope with the thousands of paisley-clad peons looking to straighten their heads.

In their book Hollywood On The Couch, Stephen Farber and Marc Green share the results of their extensive research on the alternative therapies doing the rounds of Beverly Hills in the heady days of Jonathan Livingston Seagull. These included bioenergetics, psychosynthesis, the Feldenkreis method, Silva mind control, primal screaming, biofeedback and Rolfing - which, far from being the exotic perversion it sounds, is a painful type of muscle massage. Naturally, not every novel form of self-help has been an ongoing success among movie types; you don't hear much about celebrity Rolfing any more (although Farber and Green report that Sean Young "once confided to an interviewer that she had been ïseriously Rolfed'"). However, some of the more digestible elements of the consciousness revolution have passed into the mainstream.

Take, for example, all those movies that aim to speak to "the child in all of us". The Inner Child - with whom Steven Spielberg and George Lucas seem to enjoy an almost indecent rapport - is a concept lifted straight from the pages of Dr Eric "I'm OK - You're OK" Berne. (As the author of such kipper-tie classics as Games People Play, Berne was also responsible for introducing the world to the idea of the Life Script.)

Then there's the aggressive self-love of movie folk. One key text for this is the 1973 bestseller How To Be Your Own Best Friend by Mildred Newman and Bernard Berkowitz, a folksy pair of pop psychologists who once ministered to a small platoon of celebrity narcissists including George Segal, Neil Simon, Joel Schumacher and Anthony Perkins. But the acknowledged leader in this field was Werner Erhard - the founder of Erhard Seminars Training, better known as est.

This was an enormously influential blend of dianetics, Zen and motivational psychology, which Erhard (a former used-car salesman) cobbled together in 1971. The training involved an intense weekend of sitting in a huge seminar room and being ranted at by Erhard or one of his assistants. The theme of the introductory lecture was "you're all assholes", and, since bathroom breaks were prohibited, powerful bladder control was essential. (According to Bert Convy, who played an Erhard-like character in the 1978 Burt Reynolds comedy Semi-Tough, people who wet themselves were told to "experience the warmth".)

Erhard's teachings emphasised personal responsibility for everything in your life. Victimhood was anathema to est. Rounded up in the Holocaust? You put yourself in that camp, pal - deal with it. John Denver, Yoko Ono and Diana Ross were among the celebrities who took this bracing message to heart, but est's biggest success was in the executive suite. Ted Ashley, then head of Warner Brothers, was so enthusiastic about Erhard that his studio became known as Werner Brothers. Peter Guber, the sometime head of Sony Pictures, was another convert, as was the music and movie mogul David Geffen. (Geffen also exploited the est connection to smooth out his business dealings with Ashley).

The screenwriting guru Syd Field went so far as to dedicate his enormously influential book Screenplay "to Werner and all the people in est" (which may or may not explain why so many Hollywood movies are obsessed with manic individualism, self-confrontation and off-the-peg introspection). Joel Schumacher told Farber and Green he had such a revelation after some est weekends ("It hit me like the sword from Star Wars") that he found the inner strength to make the transition from lowly costume designer to highly paid hack director - which means we have Werner to thank for such cinematic marvels as Batman Forever.

Unfortunately, est went belly up long ago. It was always controversial - one graduate took the you-can-do-anything message too literally and was institutionalised after taking some deep breaths at the bottom of his swimming pool - and Erhard finally disappeared in the early 90s amid lawsuits alleging various cult-leader-style excesses.

Since then, nothing has caught the imagination of the A-list in quite the same way. Perhaps it's because the cults are all so mainstream these days; after all, where's the fun in having strange beliefs when even the head of the Federal Reserve can get away with a lifelong enthusiasm for the mad-as-a-lorry Ayn Rand and her philosophy of objectivism?

Whatever the causes, it's a sad situation. Not having a royal family, Americans need rely on their film stars to provide the celebrity pratfalls. With the honourable exception of high-profile Scientologists like John Travolta, Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman, there's a desperate shortage of bankable actors now willing to brandish their metaphysical dunce's caps with the glassy-eyed abandon we've come to expect.

 Battlefield Earth is out on Friday

But the acknowledged leader in this field was Werner Erhard - the founder of Erhard Seminars Training, better known as est. This was an enormously influential blend of dianetics, Zen and motivational psychology, which Erhard (a former used-car salesman) cobbled together in 1971. The training involved an intense weekend of sitting in a huge seminar room and being ranted at by Erhard or one of his assistants. The theme of the introductory lecture was "you're all assholes", and, since bathroom breaks were prohibited, powerful bladder control was essential. (According to Bert Convy, who played an Erhard-like character in the 1978 Burt Reynolds comedy Semi-Tough, people who wet themselves were told to "experience the warmth".) Erhard's teachings emphasised personal responsibility for everything in your life. Victimhood was anathema to est. Rounded up in the Holocaust? You put yourself in that camp, pal - deal with it. John Denver, Yoko Ono and Diana Ross were among the celebrities who took this bracing message to heart, but est's biggest success was in the executive suite. Ted Ashley, then head of Warner Brothers, was so enthusiastic about Erhard that his studio became known as Werner Brothers. Peter Guber, the sometime head of Sony Pictures, was another convert, as was the music and movie mogul David Geffen. (Geffen also exploited the est connection to smooth out his business dealings with Ashley). The screenwriting guru Syd Field went so far as to dedicate his enormously influential book Screenplay "to Werner and all the people in est" (which may or may not explain why so many Hollywood movies are obsessed with manic individualism, self-confrontation and off-the-peg introspection). Joel Schumacher told Farber and Green he had such a revelation after some est weekends ("It hit me like the sword from Star Wars") that he found the inner strength to make the transition from lowly costume designer to highly paid hack director - which means we have Werner to thank for such cinematic marvels as Batman Forever. Unfortunately, est went belly up long ago. It was always controversial - one graduate took the you-can-do-anything message too literally and was institutionalised after taking some deep breaths at the bottom of his swimming pool - and Erhard finally disappeared in the early 90s amid lawsuits alleging various cult-leader-style excesses. Since then, nothing has caught the imagination of the A-list in quite the same way. Perhaps it's because the cults are all so mainstream these days; after all, where's the fun in having strange beliefs when even the head of the Federal Reserve can get away with a lifelong enthusiasm for the mad-as-a-lorry Ayn Rand and her philosophy of objectivism? Whatever the causes, it's a sad situation. Not having a royal family, Americans need rely on their film stars to provide the celebrity pratfalls. With the honourable exception of high-profile Scientologists like John Travolta, Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman, there's a desperate shortage of bankable actors now willing to brandish their metaphysical dunce's caps with the glassy-eyed abandon we've come to expect.  Battlefield Earth is out on Friday

webTitle: Oi! Mate! Wanna buy a spin-off?

fields.headline: Oi! Mate! Wanna buy a spin-off?
fields.standfirst: Guy Ritchie has  turned his hit film Lock, Stock And Two Smoking Barrels into a TV series. Big mistake, says Richard Vine. It's rare to repeat the trick on the small screen
fields.trailText: Guy Ritchie has turned his hit film Lock, Stock And Two Smoking Barrels into a TV series. Big mistake, says Richard Vine. It's rare to repeat the trick on the small screen
fields.body:
When a classic TV show gets made into a film it's an upgrade to first class, a super-sized meal, as formerly inch-high private eyes become towering cinematic gods. However, the trick does not always work in reverse. As their stars are replaced with dimmer stellar bodies, smaller than real life, films that become TV shows are the crash diets of the entertainment world. "That was good, now let's make a cheaper version with a lookalike cast where we stretch the original concept for months until it snaps and people end up hating the movie" is not the sort of pitch that you'd imagine goes down particularly well. And yet, it happens all the time - the latest example being Lock, Stock And Two Smoking Barrels.

There's a simple, four-letter reason trotted out every time someone thinks of ploughing another movie into the ground: M*A*S*H. The TV spin-off of Robert Altman's film about American medics Donald Sutherland and Elliott Gould became one of the most-loved sitcoms of all time, winning more battles in the ratings war than US troops did in Korea. And staying in combat a lot longer.

And, to be fair, M*A*S*H is not an isolated case. A mere 14 years later, Buffy The Vampire Slayer arrived. Sarah Michelle Gellar has been so successful as The Chosen One that few have noticed the meteoric cruise of The Other Chosen One, Kristy Swanson, who went on to score bit parts in 8 Heads In A Duffel Bag, Lover Girl and Meeting Daddy. Buffy The Ratings Slayer regularly survives the almighty season sweeps in America at a time when shows are being axed with less warning than Sunnydale's undead.

How did these two succeed where countless other attempts have failed (Honey I Shrunk The Kids: The TV Show, anyone?) The difference lies in the way they treat their origins. The writers of Buffy and M*A*S*H struck a crucial balance between honouring the original premise and moving on from it. It's not enough simply to condense the movie's plot with a different spin on it every week and hope for the best (The Odd Couple). Nor is it enough to drag out the suspense for the entire series (Logan's Run).

Buffy quickly superseded the film's one-joke note ("Valley girl kills monsters") with soap aspects: a doomed romance and a cast of sidekicks all dealing with homework, parents and teachers, as well as vampires. M*A*S*H understood the dynamics of American sitcoms, trading Altman's caustic sensibility for a more loveable cast, with the occasional bout of pathos and a constant barrage of one-liners.

Look further into this field and you come across a bewildering array of mutant offspring.Unlike at Crufts, pedigree is no object to interbreeding. Ever wonder what happened to Rick after Ilse got on the plane? Producer William T Orr did in 1955, and so Casablanca the TV show, with Charles McGraw stepping into Humphrey Bogart's platform shoes, was born. And died after 10 episodes. Al Pacino's 1973 seminal cop workout, Serpico spawned Serpico, a less than essential 70s cop show. Seven Brides For Seven Brothers? Barely lasted seven episodes.

You can see why people think it's a good idea. Films are cash cows waiting to be milked dry, with merchandising that boosts sales for months after the film has played. Now there's another chance to drink powdered milk, with Lock, Stock And Two Smoking Barrels. Unlike Buffy and M*A*S*H, this attempt is udder crap.

Guy "Mr Madonna" Ritchie's movie took the cheeky gangster heritage of Alfie, The Italian Job and Get Carter, and propelled it into the 90s with peppy Tarantino-does-cockney dialogue, some tricksy camera effects, and a convoluted plot that resolves in a carefully constructed ducking and diving kind of way.

Lock, Stock... (The TV Show) features four more neo-mod cheeky mockney hustlers, called things like Bacon and Moon, wheeling and dealing with other "faces on the manor" with equally realistic names (Firebug, Miami Vice and Three Feet). And no Vinnie Jones.

The story for the first "feature-length" episode is essentially the same as the feature-length feature: the four receive some dodgy goods (bestiality videos and a porno-chic watch) and then spend the rest of their time trying to flog them/ return them to the rightful owner/ not get killed (stop me if you've seen this one before).

It's an even lazier portrait of East End life than the film, but without the wit - by the end it's amazing that Chas and Dave haven't shown up, argued with the missus on the dog and bone and pushed each other down the apples and pears. Everyone's a crafty geezer or a tarty bird with a crafty scam on the go, drinking in the same three places in London, driving on the same roads, and saying things like "He could talk a nun into having 666 tattooed onto her arse" with a straight face.

Plot twists arrive every time a new stereotype is introduced to pass the dodgy gear onto: the traveller family, a direct lift from Viz's Thieving Gippo Bastards; the Dutch perma-stoners who steal the videos in the first place (literally off the back of a lorry); the Greek fence-cum-bookie-cum-kebab shop owner happy to slaughter a horse and serve it in a post-pub doner.

It's shot with the same frenetic, desperate-to-be-hip aesthetic as the film, with scenes slowing down and speeding up at random to create the illusion that you are watching something thrillingly cutting edge, ie a medium-budget beer ad. Casual violence is peppered throughout, homophobia masquerades as humour, and the women are only capable of stripping, working in pubs or having a quick shag.

There's little sign of it being able to transcend the film's plot, which, like a crap magician stuffing a rabbit slowly up his sleeve, just isn't as clever the second time around. If the Lock, Stock titles weren't plastered over every break, you'd be forgiven for thinking they'd remade Minder. Another couple of episodes, and you might wish they had.

 Lock, Stock... And Four Stolen Hooves, 9pm, Monday, C4

fields.headline: Hollander hollers once more
fields.standfirst: He makes some noise in Ben Elton's new romantic comedy, but young actor Tom Hollander insists there's more to him than playing loudmouths
fields.trailText: He makes some noise in Ben Elton's new romantic comedy, but young actor Tom Hollander insists there's more to him than playing loudmouths
fields.body:
Tom Hollander is one of those actors who makes the most of his roles. Even if he's only playing a supporting part, he's usually the one you'll remember afterwards. In his Cambridge days he worked with Sam Mendes, and went on to several stage triumphs before crossing over into features like Bedrooms And Hallways and Martha Meet Daniel, Frank And Lawrence. In Ben Elton's new comedy Maybe Baby, Hugh Laurie and Joely Richardson are the fertility-obsessed romantic leads, but Hollander steals the show once again, as Ewan Proclaimer, the oppressively trendy Scottish film director.

Did you recognise Oscar potential in Sam Mendes in your Footlights days?

He was always very good. He directed me as Cyrano de Bergerac, and in plenty of other things, and it was very exciting working with him. No one quite thought he'd get an Oscar for his first film though - I'd hardly believe anyone would.

So did you call him up after American Beauty and ask for a part in his next film?

Well, the smart money doesn't actually say, "Can I be in your next film?" But I did ring him to say, "Well done."

And how about Ben Elton? Was it strange working with a first-time director?

To tell the truth, I've hardly worked with anyone who wasn't! So what would be very unusual would be to work with someone who had directed a film before, which seems to be typical of the British film industry.

Was he nervous?

He was at first, but he kept up such a constant rate of gags. If the camera wasn't rolling, Ben was, so you didn't really have time to sense he was nervous. He was open to suggestions the whole time which was really refreshing. But at the end of the day it was his project and he'd go off and edit it and make all the decisions he wanted to make.

So how much of your character was left on the floor?

Maybe a third. Apparently it's on the DVD. That's what always happens, I think, with romantic comedies. It was the same in Notting Hill. All those other characters had their own stories, but when push comes to shove they have to focus on the central plotline, which in this case was Hugh and Joely, obviously.

The film has plenty to say about the current British film industry. Do you think there's still a "Brit Pack"?

All that Brit Pack stuff - people have been talking about the film industry in those terms for the past five years. That's all just convenient magazine sub-heading stuff really. But I think we need to start regularly pumping out some films of a certain standard, rather than the usual, very well-made film by Ken Loach or Mike Leigh every year, otherwise it's all going to start to look pretty stupid.

As the movie director character, did you feel like you were Ben's alter-ego?

Well, schematically I was. I thought the writing of my character was most similar to the writing I recognised as "Eltonesque", you know, the ranty man. It was a part to draw attention to itself.

You do usually seem to play the loudest character in the film.

I know and I'm sick of it. You do it once and that's all they want you to do. It's like if you're naughty at school, they'll be singling you out for the rest of the year. So yeah, I'm trying to do some studied, understated, subtle work.

What's next?

At the moment I'm working with Michael Apted, who directed the last Bond film, on an adaptation of Robert Harris's Enigma. It's a "faction" with Kate Winslet and Dougray Scott. He's a codebreaker who's also a romantic hero, and I'm the terribly nice chap who believes in him. And I smoke a pipe, which I've never done before.

So are you a quiet character this time?

Do you know, I am! It's a breakthrough.

fields.headline: Hard to swallow
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: The wedding went off all right. I was the only man there. Even the registrar was a woman. Is this the beginning of the end for men?
fields.body:
Wednesday, May 17, 2000, Ashby-de-la-Zouch

After a visit to my father, who has been urged by Tanya to sue the hospital for neglect and loss of dentures, I went to Pankhurst Ward to see Mrs Wormington. She is still nil by mouth, though there is now some doubt as to her swallowing ability.

I was there when a young doctor, in jeans and T-shirt (slogan: "Trust me, I'm a journalist") bellowed, "We've asked Mrs Ng, the ear, nose and throat consultant to have a look at you, Mrs Wormington." I asked if this meant that Mrs Wormington could drink a cup of tea. "Not yet. We don't want to risk her choking to death," she said. "I shall die if I don't have a cup of tea soon," rasped Mrs Wormington. The doctor hurried off down the ward. I followed her. "When will the consultant next be on the ward?" I said. "Mrs Ng's next ward round is on Friday afternoon," she said.

When the tea trolley came round, I placed myself between it and Mrs Wormington, but she heard the wheels. "I've drank eight cups of tea a day for 92 years," she choked. The poor woman ought by right be admitted to the Priory. She is doing the equivalent of coming off crack.

When I went into the sluice room to find a vase for the carnations I'd bought, I heard a registrar at the nurses station whining about the "bed-blockers". When I said goodbye to Mrs Wormington, she said, "Tara lad, God bless, see you tomorrow." I'm trapped! Trapped!

Another pensioner has broken into my life and is holding me to ransom.

Friday, May 19

Glenn asked why the washing line was full of wincey-ette nighties and big knickers. I explained, and he said, "I'm relieved, Dad, I thought you was on the turn."

Saturday, May 20

I woke with a jolt at 3am just as Leo Blair was being born (am I psychically connected to Cherie?). I went downstairs to discover that Pamela Pigg had shoved a note through the letterbox at some time during the night. On pink Filofax paper, she had written:

Dear Adrian,

I went out on a hen night with the girls from the homeless unit tonight. Phillipa, the one with the teeth, is getting 'married' to Mary, the one with the nose, on Wednesday morning. We went to Humperdink's, the new nightclub in Melton Mowbray. I felt terribly out of place. It was full of teenage girls wearing very small garments. I felt horribly frumpy in my Principles polka-dot outfit. It's the last time I follow the advice of the Leicester Mercury's fashion correspondent.

However, the point is, Adrian, the DJ played our song, My Heart Will Go On. I had to leave the dancefloor. Do you remember your emotional state when we came out of the multiplex, after seeing Titanic? It was the first time I had seen a grown man cry. I felt very privileged. I miss you, Adrian. Can we try again? It was stupid of me to have flown into a temper over a silly book.

Love, forever, Pammy.

PS: Mary and Phillipa say you are welcome to come to the wedding. I am to be their best person. No presents, but donations to the Fawcett Society appreciated.

PPS: I've had disturbing thoughts of yielding myself to you.

Talk about blackmail! If I attend the lesbian wedding with her, she will "yield" to me, will she? Does she imagine that I am so sexually frustrated that I would spend another minute in the company of a woman who became hysterical when she discovered a copy of Philip Larkin's Diaries on my bookshelf?

Wednesday, May 24

The wedding went off all right. I was the only man there. Even the registrar was a woman. Is this the beginning of the end for men? Pamela came back to Arthur Askey Way, but refused to "yield" to me when she saw Kingsley Amis's Letters on my bedside table and Mrs Wormington's knickers on the line.

fields.headline: The genteel assassin
fields.standfirst: She is famous for the brilliant language and dark undercurrents of her novels. Her life, moving from Edinburgh to Rhodesia to New York, includes brushes with madness and the sinister, and a very public estrangement from her son.  Emma Brockes finds her in Tuscany, now 82, still honing stilettos of wit
fields.trailText: She is famous for the brilliant language and dark undercurrents of her novels. Her life, moving from Edinburgh to Rhodesia to New York, includes brushes with madness and the sinister, and a very public estrangement from her son. Emma Brockes finds her in Tuscany, now 82, still honing stilettos of wit
fields.body:
For half a century Muriel Spark has been stripping away human vanity with the force of a blowtorch. "You will end up as a girl-guide leader in a suburb like Corstorphine," withers Jean Brodie, Spark's most famous heroine, to one of her young charges. And her now infamous demolition of Marie Stopes, an adversary during Spark's time as editor of the Poetry Review, vibrates with her signature tone: "I used to think it a pity that her mother rather than she had not thought of birth control," Spark said, with an irony so delicate there is no sound of tearing as the knife goes in.

Because of this, her polite curiosity comes across in conversation as a front for more ruthless operations; her generous manner as a ruse to draw out pretensions. Naturally, this is absurd. She has lived here, an hour from Florence, for the last 20 years. It is a fitting backdrop for a woman to whom dark and dramatic things seem to happen, or at least, who presents them as such in the retelling. When I went to the police, they asked me what was in the bag, and I said, there was a poem. The policeman said can you describe the poem? I said, it was about a hat. Not taking Spark seriously is an error that critics have been sporadically making since her first novel, The Comforters, was published in 1957. "She carves with a very sharp knife. Muriel Spark was the keenest, sharpest, most agile brain that I ever came across. She is light years more intelligent than most people."

She knew that she wanted to write and she knew how she wanted to write, but it was many years before she was in a financial position to do anything beyond getting by. From the outset, however, she had a sort of damn-you self-assurance that kept her from editing her style to suit publishers' fancies.

"I was very much myself," she says. "I felt I should be getting as much money as people like Kingsley Amis, who was my contemporary." Spark, however, was from a background quite at odds with the tenor of her prose - that glittering levity enabled by not having to worry about paying the gas bill. "I had a certain throw-away attitude which really didn't belong to my upbringing. I had to adapt it to a life that was totally different from that of the people who had used that kind of prose style before. It usually belonged to people of leisure and I had always had to struggle."

She was born Muriel Camberg in Edinburgh in 1918, to a Scots-Jewish father and an English mother, a fact that her own son, Robin, would contest 70 years later in a bid to vindicate his own religious choices by claiming that both his grandparents were Jewish. "My mother and father were both religious," says Spark. "But not along any sectarian line. They believed in the Almighty." Her confidence in her own talent was formidable. As a child she liked reading Sir Walter Scott's Border Ballads and eavesdropping on adult conversations, both of which stimulated what she later called, her "literary sense", a highly-tuned ear for language.

Her precocious interest in literature (she was reading Browning and Swinburne at 11) was not shared by her parents, an engineer and a music teacher, although they encouraged Spark and her brother to pursue their own interests. "My mother wrote a nice letter, that was all. My father read the racing papers. My mother, however, liked to play the piano and was a music teacher, so maybe I get the musical side and imagination from her."

In 1957 when her first novel, The Comforters - an exploration of the mechanics of writing in which a woman hears the text of the book being narrated in her head - was published, Spark's parents were bemused. "They didn't know what it was all about really," she says, giggling at the memory of her mother's startled reaction. "'Oh darling!' she said. 'You've written a novel!' She didn't take it in." Spark, however, had never doubted that she would be a writer. At 11, she came under the influence of Miss Kay of James Gillespie's School in Edinburgh, a woman on whom the character of Miss Jean Brodie would eventually be based. Miss Kay taught Spark and her classmates that they were "not to be carried away by crowd emotions, not to be fools," a lesson that Spark would remember and translate into the cool-headed, unsentimental slant of her own literature.

Whilst still at school, five of her poems were accepted for an anthology, and at 14 she won first prize in a 1932 poetry competition to commemorate the death of Scott. "The Border Ballads were a heavy influence on her," says Alan Taylor, man aging editor of the Scotsman and a frequent visitor to Spark's home in Tuscany. "They have these summary ways of dispatching people and she does this all the time."

"I still take a poetic view of life as I see it through the novel", says Spark, explaining that she views her novels as long prose poems, a claim that might inspire eye-rolling cynicism if it came from a less disciplined writer. Spark, however, refers not to the use of poetic language or to flowery imagery, but to the hard-boiled matter of rhythm and cadence. "It is a question of construction, of lyricism - lyricism in that poetry has music in it. There are repetitive motifs; repetitive little phrases, themes, always returning and a complete reversal of circumstances towards the end."

The repetitive motif beats time not only in her writing but in her speech. She has a talent for packaging statements in such a way that they have a theatrical momentum, a spontaneous rhythm and suspense that at once explains how she writes her novels in a single go, without returning to edit them. She punctuates her spoken word as exactly as her written. There is a full stop at the end of each statement that she indicates by staring into space and tuning out. She has it first time.

She observes a writing routine that goes beyond strictness into the realm of superstition, pouring out each novel, in longhand, onto yellow note pads she buys from James Thin, the Edinburgh stationer. "I have an absolute will to write," she says. This can leave the impression of a chilly character, a woman meticulous in her enthusiasms, who regards people as if they appear on the end of a pin. Critics have marked her as, "cold" and "highly calculated", a writer whose faculties, like a set of surgical instruments, ensure that "every stitch is small and perfect".

"She has a sense of humour but I don't think she has a sense of the ridiculous," says Iris Birtwistle. "I've never heard her do a hearty laugh, ever. All her conversation is spiked with merriment, but in the old-fashioned way. I think the ridiculous would probably be lowbrow for her."

"I simply can't take the jocular," Spark has said, "either in life or art. A well-brewed send-up is delightful. Derision is boring." Friends insist that her steely composure should not be mistaken for aloofness. "She thinks before she speaks," says Auberon Waugh, whose father Evelyn was a great promoter of Spark's work before it became well known. "But she is terribly warm, terribly affectionate."

After leaving school, Spark wanted to go to university but the family couldn't afford it, so she enrolled on a course in précis writing at Herriot Watt College (now university), a natural home for her writing style. "I do like to be brief," she says. She didn't mope for her lack of a degree. It was regrettable, of course, but with her trademark defiance Spark did not feel it diminished her. "I thought all the books of the world are open to me if I can get at them. I could read all that I wanted."

The war hadn't yet started and as nice girls didn't have sex before marriage, Spark made the practical and hasty decision at 19 to get engaged to Sydney Oswald Spark - SOS as he was known - 13 years her senior, whom she had met at a dance and whose history was largely unknown to her. He was going to Rhodesia as a school teacher and, keen for adventure, she grabbed at the chance to go with him. They were married on September 3 1937. Within six months of arriving, she knew she had made a terrible mistake. Spark talks about this phase of her life with the same unblinking detachment she turns on everything: she is faintly amused, mildly astonished, forever precise and indignant at this, the crazy narrative of her 20s.

"My husband had an unbalanced family, and his sister had to go in a loony bin because she attempted to murder my mother. And then I realised that I had been taken in. But by that time I was expecting a baby." Spark was in a genuinely precarious position. When Nita McEwan's husband killed her in the boarding house, Spark was rattled enough to hide the gun that her own husband liked to wave around and occasionally point at her.

And she hated the colony. "The white people were not very nice," she says. "There was a feeling of people coming in just to exploit and I felt uneasy and frightened. I could see this myriad of blacks against 50,000 whites who wouldn't have a chance if it came to a showdown. And I could see that it was wrong. It was their house, not ours."

Her husband became more manic and increasingly more violent and when Spark eventually left him, two years into the marriage, he was committed to a mental institution. She tried to get passage home, but the second world war had broken out and there were no passenger ships sailing. "I had to stick it out as much as possible, but it was all very much life and death for me."

Throughout this time, she had not stopped writing. She twice won Rhodesia's annual poetry competition, and her appreciation for a strong narrative made her desperate to return to Britain to experience the war. She enrolled Robin, then five, in a convent in Rhodesia, and eventually sailed for England, not a decision she regrets, she says, because there was little alternative.

"There was almost no work for me to do there. I thought the war would be over in six months. Instead it was 18 months. It was quite a separation." Friends have since raised eyebrows and muttered that she is not very maternal, that writing always came before her son, who she never quite seemed to identify with.

When Robin returned from Rhodesia, he went to live with his maternal grandparents in Edinburgh and decided, as a teenager, to embrace his grandfather's religion, Judaism. As an adult, he started campaigning for his late grandmother (Muriel's mother) to be recognised as a Jew, a cause taken up, to Muriel Spark's immense annoyance, by the Jewish Chronicle. "They are really like hounds," she says. "Absolute hounds." What is at least probable, in this pedantic and irritable dispute, is that her mother, Sarah Uezzel, signed a false Jewish name on her wedding certificate in order to be allowed to marry Spark's father in a synagogue.

Spark is at her haughtiest, her uncrushable best on this, the subject of her own contested heritage. "The very strict Jews such as those at the Jewish Chronicle refuse the word half-Jew altogether, which is, of course, in the dictionary. One knows what half-Jew means. Hitler didn't care one damn what the Jews' definition was." She pauses. "They say there is no such thing as a half-Jew and I say there is, because I experienced it."

There is a sense that this episode infuriated Spark less for its content than for what it did to her perception of Robin: that he appeared feeble to her, relying for his identity on some bogus interpretation of his ethnic background rather than his own convictions; that he was not like his mother at all.

Spark's own religious convictions were cemented in 1954 when she converted to Catholicism, a faith she practises, like all things, on her own terms. She is anti-clerical, dislikes dogma and will not remain silent on church matters she finds absurd. She doesn't believe in good and evil, but in absurdity and intelligence - in the fact that people who do "evil" acts are pursuing a logic that intelligent people call absurd. "I like to speak out," she says. "If the Catholic religion, to which I belong, can't allow me to speak out frankly, it is no religion for me."

Her reasons for converting are deeply embedded in her prose. She speaks of the importance of recognising a "life beyond this life," of acknowledging the supernatural and, in a rare concession to poetic fancy, of believing in angels. "I do think the whole of nature is impregnated with spiritual life. There is no substance without some spirit and no spirit without substance. "

It is possible that as a writer, she was attracted to Catholicism for its strong narrative, its seductive ritu als and repetitive motifs, the sheer theatrical force of its history. It is also possible, as Auberon Waugh observes, that Spark's mental filing system required a repository of faith. "The thing about Catholicism," he says, "is that there's no bloody nonsense - something is right, something is wrong."

After she returned to London, Spark fulfilled her wish to "see" the war, by working as a duty secretary at a military intelligence base in Milton Bryan, Bedfordshire, taking down telephone messages from allied bombing crews and passing them on for use as black propaganda. It was not until after the war that she started writing in earnest, for a jewellery trade magazine called Argentor, a political magazine called European Affairs, and, after distinguishing herself in a number of its competitions, as editor of the Poetry Review. She was 29, and determined to rescue the magazine from ignominy as a forum for weak and vain poetry.

"I started publishing modern poems rather than Christmas card-type poems," she sniffs and, not shy to admit it, she made enough enemies to be dismissed from the post after two years of constant assault from lecherous board members and bitter poets. "They would do anything to get published. Those that weren't queer wanted to sleep with me. They thought they were poets and there should be free love or something. I've never known anything like it."

Spark's friendship with Penelope Jardine has since provoked speculations about her own sexuality, although both she and her friends reject them as fanciful. "She had enormous vitality and great appeal to the opposite sex," says Iris Birtwistle. "We had masses of boyfriends, and why not?" Theirs is an old-fashioned friendship, Spark says, although one that has evolved into a peculiar intensity. "Penelope is like the archetypal novelist's wife," says John Mortimer, who rents a summer house near their home. "She is protective of Muriel."

Spark's stint at the Poetry Review gained her a reputation as a stylish editor and she built on it with her biographies of Mary Shelley (1951) and Emily Bronte (1953). The real break, however, came on November 5 1951, when she entered a short story competition in the Observer. The subject was "Christmas" and the prize £250, big enough to attract 6,700 entries. Spark was 33, renting a room in London's Old Brompton Road and earning £134 a year as a jobbing writer - of poetry, journalism and speech material on industrial relations, a subject about which she knew nothing but, with her customary flair, managed to pull off.

"It was on a Saturday that I finished writing the short story," she recalls, in a polished anecdote. "I was going to type it out and I found that I had no typing paper, and all the shops were shut except for one, a picture framer's. And so I said to him, 'Just give me 20 pieces of paper, that's all I want'. He said, 'I don't sell paper'. I said, 'I can see you've got a typewriter there, I just want paper'. I said 'I'm going to go in for this prize and if I win it I'll buy a picture off you'." She smiles sardonically. "I bought a picture."

The success of the story, The Seraph And The Zambesi, based on her time in Rhodesia, prompted a commission for a novel from Macmillan. Spark, still desperately poor, was only able to write it thanks to the patronage of a kindly Grahame Greene. He had read and admired her non-fiction and, learning from her boyfriend, the critic and literary schmoozer Derek Stanford, that she was poor, offered to pay her an allowance.

Iris Birtwistle was one of the first people Spark knew intimately to have come from a background of private means. "She was quite intrigued by it," Birtwistle says. "She was hooked on class, fascinated by the structure and interplay."

"She has ideas of grandeur," says Auberon Waugh. "She has to be driven in a car everywhere." She is acutely interested in the dynamics of snobbery, a subject that she examines in the novel she is currently writing. It will be called The Finishing School and she is reading DeBrett's peerage and a book on social manners for it, which she finds "killingly funny". Spark's own social position changed radically, not with the publication of her first novel - which was generally well received but didn't make her fortune - but with the success of The Prime Of Miss Jean Brodie, the fictional schoolteacher who incinerates her enemies with a sharp tongue.

That 1961 hit was the turning point for Spark; William Shawn, then editor of the New Yorker, printed the entire manuscript of Jean Brodie in one issue of the magazine and offered Spark the use of an office overlooking Times Square. She took up his offer in 1963 when she moved to New York and, with the stage and film versions of Jean Brodie bringing her international acclaim, started knocking around the celebrity circuit with Norman Mailer and Mary McCarthy.

This is the glamorous period, full of parties and salons, which she revelled in, briefly, before shunning it to get back to writing. Even during the headiest days, however, she remained sceptical of Hollywood's interest in her and is critical of all the film versions of her work, considering Geraldine McEwan in the stage version to have been the best Jean Brodie. "The colours in the film [dir. Ronald Neame, 1969] were much too bright for Edinburgh, which has a sort of pearly light. And everyone's hair was too red. Apart from that, I thought it quite well written." It tickles her however, that all the actresses who have been in dramatisations of her books have become dames: Judi Dench, Maggie Smith, Vanessa Redgrave, Elizabeth Taylor and Spark herself, in 1993. "We are all dames together," she says and smiles.

The attention didn't change her; in fact, the moment the publicity circus threatened to interfere with her writing she fled, from London to New York, New York to Rome and finally to Arezzo. "She has made a career of escaping when she thinks something is going to stop her writing," says Alan Taylor.

To Spark, everything comes second to the story: sons, lovers, health and welfare. She gets up at seven every morning to write, aware in that unflinching way of hers that every novel might be her last. "When I begin a novel, I want to absorb it through my pores," she says, and this is apparent in the words that she uses, in the tiny shifts in temperature she records. Her defiance is in her detail, her precision driven by the knowledge that by fixing things exactly, we widen their possibility.

The novel she has just submitted is called Aiding And Abetting, a fictional account of what happened to Lord Lucan after he murdered the family nanny. (There are a few legal wrangles to negotiate, although Spark, poised as if at the head of an army, declares "let him come forward and sue me".)

It is part of her resilience that she finds dramatic potential in everything. At the end of the interview, she is asked if she would mind being photographed outside in a gale. Spark bobs about in huge red hockey socks and yellow anorak, blinking gamely into the wind, throwing her bird-like frame against the elements with a wicked smile. It might be that she is content to suffer a little discomfort for the story she will tell when the door shuts behind her.

Life at a glance

Muriel Sarah Spark

Born: February 1 1918, Edinburgh.

Education: James Gillespie's school for girls, Edinburgh; Heriot Watt College.

Married: 1937, Sydney Oswald Spark (one son, Robin), dissolved.

Employment: 1944 Foreign Office; 1947-9 general secretary, Poetry Society, editor, Poetry Review.

Some fiction: 1957 The Comforters; 1958 The Go-Away Bird; 1959 Memento Mori; 1960 The Ballad Of Peckham Rye; 1961 The Prime Of Miss Jean Brodie; 1963 The Girls Of Slender Means; 1965 The Mandelbaum Gate; 1974 The Abbess Of Crewe; 1981 Loitering With Intent; 1988 A Far Cry From Kensington; 1996 Reality And Dreams.

Some non-fiction: 1952 Child Of Light: A Reassessment Of Mary Shelley; 1992 Curriculum Vitae (autobiography).

Honours: 1993 Dame of the British Empire.

· Aiding And Abetting will be published by Penguin in September.

Whilst still at school, five of her poems were accepted for an anthology, and at 14 she won first prize in a 1932 poetry competition to commemorate the death of Scott. "The Border Ballads were a heavy influence on her," says Alan Taylor, man aging editor of the Scotsman and a frequent visitor to Spark's home in Tuscany. "They have these summary ways of dispatching people and she does this all the time." "I still take a poetic view of life as I see it through the novel", says Spark, explaining that she views her novels as long prose poems, a claim that might inspire eye-rolling cynicism if it came from a less disciplined writer. Spark, however, refers not to the use of poetic language or to flowery imagery, but to the hard-boiled matter of rhythm and cadence. "It is a question of construction, of lyricism - lyricism in that poetry has music in it. There are repetitive motifs; repetitive little phrases, themes, always returning and a complete reversal of circumstances towards the end." The repetitive motif beats time not only in her writing but in her speech. She has a talent for packaging statements in such a way that they have a theatrical momentum, a spontaneous rhythm and suspense that at once explains how she writes her novels in a single go, without returning to edit them. She punctuates her spoken word as exactly as her written. There is a full stop at the end of each statement that she indicates by staring into space and tuning out. She has it first time. She observes a writing routine that goes beyond strictness into the realm of superstition, pouring out each novel, in longhand, onto yellow note pads she buys from James Thin, the Edinburgh stationer. "I have an absolute will to write," she says. This can leave the impression of a chilly character, a woman meticulous in her enthusiasms, who regards people as if they appear on the end of a pin. Critics have marked her as, "cold" and "highly calculated", a writer whose faculties, like a set of surgical instruments, ensure that "every stitch is small and perfect". "She has a sense of humour but I don't think she has a sense of the ridiculous," says Iris Birtwistle. "I've never heard her do a hearty laugh, ever. All her conversation is spiked with merriment, but in the old-fashioned way. I think the ridiculous would probably be lowbrow for her." "I simply can't take the jocular," Spark has said, "either in life or art. A well-brewed send-up is delightful. Derision is boring." Friends insist that her steely composure should not be mistaken for aloofness. "She thinks before she speaks," says Auberon Waugh, whose father Evelyn was a great promoter of Spark's work before it became well known. "But she is terribly warm, terribly affectionate." After leaving school, Spark wanted to go to university but the family couldn't afford it, so she enrolled on a course in précis writing at Herriot Watt College (now university), a natural home for her writing style. "I do like to be brief," she says. She didn't mope for her lack of a degree. It was regrettable, of course, but with her trademark defiance Spark did not feel it diminished her. "I thought all the books of the world are open to me if I can get at them. I could read all that I wanted." The war hadn't yet started and as nice girls didn't have sex before marriage, Spark made the practical and hasty decision at 19 to get engaged to Sydney Oswald Spark - SOS as he was known - 13 years her senior, whom she had met at a dance and whose history was largely unknown to her. He was going to Rhodesia as a school teacher and, keen for adventure, she grabbed at the chance to go with him. They were married on September 3 1937. Within six months of arriving, she knew she had made a terrible mistake. Spark talks about this phase of her life with the same unblinking detachment she turns on everything: she is faintly amused, mildly astonished, forever precise and indignant at this, the crazy narrative of her 20s. "My husband had an unbalanced family, and his sister had to go in a loony bin because she attempted to murder my mother. And then I realised that I had been taken in. But by that time I was expecting a baby." Spark was in a genuinely precarious position. When Nita McEwan's husband killed her in the boarding house, Spark was rattled enough to hide the gun that her own husband liked to wave around and occasionally point at her. And she hated the colony. "The white people were not very nice," she says. "There was a feeling of people coming in just to exploit and I felt uneasy and frightened. I could see this myriad of blacks against 50,000 whites who wouldn't have a chance if it came to a showdown. And I could see that it was wrong. It was their house, not ours." Her husband became more manic and increasingly more violent and when Spark eventually left him, two years into the marriage, he was committed to a mental institution. She tried to get passage home, but the second world war had broken out and there were no passenger ships sailing. "I had to stick it out as much as possible, but it was all very much life and death for me." Throughout this time, she had not stopped writing. She twice won Rhodesia's annual poetry competition, and her appreciation for a strong narrative made her desperate to return to Britain to experience the war. She enrolled Robin, then five, in a convent in Rhodesia, and eventually sailed for England, not a decision she regrets, she says, because there was little alternative. "There was almost no work for me to do there. I thought the war would be over in six months. Instead it was 18 months. It was quite a separation." Friends have since raised eyebrows and muttered that she is not very maternal, that writing always came before her son, who she never quite seemed to identify with. When Robin returned from Rhodesia, he went to live with his maternal grandparents in Edinburgh and decided, as a teenager, to embrace his grandfather's religion, Judaism. As an adult, he started campaigning for his late grandmother (Muriel's mother) to be recognised as a Jew, a cause taken up, to Muriel Spark's immense annoyance, by the Jewish Chronicle. "They are really like hounds," she says. "Absolute hounds." What is at least probable, in this pedantic and irritable dispute, is that her mother, Sarah Uezzel, signed a false Jewish name on her wedding certificate in order to be allowed to marry Spark's father in a synagogue. Spark is at her haughtiest, her uncrushable best on this, the subject of her own contested heritage. "The very strict Jews such as those at the Jewish Chronicle refuse the word half-Jew altogether, which is, of course, in the dictionary. One knows what half-Jew means. Hitler didn't care one damn what the Jews' definition was." She pauses. "They say there is no such thing as a half-Jew and I say there is, because I experienced it." There is a sense that this episode infuriated Spark less for its content than for what it did to her perception of Robin: that he appeared feeble to her, relying for his identity on some bogus interpretation of his ethnic background rather than his own convictions; that he was not like his mother at all. Spark's own religious convictions were cemented in 1954 when she converted to Catholicism, a faith she practises, like all things, on her own terms. She is anti-clerical, dislikes dogma and will not remain silent on church matters she finds absurd. She doesn't believe in good and evil, but in absurdity and intelligence - in the fact that people who do "evil" acts are pursuing a logic that intelligent people call absurd. "I like to speak out," she says. "If the Catholic religion, to which I belong, can't allow me to speak out frankly, it is no religion for me." Her reasons for converting are deeply embedded in her prose. She speaks of the importance of recognising a "life beyond this life," of acknowledging the supernatural and, in a rare concession to poetic fancy, of believing in angels. "I do think the whole of nature is impregnated with spiritual life. There is no substance without some spirit and no spirit without substance. " It is possible that as a writer, she was attracted to Catholicism for its strong narrative, its seductive ritu als and repetitive motifs, the sheer theatrical force of its history. It is also possible, as Auberon Waugh observes, that Spark's mental filing system required a repository of faith. "The thing about Catholicism," he says, "is that there's no bloody nonsense - something is right, something is wrong." After she returned to London, Spark fulfilled her wish to "see" the war, by working as a duty secretary at a military intelligence base in Milton Bryan, Bedfordshire, taking down telephone messages from allied bombing crews and passing them on for use as black propaganda. It was not until after the war that she started writing in earnest, for a jewellery trade magazine called Argentor, a political magazine called European Affairs, and, after distinguishing herself in a number of its competitions, as editor of the Poetry Review. She was 29, and determined to rescue the magazine from ignominy as a forum for weak and vain poetry. "I started publishing modern poems rather than Christmas card-type poems," she sniffs and, not shy to admit it, she made enough enemies to be dismissed from the post after two years of constant assault from lecherous board members and bitter poets. "They would do anything to get published. Those that weren't queer wanted to sleep with me. They thought they were poets and there should be free love or something. I've never known anything like it." Spark's friendship with Penelope Jardine has since provoked speculations about her own sexuality, although both she and her friends reject them as fanciful. "She had enormous vitality and great appeal to the opposite sex," says Iris Birtwistle. "We had masses of boyfriends, and why not?" Theirs is an old-fashioned friendship, Spark says, although one that has evolved into a peculiar intensity. "Penelope is like the archetypal novelist's wife," says John Mortimer, who rents a summer house near their home. "She is protective of Muriel." Spark's stint at the Poetry Review gained her a reputation as a stylish editor and she built on it with her biographies of Mary Shelley (1951) and Emily Bronte (1953). The real break, however, came on November 5 1951, when she entered a short story competition in the Observer. The subject was "Christmas" and the prize £250, big enough to attract 6,700 entries. Spark was 33, renting a room in London's Old Brompton Road and earning £134 a year as a jobbing writer - of poetry, journalism and speech material on industrial relations, a subject about which she knew nothing but, with her customary flair, managed to pull off. "It was on a Saturday that I finished writing the short story," she recalls, in a polished anecdote. "I was going to type it out and I found that I had no typing paper, and all the shops were shut except for one, a picture framer's. And so I said to him, 'Just give me 20 pieces of paper, that's all I want'. He said, 'I don't sell paper'. I said, 'I can see you've got a typewriter there, I just want paper'. I said 'I'm going to go in for this prize and if I win it I'll buy a picture off you'." She smiles sardonically. "I bought a picture." The success of the story, The Seraph And The Zambesi, based on her time in Rhodesia, prompted a commission for a novel from Macmillan. Spark, still desperately poor, was only able to write it thanks to the patronage of a kindly Grahame Greene. He had read and admired her non-fiction and, learning from her boyfriend, the critic and literary schmoozer Derek Stanford, that she was poor, offered to pay her an allowance. Iris Birtwistle was one of the first people Spark knew intimately to have come from a background of private means. "She was quite intrigued by it," Birtwistle says. "She was hooked on class, fascinated by the structure and interplay." "She has ideas of grandeur," says Auberon Waugh. "She has to be driven in a car everywhere." She is acutely interested in the dynamics of snobbery, a subject that she examines in the novel she is currently writing. It will be called The Finishing School and she is reading DeBrett's peerage and a book on social manners for it, which she finds "killingly funny". Spark's own social position changed radically, not with the publication of her first novel - which was generally well received but didn't make her fortune - but with the success of The Prime Of Miss Jean Brodie, the fictional schoolteacher who incinerates her enemies with a sharp tongue. That 1961 hit was the turning point for Spark; William Shawn, then editor of the New Yorker, printed the entire manuscript of Jean Brodie in one issue of the magazine and offered Spark the use of an office overlooking Times Square. She took up his offer in 1963 when she moved to New York and, with the stage and film versions of Jean Brodie bringing her international acclaim, started knocking around the celebrity circuit with Norman Mailer and Mary McCarthy. This is the glamorous period, full of parties and salons, which she revelled in, briefly, before shunning it to get back to writing. Even during the headiest days, however, she remained sceptical of Hollywood's interest in her and is critical of all the film versions of her work, considering Geraldine McEwan in the stage version to have been the best Jean Brodie. "The colours in the film [dir. Ronald Neame, 1969] were much too bright for Edinburgh, which has a sort of pearly light. And everyone's hair was too red. Apart from that, I thought it quite well written." It tickles her however, that all the actresses who have been in dramatisations of her books have become dames: Judi Dench, Maggie Smith, Vanessa Redgrave, Elizabeth Taylor and Spark herself, in 1993. "We are all dames together," she says and smiles. The attention didn't change her; in fact, the moment the publicity circus threatened to interfere with her writing she fled, from London to New York, New York to Rome and finally to Arezzo. "She has made a career of escaping when she thinks something is going to stop her writing," says Alan Taylor. To Spark, everything comes second to the story: sons, lovers, health and welfare. She gets up at seven every morning to write, aware in that unflinching way of hers that every novel might be her last. "When I begin a novel, I want to absorb it through my pores," she says, and this is apparent in the words that she uses, in the tiny shifts in temperature she records. Her defiance is in her detail, her precision driven by the knowledge that by fixing things exactly, we widen their possibility. The novel she has just submitted is called Aiding And Abetting, a fictional account of what happened to Lord Lucan after he murdered the family nanny. (There are a few legal wrangles to negotiate, although Spark, poised as if at the head of an army, declares "let him come forward and sue me".) It is part of her resilience that she finds dramatic potential in everything. At the end of the interview, she is asked if she would mind being photographed outside in a gale. Spark bobs about in huge red hockey socks and yellow anorak, blinking gamely into the wind, throwing her bird-like frame against the elements with a wicked smile. It might be that she is content to suffer a little discomfort for the story she will tell when the door shuts behind her. Life at a glance Muriel Sarah Spark Born: February 1 1918, Edinburgh. Education: James Gillespie's school for girls, Edinburgh; Heriot Watt College. Married: 1937, Sydney Oswald Spark (one son, Robin), dissolved. Employment: 1944 Foreign Office; 1947-9 general secretary, Poetry Society, editor, Poetry Review. Some fiction: 1957 The Comforters; 1958 The Go-Away Bird; 1959 Memento Mori; 1960 The Ballad Of Peckham Rye; 1961 The Prime Of Miss Jean Brodie; 1963 The Girls Of Slender Means; 1965 The Mandelbaum Gate; 1974 The Abbess Of Crewe; 1981 Loitering With Intent; 1988 A Far Cry From Kensington; 1996 Reality And Dreams. Some non-fiction: 1952 Child Of Light: A Reassessment Of Mary Shelley; 1992 Curriculum Vitae (autobiography). Honours: 1993 Dame of the British Empire. · Aiding And Abetting will be published by Penguin in September.

webTitle: Self Portrait in a Straw Hat, Elizabeth Louise Vigee Le Brun (1782)

fields.headline: Self Portrait in a Straw Hat, Elizabeth Louise Vigee Le Brun (1782)
fields.trailText: · View the work online
fields.body:
· View the work online

Artist: Elizabeth Louise Vigee Le Brun (1755-1842), friend and favourite artist of Marie- Antoinette, and the most stylish portrait painter in France on the eve of the Revolution.

Distinguishing features: Mon Dieu, she's no Amazon, this Vigee Le Brun, but a true woman - and yet what an artist! That's what she wanted her contemporaries to say when they saw this seductive, confident, intellectual, pastoral, spontaneous, erudite... just listing the attributes the painting attributes to its subject and creator is exhausting.

Vigee Le Brun looks at us frankly, holding a painter's palette that isn't aggressively asserted but is just there. She is dressed in a self-consciously natural style that shows she has read Rousseau she has a rustic straw hat, no powder, unkempt hair (a style she took credit for introducing to the French court). Her decolletage is revealing, not unseemly, and if you thought the rustic garb meant she was poor, look at those earrings.

Vigee Le Brun's father was an unsuccessful painter she easily eclipsed him. She became a star of the biennial public art exhibition, the Salon, specialising in portraits of courtiers, their children, and, most importantly, her friend the Queen. She and Marie-Antoinette shared a cult of simple things uncomfortably at odds with the wealth of the court. Like Marie-Antoinette, Vigee Le Brun attracted sleazy gossip she was said to sleep with the men she painted. This was the time of a new cult of masculinity in art, exemplified by Jacques Louis David's paintings of Roman heroes. In David's art the most noble thing a woman can do is kill herself.

So there is a courage to Vigee Le Brun's self-portrait that isn't immediately obvious, but it would have been to contemporaries. They would have recognised this painting as a version of what was then one of the best-loved portraits in the world, Rubens's The Straw Hat (1622-25), actually showing its subject Susanna Lunden wearing a felt hat.

"This painting inspired me to the point where I made my own portrait in search of the same effect", wrote Vigee Le Brun, but this self-portrait - the artist's "autograph" copy of a previous version - does much more than emulate the light effects she admired in the Rubens. Both paintings are now in the National Gallery so you can compare them. Rubens's Susanna Lunden is both more sexually available to the viewer and more timid. Her bosom is presented to us while she looks to the side the light is on her breasts, not her face. Vigee Le Brun said she loved this effect, but she has the light leading up from her semi-exposed breast into her frankly returned gaze. In the Rubens there is flesh for the male eye, yet Lunden's face is in shadow in Vigee Le Brun's self- portrait it is her entire social being that is illuminated. You can't have the woman unless you also acknowledge the brilliant painter.

Did she like it? We assume so, since she did more than one version and wrote about it: "Mme Le Brun - is she not astonishing? The works of the modern Minerva are the first to attract the eyes of the spectator, call him back repeatedly, take hold of him, possess him, elicit from him exclamations of pleasure and admiration" - anonymous report on the 1783 Paris Salon.

Where is it? The National Gallery, London WC2 (020-7747 2885).
