fields.headline: Buyers queue for Telewest
fields.standfirst: Scramble for Microsoft's leftovers
fields.trailText: A number of would be rival buyers have emerged for the 29.7% stake in cable company Telewest which Microsoft had agreed to buy, but which has become mired in regulatory problems.
fields.byline: David Teather  and Jane Martinson  in New York
fields.body:
A number of would be rival buyers have emerged for the 29.7% stake in cable company Telewest which Microsoft had agreed to buy, but which has become mired in regulatory problems.

Several of the large European telecom operators looking for a way into Britain are understood to have approached US cable company MediaOne to express an interest in taking the stake off its hands. The £2bn binding agreement with Microsoft expires at the end of June.

Deutsche Telekom and Telefonica have each made clear their intent to extend their reach across Europe, with the German company already owning British mobile phone business One2One.

The potential buyers emerged as Microsoft was dealt a blow by the European commission which sent the software group a detailed list of concerns over the deal struck more than 12 months ago.

Competition commissioner Mario Monti said he feared that Microsoft could create a technical bottleneck in fledgling services such as interactive television, e-commerce and internet via cable. The commission is concerned that Microsoft's equity stakes in UK cable companies will influence them to use its software.

Microsoft now has until July 4 to respond to the points raised; it said last night it was still confident about winning its stake in Telewest.

The setback came as the US justice department was preparing to deliver an amended version of its proposal to break Microsoft into two separate companies last night. Microsoft has decided to postpone a high-level conference designed to outline its internet strategy for several weeks because of Judge Jackson's decision to speed up the proceedings.

The conference was due to be held next Thursday. A spokesman for the company said: "This decision [to delay] was not taken lightly. This is the most important strategic event in five years. But what the justice department is talking about next week is the destruction of Microsoft, not its reorganisation."

Microsoft has been buying up stakes in cable networks worldwide with the aim of ensuring that its software will remain the standard for delivering internet and data services to the home. The group also owns 5% of the British cable company NTL and has begun supplying software to some of the company's digital set-top boxes.

Microsoft alighted on the stake in Telewest last May as part of a broader £3bn alliance between the software business and US telecoms operator AT&T.

In a complex deal, AT&T bought MediaOne and agreed to pass its share in Telewest on to Microsoft. The move appeared to have been structured to persuade Microsoft not to back a second bid for MediaOne from US cable business Comcast. Microsoft also took a 3% stake in AT&T.

AT&T last night won conditional approval for its $58bn takeover of MediaOne from the justice department.2727

Judge Jackson's run-ins with the court of appeals are expected to prompt the justice department to ask for the case to go straight to the supreme court once Microsoft officially appeals. The company is expected to do so directly after the judgment is delivered, which could be as early as next week.

Judge Jackson's public support for a brief filed by two industry associations appears to have escalated tension between them and Microsoft.

fields.headline: Maison Novelli, London
fields.standfirst: Jean Christophe Novelli is back doing what he does best, says Matthew Fort
fields.trailText: Jean Christophe Novelli is back doing what he does best, says Matthew Fort
fields.body:
'Oh, come on," I said to Drummond. "Can't we do a bit better than 'It's good'?"

He prodded at the roast cod on its bolster of truffle mash with its sauce of a reduction of balsamic vinegar zig-zagging like a mountain road all over the plate. 'Texture . . ." he said at length. "The texture is just right. And texture is very important." That was it. Oh well.

Cod. Truffle. Mash. Balsamic. It's a litany of what's been moving and shaking around the capital's kitchens for some time, a mantra of high and medium fashion. Well, who's to say that they don't taste nice when they fall into talented hands?

It has been agreed for some time that the hands of Jean Christophe Novelli are awash with talent. The man, it was generally said, can cook - even if, at one time, you weren't quite sure where he was cooking. He was here, there and everywhere. Hardly a week went by without another outpost of the Novelli catering empire opening up, or so it seemed, with the books, the articles, the TV appearances filling in the bits between. It was wall-to-wall JCN.

Then came - what shall we say? - a period of readjustment. It seems, perhaps, that Jean Christophe did not have the same flair for high finance as he does for haute cuisine. Hubris took a hand. He abandoned the takeover/makeover trail, sold off the outposts of empire, and retreated to the kitchens of his original, highly-praised enterprise, Maison Novelli on Clerkenwell Green, along with some of his longer-serving team, and that's where you find him now.

I reviewed it when it first opened a few years back, and generally liked what I found, particularly in the cheaper, simpler brasserie on the ground floor. The higher-flying cooking in the dining room on the first floor was confident, rococo stuff, a bit convoluted and rich for my taste, although undoubtedly individual, bouncing with flavours, and carried off with the flair of the supremely confident.

Anyway, having followed the ups and downs of JCN's Hale-Bopp path, I went along to Maison Novelli to see if style or substance had changed as a result of his experiences. Actually, that's not quite true. I had already dropped by for lunch, just to see how things were getting on, and was agreeably surprised. Gloriana, with whom I had dined on that day, is a stern vegetarian, and was pretty bowled over by her unmeated dishes; two first courses, as it happens. Two first courses may seem a little on the light side, but mingy portions have never been one of JCN's faults. My food, too, showed an appreciable simplification without quite returning to the brasserie bonbons of former times.

Drummond and I were out for a closer critcial scrutiny, to see whether the master's hand had lost its cunning in the fancy cooking department. Certainly, he has lost none of his taste either for the eclectic, exotic mix of ingredients or for eye-seducing plate display. Novelli's dishes are the gastronomic equivalent of Versace's catwalk pyrotechnics, although, in place of gauzy materials, he employs bushels of chervil and other light-leafed herbs to froth up all over the place.

Drummond had what was called a crown of avocado and gambas prawns with a citrus vinaigrette, followed by the cod, mash and balsamic dish of the day. I ranged a bit wider in my choices: spiced aubergine and Greek yoghurt tian, mixed leaves and roast red pepper dressing, and then chicken with Masala curry vegetables, lime pickle and dried mango. See what I mean by JCN's love of the eclectic and the exotic?

I couldn't get a lot of sense out of Drummond. Certainly he enjoyed what he ate greatly, and he has wide enough experience to know when the food is good, but "Good", and that little observation about texture, was about it for critical comment.

Actually, he's quite right about texture. You get the right texture when the cooking techniques are finely honed. Drummond's cod was cooked to the nano-second to keep the sweet, firm-fleshed delicacy of the fish, which is not quite as easy as it seems. My chicken oozed juice and flavour while being without a trace of pinkness (even harder to achieve than with fish). And the sablé biscuits that formed several floors of my towerblock pudding of wild strawberries and crème légère (very summery) were crisp and snappy, as they should be. So, you see, the technical niceties were strictly observed, too.

I don't think that there's much you can say about the style of avo and prawns. This was a clean-cut reworking of a classic, and the prawns were notably good. The cod, truffle mash, balsamic business, well, likewise. There's nothing strikingly original about it. There are dozens of versions of the dish going the rounds, but this was done with style and a sense of flavour.

My spiced aubergine and yoghurt tian was interred beneath a hill of greenery that looked very pretty but did not add much in the area of harmonious flavours. The aubergine end of the dish, however, was top-notch: lovely clear flavours, not over-spiced, but justly so, all made seductively sloppy by the yoghurt and the sweet pepper goo that was slicked around the plate.

I see no need to repeat the virtues of the chicken. The vegetables with it had been lightly curried. The spicing did not have the sure-handed clarity of, say, Paul Merrett at The Greenhouse or Vineet Bhatia at Zaika, but the dish was exceedingly pleasant, soothing, easily eaten - easily eaten a second time round, I dare say, although perhaps not if you're going on to pudding afterwards.

We did do a bottle of very classy rosé - Chteau St Marguer - but then, at £33.75 a bottle, so it should have been classy. It filled out the bill to £97.20. If you take that, and the water and coffee, away from the total, you get £54.95 for the food. That's not a small sum. But this is cooking with style and a good deal of panache, lighter than formerly - and, for my money, more fun.

Now

Europe

The Lake District:
Seven-night guided walk from Ulverston to Coniston, Derwentwater, valleys of Langdale and Borrowdale to Keswick. June 24 for £452pp. Sherpa (020-8577 2717).

Stockholm:
Restaurant festival in the centrally-located Kungsträdg rden Park between May 31 and June 4, with 35 different eateries. Flights from Scandinavian Airlines (0845 60727727) or Ryanair (0541 569569). For accommodation from around £22pp a night, contact the Swedish Travel & Tourism Council: 020-7870 5600 (Mon-Fri, 10am-3pm), 01476 578811 (24-hour brochure line), visit-sweden.com

Burgundy:
Learn to ride a horse in the countryside at St Pereuse. Pony trekking from FFr75 an hour as part of a 12-night camping holiday, starting between June 11 and 15, for £395 for a family of two adults and up to four children, including car ferry and tent accommodation. Canvas Holidays (08709 022022 canvas.co.uk).

Valencia:
A three-night stay in Spain's third city starts from £298pp from June 1 to July 12. This includes return flights from Heathrow or Gatwick, private car transfer on arrival, accommodation in a three-star superior hotel, buffet breakfast and all taxes. Kirker Holidays (020-7231 3333).

Pyrenees:
Seven-night walking holidays including full-board, all drinks, plus five escorted walks, departing June 3, 10, 17 and 24 for £293 plus Eurostar/TGV for £165. Pyrenees Adventures (01433 621498).

North America

New York and St Lucia:
Ten-night holiday, three in New York and a week at the Wyndham Morgan Bay. Departures start June 10 (book by May 31) for £1,349pp. Tradewinds (0870 7510004).

Indian Ocean

Maldives:
Departing June 23 for seven nights, all inclusive. Facilities include windsurfing, scuba diving, sailing, beauty centre and hydro-massage. £1,242pp. Cadogan (0870 0363666).

Asia

Mongolia:
Each July, the Mongolian men test their strength in a series of competitions at the Naadam Festival. A 14-day trip, incorporating the festival, departs July 2. Prices from £2,585pp from Bales Worldwide (01306 732700).

Vietnam:
Holiday on China Beach, near Danang. Once used by American GIs for R&R, it is now almost deserted. Five days' holiday is £1,153pp, with extra days available for £66, from Magic of the Orient (01293 537700).

Pacific

Hawaii:
Seven-night camping trek on Oahu for £355 departing June 11, excluding UK fare. The Imaginative Traveller (020-8742 8612). Europe

Later

Europe

England:
The Rothay Garden Hotel (015394 35334 grasmere.com.) at Grasmere is offering an all-inclusive week for 50 guests from Saturday August 5 from £595pp. The price includes lunch hampers, five-course dinners, unlimited wine plus free entrance to local attractions.

Germany:
Three night breaks to the Munich Beer Festival, which runs from September 16 to October 1. Price, including flights from Stansted and B&B, is £320pp. German Travel Centre (020-8429 2900).

The Netherlands:
The Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam is celebrating its 200th anniversary with a major exhibition of 17th-century Dutch art. Three-night trip including guided visit - from £425pp, departing July 6 and August 10. Prospect (020-7486 5704).

France:
Five-day trip to the D Day beaches of Normandy. Price of £199 includes Portsmouth-Le Havre ferry and escorted tours of all the sectors. Galina International Battlefield Tours 01244 340777.

Africa

Morocco:
Explore the souks, gardens and architecture of Marrakech, stay in the foothills of the Atlas Mountains, visit the high valley of Niss, journey through the Tizi-n-Test pass and drop down into the walled town of Taroudant. Eight-day trip from £695pp including flights, seven nights' accommodation, transfers and car hire. Departures all summer. Steppes East (01285 810267).

Madagascar:
A 17-day trip including visits to the "Last Edens" of the Masoala Peninsula and Ranomafana National Parks. The trip combines relaxing at the beach with guided wildlife walks by day and night, boating along the coast, camping and snorkelling. From £2,995pp including flights, transfers, transport, accommodation in hotels and tents, most meals, leader expertise, coordinator, guides and park fees. Departs: July 28. Discovery Initiatives (020-7924 5696).

Cruise

Starting Southampton:
Fourteen nights' sailing down the Norwegian Coast with numerous calls. Departure dates 1 and 15 July. From £549pp with two sharing inside cabin. Airtours (08701 577775).

Australasia

New Zealand:
Explore the whole country in your own dedicated aircraft - a 12-day Circumnavigate New Zealand Aircruise. Priced from £3,710pp. Details from Tailor Made Travel (01386 712050).

North America

Canada:
Take a helicopter to the mountains and ride in the wilderness on a seven-day heli-biking adventure. Price from £1,430, including flights, transfers, five nights' accommodation in Whistler and Vancouver, and two nights' mountain camping. Frontier Canada (020-8776 8709).

webTitle: 30 years on, pay of men and women is far from equal

fields.headline: 30 years on, pay of men and women is far from equal
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: This week marked the 30th anniversary of Equal Pay legislation, so you might think that pay parity between the genders is long sorted. However, the harsh reality, according to a TUC report out this week, is that the gap between men's and women's earnings is still a staggering 20%.
fields.body:
This week marked the 30th anniversary of Equal Pay legislation, so you might think that pay parity between the genders is long sorted. However, the harsh reality, according to a TUC report out this week, is that the gap between men's and women's earnings is a staggering 20% and it might not be closed for another 30 years.

The figures show that for every £1 that a woman worker earns, her male counterpart is paid £1.20. The gap is even wider for part-time workers, where the differential in male and female wages is 40%.

"Women workers have put up with poor pay because of institutionalised discrimination and the fact that society has traditionally undervalued the kind of work they do," commented general secretary John Monks.

Goodness gracious me! Hundreds of budding Asian artists turned up at the Institute of Contemporary Arts in London in response to CreAsia 2000, an event to uncover the next generation of Asian talent. The bash, organised by the talent and skills charity, TS2k with Asian Business Initiative (ABi ), was backed by the government.

TS2k is a talent and skills charity which runs Enterprise Centres in Brixton and Shadwell, where it offers free training courses covering a variety of areas including TV and film production, journalism, performance arts, website design and music.

 For more information about future events and courses check out www.ts2k.org.uk, or visit the CreAsia 2000 site at www.creasia2000.co.uk. Xebec McGraw-Hill, the interactive teaching outfit, is hosting free seminars for human resources professionals responsible for organising in-house training projects. The seminars will explain the benefits of online learning and the practicalities of getting started, developing a business case, creating an effective desktop learning environment and supporting learners. Delegates can test drive any of its 140 online courses. For booking details and venues call Suzanne Staddon on 01453-837641.

fields.headline: Hotel Kandinsky, Cheltenham
fields.trailText: This newly-refurbished Georgian building has been infused with Chinese and Indonesian objets d'art , furniture and carpets.
fields.body:
Address: Bayshill Road, Montpellier, Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, GL50 3AS.

Tel: 01242 527788.

Email: reservations@ hotelkandinsky.com

Web address: hotelkandinsky.com

First impressions:

This newly-refurbished Georgian building has been infused with Chinese and Indonesian objets d'art , furniture and carpets. Russian painter Wassily Kandinsky is honoured with posters in every room.

What are the rooms like? A Georgian shell warmed by a mixture of Asian aesthetics. Small TV, CD/radio player and hot drink facilities.

Bed test: Pillows that sink on a bed that does not.

The bathroom test: Deep bath and strong shower. Aquae Sulis soaps and lotions on standby.

The restaurant: Café Paradiso's speciality is pizza made by a Neopolitan pizziaolo in a wood-burning oven. Other options include pasta, meat and fish dishes. Vegetarians are well catered for (£25 per head for dinner, including a good wine).

The lounge: A warm meeting place full of alcoves, antique chairs and carpets. There's also a 50s-style nightclub, U-bahn, open to residents and local members.

Other facilities: Child-friendly, the hotel offers babysitting and baby-listening services. Computer games. Also: a library, billiards and conference rooms.

What is there to see within walking distance? The impressive Bath stone and stuccoed Georgian architecture of the Montpellier district and its exclusive shops. Gustav Holst museum, the spa and the ladies' college.

Within a 10-minute drive? Cotswold wildlife park; Cheltenham racecourse (from October until May); the Cotswolds; the start of the "Romantic Road", taking in some of Gloucestershire's most attractive villages.

How much a night? Single £65, Double £85, King £90, Large £120 (with special weekend rates).

Would you go back? Looking for an excuse to do so.

fields.headline: Unionists vote for Stormont return
fields.standfirst: Special report
fields.trailText: David Trimble has won the backing of the Ulster Unionist Party to re-enter a power-sharing government with Sinn Fein.
fields.body:
David Trimble has won the backing of the Ulster Unionist Party to re-enter a power-sharing government with Sinn Fein.

"Let there be absolutely no doubt that I and my colleagues will hold the Republicans to the promises they have made," he said.

The motion was passed with a margin of just three per cent, with 459 of the party's ruling council voting to accept the IRA offer on disarmament as a basis for the return to Stormont. There were 403 votes against the motion.

The critical decision means Secretary of State Peter Mandelson can sign the order to reinstate the Northern Ireland Assembly.

webTitle: Why play-offs are the new cup finals

fields.headline: Why play-offs are the new cup finals
fields.trailText: We have all been gearing ourselves up for the wrong event. In the same period that the Cup final has deteriorated, virtually every year the play-off finals have thrown up a classic.
fields.body:
As an entire nation snoozed through the FA Cup final, roused only by the sight of Dennis Wise apparently conducting some sort of Crazy Gang initiation ceremony by grabbing his son firmly by the nappy, it is now obvious we have all got it wrong in our end-of-season viewing habits.

True to form, the Cup final was a groan, concluding a decade of one-sided or negative matches which have induced nothing more than collective slumber for the non-partisan.

Not since Ian Wright re-invigorated the 1990 final with two late goals for Crystal Palace has there been a contest worthy of the name. And even then the replay that year was, inevitably, a snore-fest.

It is our own fault: we have all been gearing ourselves up for the wrong event. In the same period that the Cup final has deteriorated, virtually every year the play-off finals have thrown up a classic.

There was Swindon beating Leicester 4-3 in 1992; in 1994 Reading threw away a 2-0 lead and missed a penalty before Bolton equalised and went on to win 4-3; and last year Manchester City won on penalties against Gillingham, after drawing level so deep into injury-time many assumed neighbourly intervention from Sir Alex Ferguson and his time-warp stopwatch.

That is not to forget the game reckoned by Total Football magazine to be the most dramatic ever played at Wembley, Sunderland against Charlton in 1997, which included not only eight goals but a penalty shoot-out so long it threatened to continue into the next season.

Various explanations have been mooted for the play-offs' capacity to produce bitten nails, many centring on the added motivation of a promotion. The most plausible, though, suggests that lower-division defenders, weakened by Wembley's exhausting acreage, offer far more space than their illustrious Cup final counterparts.

A comedy of errors, perhaps, but one worth watching this weekend.

webTitle: Fiji rebels talk down military roadblock

fields.headline: Fiji rebels talk down military roadblock
fields.trailText: Fiji's tribal chiefs reopened talks yesterday with George Speight, the coup leader holding the country's elected government captive, as rebels flouted security by knocking down a roadblock to let in more supporters.
fields.body:
Fiji's tribal chiefs reopened talks yesterday with George Speight, the coup leader holding the country's elected government captive, as rebels flouted security by knocking down a roadblock to let in more supporters.

Surrounded by a human barricade, Mr Speight walked out of the grounds of Fiji's parliament compound to two barbed-wire checkpoints guarded by armed soldiers.

At the first barricade, Mr Speight's supporters scuffled with soldiers. One rebel and an army officer pointed their guns at each other. No shots were fired. Moments later, Mr Speight shook hands with the senior officer at the roadblock and a rebel supporter pushed aside the barricade to allow more backers through.

Mr Speight then walked to a second roadblock, talked with soldiers, and cleared the way for more supporters.

The incident came as a committee of the Great Council of Chiefs re-entered negotiations with Mr Speight.

After a two-hour meeting, a spokesman for the committee, Epoli Kanaimaii, said no resolution had been reached and meetings would resume today.

Mr Speight and about 60 gunmen have been holding the prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, and more than 30 members of his government hostage since storming parliament on May 19.

Mr Chaudhry, who was elected prime minister last year, is the first leader from the country's ethnic Indian minority. Mr Speight claims to be acting on behalf of the island's majority ethnic Fijians.

Mr Speight is demanding immunity from prosecution, the abrogation of the constitution and the resignation of the president, Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara. The chiefs have agreed to some of the conditions, but were rebuffed by Mr Speight.

Yesterday, a platoon of 16 soldiers and two officers marched unarmed to the gates of the parliament compound and defected to the rebels.

webTitle: EC insists: once in euro it's for ever

fields.headline: EC insists: once in euro it's for ever
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The European commission yesterday sought to quash suggestions that Britain could leave the European single currency once it had joined, and made it clear there were no circumstances under which the UK could ever abandon the euro if things did not work out.
fields.body:
The European commission yesterday sought to quash suggestions that Britain could leave the European single currency once it had joined, and made it clear there were no circumstances under which the UK could ever abandon the euro if things did not work out.

Remarks made by the commission president, Romano Prodi, in a recent interview in which he suggested it might be an option had, it said, been a complete misunderstanding and taken out of context.

Mr Prodi is quoted in an interview with the Eurosceptic Spectator magazine as saying that Britain could abandon the single currency after joining and still remain a member of the EU under "exceptional circumstances".

His words have been interpreted as an attempt to turn the hostile tide of UK public opinion by floating the possibility of a euro "get-out clause" but that now seems not to be the case.

The commission yesterday did not try to disown Mr Prodi's controversial remarks but argued instead that "a misunderstanding of language" had occurred. The idea that the UK could abandon the single currency, if it ever joined, was "totally inconceivable," it maintained.

Mr Prodi had, it stressed, been speaking hypothetically about exceptional circumstances in the distant future which "no intelligence on earth" could predict.

His spokesman, Jonathan Faul, was quick to try to dispel any confusion over Mr Prodi's remarks: "The euro represents an irreversible commitment and no new door has been opened. No exit is provided for and none is expected. The euro is for ever."

Anxious to stem suggestions that any of the 11 countries which have so far signed up to the euro could ever change their minds, the commission said it was "legally impossible" for a country to leave the euro zone once it had entered.

"It's wrong to say that this in any way contemplates the breakup of anything. [The euro] is a substantial and serious commitment and people must not feel they can deal with this lightly."

One EU source yesterday claimed that Mr Prodi had been set up and that he had no idea a private conversation with the Conservative MEP for the south-east, Daniel Hannan, would be published.

The episode is certain, however, to damage Mr Prodi who has been accused of being gaffe-prone and naive.

In June of last year the euro took a beating on foreign exchange markets after Mr Prodi raised the spectre of Italy being forced to pull out of the euro. He later claimed to have been "misinterpreted" and said he did not believe Italy's future within the single currency zone was in question.

He is reported to have made similar comments about Denmark which, together with Sweden, Greece and the UK, is outside the euro area.

He courted controversy at the end of last year by inviting the Libyan president, Muammar Gadafy, to visit EU headquarters in Brussels ahead of the Lockerbie trial in the Netherlands. EU member states were irked that he had not consulted them.

Earlier this month Mr Prodi effectively sacked his official spokesman after months of media criticism. The commission claimed yesterday that Mr Prodi had chosen his words in the Spectator with "great care".

webTitle: Intervention hint sends the euro surging

fields.headline: Intervention hint sends the euro surging
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The euro staged a dramatic recovery on the foreign exchanges yesterday after threats of intervention from a senior European Central Bank policy maker spooked the markets.
fields.body:
The euro staged a dramatic recovery on the foreign exchanges yesterday after threats of intervention from a senior European Central Bank policy maker spooked the markets.

Late yesterday, the currency was trading at a four-month high of 62.67 against sterling after gaining nearly 1p from its close in London on Thursday night.

Against the dollar it raced up nearly two cents, to a one-month high of just above 93 cents to the greenback.

Analysts said comments from Ernst Welteke, president of the Bundesbank and a member of the ECB council, were behind the rise. Mr Welteke was quoted as saying that intervention on the foreign exchanges to buy euros could not be ruled out and that the single currency's weakness "bothers us each day".

Up until now, Mr Welteke has ruled out taking on the might of the foreign exchanges without cooperation from the US. The prospect that the ECB might take advantage of the public holidays in Britain and the US to intervene and boost the euro sent dealers scrambling to cover short positions.

"There was some just-in-case buying because people thought that with both the UK and US on holiday and the market substantially thinned, it would be an opportunity," Chris Furness at 4Cast said.

City analysts now think that the euro's steady decline since its introduction 18 months ago may be drawing to an end.

"It will need to go above 95 cents before even the doubters will agree," said Nick Parsons, currency analyst at Commerzbank. "But it looks more likely that this will happen."

The euro's recent rise against sterling will be a relief for Britain's hard-pressed manufacturing sector which has found exporting into the eurozone increasingly difficult as the euro has plunged.

Mr Parsons said the next story in the currency markets could be the dollar's decline. It has been rising against most world currencies since mid-1995 and its strength has helped keep inflation in the red-hot US economy under control. "This is the beginning of the end for the dollar," he said.

A weaker dollar could add to nerves on Wall Street where fears of higher borrowing costs have dented share prices.

 Wet weather and higher borrowing costs detered homehunters last month, sending demand for mortgages falling.

Gross mortgage lending by major British banks fell in April to £5.822bn from £6.502bn the previous month, according to the latest monthly data released by the British Bankers' Association.

fields.headline: The good life 2000
fields.standfirst: Come rain or shine: anatomy of a green house
fields.trailText: Come rain or shine: anatomy of a green house
fields.body:
It's like arriving at any other family home. Within minutes, a boisterous labrador called Rover has been restrained from trying to pin me to the wall, a 10-year-old boy called Jeremy has been gently coaxed away from testing the limits of the stereo, and his mother has offered me a choice of tea or coffee. In a house that produces its own electricity and supplies its own water, there's evidently no shortage of either.

We're sitting in a comfortable lounge on the first floor of what is known as the Autonomous House, with four bedrooms and two back-to-back bathrooms below us. (There are reasons for that, which will become apparent.) Only to a visiting Englishman does this arrangement seem a bit topsy-turvy. To the current tenants, David and Helen Croaker, who come from Australia, however, there's nothing unusual about it.

Nor, apparently, to Brenda and Robert Vale from New Zealand, who designed and built the house. In 1991, they paid £69,000 for the site near the centre of Southwell, a small town with a Norman minster and a racecourse, 15 miles from Nottingham University, where they were readers in green architecture. In 1996, the Vales took up posts at the University of Auckland, but a copy of their latest book, The New Autonomous House, is lying on the Croakers' coffee table. Note the word "new". It was as long ago as 1975 that the Vales published their first work on the subject, a substantial manifesto offering suggestions for building houses that don't pollute the earth or squander its resources. Nearly 20 years on, they set out to put their theories into practice.

The new book is an account of how they did it. The house is the result. It's a building that fits in with the surrounding red-brick-and-tile vernacular, yet is fundamentally different from its neighbours insofar as it has the means to produce power from the sun, facilities to collect and store the rain, as well as a sewerage system based on recycling.

David Croaker knew nothing of this when he called round one evening last year to pick up his eight-year-old daughter, Meredith, from the home of a friend, Katie Barker. But he was intrigued by the unusual internal appearance of the house - the abundance of unvarnished pine surfaces, the downstairs bathrooms, the whitewashed walls and the stainless-steel pipes conveying heat upwards and ventilation down. Katie's parents gave him a guided tour after revealing that, like the Vales, they would soon be moving on to take up posts elsewhere.

At that time, the Croakers had been in England just a few months. David is a surgeon in Nottingham; Helen, a GP back home, is working part-time as a senior hospital house officer. They have another home close to the centre of Sydney, and 1,200 acres in rural New South Wales. In Southwell, they were renting a 70s estate house. "It was perfectly functional, but it lacked any character," says Helen.

Her husband liked the distinctive character of the Autonomous House as soon as he stepped over the threshold. "When I was told about the self-sufficiency aspect, I thought it sounded like a bit of fun," he recalls, dryly. He's keen to stress, however, that living here is not a "hair-shirt existence" of toil and drudgery. But nor does he wish to sound flippant about the damage caused by the vast majority of us who don't live in environmentally-friendly homes such as this. Pointing to the CFC-free fridge bequeathed by the Vales and the Barkers, he says, "There's no doubt in my mind of the effect that 6,000 million people are having on this planet. An ice sheet the size of Wales has broken away and is floating towards Argentina as we speak."

The Croakers moved in last August, fully briefed on their responsibilities not just in the house, but also in what remained of the large, ancient garden where it was built. Southwell is the birthplace of the Bramley apple, and a couple of wonderfully gnarled trees stand outside, along with a lawn, an expansive vegetable patch and a very unusual compost heap. The contents are derived from human excrement.

Apologies to anyone reading this over breakfast, but the subject can't be avoided. To understand the Autonomous House, we must go deep into its bowels. In a spacious cellar is housed the bulky, clinically-white presence of the Clivus Multrum composter. As the Vales explain in their book, "the decision to put the bathrooms on the ground floor was partly related to the desire to minimise the drop from the toilet seat to the compost chamber".

The two are connected by shafts so large in diameter that very little waste touches the sides. There's something about the toilet that's vaguely reminiscent of an aircraft lavatory, except that it's slightly bigger and requires no flushing. An electric fan eliminates any lingering smell in the bathroom by drawing air from the room into the toilet, rather than the reverse. The end result of the composting process is odourless, too, as well as dry, and hence easy to transfer to the heap in the garden every six months or so.

The entire flush-free sewerage system minimises water consumption. Water for washing and drinking is collected in large roof tanks. It trickles down through vertical pipes, well hidden from view, for the most part, until it reaches the cellar. There, it is stored in great vats, formerly used to transport orange juice, 20 of them and each holding 1,500 litres. Drinking water passes through a double- filtration system.

Showers come out at what David calls "a lovely pressure and nice temperature - the best we've had in England". But the Croakers have become acutely conscious of the need to conserve. "I count while I'm in there," says Helen, "and turn it off after three minutes."

The Autonomous House has never run out of water. Not even during the drought of 1995. All the same, the Croakers are constantly reassured by the sound of trickling and gurgling through the building. "It's like the rattle on corrugated tin roofs in the bush," says Helen. "On rainy nights, we stand out in the conservatory and it's music to our ears."

The conservatory is large, south-facing and, along with the solar panels in the garden, plays a vital role in heating the whole house. "When it gets over a certain temperature in here, we just open the roof windows and the heat rises to the living quarters," David explains. "We can maintain the house at between 12C and 21C the year round."

The Vales would appear to have achieved the right balance between insulation and ventilation. Outside walls are a good 2ft 6in thick and lined with concrete to hold in the heat. Windows are triple-glazed, their edges sealed with rubber. But built into the top of each frame is a ventilator, which allows air to trickle through.

"Certainly, it feels less stuffy than a centrally-heated house," Helen maintains. "And we've always got a pot-bellied stove downstairs if it gets really cold. We've had it on twice since the middle of February."

What if the solar-powered electricity ever ran out? "Then we switch automatically to the National Grid," says David.

Electricity bills are less than half what they were in their former home, where the cooking and central heating were both gas-run. Even the Vales, high priests of environmental-consciousness, are well aware of a rather more selfish benefit to be grasped from autonomous servicing: "Since 1989-90," they write, "average bills for water and sewerage alone have risen by 77% and 70% respectively, more than three times the rate of inflation."

Perhaps their best hope of spreading the gospel of autonomous housing is financial rather than environmental. A massive ice sheet floating towards Argentina seems remote to many UK residents - but offer them the chance drastically to slash what they pay to the likes of PowerGen and Severn Trent, and they might just sit up and take notice

 The New Autonomous House, by Brenda and Robert Vale, is published by Thames & Hudson, priced £18.95. To order a copy for the special price of £15.95 (plus 99p UK p&p), freephone Guardian CultureShop on 0800 316 6102.

webTitle: Teacher fatally shot by student on last day of classes

fields.headline: Teacher fatally shot by student on last day of classes
fields.trailText:
A 13-year-old student sent home from school for throwing water balloons on the last day of classes
returned and fatally shot a teacher with a semi-automatic pistol Friday, police said.
fields.body:
A 13-year-old student sent home from school for throwing water balloons on the last day of classes returned and fatally shot a teacher with a semi-automatic pistol Friday, police said.

Seventh grader Nathaniel Brazill returned to Lake Worth Community Middle School Friday afternoon, Police Chief William Smith said. He spoke to teacher Barry Grunow, pulled out the small handgun and fired a single shot, killing the 35-year-old language arts teacher, he said.

Brazill flagged down a police officer close to the school and surrendered. He was being questioned by police late Friday afternoon.

There were no other injuries and no other suspects, Smith said.

Grunow, of Lake Worth, was shot in the face, said Mabel Cardec, a spokeswoman for the Palm Beach County School Board.

Brazill had returned to school to see some students in Grunow's class before school let out for the summer, police Lt. Rachel Houston said. When the teacher asked him to leave the classroom, the boy pulled out the gun and fired, she said.

Grunow was one of Brazill's teachers, but another teacher had suspended the boy. Amanda Grunwald, 13, who was in Grunow's class, said the teacher was standing in the doorway, talking to students in the hallway when he was shot.

"He was standing out in the hall, telling everybody to go back into class because it wasn't time to be dismissed," she said. "Five seconds later he was shot."

Brazill's grandmother, Eberlena Josey, said the boy went to her house mad and wanting a key to his house about an hour before the shooting.

Josey said her daughter had called her in the morning and said that Brazill was being suspended and that he was going to have to walk home.

She said she didn't have a gun in her house. "I thought he was the best boy. He was good," she said.

Smith said that Brazill didn't cause any previous problems at school.

"This young man as far as we know was a good student, in school every day," he said. Lake Worth is just south of West Palm Beach. The school has about 1,500 students. It is a community school because adult-education classes are held there in the evenings.

Lake Worth is in Palm Beach County, the fourth largest school district in Florida and 14th largest in the nation with more than 149,500 students.

Brazill had returned to school to see some students in Grunow's class before school let out for the summer, police Lt. Rachel Houston said. When the teacher asked him to leave the classroom, the boy pulled out the gun and fired, she said. Grunow was one of Brazill's teachers, but another teacher had suspended the boy. Amanda Grunwald, 13, who was in Grunow's class, said the teacher was standing in the doorway, talking to students in the hallway when he was shot. "He was standing out in the hall, telling everybody to go back into class because it wasn't time to be dismissed," she said. "Five seconds later he was shot." Brazill's grandmother, Eberlena Josey, said the boy went to her house mad and wanting a key to his house about an hour before the shooting. Josey said her daughter had called her in the morning and said that Brazill was being suspended and that he was going to have to walk home. She said she didn't have a gun in her house. "I thought he was the best boy. He was good," she said. Smith said that Brazill didn't cause any previous problems at school. "This young man as far as we know was a good student, in school every day," he said. Lake Worth is just south of West Palm Beach. The school has about 1,500 students. It is a community school because adult-education classes are held there in the evenings. Lake Worth is in Palm Beach County, the fourth largest school district in Florida and 14th largest in the nation with more than 149,500 students.

webTitle: Dome architect attacks lack of vision

fields.headline: Dome architect attacks lack of vision
fields.standfirst: Special report: The Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Lord Rogers, the architect who once called the Millennium Dome "a huge vote of confidence in the people", yesterday condemned the attraction and washed his hands of it.
fields.body:
Lord Rogers, the architect who once called the Millennium Dome "a huge vote of confidence in the people", yesterday condemned the attraction and washed his hands of it.

He attacked the project for its lack of "a ringleader with a vision" and delivered a sideswipe at the government's attempt at populism: "We tend to go for what we call 'popular', and people don't fall for it."

Lord Rogers, who designed the dome, said on Radio 4's Today programme: "I don't have any responsibility for the odium in which the dome is held. My responsibility was for the construction.

"In terms of the content, we were not involved. I was asked what I felt about the content, and I made it quite clear that it was not the way I would go."

He said the project should have had the same creative vision as the Tate Modern gallery. "You can't just go and say, I want to make the most popular place - that isn't a vision. You could have made it a great sports centre, then it would be the best; or it could have been the best music centre.

"There was no clear, visionary person who had a clear brief in charge of it. We have many amazingly capable people in Britain and in the rest of Europe.

"I said we needed a ringleader with a vision - whether it was cultural or more sports-related did not matter ... It should have had a vision of the culture of the future."

The architect, whose buildings include the Pompidou centre in Paris, the Lloyd's building in London and the Welsh assembly building, made his attack after hearing that the Cardiff opera house has been refused a lottery grant. "It is a great shame that they have not been given any funding for this worthwhile project," he said.

On June 19 1997, when Tony Blair announced the go-ahead for the dome, Lord Rogers said this was "a huge vote of confidence in the people of this nation and their ability to create and deliver an event of world significance".

webTitle: Judicial review sought over Tyson visa

fields.headline: Judicial review sought over Tyson visa
fields.standfirst: Boxing: special report
fields.trailText: A rape support group is to seek a judicial review of the home secretary's decision to allow the boxer Mike Tyson into Britain to fight at Hampden Park in Glasgow next month.
fields.body:
A rape support group is to seek a judicial review of the home secretary's decision to allow the boxer Mike Tyson into Britain to fight at Hampden Park in Glasgow next month.

The Glasgow rape crisis centre will lodge a petition at Scotland's court of session on Tuesday challenging Jack Straw's approval of the boxer's visa request.

A centre spokeswoman, Sandy Brindley, said that it was aware that the process of seeking judicial review would be difficult. The campaign group Justice for Women was unsuccessful in its bid for judicial review of Mr Straw's decision to allow Tyson, a convicted rapist, into Britain last January. "We feel strongly, however, that his decision to make an exception to immigration law to allow a convicted rapist into the country is one that should be subject to legal scrutiny," Ms Brindley said.

"We are very concerned about the message that Jack Straw's decision gives about the seriousness of violence against women and the priority which the government gives to this issue. Given the gravity of the crime of rape, we were deeply saddened that the home secretary appears to have given economic considerations greater weight than the trauma experienced by women and girls who have suffered the crime of rape."

The development came as police in Las Vegas said that they would not be charging the boxer over an alleged attack on a topless dancer. Victoria Bianco, 24, had filed a police report claiming that Tyson knocked her to the floor and yelled obscenities as she approached him in a nightclub.

"There was a lot of information saying it didn't happen, and very little saying it did," a police spokesman said.

Tyson's impending visit to Scotland has caused outrage among women's groups and some parliamentarians. Earlier this week, a motion by the Scottish National party calling on the Scottish parliament to seek a judicial review of the decision was defeated by Labour and Conservative members.

The issue has split the parliament, which was powerless to intervene in Mr Straw's decision because immigration is not a devolved matter. It has been left to Glasgow city council to decide if an entertainments licence should be approved for the event.

Promoters of the bout with Lou Savarese on June 24 say it will be the biggest in audience and financial terms held in Britain, with more than 40,000 people expected to attend. It has been claimed £30m will flow into the Glasgow economy.

webTitle: Baan shares roll round rumour mill

fields.headline: Baan shares roll round rumour mill
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Shares in Baan, the troubled Dutch business software group were on a roller-coaster ride yesterday amid fresh speculation that a takeover bid could be on the way.
fields.body:
Shares in Baan, the troubled Dutch business software group were on a roller-coaster ride yesterday amid fresh speculation that a takeover bid could be on the way.

The shares, which almost doubled in value on Thursday, continued to climb sharply in early trading on the Amsterdam stock market yesterday but then fell back despite the bid rumours.

The latest name to be linked with Baan is that of UK industrial automation group Invensys. The Wall Street Journal described talks between the two companies as "serious" . However both Baan and Invensys declined to comment.

Baan shares have slumped from a high of €49 (£30) two years ago - when it rivalled Germany's SAP as the leading European provider of business software - to as low as €1.16 in recent days. The share price has been undermined by a string of losses stretching back over seven successive quarters and doubts about the company's recovery prospects.

Baan has recruited investment bank Lazard Freres to consider its strategic options but has yet to make any announcement. One possibility could be the sale of its customer relationship management software arm.

On Thursday news that the US software group Oracle could be interested in buying at least part of Baan sent the Dutch company's share price up to more than €3, although many analysts were sceptical about a tie-up.

Yesterday's report sent Baan shares up 14% in the first half hour of trading before it dropped back to €2.40 then recovered to end at €2.80. "Today it's Invensys, yesterday it was Oracle. [Baan] is a very volatile stock," said one trader in Amsterdam. Dealers say the sharp price movements are being driven by demand from retail investors.

Microsoft and the data network equipment maker Cisco Systems have also been tipped as possible suitors for Baan.

webTitle: Council holds confidence poll on NHS leaders

fields.headline: Council holds confidence poll on NHS leaders
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Fierce controversy over the provision of hospital services in Grantham will today reach an extraordinary climax when voters go to the polls to call for the resignation of local NHS leaders.
fields.body:
Fierce controversy over the provision of hospital services in Grantham will today reach an extraordinary climax when voters go to the polls to call for the resignation of local NHS leaders.

In a first for local government, the Lincolnshire town's district council is holding a referendum on the closure, two years ago, of in-patient children's and consultant-led maternity facilities at Grantham hospital.

There is little doubt about the outcome. The question on the ballot paper reads: "In view of the unsafe standards of services being provided by the local hospital for mothers and children, should the chairman and chief executive of Lincolnshire Health resign?"

The issue, which has implications for the government's current review of the NHS, traces back to the scandal of Beverley Allitt, the nurse who killed four children and injured nine others by injecting them with insulin at Grantham hospital.

Following an inquiry into the scandal, the hospital's children's ward was taken over and run by Queen's medical centre in Nottingham. But it was closed in 1998 after the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health advised that patient numbers were insufficient to give doctors enough practice to ensure robust services.

Lincolnshire health authority said this week: "Being treated by a doctor who does not get enough experience for want of sufficient patients is like being a passenger in an airliner flown by a pilot who only takes to the air once a year.

"This is not about money. No amount of extra money would create the additional patients Grantham would need in order for it to provide in-patient services for children or high-risk expectant mothers."

The authority insists replacement services for children and mothers are safe. These are based on midwife-led maternity care, with higher-risk cases referred further afield, and "ambulatory" children's care provided at home or at an assessment unit open 10am to 7pm Monday to Friday.

Following an objection by the local community health council, the revised maternity services have been under joint assessment by the royal colleges of paediatrics, obstetricians and midwives, which have reported to health ministers.

What prompted today's referendum, called by South Kesteven council, was the death in February of 23-month-old Tyler Foster, who had meningitis and was sent on a 60-mile ambulance journey in search of an intensive care bed.

Labour councillor John Hurst, who proposed the ballot, said: "He was dragged across Lincolnshire twice, and then into Nottinghamshire when it was too late to save him. The community wants to vote and it is our job to give them a vote."

The referendum, costing £3,000, was approved unanimously by the Conservative-controlled council. Up to 35,000 people are entitled to take part.

Today is the main ballot day, but people have been voting since Monday. A council spokeswoman said there had been queues at electronic polling booths and votes were being cast at the rate of at least one a minute.

The health authority is braced for large vote for the council's proposition, but Brenda Sills, chairwoman of the authority, and Richard Jeavons, its chief executive, have made it clear they will not resign.

The ballot demonstrates the tension in parts of the country over plans to reshape health care. People can cling to local hospital services, even when doctors say they doubt the quality and safety of small-scale provision.

In Worcestershire, campaigners fighting the downgrading of Kidderminster hospital defeated six Labour councillors in local elections this month.

fields.headline: NewMediaSpark buys rival firm
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: NewMediaSpark, Europe's largest quoted internet and seed investment firm, said the purchase gave it an edge by bolstering its balance sheet as well as offering a window to the strategically important Indian market, on which Softtechnet is particularly focused.
fields.body:
NewMediaSpark, Europe's largest quoted internet and seed investment firm, said the purchase gave it an edge by bolstering its balance sheet as well as offering a window to the strategically important Indian market, on which Softtechnet is particularly focused.

The offer, equivalent to around 24p for each Softtechnet share, represents a 65% premium over Thursday's closing price of 14.5p.

Yesterday, Softtechnet shares climbed 3.5p to close at 18p, while NewMediaSpark eased 6.5p to 53.5p.

The combined group will have more than £145m in its investment portfolio and cash resources of more than £45m.

"The specialist internet and technology strategy of Spark complements our strategy of pre-IPO investments, resulting in a combined ability to nurture investee companies from inception to IPO [initial public offering]," said Softtechnet chief executive Tony Sarin.

NewMediaSpark has offered four new shares and one new warrant for every 10 shares in Softtechnet, which was only founded in January. It floated on London's Alternative Investment Market in March.

NewMediaSpark also announced a maiden pre-tax profit of £2.85m for the period from July 26 1999 to March 31.

Softtechnet.com is an internet investment firm with a particular focus on investments in India's burgeoning internet sector. Shekhar Kapur, the Indian film director behind the camera for the Oscar-nominated film Elizabeth, is a board member.

The company raised around £26m through its Aim flotation in March.

webTitle: Weather likely to put damper on bank holiday

fields.headline: Weather likely to put damper on bank holiday
fields.standfirst: The weather: special report
fields.trailText: Britain is set to maintain its tradition of truly awful Spring bank holiday weather this weekend as weathermen reported a wet and windy weekend.
fields.body:
Britain is set to maintain its tradition of truly awful Spring bank holiday weather this weekend as weathermen reported a wet and windy weekend.

The Met office has predicted showers, long spells of rain, icy sea winds and maximum temperatures of 14C (57F), only a marginal improvement on last year's thunder storms, severe flooding and lightning fires.

Last month was the wettest since records began in 1766, and the weekend's temperatures are predicted to be well below the seasonal average of 18C. The Met Office predicted only a few hours of sunshine on Sunday.

In the absence of sunshine, AA Roadwatch predicted that the only severe traffic trouble spots would be north London for the Wembley football play-offs on Saturday, Sunday and Monday afternoon. Plymouth will also shut down on Monday for its marathon.

As a result of the weather, Heathrow airport expects an increase in passenger traffic on Saturday and Sunday. Around 188,000 passengers will pass through the airport, about 20,000 more than on the average weekend.

Last night roads were packed as thousands had to contend with numerous accidents and heavy rain as people went in search of sunnier weather. The AA reported very heavy traffic in all areas: "There have been a lot of accidents caused by the wet weather," said a spokeswoman. "The Thames Valley and the south coast are particularly busy areas and we expect the weekend activities to attract large crowds and, hence, dense traffic."

fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: BMW's disastrous acquisition of Rover has not discouraged other companies from pursuing strategies that look strikingly similar. This month WPP, Britain's biggest advertising agency, and Unilever, the household products group, have been on   the bidding trail for Young & Rubicam and Beatrice Foods respectively.
fields.body:
BMW's disastrous acquisition of Rover has not discouraged other companies from pursuing strategies that look strikingly similar. This month WPP, Britain's biggest advertising agency, and Unilever, the household products group, have been on the bidding trail for Young & Rubicam and Beatrice Foods respectively.

The quest is to get bigger. As markets globalise, the argument goes, there will be room only for a handful of huge international companies selling global brands. The bigger a company is the more efficient it will be. So unless management can get it to be the number one or two it will lack the economies of scale to be competitive.

But the evidence does not support this. Over the last decade, in more than 80% of markets, the largest companies have not generated the highest returns to shareholders, who have generally done better buying into smaller competitors. The winners have not been the biggest - Boeing, GM, IBM, Proctor & Gamble. It has been their smaller competitors - General Dynamics, Dell and Colgate - which have produced the better financial results.

When companies go for the top spot via acquisitions, the results are even worse. Two-thirds of acquisitions fail to generate value for the acquirer. The reasons why acquisitions so often fail are easy to understand. Acquirers pay a bid premium amounting typically to above 40% more than the market thinks the target is worth. The purchase then only makes sense if the buyer can make truly remarkable improvements in the acquired company's business.

These improvements are the so-called synergies that are supposed to occur. The most obvious are cost savings from eliminating duplicate jobs, closing offices and economies of scale in purchasing. Other synergies occur when the acquirer can boost the sales of the new company by improving its marketing and cross-selling its products.

But these synergies are much harder to achieve than managers think. For BMW, unit costs at Rover actually rose and market share halved. The merger destroyed value at both companies. Both declined in competitiveness. Billions were wiped off the value off BMW. Looking at WPP's quest for global dominance in the advertising industry, it is even harder to see where synergies can come from.

The history of such strategies is bleak. A decade ago, first Saatchi and Saatchi and then WPP itself achieved the global number one position in advertising following major acquisitions. But their successes were very short-lived and the losses their shareholders sustained exceeded even those of BMW's. Saatchis had to extract itself painfully from its acquisition. It has taken WPP's share price 13 years to recover.

The problem with acquisitions in the advertising industry is that there is little scope for cost savings. Groups like WPP are holding companies that do not integrate their acquisitions. Its new acquisition, Y & R, will continue as before as a stand-alone business competing against other companies in the group. So few jobs or facilities will be eliminated. Second, advertising agencies are notoriously unsuccessful at cross-selling, which makes revenue synergies invariably illusory.

Companies create value when they get better, not when they get bigger. So often the problem with acquisitions is that they destroy value by distracting management from the key task of improving the quality and creativity of what they offer to their customers.

 Peter Doyle is professor of marketing & strategic management at the University of Warwick Business School.

fields.headline: Crack dealer, 13, faces custody
fields.trailText: A judge spoke yesterday of his "sadness and horror" over a 12-year-old caught cycling to his next crack cocaine deal.
fields.body:
A judge spoke yesterday of his "sadness and horror" over a 12-year-old caught cycling to his next crack cocaine deal.

"This is a serious and very, very worrying case," judge Quentin Campbell said after the schoolboy was found guilty of possessing possessing heroin and crack cocaine with intent to supply, at Inner London crown court.

The youth, who cannot be named due to legal reasons, was found with nearly £1,000 in cash and narcotics in his pocket, the court was told.

After warning the child he faced a risk of custody, the judge remanded him into local authority care for a month, took off his wig, rubbed his hands across both eyes and added: "Isn't it sad."

The court heard how the schoolboy, now 13, had repeatedly tried to escape as plain-clothed police found 18 rocks of crack cocaine and two wraps of heroin worth £500 in his left tracksuit trouser pocket.

Underneath them was £400 in cash. More crack cocaine, a small amount of cannabis and a further £1,600 was found shortly afterwards at a friend's flat, which the youngster had moved into after a row with his mother.

Detective Constable Ian Dickson, one of those who helped arrest and handcuff the boy, said after the trial: "This has to be a terrible indictment on society."

The youth showed no reaction as the foreman made it plain his defence of duress had been rejected by announcing majority 10-2 convictions on one count of possessing nearly 5 grams of crack cocaine and just over 700 milligrams of heroin, both with intent to supply.

The boy had spent the two-day trial sitting in the well of the court between his mother and his solicitor.

The court had heard how the youngster, acquitted at another court last week of two counts of robbery, was spotted cycling with a 15-year-old youth, by police last September in south London.

Detective Constable Lesley Crofts recalled how she confronted the defendant while a colleague approached the older youth.

"As soon as I showed him my warrant card he slid off his bike and attempted to run away," she said.

"So I took hold of his arm, said I was going to search him and asked if he was carrying anything he shouldn't."

In evidence the youth repeatedly told the court he had been "frightened" of the older, much bigger boy arrested with him and felt he had no choice but to obey him when told to look after the drugs and money.

But in summing up the judge made it clear that for the child's duress defence to succeed he would have to have really believed that disobedience would result in "death or serious injury".

Simply being in awe of somebody was not enough. Press Association

webTitle: An old cast can steal the show

fields.headline: An old cast can steal the show
fields.standfirst: Prices for antique fishing tackle have started to chase those of golf memorabilia. Stewart Dalby reports on a very reel world
fields.trailText: Prices for antique fishing tackle have started to chase those of golf memorabilia. Stewart Dalby reports on a very reel world.
fields.body:
Anyone who has ever been a keen angler knows that it is common to become an indiscriminate accumulator of equipment. As you learn more about the sport you just want more gear. You need different rods for fly-fishing, spinning and coarse fishing, and different reels. Then there are all the ephemera, floats and flies and boxes to put them in. Sea fishing is in a category of its own with multiplier reels, weights, feathers and lures.

But anglers do not just buy new, state-of-the-art equipment. Many move towards collecting old and antique fishing tackle and memorabilia, anything from books and catalogues to reels, lures and floats. Some buy the equipment to use, others to admire or mess around with on a rainy day.

Neil Freeman at Angling Auctions in Hammersmith, London, which he says is the world's leading specialist auctioneers, says: "About 90% of the people who buy are fishermen or former fishermen."

Chris Hewitt at Phillips auction house in London agrees. He holds two dedicated auctions a year that are well attended. "There is a constantly growing interest. It is mostly anglers. There are a few investors," he says.

And there are a lot of anglers, an estimated four million in the UK. The Dutch and the Germans are great fishing nations and the Japanese developed a craze for fishing in the good times of the 80s. The Americans are also enthusiastic, especially for big game fishing.

Neil Freeman says: "When I started in the 80s there was a handful of private clients; the rest were dealers. So prices were dealer-led. We have tried to build up a big client database around the world. The idea was to make fishing tackle like golf ephemera, where some fancy prices have been seen."

In this, auctioneers and dealers like Freeman have been helped by the number of specialised books published. In England there have been The Best of British Baits by Chris Sanford and Hardy Brothers, The Masters, the Men and Their Reels by John Drewett. These have helped fishing tackle to become like golf items in that prices for really rare and well-made pieces have rocketed.

Hardy Brothers' reels are top of the range. John Stephensen, who runs The Tackle Exchange in Stoke-on-Trent, Staffordshire, says: "To collectors they are the best. They have precision engineering and are run on ball bearings. With ivory handles they can still be used today."

Hardy Brothers was a small firm of gunsmiths and cutlery makers founded in Alnwick, Northumberland in 1872. In 1886 it turned to making sports goods equipment and has been making them ever since. Four years ago a small brass reel measuring 2.5 inches was sold at auction for £17,000. It was a Hardy Perfect made in 1891, one of the first to be produced and extremely rare.

This price was topped this week, however, when the White-Wickham Big Game Sea Fish Reels, which were estimated at £15,000 to £25,000, sold at the Phillips Fishing Tackle and Piscatoriana sale on Tuesday for £48,000. These were made in 1929 to the specification of Huntington White Wickham, a well-known big game fisherman, who was an Ameri can, lived in England and fished in New Zealand. The reels are stamped No 1 and No 2 on to their respective drag wheels and, according to the Drewett book, only two are known to be in existence.

Chris Hewitt reckons 10 years ago even these reels would have only fetched £1,000. There has been a similar inflation in lures (baits). Chris Sandford's book has had a similar effect. Neil Freeman said he recently sold a very rare fish-shaped lure for £5,000 which would have realised £50 10 years ago.

But these are rare items. Not all reels fetch these prices. John Stephensen recommends people look at Nottingham reels. These are cheap and easy to find and can be bought for around £50 upwards. They were first made in the 1830s of wood, often with brass fittings, and are three to four inches in diameter. Other well-known makes of reels include Van Hofe, Abu, Illingworth, and Farlows on sale at Phillips from £80 and, as we have seen, up to £48,000.

It is not just reels. At the Phillips sale there were some 400 items including some wonderful ephemera. Rods used to be made of split cane, before the lighter carbon fibre ones came into vogue. Rods do not fetch the same prices as reels as they are more difficult to display. A Chapman "550" 10ft built cane Avon Rod three-piece, also on sale at Phillips, was offered at £80 to £90. A Victorian wicker creel, late 19th century, was priced at £60-£80. Fish in glass cases were anything from £80 to £1,000. These prices are higher than they were five years ago, but still affordable. The Sandford and Drewett books were privately printed and are available at Phillips, Bayswater, but are expensive.

 For further information, telephone Phillips, 020-7313-2700, Angling Auctions Hammersmith, London, 020-8749-4175, The Tackle Exchange, Dresden, Stoke-on-Trent, Staffordshire, 01782-599858.

webTitle: Conveyancing at the speed of light

fields.headline: Conveyancing at the speed of light
fields.trailText: New legislation should prove the first step towards speeding up England and Wales' antiquated conveyancing system.
fields.body:
New legislation should prove the first step towards speeding up England and Wales' antiquated conveyancing system, writes Richard Colbey.

Clause 8 of the Electronic Communications Bill, which came into force this week, will enable documents needed to buy and sell a house to be transmitted in a binding form via the internet. But only once fundamental reforms are made to the Land Registration Act will the bureaucratic hold-ups of conveyancing be eliminated.

Law Commissioner Charles Harpum summed up the modern view on this Act, unchanged since 1925: "It is a terrible piece of legislation. It is only because the staff at the Land Registry are remarkably sensible and efficient that it works at all." It creates a system which means the Register does not always show the true owner. There is a gap between transfer and registration when the old owner still appears on the Register.

This can lead to fraudsters selling the same property twice. While the Land Registry does pay compensation in that situation, the risk would be eliminated by making transfer and registration simultaneous. Better drafted legislation could probably have achieved that 75 years ago. Modern technology would make it very easy.

The process of reform is slow. The Law Commission made recommendations in September 1998 which should make conveyancing faster and more secure. The legislation is now in the hands of parliamentary draftsmen and is unlikely to be ready much before the end of the year. Then there will be further consultation, so that it is unlikely to become law until well after the next general election.

Once the law is changed solicitors will be able to make instantaneous pre-sales checks to establish who owns land. It will thus theoretically be possible to complete the process of buying a house within an hour. But even these reforms are unlikely to remove one barrier to most transactions, the "local search".

This is information provided to prospective buyers by the local authority about matters such as new roads and planning restrictions. The vast majority of these searches, for which authorities charge more than £100, find nothing untoward. Many conveyancers think they are unnecessary, but mortgage lenders insist on them.

Getting the answers from the authority can take weeks. A personal search speeds the process up, but a personal search will not be accepted by all mortgage companies.

A pilot scheme to allow this information to be obtained by e-mail has been launched in Bristol. But it does little more than eliminate postal delays. Only once searches of local authority databases can be made online will the delay be eliminated.

This is unlikely to be incorporated into any planned legislation; it may be decades before land law catches up with computers.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister

fields.headline: Right at the cutting edge
fields.standfirst: It's time to tackle that overgrown lawn again - Richard Nelsson offers a comprehensive guide to finding a perfect mower
fields.trailText: It's time to tackle that overgrown lawn again - Richard Nelsson offers a comprehensive guide to finding a perfect mower.
fields.body:
It has been called the latest in cutting-edge technology. Last week news emerged that a lawnmower has been developed that not only cuts the grass but also acts as a guard dog.

While the details are still secret, it is believed that this robot mower will be fitted with infra-red detectors to check for intruders in the garden, while an early warning system will deter thieves. But for the thousands of gardeners planning to cut the grass this weekend, a more pressing concern is whether the machine will help create a tennis court-like lawn.

There are lawnmowers to suit every size of garden and pocket. Traditional manual and electric powered models are ideal for small to medium sized gardens, while petrol-driven ones are more suitable for larger areas.

Prices range from around £40 to more than £1,000, but £100 will buy a reliable machine.

The lawnmower was invented in 1830 by Gloucestershire engineer Edwin Beard Budding and his design, using a heavy roller and a cutting cylinder, was not that different from the manual ones that are used today. The most popular self-propelled mowers though, like the Qualcast Panther 30 (£45), have large side wheels and are light to carry.

While manual mowers are good for those who like to combine grass cutting with keeping fit, many gardeners prefer electric ones as they are easy to use and require little maintenance. They come either with a 10-15 metre lead or are cordless, running on rechargeable batteries. There are three types; rotary mowers that hover, rotary mowers with wheels and the cylinder mower.

If you're after a classic striped lawn effect, look for a wheeled cylinder machine. The Qualcast Concorde 30 (£89) is a lightweight model that has a grass collector at the front and is perfect for straight cutting.

To mow under trees and around ornaments it is better to opt for a hover. Inspired by the hovercraft, these work by a fan building up air which allows the machine to float while a horizontal rotating blade cuts the grass.

Since the 60s the name synonymous with this design has been Flymo, short for flying mower.

The Flymo Turbo Lite 330 (£70) will cut in any direction and is light enough to hang up in the garden shed. Like many hovers it doesn't have a grass box; clippings are chopped up and returned to the lawn as a fine mulch. If you'd rather vacuum them up, the Flymo Turbo Compact 330 (£100) has a large grass collector box with a light to show when it is full.

The problem with electric leads is that they limit the distance you can mow and can be dangerous in wet weather. It is essential to use a Residual Current Device (RCD) which automatically shuts down the power in case of accident.

For peace of mind look for a cordless machine powered by a rechargeable battery. The main point to consider is whether there is enough power to cut all of your lawn in one go. They can also take up to 24 hours to charge up. One of the more powerful models is the Bosch ARM 36 ACCU (£340), while a Flymo cordless such as the RC320 (£200) will mow a lawn the size of a tennis court.

If you're unsure of what type you require, it may be worth looking at the Black & Decker GF 834 4x4 (£100). This is a four-wheel steering mower which combines the manoeuvrability of a hover with the efficiency of a traditional mower. Rear castors can be locked to mow in straight lines while, unlocked, it can mow up hills and around flower beds.

For really big gardens, though, it is essential to get a petrol driven mower as they can run for a much longer time and there are no troublesome cables to get in the way. The first ones appeared in the 1890s and a collection of vintage grass-cutters can be seen at the Lawnmower Museum in Southport. Unlike the early machines, modern ones run on unleaded fuel and have cleaner emissions. The Honda HRG 415 (£205) has a 4.5hp four-stroke engine and five cutting heights as well as electric ignition. Hayter, which has been in the mower manufacturing business for more than 50 years, produces a wide range of domestic and industrial mowers. Its classic Hayterette costs £479, while the cheapest is the reliable Harrier 41 at £399.

The problem with most mowers is that, while you're cutting the grass, your neighbours may want to spend their bank holiday relaxing in peace. To combat noise pollution, Qualcast have produced the Cobra Quiet 32 (£120 for lead, £200 for cordless) which is claimed to be much quieter than other mowers. The noise is dissipated by holes drilled into both ends of the blade.

Possibly the quietest mower on the market is the Husqvarna (£1,699) which is self-powered using solar panels. It doesn't have guard dog qualities but it's designed with the truly lazy gardener in mind as you simply punch in a code and off it goes, gently cutting the grass with three rotary blades. The cuttings are returned back to the earth as fertiliser.

A thin wire is pegged around the edge of the lawn and whenever the machine touches this, it reverses and heads off in a different direction.

The Robomow (£499), powered by rechargeable battery, follows the same principle and can even be driven back to the shed with a remote control.

If it's a quiet, rambling grass cutter that you're after though, it may be cheaper to invest in a sheep.

webTitle: Police inquiry into grant by agency

fields.headline: Police inquiry into grant by agency
fields.standfirst: Government redevelopment money was allegedly diverted
fields.trailText: Whitehall auditors investigating a former government agency which spent hundreds of millions redeveloping parts of the north-east have uncovered potential evidence of criminal behaviour, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Whitehall auditors investigating a former government agency which spent hundreds of millions redeveloping parts of the north-east have uncovered potential evidence of criminal behaviour, it emerged yesterday.

Police have launched an inquiry into one deal involving Teesside Development Corporation after allegations by local MPs over the past three years.

But in a report for ministers, likely to be published shortly, auditors from the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions will say they have been unable to prove or disprove other allegations against the agency, which was wound up two years ago.

Sources say the allegation refers to a grant passed by the corporation to a company and allegedly subsequently diverted.
