fields.headline: 'Skylarking' soldier wins damages claim
fields.trailText: A former Grenadier Guardsman who fell from an army truck when drunkenly showing off in front of a car-full of girls has won the right to substantial compensation from the Ministry of Defence.
fields.body:
A former Grenadier Guardsman who fell from an army truck when drunkenly showing off in front of a car-full of girls has won the right to substantial compensation from the Ministry of Defence.

Almost all the guardsmen on board were "plastered" when Christopher Jebson, then 21, tried to climb on to the roof of the truck in an attempt at "urban surfing", three appeal court judges heard.

Behind the lorry were four girls in a car and some of the guardsmen could not resist "showing off, skylarking and fooling around," said Bill Braithwaite QC, representing Mr Jebson.

Mr Jebson suffered grievous head injuries and brain damage in the 1995 accident, but his damages claim against the MoD was dismissed by a high court judge las t May.

That decision has now been reversed by Lord Justice Kennedy, Lord Justice Potter and Mr Justice David Steel, who ruled the MoD 25% responsible for the accident.

The ruling means Mr Jebson is now due "substantial" compensation for his plight. The MoD was also ordered to pay the action's legal costs.

The truck was moving at 40-50 mph on a slip road joining the M275 near Portsmouth when Mr Jebson, of Bulwell, Nottingham, fell on to the road. His injuries were so severe he had to be discharged on medical grounds in February 1996.

The court heard the soldiers had been driven into Portsmouth for a night out. During the journey back to barracks they started to show off, skylark and fool around in front of the car carrying the girls.

The girls saw three guardsmen clamber on to the tailgate before Mr Jebson stood up and tried to clamber on to the roof. It was then that he tumbled headlong on to the road.

Mr Braithwaite told the court that, had there been someone in authority in the back of the truck supervising the guardsmen's behaviour, the accident would never have happened.

The hearing continues.

webTitle: Musical vanguard whips up ice cream jingle symphony

fields.headline: Musical vanguard whips up ice cream jingle symphony
fields.trailText: A composition for eight musicians, four ice cream vans and four ice cream tricycles is to be given its world premiere this weekend on a canal bank in Birmingham.
fields.body:
A composition for eight musicians, four ice cream vans and four ice cream tricycles is to be given its world premiere this weekend on a canal bank in Birmingham.

Music For Ice Cream Chimes, lasting up to 32 minutes, incorporates a selection of the familiar tunes used to announce the arrival of the vans - Greensleeves, Oranges and Lemons, and I Do Like To Be Beside the Seaside.

"The piece has turned out to be a battle between my jazz modality and European tonality," said the composer, Nigel Goss, who teaches in Manchester. "When I had finished it, I asked myself what I had done. But after a rehearsal I realised it had really moved on my composition process."

The piece, performed with sponsorship from the ice cream firm Walls, will launch the Splash canal festival in the heart of Birmingham on Bank Holiday Monday, and will also form part of Music Live, the BBC's five-day national music festival.

For the first 18 minutes, the vans and tricycles will line up in an arc in front of the eight players on stage. "This part involves a dialogue between the ice cream chimes and the musicians," said Mr Goss.

"All we ever hear of the chimes is a fragment. I have used the model of a Martian who comes down to earth, hears the chimes, and tries to rationalise them by making a piece of music without knowing the standard rules of composition.

"The eight jingles will be played simultaneously. I have then taken samples of this chaos and used them as motifs for development."

For part two, each instrumentalist (from a line-up that ranges from accordion to bass trombone) will pair up with one vehicle to journey around Brindleyplace, a canal-side area of shops and restaurants, for a series of duets ranging from five to 14 minutes in length.

Titles include Licks For Bassoon and Deep-Fried Ice Cream, while another more exotic composition is called An Unfortunate Moment in the Life of the British Fighting Metronome for trike and bass trombone - a recollection of how second world war pilots used motorcycle combinations for mock dog-fight training when Spitfires were in short supply.

"You could put the work in Tate Modern because it's a happening," said Mr Goss.

The team of vans comprises one modern state-of-the-art plus three classics, one a rare 1963 left hand drive vehicle based on the old Ford Anglia. One of the trikes dates from the 1920s, another from the 1930s, and two are modern. The vehicles have been supplied by Whitby Morrison of Crewe, the world's largest specialist manufacturer of ice cream vehicles.

"I found the idea fascinating," said Stuart Morrison, the company's managing director, who will be driving one of the vans. It took quite a while to set up but I have been very impressed by the standard of the musicians. The way the piece relates to the ice cream vehicles has to be heard to be believed. It promotes the business in a most positive light."

Mr Morrison, who has helped write a history of the ice cream van, added: "We all take ice cream chimes for granted, but I don't think there can be a single person in the country who has not had an ice cream from a van. It's part of our heritage."

The company has 26 historic vehicles and plans to open a museum when the collection reaches 50.

webTitle: Millennium projects pass the numbers test

fields.headline: Millennium projects pass the numbers test
fields.standfirst:
As the dome wilts under continuing criticism, the popularity of other major schemes suggests they will leave a more lasting legacy
Special report: The Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: As the dome wilts under continuing criticism, the popularity of other major schemes suggests they will leave a more lasting legacy.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, Kirsty Scott, Martin Wainwright, Geoffrey Gibbs and David Ward
fields.body:
The millennium commission used to boast of the dome as the jewel in its crown. These days it points out loudly that far more of its money - 75% of around £2bn - has gone on dozens of large and thousands of small projects around the country, mostly finished on time, on budget, and a source of pride and pleasure to their communities.

The millennium village halls, bridges, village greens and woodlands will mark the date for generations to come, when the memory of the dome has faded into a faint blush of embarrassment.

Most of the funds, £1.3 bn, have gone on 200 new and renovated buildings, from the towering mass of Tate Modern to a community hall in the Hebrides, on environmental projects and visitor attractions at more than 3,000 new sites.

Among the 27 capital projects, each of which got a grant of over £15m, a handful were the so-called "landmark" sites, including Tate Modern, the Lowry, and the National Botanic Gardens of Wales, which got grants of around £50m.

As the dome descends into further difficulties, just how well are the other millennium projects faring?

Dynamic Earth

There's an awkward symmetry between Scotland's showcase millennium attraction, opened last July, and the country's new parliament building.

They should be neighbours; matching flagship projects for the historic quarter of Holyrood. But while the parliament remains an empty construction site, hampered by red tape and rising costs, Dynamic Earth is up, open and earning a reputation as one of the country's most popular tourist destinations. The centre tells the story of the planet in a series of audio-visual displays. Using wide-screen film projection, simulated earthquakes, virtual flyovers and hands-on exhibits, it takes visitors from the big bang through to an uncertain future. On the way they will come across a volcano erupting beneath their feet, a rainforest downpour, and the chill of the polar regions. Built on an industrial wasteland gifted to the city by a brewery firm, it is housed in a three-storey building designed by Sir Michael Hopkins with a translucent tented roof and a natural stone amphitheatre for a forecourt. Its chief executive, Julia Fawcett, who worked previously on the Granada Studios Tour, said Dynamic Earth was 30% ahead of its revenue targets and cautiously optimistic about the future.

Cost: £34m; £15m lottery money.

Expected numbers: 434,000 a year.

Numbers so far: (July 1999 to May 2000): 480,000.

Verdict: Tracey Preiss, 35, from York shire: "I thought it was great. I was expecting more interactive exhibits, however. I would give it a seven out of 10." Stephanie Florence, nine, from Maryhill, Glasgow, visiting with her primary school class: "I loved the time machine when you go down in the lift, with all the pictures; and the volcano when the floor was moving underneath your feet. It's really good."

National Cycle Network

The longest, most accessible and potentially best-used of all the millennial attractions is the National Cycle Network, which opens with a two-wheeled bonanza in Birmingham next month.

The 5,000 mile route for cyclists and walkers threads across Britain, linking former railway lines and forest tracks with canal towpaths and stretches of minor road equipped with bike lanes or traffic calming measures.

Made up of hundreds of self-contained parts, it is scheduled to double to 10,000 miles by the end of 2005.

"We haven't had this problem of a huge millennium attraction trying to encourage people to come to a single site," said Richard Tibbingham of Sustrans, the sustainable transport group behind the project. "Everyone can be sure that a part of the National Cycle Network will be close to where they live."

Organisation has also been modest and local. Cautious housekeeping has saved the network from serious financial flak, while the number of users of the first links to open has headed off criticism of empty cycle lanes or over-lavish track-laying on rural stretches. "We think we're the most egalitarian of the big millennium projects," said Mr Tibbingham."

Cost: £200m. £43.5m lottery money.

Expected numbers: 100m cycle trips and 40m walking trips a year.

Numbers so far: The 15 mile Bath-to-Bristol link - 1.5m cycle trips in its first year. Crude indicators suggest forecast will be exceeded.

Verdict: Success so far. Devon police officer Brian Askew: "I bike to work - 10 miles between Torrington and Bideford - on a route that's safe day and night. It's a nice sedate ride and it clears your head coming back from work."

National Botanic Garden of Wales

Boasting the world's largest single span glasshouse and one of the longest herbaceous borders in Europe, the National Botanic Garden of Wales opened this week, aiming to be the model for the environmentally sustainable garden of the future.

The first national botanic garden to be created for 200 years, situated in the Towy valley near Llanarthne, Carmarthenshire, it is expected to become one of Wales's leading visitor attractions but is also ded icated to scientific research, conservation and education. Conservation projects will include work to preserve Britain's rarest tree, Sorbus Leyana. The gardens have been established in 568 acres of historic parkland at Middleton Hall, the country estate designed for the financier William Paxton. They mix carefully restored regency buildings with Norman Foster's glasshouse, a tilted glass dome housing myriad plants. Other features include a water discovery centre set on stilts over one of the seven lakes that form a "necklace" around the grounds and an exhibition dedicated to the Physicians of Myddfai, the Welsh herbal healers of the middle ages.

Cost: £43.3m; lottery money: £21.7 m.

Expected number of visitors. This year 170,000, rising to 250,000 a year after four years.

Visitors so far: 1,200 on day one.

Verdict: The plants will take time to mature and establish themselves but much praise from opening day visitors.

The Lowry

The Lowry in Salford opened in a blaze of fireworks and some chaos caused by building delays on April 28, a date its managers had bravely announced two years in advance. An estimated 70,000 visitors - way above expectations - turned up in the first week to see its galleries, two auditoriums and bars. Some were awestruck, not least by the brash purple and yellow of the foyer's walls and the lurid orange carpet.

Other visitors complained that they could not find the lavatories (no signs) or their seats in the smaller theatre (no numbers). "We planned to have a commissioning period of a couple of months before opening," said Stephen Hetherington, the Lowry's director. "In the end we had a couple of hours. But it's a fantastic place and the building has been so well received."

The Lowry has become a major visitor attraction and some tinkering with arrangements designed to serve the galleries and theatres has been done to cope with rush.

Paris Opera Ballet's production of La Bayadere, the Royal National Theatre's Oresteia and Fascinating Aida sold out and Opera North is selling well but other shows have played to sometimes sparse houses.

Cost: £106m. Lottery money: £68.9m.

Projected visitor numbers: 770,000 a year.

Numbers so far : 70,000 in first week.

Verdict : A huge asset for the north - or it will be when it's finished.

Special report on the Guardian network at www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/2000

webTitle: Peruvians called on to boycott 'unfair' election

fields.headline: Peruvians called on to boycott 'unfair' election
fields.trailText: Peru faces violent street demonstrations tomorrow when President Alberto Fujimori stands in a run-off election that the opposition candidate has boycotted, international monitors have declared unfair and which promises to herald diplomatic isolation.
fields.body:
Peru faces violent street demonstrations tomorrow when President Alberto Fujimori stands in a run-off election that the opposition candidate has boycotted, international monitors have declared unfair and which promises to herald diplomatic isolation.

President Fujimori, who is running for an unprecedented third term, has been characteristically uncompromising in refusing to delay the vote, despite recommendations from the Organisation of American States (OAS), the US, and several European and Latin American governments.

The election process - already largely discredited by allegations of fraud - was plunged into its deepest crisis last week when Mr Fujimori's challenger, Alejandro Toledo, pulled out of the race, saying it was pointless running in unfair elections.

A wave of social unrest has spread across the country since Mr Toledo - a former World Bank economist who appeared from nowhere to push Mr Fujimori into a second round last month - withdrew his candidacy.

On Thursday night tear gas was used to disperse protesters who had set fire to a balcony of the presidential palace in Lima. Truck drivers and teachers staged a strike in the Andean city of Cuzco, and university students in Lima and Arequipa repeatedly attacked riot police officers with stones.

fields.headline: Capital letters
fields.standfirst: The Romans know the score: suspect everyone and believe no one
fields.trailText: It was the 90th minute when Fabio Cannavaro's head directed the ball into the net. He was playing for Parma against Juventus in Turin, but it was the streets, bars and homes around Rome   that exploded in joy. The goal denied Juventus victory and meant Lazio, the Rome-based football club, had a good chance of snatching the league title from their northern rivals in the final match of the season.
fields.body:
It was the 90th minute when Fabio Cannavaro's head directed the ball into the net. He was playing for Parma against Juventus in Turin, but it was the streets, bars and homes around Rome that exploded in joy. The goal denied Juventus victory and meant Lazio, the Rome-based football club, had a good chance of snatching the league title from their northern rivals in the final match of the season.

A gift from the gods, roared my friend Massimo.

It took a few seconds to realise that the referee had disallowed the goal, citing scuffles in an off-the-ball incident not captured in replays. Victory to Juventus, and almost certainly the championship.

Rage rarely visits that open, smiling face but Massimo was volcanic. Hate and hurt were spewed at the television. It was a stitch-up; the referee was bribed; Juventus had rigged the game; they were all thieves; Lazio was robbed ...

I left Massimo to his pain and delusion. Waiting outside were 3m Massimos. Every shopkeeper, every neighbour and every colleague was convinced, beyond argument, that Lazio had been robbed, literally. Not by bad luck or a referee's misjudgment but by corruption at football's highest level.

"We're sorry, but it's a scandal," screamed Corriere dello Sport. "The poisoned league title," blared La Gazzetta dello Sport.

The anguish was real, but there was an unmistakable relish about it all. Massimo's voice dripped disgust, but you could hear the lips smack, for if there is one thing Romans enjoy more than sport, it is conspiracies. About everything.

No government can fail a confidence vote without suspicion that parties were bought by the opposition. No gallery can be burgled without hints of an inside job. No job given without whispers of brown envelopes.

Families in Cesano, a northern suburb, believe electromagnetic waves from Vatican Radio's masts are giving their children leukaemia. Some scientists think they're right. When a Rome newspaper quoted the head of Vatican Radio rubbishing the claim, the families told me it was because the paper had lucrative deals with the church.

Distrust of officaldom is not unique to Romans, but when nothing can be as it seems, paranoia blooms more vividly than azaleas on the Spanish Steps.

Some say the Italians have a lot to be paranoid about. Intelligence agencies were almost certainly involved in some of the myriad unsolved bombings, shootings, kidnappings and plane crashes of the terrorist-strewn 70s and 80s. Collusion between the mafia, police and political parties was routine for decades. Governments rose and fell through backroom deals; politics was - is - conspiracy.

Vatican-watchers wonder whether Pope John Paul I was bumped off and whether his successor's attacker, Mehmet Ali Agca, was assisted by the KGB. Massimo watches football on the Mediaset television channels - which Silvio Berlusconi controls thanks to a secret deal he made with the late and crooked former prime minister Bettino Craxi.

It breeds cynicism and fatalism, which some blamed for the failure of a referendum this month to reform the electoral system.

In the final match of the season, Juventus stumbled and Lazio actually won the championship, yet Romans remain convinced that malign forces plotted their downfall.

Suspicion is infectious. Last month, in the process of moving flat, my telephone disappeared. Only two people on this planet could have taken it: the landlady or the concierge. Both deny all knowledge. Massimo and I agree: they are in it together.

fields.headline: End of the road
fields.standfirst: Indian government poised to ditch legendary Ambassador car for modern Japanese-style rival
fields.trailText: The Indian government last night appeared to be on the brink of ending its 50-year love affair with the Hindustan Ambassador car, the subcontinent's most venerable, unreliable and stately mode of transport for officials.
fields.body:
The Indian government last night appeared to be on the brink of ending its 50-year love affair with the Hindustan Ambassador car, the subcontinent's most venerable, unreliable and stately mode of transport for officials.

The ministry for heavy industry, which is responsible for car production, said it was considering recommending that the government dumps its 3,000-strong Ambassador fleet in favour of more modern-looking Marutis. Both cars are made in India, but the Maruti company - a partnership with the Japanese Suzuki corporation - is 50% state-owned.

Although no final decision has been made, ministers are sympathetic to the argument that it makes economic sense to buy official vehicles from a government concern. They are also painfully aware of the increasingly incongruous figure the Ambassador cuts, in a capital city now full of imported BMWs and Mercedes.

"People have lost their taste for it. The Ambassador is diesel driven and makes a lot of noise. In the winter it takes time to start up. If the battery is slightly low, you have to push it to get it going. You often need help," a senior official said.

The Ambassador, which is based on the Morris Oxford, has been rolling off the production line since 1957. It has been used as an official car by every Indian prime minister since independence. For much of the post-war period it enjoyed a virtual monopoly on India's potholed and cow-infested roads. It remains the official vehicle of senior politicians, top civil servants, bank managers, generals, and taxi drivers.

But with the arrival in 1983 of the Maruti, which proved an instant hit with the burgeoning middle-class, it fell on hard times. The Amby, as it is affectionately known, now only commands 5% of India's car market, compared to Maruti's 80% share.

"It was never a particularly reliable car. But at least it was cheap. Now newer, better cars are only a little more expensive," a motor analyst, Murad Ali Baig, said.

Deepak Jain, the general manager of Hindustan Motors, which has manufactured Ambassadors in its Calcutta factory since 1942, last night denied it was the end of the road for the car.

"Our relationship with government goes back a long way. They like our cars because of their safety and comfort. People will continue to drive them." The Ambassador had undergone several modernisations, he added.

The Ambassador is likely to be replaced by the Maruti Baleno, a top-of-the-range saloon which was launched six months ago.

fields.headline: Humiliated Rafsanjani steps down
fields.standfirst: More about Iran
fields.trailText: The former Iranian president Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, a powerful figure in the conservative establishment, has resigned his seat in the new parliament scheduled to convene today, freeing reformers of a potentially huge obstacle toward change.
fields.body:
The former Iranian president Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, a powerful figure in the conservative establishment, has resigned his seat in the new parliament scheduled to convene today, freeing reformers of a potentially huge obstacle toward change.

But despite his departure, Mr Rafsanjani will continue to wield power behind the scenes as head of the Expediency Council, a body which has final say in disputes over laws between the parliament, now dominated by pro-reform MPs, and the Guardian Council, a watchdog group led by conservative clerics.

Mr Rafsanjani's resignation was announced in a letter read out on state television on Thursday evening. He had been publicly humiliated by widespread accusations that his conservative supporters on the Guardian Council, which supervised the February 18 poll, had rigged the results to give him a seat in the first round.

On May 20, the Guardian Council announced final results in the poll, placing Mr Rafsanjani 20th among the 30 seats for Tehran. The public and reformist politicians openly challenged the veracity of the count, arguing that his widespread unpopularity among youth and other key voting blocs was likely to have caused him to finish much further down the list. The 12-member Guardian Council also cancelled 726,000 votes in Tehran - a quarter of all ballots - tainting the poll.

The cancellation of the ballots, primarily from pro-reform districts, moved Mr Rafsanjani from 30th in the preliminary count to an offi cial 20th place and deprived reformers of three seats in the first round.

During the campaign, Mr Rafsanjani's candidacy became a symbol of the old guard's determination to cling to power. Many Tehran residents said they had voted against him to show their desire for political and social reform and to denounce his presidency, from 1989 to 1997, which was marked by severe restrictions on social freedom.

Mr Rafsanjani, caving in to enormous pressure to resign, said his enemies were plotting against him.

"I withdraw with all due respect to those who voted for or against me and forgive those who engaged in propaganda against me," he said. "A heavy dose of adverse and poisonous propaganda by enemies created an ambiguous and doubtful atmosphere and there are still ambiguities [about the election results] which could be used by internal and foreign enemies against the system."

His resignation ends his chance of becoming the new speaker of parliament, a powerful post which conservatives planned to use to dilute the reformers' power. Now, the post is likely to go to a politician seen as less hostile to reform.

Cleric Mehdi Karroubi, an establishment figure, has been tipped to be speaker. He is not the reformists' preference, but is considered to be less objection able than Mr Rafsanjani.

Even though Mr Rafsanjani will continue to head the Expediency Council, whose members are appointed by the conservative-leaning supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, his departure from parliament and the ensuing damage to his prestige has seriously undermined his ability actively to veto reformist legislation.

Iranian voters, particularly the young, see Mr Rafsanjani's withdrawal as a psychological and symbolic victory. It marks the decline in his legacy, characterised by authoritarian rule.

Despite his unpopularity and the growing demands for him to step down, he refused to do so until reformers in his political faction, the Executives of Construction, drafted the letter and pressured him to sign it, according to a former aide.

"With friends like these, Rafsanjani does not need opponents or critics," a leading reformist, Abbas Abdi, said.

webTitle: Russia to release 120,000 from packed prisons

fields.headline: Russia to release 120,000 from packed prisons
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Up to 120,000 convicts are to be freed in Russia, after the government yesterday approved a big amnesty to relieve chronic jail overcrowding.
fields.body:
Up to 120,000 convicts are to be freed in Russia, after the government yesterday approved a big amnesty to relieve chronic jail overcrowding.

The amnesty, adopted to mark the 55th anniversary of the defeat of Nazi Germany, the files of anyone who "risked his life to defend his motherland" during the second world war will be reviewed first. The cases of those who fought during either of Russia's wars against Chechnya will also be given precedence.

More than 1m people are serving time in Russian prisons and penal colonies, where overcrowding, bad diet and poor hygiene - particularly in the pre-trial detention centres - continue to horrify campaigners for prison reform.

Russia has one of the highest rates of incarceration per head of population in the world. Campaigners estimate that its jails hold up to four times the numbers they were designed for, and this has turned the them into a breeding ground for disease. One in 10 detainees have tuberculosis.

In 1997, a much smaller amnesty of 40,000 prisoners, at least 4,000 of whom were suspected TB sufferers, sparked widespread fears of an epidemic breaking out across the country.

Under the amnesty, which was unanimously approved by parliament, 80,000 prisoners who have less than a year to serve will be released, as will another 10,000 relatively minor offenders - mainly thieves - who are deemed to pose no danger to society.

The burden of housing and feeding the vast prison population has weighed heavily on the government, particularly in the wake of the economic turmoil of the 1990s, and the amnesty is just the latest of several aimed at cutting prison numbers. Last June there was a similar amnesty, under which up to 94,000 prisoners could have been released, but in the event only about 30,000 were freed.

However Valery Abramkin, head of the Centre for the Promotion of Penal Reform, welcomed the new amnesty, saying that the bureaucratic obstacles which had hampered previous releases had been resolved. "This one should have a more radical effect. It won't resolve the problem of overcrowding, but it will at least alleviate it."

A very high proportion of teenage prisoners are serving time for minor theft offences and should be released under the amnesty. "We know of a teenager serving two and a half years for the theft of three hamsters and some pet food from a shop, and of a 16-year-old who received a three year sentence for stealing 23 loaves of bread," Mr Abramkin said.

The justice minister, Yuri Chaika, said the amnesty would prevent future overcrowding by ensuring that another 200,000 people currently under investigation do not go to prison.

fields.headline: Dozens killed in Moluccas attack
fields.trailText: Shattering weeks of uneasy calm on Indonesia's northern spice islands, hordes of Muslim fighters launched a land and amphibious assault against Christians on a remote village on Halmahera island, the military confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
Shattering weeks of uneasy calm on Indonesia's northern spice islands, hordes of Muslim fighters launched a land and amphibious assault against Christians on a remote village on Halmahera island, the military confirmed yesterday.

At least 34 people were killed and 66 seriously injured on Thursday morning in the hour-long attack on Mamuya village in North Moluccas province, said Captain Sutarno, a regional military spokesman. Twenty-six of the fatalities were local Christians, the rest were Muslim attackers.

"Many Muslims attacked the village from three different directions, including from the sea, just after dawn," captain Sutarno said. "It was very well planned. The locals were not ready and many died in their homes, unable to escape."

Several houses and places of worship were burnt down in the fighting and hundreds of people fled the sectarian violence, which since January 1999 has claimed 2,500 lives.

Security forces were unable to halt the violence in Mamuya, Capt Sutarno said, because the majority had withdrawn to barracks after coming under attack earlier this year. Both sides have accused the military of taking sides and so they now rarely patrol remote areas, which are controlled by heavily armed gangs.

Indonesia's Antara news agency reported that identity cards found on two of the dead Muslims said they were from Sumatra, almost 2,000 miles away in western Indonesia. It is thought they were members of Laskar Jihad, a Java-based Muslim group that has sent thousands of "warriors" to the Moluccas to wage a holy war against the Christians.

Christian leaders in Halmahera were outraged yesterday that the authorities had allowed the jihad fighters into the Moluccas.

"The situation had improved in recent months," said Issac Suntaki, a local Christian leader. "Now it is worse than ever and we are having to bury women and children who were killed in their beds. There is a great desire for revenge and I don't think it will be easy to control."

Indonesia's Antara news agency reported that identity cards found on two of the dead Muslims said they were from Sumatra, almost 2,000 miles away in western Indonesia. It is thought they were members of Laskar Jihad, a Java-based Muslim group that has sent thousands of "warriors" to the Moluccas to wage a holy war against the Christians. Christian leaders in Halmahera were outraged yesterday that the authorities had allowed the jihad fighters into the Moluccas. "The situation had improved in recent months," said Issac Suntaki, a local Christian leader. "Now it is worse than ever and we are having to bury women and children who were killed in their beds. There is a great desire for revenge and I don't think it will be easy to control."

webTitle: Texas prisoner fails in attempt to sell tickets to his execution

fields.headline: Texas prisoner fails in attempt to sell tickets to his execution
fields.trailText: They were front row seats to die for and they were going for a bargain $100 each. But yesterday a death row prisoner in Texas was told that his attempt to sell tickets for his execution via the internet had been banned by the authorities.
fields.body:
They were front row seats to die for and they were going for a bargain $100 each. But yesterday a death row prisoner in Texas was told that his attempt to sell tickets for his execution via the internet had been banned by the authorities.

Michael Toney, aged 34, is on death row in Forth Worth for a triple murder committed in 1985. Anxious to have some money to fund a last-minute appeal - and, if that failed, to leave something for his family - he asked a friend to advertise five tickets for his execution on the online auction service, eBay.

"I am on Texas death row for a crime I did not commit," read the advertisement, which offered five front row seats for $100 each. "I do not know what kind of people would donate money to watch an innocent man be murdered. However, I do know that there are people out there who will."

Prisoners are not allowed to make use of the internet in this way, but Toney managed to persuade a woman who had been a prosecution witness against him but had since become a friend to place the ad. However, retribution was swifter than is normal in the Texan justice system.

A spokesman for eBay, Kevin Pursglove, said yesterday that the item had been withdrawn as soon as the company became aware of its import. "Clearly we don't want an item like this on eBay," he said. "The bottom line is, he doesn't have a right to do this."

Mr Pursglove said that Toney had violated the eBay agreement by including a long plea about his innocence when the rules stated that only descriptions of the items on sale were allowed.

A spokesman for the criminal justice department in Texas said of the plan: "Clever idea, but it never had a chance to get off the ground."

While Toney is entitled to have five guests attend his farewell, there has to be a legitimate connection and those attending have to be family, friends or a spiritual adviser.

"There has to be a relation ship and we do not consider that the buyer-seller relationship qualifies." Another criminal justice department spokesman said that Toney, as a convict, had no right to sell anything: "He could not sell popsicles on the street. This man has no rights in the free world. Period. End of story."

Even Toney's lawyer was unimpressed by his client's move. Robert Ford told the internet crime news service APBnews: "This makes him look like an idiot.

"I just hate to have clients do things like this. The courts here are very political and, contrary to what people would be led to believe, judges do read newspapers. I think they're influenced by many factors, and this is negative."

Toney was convicted of the murder of 15-year-old Angela Blount, her father Joe and her cousin, Michael Columbus, aged 18. The three were killed in 1985 after a bomb in a briefcase - intended for a different victim in a drugs feud - was left outside their mobile home by mistake.

Toney was arrested after allegedly boasting about the case to a fellow-inmate in jail where he was serving a sentence for a different crime.

Texas, the state of which the Republican presidential candidate George W Bush is governor, executes more people than any other US state.

Years ago Bob Dylan wrote in his song Desolation Row that "they're selling postcards of the hanging". Toney might concede that that still has more of a ring to it than "they're selling tickets to the lethal injection".

fields.headline: A car for all seasons
fields.standfirst:
Land Rover

Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Maurice Wilks was not happy with the clapped-out second world war Willys jeep he had on his Anglesey farm. It was 1946, and parts for the war surplus American-built vehicle were hard to come by. It was also fast approaching the end of its working life.
fields.body:
Maurice Wilks was not happy with the clapped-out second world war Willys jeep he had on his Anglesey farm. It was 1946, and parts for the war surplus American-built vehicle were hard to come by. It was also fast approaching the end of its working life.

So Mr Wilks, prompted by his brother, set about designing a replacement four-wheel drive vehicle for farmers. He was well qualified for the task. His main job was chief engineer of the old Rover car company, and his brother was its chairman.

The Willys jeep had been a rush job. The US government had asked its motor industry in 1940 to come up with an all-terrain general purpose vehicle in 49 days. One company, Bantam, met the deadline.

However, its finances were parlous and the contract for the GP vehicle - or jeep as it quickly became known - went to Willys-Overland. Willys and Ford modified the Bantam design and between them made 700,000 jeeps during the war years.

Mr Wilks's rival to the jeep for post-war Britain had to overcome materials shortages such as steel. He used flat aluminium panels for the bodywork, which had the added advantage of eliminating costly body pressing. The chassis was made of flat sheet steel plate formed into boxed-frame sections, which again cut costs.

The first Land Rover, launched at the Amsterdam motor show in April 1948, cost £450. It had three bucket seats in the front and a canvas roof. Doors, initially an optional extra, soon became standard. A metal alternative to the canvas roof was introduced two years later. The vehicle soon found a market at home and abroad, not only among farmers, but also among foresters, the police, the armed forces and adventurers. The army ordered its first Land Rovers in 1949.

Overseas sales were needed and one prototype even had a central steering wheel with a view to boosting its export potential. The first Land Rover to be exported to Australia arrived in 1948 and, full restored, it is still going strong.

By 1951 Rover was selling two Land Rovers for every one of its sedate saloon cars. They were, and still are, made at Solihull near Birmingham.

The first of the long wheelbase Land Rovers, so beloved of expedition leaders, appeared in 1954. Land Rover broke from its tradition of rugged looking off-road workhorses when in 1970 it introduced its first completely new vehicle, the Range Rover.

Despite initial mechanical problems, the Range Rover lived up to its parentage and was widely used for expeditions. In 1972 a Range Rover crossed the 7,500-mile Sahara desert in 100 days. Nine years later another Range Rover won the Paris-Dakar Rally.

Land Rover had sold 1.6m vehicles by its 40th anniversary in 1988. The following year it produced a third new model, the Discovery. The original Land Rover was renamed the Defender shortly afterwards. The new name was a tribute to its use by armies around the world but added to the myth that the vehicle had been around since the time of Dunkirk.

The company celebrated its 50th anniversary with the launch of another model, the Freelander, a small vehicle aimed at the fast expanding 4x4 leisure market.

Ford, the second largest motor manufacturer, had almost no 4x4 vehicles until it bought Land Rover from BMW earlier this week. Now its new and smaller Maverick will compete head to head with the Freelander. Mr Wilks thought Rover could build better 4x4s than the Americans. The market will now decide whether that is still the case.

fields.headline: Moss loss
fields.standfirst: Dress-down days hit the suit-seller
fields.trailText: The e-age passion for combat trousers and trendy shirts is taking its toll on suit retailer Moss Bros which warned yesterday that it would make a loss in the first half of the year.
fields.body:
The e-age passion for combat trousers and trendy shirts is taking its toll on suit retailer Moss Bros which warned yesterday that it would make a loss in the first half of the year.

To restore profitability Neil Benson, the chairman, said it would need to cut head office staff, sell off underperforming shops and scrap its plans to launch wedding internet portal ourbigday. Instead, it will take an equity stake in confetti, an established website.

The surprise announcement knocked almost a quarter off its stock market value as the shares ended at 37.5p, a new low. The group, which includes the hire company which bears its name, Savoy Taylor's Guild, The Suit Company and Blazer, admitted that it was feeling the pain of a polarisation between shoppers looking for more affordable clothing as well as leading brands. It also blamed its woes on squeezed operating margins as a result of price deflation and cost inflation.

General changes in shopping habits is also forcing the group to rethink its presence on the high street and out-of-town shopping centres, which prompted speculation in the City that it would sell off one its chains, possibly Cecil Gee.

The rationalisation announced yesterday, which follows a profits warning in January and the publication of profits figures last month which showed a 51% drop to £7.8m, will cost £12m to implement.

However, Mr Benson said the painful process was intended to improve operating profits by £2.4m annu ally by eliminating store losses of £1.3m and central costs of £1.1m.

While its sales in the 16 weeks to May 20 were 7.8% ahead of the previous year, the City took little comfort from the acknowledgement that on a like-for-like basis they were 2.5% lower.

webTitle: Japan denies fiddling key figures as it revises economic data

fields.headline: Japan denies fiddling key figures as it revises economic data
fields.trailText: The Japanese government was forced into an embarrassing revision of the nation's economic performance yesterday after criticism that it had fiddled key figures to paint an unrealistically rosy picture ahead of next month's general election.
fields.body:
The Japanese government was forced into an embarrassing revision of the nation's economic performance yesterday after criticism that it had fiddled key figures to paint an unrealistically rosy picture ahead of next month's general election.

The about-turn followed reports in the New York Times that the economic planning agency had omitted gloomy data on investment by financial institutions that would have reduced the national economic output by 0.2 percentage points in the final three months of last year.

With the ruling Liberal Democratic Party struggling to achieve an annual growth target of 0.6%, this figure has enormous political implica tions, but government ministers insisted the omission was an innocent mistake.

"It was simply a matter of data processing. There was no political motivation," said Taichi Sakaiya, head of the economic planning agency.

The finance minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, said it was "unthinkable" that the agency could have deliberately tampered with the data - the gov ernment's main measurement of the economy. "Unquestionably and undoubtedly, neutrality is assured," he said.

Despite such protestations, the EPA said it would have to change its statistics, which have also been questioned by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and several leading economists.

The revision is bad news for the cabinet which has seen its popularity plunge in the last month along with a sharp fall in stock prices, which hit a one year low earlier this week.

With an election due on June 25, the ruling party were hoping for a boost from GDP figures to be released on June 10 that are expected to show strong growth from January to March.

However, Mr Miyazawa, acknowledged that the downward revision of earlier data may now make it difficult for the government to reach its goal.

The Japanese economy will have to expand by a huge 2.4 per cent in the first quarter to avoid further embarrassment for prime minister Yoshiro Mori and his colleagues in the Liberal Democrats.

fields.headline: Underside
fields.trailText: • As the painters and decorators of the Private Finance Initiative move into the Treasury under the innovative tarting-up partnership between Her Majesty's government and free enterprise, the department's toppest of top brass are finding themselves shoved aside to make way for the step ladders and bottles of turpentine. First to get the big-E was the chancellor, Gordon Brown, hitherto housed in an office roughly the size of Mussolini's private apartments. Mr Brown, his files, pencils, rulers and pad of graph paper have been pushed down the corridor to two rather smaller chambers, one for him to work in (formerly occupied by a humble typist) and a larger room for meeting guests. The chancellor may be exiled for up to two years, we hear. Meanwhile, another refugee is Sir Andrew Turnbull, the permanent secretary, who has been shifted out of probably the Treasury's most beautiful rooms into a smaller office. Hanging tough, Sir Andrew has insisted on taking all his furniture with him - including some very swish orange sofas - but the room is not really big enough for all his clobber. "It looks like a junk shop in there," says one Treasury mole. A junk shop! Now, there's a bit of private-sector initiative.
fields.body:
 As the painters and decorators of the Private Finance Initiative move into the Treasury under the innovative tarting-up partnership between Her Majesty's government and free enterprise, the department's toppest of top brass are finding themselves shoved aside to make way for the step ladders and bottles of turpentine. First to get the big-E was the chancellor, Gordon Brown, hitherto housed in an office roughly the size of Mussolini's private apartments. Mr Brown, his files, pencils, rulers and pad of graph paper have been pushed down the corridor to two rather smaller chambers, one for him to work in (formerly occupied by a humble typist) and a larger room for meeting guests. The chancellor may be exiled for up to two years, we hear. Meanwhile, another refugee is Sir Andrew Turnbull, the permanent secretary, who has been shifted out of probably the Treasury's most beautiful rooms into a smaller office. Hanging tough, Sir Andrew has insisted on taking all his furniture with him - including some very swish orange sofas - but the room is not really big enough for all his clobber. "It looks like a junk shop in there," says one Treasury mole. A junk shop! Now, there's a bit of private-sector initiative.

 All this moving about in Great George Street is taking its toll on those first-class minds, it seems. Treasury communiqué 69/00, issued on Thursday, declared: "Chancellor confirms unchanged monetary policy committee remit," giving an annual inflation target of 2.5%. Or rather, giving a target of 2.5% on page one. By page two, Mr Brown was declaring: "The inflation target is 2.25% at all times: that is the rate which the MPC is required to achieve." (Definitions of "at all times" on a postcard, please). With the inflation target diving faster than the euro, the Treasury was clarifying like billy-oh. The target is, in fact, 2.5%, and inside the Treasury a hapless official is writing this fact out, 100 times.

 Elsewhere in the wonderful world of government numbers, the new head of the Office for National Statistics flew into London on Tuesday to take up his new post. Hardly had Len Cook - formerly head of the ONS's New Zealand equivalent - time to stretch his legs than an ONS official - unaware that this was the new boss-man - selected him to take part in an international passenger survey.

 Over in the e-economy - where no responsible person (hee, hee) should take any pleasure from the sight of web business heading south (ha, ha, ha) - the 170-page lurid green prospectus for Egg, the about to be floated banking arm of the Prudential, contains a number of gems, including this prize piece of e-babble about developing the Egg name: "We seek to build our brand by delivering an experience that encourages customers to consider Egg as 'my ground-breaking e-partner who helps me grow by making the most of my money and my life'." Oh that's so, like, deep. Prudential must just hope that, on the day, the shares aren't.

 Meanwhile, the e-est of e-commerce outfits, the First Tuesday networking club famed for bringing bright sparks and money-bags together in the same room, is starting its own venture capital fund. Bad news for fans of co-founder Julie Meyer's personal web page which, over the years, has beamed the thoughts and doings of the network queen across the world. Who can forget her restaurant reviews from her time at the Insead management school in France? Alas, the weighty responsibilities of risk capitalism seem to have persuaded Miss Meyer to cease transmission.

 Finally, R3, the modish new handle for the insolvency practitioners' professional body, is hosting a big-big seminar on June 12 to get some kind of focus on the blizzard of government initiatives to get bankrupt persons and companies off the hook more easily/to develop a real culture of risk and enterprise (take your pick). Where to hold it? The Dome, itself allegedly threatening to slide into insolvency, would have been the obvious choice, but in the end R3 settled for the new dumbed-down Barbican Centre, where the ceaseless amusement arcade racket from its wretched Star Wars exhibition ought to give a reasonable facsimile of being in the Pride of Greenwich. How they will hear themselves think is another problem.

fields.headline: Trust me, I'm the regulator
fields.standfirst: Howard Davies, chairman of the financial services authority
fields.trailText: Woman's Hour listeners once voted Howard Davies one of the country's most desirable men. Lean, trim and white-haired, the chairman of the financial services authority expects no such adoration from the financial firms he regulates.
fields.body:
Woman's Hour listeners once voted Howard Davies one of the country's most desirable men. Lean, trim and white-haired, the chairman of the financial services authority expects no such adoration from the financial firms he regulates.

As he chortles at the memory of a claim to fame few City figures can match, the 49-year-old recalls being a "bit upset" that his journalist wife and her friends found the adulation of the nation's women a "bit odd".

Fortunately, popularity is not something he craves as head of the City's super regulator. "(As a regulator) you don't want to be too popular - if you were deeply popular all the time you'd wonder why you existed," he says.

Davies is used to deflecting the brick-bats thrown during the painful gestation of the vast regulator, which from airy, open-plan offices in London's docklands will oversee all areas of financial life from investment banks to the smallest credit unions, dealing with issues from the collapse of hedge funds to the misselling of pensions and endowments.

All this for a regulatory body that will not officially have any powers until the financial services and markets bill completes its marathon journey through parliament, perhaps in 10 days time. More than 200 pages of densely packed text, the bill has involved 1,500 amendments and is still causing controversy for the amount of power it vests in Davies and his 2,000-strong team.

Latest salvo

Only this week, Rosalind Wright, head of the serious fraud office, became the latest to fire off a salvo, claiming the innocent could be punished along with the guilty because of the FSA's new powers to take civil penalties against anyone, not just City professionals, accused of insider dealing. The week before, the House of Lords succeeded in reducing some of the planned powers of the FSA to police takeovers and mergers, currently handled by the takeover panel - a defeat the government appears determined to overturn.

Davies has become deft at dealing with critics who think the chairman and chief executive roles should be split and who see the FSA as prosecutor, judge and jury. "It's complete nonsense because we are a prosecutor but we are not a judge and we are not a jury and we are less of a judge than the previous regulators because if people don't agree to settle with us we have to take them to court rather than an appeal."

As the head of a watchdog which is said to have more responsibility than any financial markets regulator in the world, his attention is already on other matters, such as his "wet blanket role" towards the mortgage lenders after detecting that they were relaxing their lending criteria to homebuyers.

He also expresses general angst about how the financial markets will react to any eventual downturn in economic growth and is keeping a close eye on how life and pensions companies will respond to the challenge of the government's low-cost stakeholder pensions.

"The one thing you know about bank supervision is that the worst loans are put on the books at the top the boom. The ones which will come back and bite them will be the ones they made when everything looked great," he says.

Davies admits that there is very little the FSA can do in practice about dealing with a downturn after an unprecedented period of economic growth, other than to "ensure our flock don't get out of hand". The sell-off in the stock markets over the past three months has helped to allay some of his concerns.

Just weeks after receiving new responsibilities for listing requirements of companies on the stock exchange after its demutualisation, this week he visited Frankfurt to tackle the regulation of a merged London and German stock exchange, a complicated and sensitive issue.

While his wide-ranging brief at the FSA might appear confusing and complicated from the outside, Davies says the bill is very clear about his responsibilities. "The new legislation says we've got to maintain confidence in markets, protect customers, promote public information and fight financial crime. Those are quite clear," he says.

Of the FSA's reputation with companies ranging from provincial building societies to foreign-owned investment banks, he says he is happy. For the first time, the regulator is charged with improving consumers' understanding of financial products and is producing booklets and holding seminars. Only this week it proposed a "decision tree" to help customers decide whether they need a new stakeholder pension.

Arming the customer with knowledge is only one part of the equation. He wants to "get stuck in" to fostering a cultural change in the way financial companies treat their customers. "The life industry has, in the past, been based on the idea that life insurance is sold, not bought," he says, bringing to mind his days as a McKinsey consultant when he adds "there is no concept of customer aftercare".

Fiercely ambitious and now a regular public speaker, he will need to make progress quickly during the two remaining years of his contract if he is to be offered another term. While rumours abound that the notoriously restless Davies is already on the lookout for a new role, he says coyly that he "certainly wouldn't rule out" staying longer if offered the chance.

fields.headline: German banker turns on investor
fields.trailText: Another row erupted in Germany's strife-torn banking sector yesterday as the head of Commerzbank clashed openly for the first time with the bank's biggest shareholder.
fields.body:
Another row erupted in Germany's strife-torn banking sector yesterday as the head of Commerzbank clashed openly for the first time with the bank's biggest shareholder.

Martin Kolhausen flung accusations of irresponsibility at Hansgeorg Hofmann, head of the German arm of the Dutch investment group Rebon - which holds 17% of Commerzbank - in a dramatic exchange at the annual shareholder meeting in Frankfurt.

His anger was aroused when Mr Hofmann told other shareholders that Rebon "will help the bank find a strong European partner" and argued that Commerzbank's investments and holdings in operations ranging from online banking to asset management were worth €50 (£30) a share - 25% more than their current price.

In response, the Commerzbank chief executive warned: "What you have said about the value of our investments increases fears about a breakup of Commerzbank. I consider this to be very dangerous." He acknowledged that the bank's share price did have room to rise, but added: "In my opinion, putting forward figures like this is irresponsible."

Mr Kolhausen was also rattled by Mr Hofmann's pledge to help the management find a strong European partner. Commerzbank is fiercely independent and though it has sought to build up alliances in Europe it is looking to do so on its own terms.

Yesterday Mr Kolhausen accused Rebon of going back on statements that it would be a passive investor. "You have once again declared that you do not wish to exercise any influence on the policies of the bank. But I take it from your words that you are trying to push us into an alliance ... We are seeking alliances on our own. So there is a certain conflict with what you are saying."

Rebon bought a near 10% stake in Commerzbank in April and lifted it to 17% earlier this month. Until yesterday's meeting the bank and its biggest shareholder had been studiously polite to each other.

Rebon has said it will not raise its stake above 30%, indicating that it could prove a long-term holder of the shares, and denied any ambition to gain seats on the bank's board. Even at the beginning of yesterday's meeting Mr Kolhausen had suggested there was no conflict between Rebon's position and the bank's own strategy.

Yesterday's public row follows the acrimonious breakdown earlier this year of the planned merger of Deutsche and Dresdner banks. Analysts are still expecting some consolidation in the German banking sector and there had been speculation that Dresdner could now turn to Commerzbank.

But Mr Kolhausen rejected any such suggestion, claiming that the failure of the Deutsche/Dresdner link-up only strengthened his belief that Commerzbank should remain independent. "The planned merger between our two neighbour banks, which was announced in February but which later collapsed, prompted us to re-examine our own strategy. We have found that a radically new approach is not needed."

He dismissed reports that a foreign bank could be preparing to launch a takeover bid.

fields.headline: Private means
fields.standfirst:
Our rulers believe in privacy - but only for those taking decisions that affect the rest of us

Free speech on the net: special report
fields.trailText: Our rulers believe in privacy - but only for those taking decisions that affect the rest of us
fields.body:
There was an interesting discussion on Channel 4 News this week between a campaigner for privacy and Tom King, who was in the cabinet in those distant happy days when we looked forward to getting rid of the Tories.

The discussion was about the government's plans to snoop on our email correspondence - something I'll be stunned if they're not doing already. King said that the interception of private electronic correspondence is essential to the fight against terrorism. That is one of those neat little phrases intended to bring discussions to a close, akin to "Because I said so" and "I'm afraid that's all we've got time for".

Our rulers invite us to believe that our safety is their over-riding consideration and that they therefore fight a lonely fight, day in, day out, against crime, drugs and a host of other menaces, such as people from other countries wanting to live here. They tell us that they can and will beat these things but that it will need eternal vigilance on their part and complete subordination on ours. For these threats to be overcome, the state must know everything about us and we must know nothing about the state. And if we're not happy with the relationship, it can only be supposed either that we have no regard for the safety of our children, or that we are up to no good ourselves.

Clearly, the state is highly selective. If the government launches a big drive against some new danger, we can be almost certain that we are statistically more likely to die from choking on a stamp or drowning in the shower. Moreover, for something to scare us, and for us to be reassured that the government is tackling it, the less we know about it the better.

One of the things that the internet has done is to widely disseminate enormous amounts of factual information. It also disseminates racism and pornography, but so do newsagents. The muck that appears in mainstream newspapers defaming refugees and promoting intolerance is far more insidious in its effect than the neo-Nazi dementia appearing on the web. And one can use the web to find out about the way neo-Nazis hound eastern European Gypsies with impunity, something you won't hear about from the lips of ministers or in the editorials of many newspapers.

I'm sure the government will make great play of intercepting racists' emails but, given the way it has assisted the resurgence of racism around the asylum issue, we should not be impressed. And I doubt whether the government feels threatened by fascists in the way it feels threatened by anti-capitalists. In fact, the new laws to deal with "terrorism" define it pretty much as anything that interrupts the smooth operation of the market.

As the threat of paramilitary violence recedes, the government has thrown the dictionary out the window. "Terrorism" now incorporates what we used to call criminal damage and dissidence.

It is events like Seattle that put the wind up governments - not the fear that an as yet unknown Islamic fundamentalist group is planning to kill us all with a matchbox full of poisoned couscous, so deadly it can wipe out Middle England and so portable it can be delivered by a suicide driver to a boot-sale in Leamington Spa.

Jack Straw did not invent state paranoia. It has always been the case that even the most respectable and well-behaved activists are put under surveillance. But the more seriously the sovereignty of Whitehall is challenged, the more vengeful the state becomes. The police are still looking for people who were in Trafalgar Square when the poll tax was brought down. I'm sure they have computer generated pictures of what the people look like 12 years older and sitting at a computer. And Cherie Booth QC did very well helping councils pursue those who refused to pay the poll tax, in the days before she was known as the mother of our first hereditary prime minister.

Today, the government seems more worried than ever by direct action, perhaps because it has done so much to convince people that direct action is now the only way forward. The government will not even reform capitalism: only the power of the informed consumer and protestor will do that.

The fact that the government dislikes the exchange of information was made clear by Clare Dyer in this paper on Monday. The local government and freedom of information bills ensure that people are only entitled to privacy when taking decisions that affect the public. And the terrorism bill means that the job of journalists is not to inform us but to inform on us. So obviously information by email is something the government would be keen to discourage.

And information openly displayed on the web can be removed by those with power. The Police Federation had a whole site dedicated to miscarriages of justice taken down in February. I only found out because someone emailed me about it.

webTitle: Sierra Leone ex-dictator living in UK

fields.headline: Sierra Leone ex-dictator living in UK
fields.standfirst:
Sierra Leone: special report
Interactive guide
fields.trailText: The former military dictator of Sierra Leone is living in London with the knowledge of the British authorities, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
The former military dictator of Sierra Leone is living in London with the knowledge of the British authorities, it emerged last night.

As British charities were told to leave the war-torn African state yesterday for their own safety, news that Valentine Strasser was living legally in London prompted outrage among human rights groups. The Home Office, the Foreign Office and police are allowing him to remain.

Captain Strasser's forces were accused of torture and murder during his four-year rule, and last night Amnesty International demanded that he be brought to justice for crimes against humanity.

Amnesty said Britain had a duty to arrest Mr Strasser for alleged human rights abuses. The Pinochet case had confirmed the authorities must take into custody and investigate anyone alleged to have committed torture, the organisation said.

Opposition politicians have also expressed anger. David Lidington, the Conservative home affairs spokesman, called on the government to come clean about Mr Strasser's presence.

Jackie Ballard, the Liberal Democrat home affairs spokeswoman, said: "This is typical of the double standards we have seen coming out of the Home Office. They are allowing someone in who has a record of human rights abuses while giving a difficult time to genuine asylum seekers."

Mr Strasser swept into power in a 1992 coup and at 25 became the world's youngest national leader. He was ejected by a further coup in 1996.

After he was deposed he studied law at Warwick University. But he dropped out in 1998 after his scholarship from the United Nations development project expired.

He moved to the home of an old school friend, Gibril Samura, in Brondesbury, north London, and was allowed to remain in Britain. Mr Samura is employed at the Sierra Leone high commission in London.

Special branch is said to be aware that Mr Strasser is in London. The Home Office and Foreign Office confirmed they were also aware. The Home Office said he had not been given asylum, but would not confirm his status. "We do not discuss individual cases," a spokesman said.

webTitle: Sri Lanka offers state role to Tigers

fields.headline: Sri Lanka offers state role to Tigers
fields.trailText: The Sri Lankan president, Chandrika Kumaratunga, offered the leader of the Tamil Tigers a role in the government late last night just after the guerrillas announced a 12-hour cease-fire to allow civilians escape a "blood bath" in the decisive battle for Jaffna town.
fields.body:
The Sri Lankan president, Chandrika Kumaratunga, offered the leader of the Tamil Tigers a role in the government late last night just after the guerrillas announced a 12-hour cease-fire to allow civilians escape a "blood bath" in the decisive battle for Jaffna town.

President Kumaratunga said in a television interview from the capital, Colombo, that she was ready to offer the Tigers' leader, Vellupillai Prabhakaran, a position in the provincial government if he ended the 17-year rebellion.

"You [Prabhakaran] can even be the leader or chief minister... of the devolved unit, perhaps even for a certain period without elections," she said. "If it is required that I speak to Prabhakaran himself in order to bring about peace in my country I shall do it."

Her offer came just hours after the clandestine Voice of Tigers radio said it had stopped fighting and would observe a ceasefire today to allow civilians to escape from war-torn Jaffna town to safer places.

"To enable people to leave... on the 27th between 10am and 10pm we have stopped the fighting. We have also told the [Red Cross] about this," said the Tamil broadcast, heard by residents in the government-controlled town of Vavuniya on the Jaffna peninsula. The broadcast came three hours after the guerrillas' deadline for the soldiers to surrender or face a "blood bath" had expired.

"Jaffna is our homeland and our fight is to recover our land," said the broadcast. "We are encircling you. So we want you to surrender. After this, we will not be responsible for the disastrous consequences."

Government officials in Colombo, dismissed the Tigers' surrender call as a ploy to unnerve the soldiers; the air force continuing bombing Tiger positions on the peninsula.

Military officers said the air force bombed rebel positions half a dozen times yesterday, specifically targeting their artillery positions.

webTitle: Bride's bid to be well groomed

fields.headline: Bride's bid to be well groomed
fields.trailText: Police are hunting a vigilante bride-to-be who is believed to have raided the home of a bridal shop owner who left her without a wedding dress just before her big day.
fields.body:
Police are hunting a vigilante bride-to-be who is believed to have raided the home of a bridal shop owner who left her without a wedding dress just before her big day.

The angry customer is believed to have taken wedding dresses, tiaras, veils and shoes worth about £4,000 from a home in Fordcombe, Kent. She plans to give the dresses to other brides who were left in the lurch when the shop, Tying the Knot, in Tunbridge Wells, closed down.

Investigating officers want to speak to a woman who called her local newspaper and confessed to having taken the goods.

The bride-to-be, who has not been identified, said she had paid £200, but when she went to collect her dress she found the shop empty.

The woman told the local newspaper that she had found the dresses and accessories in a gazebo in the back garden of the house in Fordcombe. "I was really furious," she said.

The owner of the shop, Kim Smith, 26, of Fordcombe, was unavailable for comment.

A police spokesman said: "We are investigating a theft of a large number of dresses and bridal accessories from an address in Fordcombe."

He could not say whether the bride-to-be would be prosecuted if caught. "We need to establish whether the call was genuine and what the circumstances are."

webTitle: Chello denies throwing Boo a lifeline

fields.headline: Chello denies throwing Boo a lifeline
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Chello broadband, the Dutch internet service provider, yesterday ruled itself out as a potential saviour for Boo.com, the failed internet sportwear retailer.
fields.body:
Chello broadband, the Dutch internet service provider, yesterday ruled itself out as a potential saviour for Boo.com, the failed internet sportwear retailer.

Chello, which is about to be floated, rejected reports that it was having talks with Mike McLoughlin, the Boo.com liquidator. However, a spokesman for the liquidator said talks about selling all or parts of Boo.com were continuing with a handful of companies.

He refused to say whether any of the parties which had each put down £1m refundable deposits to take part in the talks had dropped out.

Several times this week the liquidator from KPMG had thought that a deal was within his grasp. He has warned that if a deal is not struck within days, he will be forced to close the company and sell its assets.

He has already made 220 of Boo.com's 250 staff redundant. The remaining 30, including its Swedish founders Ernst Malmsten and Kajsa Leander, have been retained to demonstrate the company's systems to prospective buyers.

Chello, which is owned by cable television operator United Pan-Europe Communications, is expected to be valued at up to 4.6bn euros (£2.9bn) when 10% of its shares are floated at the end of this month. This is well below previous estimates.

Boo.com's failure and the collapse shortly afterwards of Net Imperative, an internet information business, have made investors cautious about putting more money into an already shaky high technology sector.

Industry sources have blamed Boo.com's troubles on over-ambitious technology and lack of financial controls, while the company's founders have claimed that the shareholders did not provide the help they expected.

fields.headline: Labour plan for people power
fields.standfirst:
Watchdogs could get hi-tech veto after GM foods crisis

Gene patenting: special report
GM food: special report
fields.trailText: The government is planning to establish a number of powerful people's watchdogs which will be able to block commercial use of controversial new technologies, according to official papers obtained by The Guardian.
fields.body:
The government is planning to establish a number of powerful people's watchdogs which will be able to block commercial use of controversial new technologies, according to official papers obtained by The Guardian.

Documents prepared for endorsement by Labour's national policy forum this summer include the establishment of 'citizens' commissions' as an extension of plans to introduce a consumer voice into the regulation of GM technologies and human gene research.

Ministers have admitted that purely scientific advisory committees have lost the confidence of the public, and they are determined to take on board consumer views.

The environment commission paper which contains the watchdog plan is one of six prepared under the direction of cabinet ministers, such as Stephen Byers and Gordon Brown, and gives a broad insight into the direction of a second term Labour government.

Other second term ideas raised in the six documents include measures to bring more working class people into university education, a single safety body for transport, voting on the internet, expansion of the role of the UN, an end to the dogmatic belief in mixed ability teaching in secondary education and regulation of the converging communication technologies.

The confidential papers also reject union calls for renationalisation of the railways.

To the relief of supporters of electoral reform, the papers retain the commitment to hold a referendum, saying: "The final decision on changing the electoral system for the House of Commons will rest with the British people in a referendum."

But it is also pointed out that the party conference in 1993 committed the party to support first past the post.

A separate consultation paper hints the party will give all party members, including ministers, freedom to express their personal views on PR during a referendum campaign.

The papers again insist Labour will make a judgment on a single currency early in the parliament, but stress the benefits, including elimination of exchange rate risks on almost 50% of trade which British industry does.

But Labour's plans for a new citizens' commission will raise most interest.

The paper states: "To address public concerns, Labour could set up a citizens' commission, or other publicly trusted machinery, such as our two new commissions on biotechnology, to give consumers a voice within government and consider and publicly debate risks, and if necessary suspend the activities while further knowledge is gained."

Admitting the public is concerned about the risks produced from new technologies and science, and citing the example of GM foods and mobile phones, the environment paper concludes there are likely to be other examples in the future.

The government has already started to move to give greater credibility to its scientific regulatory bodies with the new human genetics commission, which reports to health and science ministers, and a new agriculture and environment biotechnology commission.

The bodies are made up of lay members as well as ethicists, consumers and industrialists, but they have no regulatory power and are meant to give advice to ministers on "the big picture". The government has to approve plans for their work and will also have the power "where appropriate" to direct them not to take on work.

The new "citizen's commissions" would have scientists as well as consumer champions on board and would crucially have the power to affect the dispersal of new technology and processes throughout the country.

The need for such a body follows the controversies over the safety of mobile phones and GM crops.

Only this week it was revealed that hundreds of farmers had unwittingly planted thousands of acres with GM seeds.

The government is well aware of the worries among consumers, and the environment policy paper is cautious about the effect of GM technology, acknowledging it must address public suspicion.

"If in the course of our tests we discover that any GM crops damage health or the environment more than conventional crops we will not allow commercial planting to succeed"

Meanwhile demands grew yesterday for the resignation of Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, over his handling of the genetically modified crops crisis.

The calls came from opposition MPs at Westminster and in the devolved Scottish parliament and Welsh assembly.

Tim Yeo, the shadow agriculture minister, accused Mr Brown of a "lack of communication" following the accidental planting of GM contaminated oilseed rape at 600 farms.

Environment campaigners urged the government to follow the lead of France and Sweden and order the destruction of affected crops.

The Conservatives claimed Mr Brown failed to inform his Scottish and Welsh counterparts about the problem of GM contaminated oilseed rape crops for more than three weeks after the agriculture ministry in London was advised that such crops were growing.
