webTitle: Seven held ahead of Unionist vote

fields.headline: Seven held ahead of Unionist vote
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Irish police last night arrested seven men believed to be members of the Real IRA ahead of a crucial vote today by the Ulster Unionist council.
fields.body:
Irish police last night arrested seven men believed to be members of the Real IRA ahead of a crucial vote today by the Ulster Unionist council.

One of the men is believed to be the head of the dissident paramilitary group, which was responsible for the Omagh bomb which killed 29 people in August 1998.

The operation follows a warning on Thursday that the rebel republican group was planning attacks in Northern Ireland to undermine the vote by Unionists on whether to resume sharing power with Sinn Fein.

David Trimble, the Ulster Unionist leader, hopes to convince his party council to re-enter the power-sharing executive next week but anti-agreement Unionists were last night claiming they had secured promises from 470 of the 886 delegates. If this is the case it would be a catastrophe for Mr Trimble.

But Mr Trimble's team insisted it had a slight majority. They think his speech will be crucial, and were also anticipating that the deputy leader, John Taylor, would swing behind his leader.

Anti-agreement MP Jeffrey Donaldson's alternative proposals, which stipulate no return to a government with Sinn Fein until the IRA begins to decommission its weapons, are further muddying the waters. His package, unveiled after a meeting with Mr Trimble yesterday, allows for the assembly to work in the meantime, with committees, including Sinn Fein representatives, shadowing government departments.

Mr Trimble said: "There isn't anything new in this. On a number of occasions over the last year proposals very like this were explored. From the response we got from other parties there wasn't much mileage in them.

"There are many safe options. We could all sit and draw up a Unionist wish list. But we are involved in a process with other parties which has been going on for several years. We can't just wind the clock back one or two years."

David Burnside, a London-based PR guru, indicated yesterday that he would be voting against Mr Trimble today. He forwarded a motion in March tying any return to government with retention of the Royal Ulster Constabulary's name. Sinn Fein would like to see it changed.

Mr Trimble has still to unveil the motion he will put to delegates. He hinted there would be some mechanism to reassure those who doubt the sincerity of the IRA's recent offer on arms inspections. But Martin McGuinness, the Sinn Fein negotiator, immediately warned him against setting new pre-conditions.

Mr Trimble entered the short-lived executive conditionally in November, vowing to quit if there was no start to IRA decommissioning before the end of January.

The British and Irish governments forwarded the Hillsborough proposals for restored devolution 22 days ago. The IRA's offer to put arms beyond use and allow weapons inspectors to inspect some of its dumps followed the next day.

Mr Trimble then fought for 10 days for concessions on the RUC's name and on the issue of flags. After making progress he decided to delay for a week his ruling council meeting in order to persuade delegates to back him.

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland Secretary, said: "Let me tell you, in all honesty, something better is not going to turn up that has the support of both traditions. It is time to choose. The time for negotiations is over.

"To make no choice is to turn your back on the best chance we are going to get. I hope we will have the courage to seize it."

His comments came less than an hour after Martin Taylor, 35, was shot dead in north Belfast, the victim of a loyalist feud. He was a friend of Billy Hutchinson of the Progressive Unionist Party, which is allied to the Ulster Volunteer Force.

His murder comes two days after the UVF tried to kill a suspected Loyalist Volunteer Force member in north Belfast. That was attempted revenge for the LVF's murder in January of mid-Ulster UVF commander Richard Jameson, 46, in Portadown, Co Armagh. Security forces fear the feud will spiral further.

webTitle: BBC agrees award to libelled woman

fields.headline: BBC agrees award to libelled woman
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: BBC television is to pay five-figure libel damages to a woman falsely labelled as a prostitute after the fly-on-the-wall documentary Hotel.
fields.body:
BBC television is to pay five-figure libel damages to a woman falsely labelled as a prostitute after the fly-on-the-wall documentary Hotel.

Tanya Merciar, 38, accepted the settlement yesterday at Liverpool county court.

Hotel was a successful documentary series giving a view behind the scenes of business at the Adelphi Hotel in Liverpool.

Miss Merciar, of Bootle, Merseyside, complained that she suffered shame, ridicule and social stigma after the show was broadcast in 1997.

She appeared in the first episode, which showed scenes at the Adelphi after the Grand National was cancelled due to an IRA bomb alert.

She had been a member of the hotel's gym for more than a decade but was shown being "ejected" from the hotel. The scene was broadcast in trailers for the programme.

An agreed statement read to the court said: "The juxtaposition of the broadcast, the accompanying narrative and the description in the Radio Times suggested that the claimant was a prostitute. In fact the claimant, who had been due to attend the race meeting, was lawfully visiting the hotel, having arranged to meet friends there.

"The programme has been repeated on BBC1, satellite and cable channels and in in-flight entertainment on airlines."

The BBC acknowledged that Miss Merciar had endured substantial distress, injury and damage to her reputation.

The statement added: "The defendants now accept the claimant is not and never has been a prostitute. They deeply regret the distress caused to the claimant and her family as a result of the broadcast.

"They have agreed to pay her substantial damages."

A BBC spokesman declined to reveal the level of damages, which is thought to be around £20,000.

Miss Merciar, whose mother died three months ago, was studying reflexology at the time of the incident but has been unable to open a business because of the libel stigma.

fields.headline: Chance of a ghost
fields.standfirst: Hunting for haunting at Hampton Court
fields.trailText: Britain's stuffy royal protocol will unbend slightly today when ghostbusters are allowed to monitor one of the Queen's palaces for the first time.
fields.body:
Britain's stuffy royal protocol will unbend slightly today when ghostbusters are allowed to monitor one of the Queen's palaces for the first time.

Thermal imaging equipment and recorders will be installed in the Tudor "haunted gallery" at Hampton Court for 10 days in the first authorised attempt to link murmurs, patches of cold air and soft footsteps to the spirit of a beheaded wife of Henry VIII.

Temperature gauges and cameras will survey other areas of the palace, where the unhappy Catherine Howard - Henry's fifth wife and the second to be executed - has long been held responsible for odd happenings.

A spokeswoman at the palace said yesterday: "There's definitely a ghost here - lots of people have seen things - so there's plenty of interest in how this goes."

The ghost hunt has been organised by the University of Hertfordshire, formerly Hatfield Polytechnic, as part of a series of events to mark the 460th anniversary of the beginning of Catherine's 18 months as queen, a reign which ended after what were almost certainly trumped-up adultery charges were brought.

The Tudor equivalent of a London "Sloane", the 20-year-old was convicted of sending passionate love letters to an admirer, although it has since emerged that she could barely write her own name.

Hampton Court, run by the government's royal palace's department, said there had been an increase in possible paranormal incidents during the approach to the anniversary.

Generally considered the most spirited of Henry VIII wives, Catherine was imprisoned in the palace by the Thames for her last days before being taken to the Tower of London for execution.

Dr Richard Wiseman, lecturer in psychological phenomena at Hertfordshire, said the young queen was supposed to have made a desperate escape attempt before being taken to the block.

Accounts describe her leaving Hampton Court insufficiently disguised and being dragged back screaming after failing to reach the king to plead for mercy.

The research will involve visitors to the palace over the bank holiday weekend, when it is hoped that increased numbers of tourists will provide a range of "psychic sensitivities" which could pinpoint areas where the queen's fate triggers hauntings, whether real or imagined.

Dr Wiseman will use thermal imaging to locate possible "cold spots" and instruments to measure changes in the magnetic field of the gallery to cover as many other causes of staff disquiet as possible.

He will explain his experiments three times daily to visitors, who will also have the chance to join a royal "goosepimples trail".

fields.headline: DNA loophole may free 'killer'
fields.standfirst: Calls for urgent review of law after court clears men of murder and rape despite 'compelling' evidence
fields.trailText: A convicted murderer is likely to walk free and a man accused of raping a 66-year-old woman has been acquitted despite overwhelming DNA evidence pinpointing them as the perpetrators of the crimes.
fields.body:
A convicted murderer is likely to walk free and a man accused of raping a 66-year-old woman has been acquitted despite overwhelming DNA evidence pinpointing them as the perpetrators of the crimes.

The court of appeal ruled yesterday that the men could not be convicted because the DNA samples that linked them to the crimes could not be used because they were gathered in connection with other, unrelated offences.

The shadow Home Office minister David Lidington last night called for an urgent review of laws on DNA evidence after three judges ruled that the two men could not be convicted despite "compelling" evidence against them.

Section 64 of the Police and Criminal Evidence Act decrees that DNA samples taken from suspects must be destroyed if they are acquitted or the case discontinued, and cannot be used in any other investigation.

The two men, whose cases are not related, were charged after DNA samples taken during investigations into other crimes linked one to the rape of a 66-year-old woman and the other to the murder of a 79-year-old man.

But the appeal court judges said they could not be found guilty because the samples that led detectives to the men were taken when they faced other charges of which they were never convicted.

"I hope that the government will look carefully at the appeal court's decision and consider whether a change in the law is necessary," Mr Lidington said.

But a Home Office spokesman said: "There are no immediate plans to change the regulations. The rules are quite clear. It's a fundamental civil liberty issue."

Lord Justice Swinton Thomas, sitting with Mr Justice Butterfield and Mrs Justice Rafferty, quashed the murder conviction of Michael Weir.

The crown prosecution service was last night considering an appeal, but lawyers thought the House of Lords would be likely to follow the appeal court because parliament's wording of the legislation is unequivocal. Judges normally have discretion to allow evidence to be used even if it was illegally obtained, but the appeal court ruled that parliament never intended a court to exercise discretion over wrongly retained DNA samples.

Weir had appealed against his conviction for murder, burglary and assault, for which he was sentenced to life imprisonment at the Old Bailey in July 1999. He was linked to the murder of Leonard Harris in north London in January 1998 by a DNA sample taken after he was charged with drug offences in August 1997. But the drug charges were discontinued. Police made the connection after running a DNA profile from blood found on a glove left outside Harris's home through their database.

webTitle: Foyles pair accused of cooking the books

fields.headline: Foyles pair accused of cooking the books
fields.trailText: Foyles, one of London's oldest bookshops, has suspended two senior managers and launched a high court action to recover millions of pounds that have allegedly disappeared over 17 years.
fields.body:
Foyles, one of London's oldest bookshops, has suspended two senior managers and launched a high court action to recover millions of pounds that have allegedly disappeared over 17 years.

Christopher Foyle and his brother Anthony, directors of the family business, are pursuing claims against 10 people employed by or associated with the company since the early 1980s, solicitors Mishcon de Reya confirmed.

The brothers, whose family opened the Charing Cross Road shop in 1904, allegedly discovered evidence of a complex invoicing and commission scam earlier this year which they fear may stretch back 17 years and have cost the business millions of pounds, according to court documents.

In a bid to uncover the full scale of the alleged losses, Mishcon de Reya has issued a high court writ calling for worldwide orders freezing the assets, accounts and paperwork of several book sales and marketing companies.

The two senior staff suspended within the past few weeks are the company secretary and general manager of the Charing Cross Road shop, Francis Steven Boal, and his assistant manager, Mark Latus. Both are accused by Foyles of conspiring with others to defraud the bookshop, and breach of contract and fiduciary duties.

The fraud is alleged to have taken place during the years when Foyles - which boasts the largest stock of any bookshop in the world - was run by the famously eccentric and autocratic heiress Christina Foyle.

Her nephews, Christopher and Anthony Foyle, took over when she died last June aged 88. She had inherited Foyles from her father, William, and his brother, Gilbert, who founded W & G Foyle Ltd in 1904. She ran the business in a style described by Usdaw, the shop assistants' union, as "crass and eccentric".

But her autocracy was put firmly behind a love of books. She once rebuked Hitler for having Jewish books burned. She offered to buy them instead. He declined but was careful to couch the refusal in extremely diplomatic terms.

The family name became almost as famous for literary luncheons where book lovers could pay to meet prominent authors such as Bertrand Russell and George Bernard Shaw.

The allegations of financial irregularities come a year after the bookshop, known for the idiosyncratic cataloguing of its 30 miles of ramshackle shelving, announced a modernisation programme.

Foyles issued a statement saying: "A number of accounting discrepancies were discovered during routine checks by Foyles at the beginning of this year. Investigations going back 17 years were immediately initiated and as a result two senior employees have been suspended.

"The irregular practices were all in the past and have now been stopped."

Neither suspended man was available for comment.

webTitle: Police win more time in Dando case

fields.headline: Police win more time in Dando case
fields.trailText: The man being held on suspicion of murdering Jill Dando was still being questioned by detectives last night after magistrates granted police a 36-hour extension to the time he can be held in custody.
fields.body:
The man being held on suspicion of murdering Jill Dando was still being questioned by detectives last night after magistrates granted police a 36-hour extension to the time he can be held in custody.

Scotland Yard now has until 6.30am tomorrow to charge or release jobless Barry Bulsara, 40, who was arrested on Thursday at his home in Fulham, south-west London.

Detective Chief Inspector Hamish Campbell, who is leading the investigation, could apply for a further extension, but Mr Bulsara cannot be held longer than a total of 96 hours.

Ms Dando, 37, died from a single shot to the side of her head as she returned to her home on April 26 last year. Mr Bulsara is the only person the police have arrested on suspicion of murder.

Although Scotland Yard refused to discuss the arrest yesterday, further details of Mr Bulsara's life began to emerge from his friends and neighbours in Crookham Road, half a mile from Ms Dando's home in Gowan Avenue.

Born in April 1960 and a fan of the pop group Queen, Mr Bulsara changed his name by deed poll from Barry Michael George several years ago. Bulsara was the real surname of the band's flamboyant lead singer, Freddie Mercury.

Mr Bulsara claimed to friends he was a relative of Mercury, who died in 1991, but this was denied yesterday by the entertainer's family.

A Bulsara family spokesman said: "We have in the past been made aware by some fans of a person claiming to be the cousin of Freddie, but we can emphatically state this person, Barry Bulsara, is no relative of the late Freddie Mercury, who was born Farok Bulsara."

Mr Bulsara had lived alone in a two-bedroom housing association flat in Fulham since he split up with his wife Itsuko Toide in 1989. They met when she moved into the flat above him in Crookham Road.

Mr Bulsara's father, Alfred, was a policeman who had also worked as a prison officer, bus driver and lorry driver. He lives in Wales. Mr Bulsara's mother Margaret, 64, lives in west London.

A Scotland Yard spokesman said yesterday: "This remains a complex and protracted investigation due to the quantity of evidential material to be examined."

Police sources insisted yesterday that Mr Bulsara had not been arrested before by the Dando murder squad.

Mr Bulsara's father, who lives in Treharris, near Merthyr Tydfil, did not want to discuss the case. His second wife Barbara said: "We've had no dealings with Barry for years and years. We were as shocked as anyone."

fields.headline: BBC defends Birt's £370,000 pay-off
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC's governors have braved political controversy by agreeing a £370,000 farewell package for the corporation's former director general, Lord Birt.
fields.body:
The BBC's governors have braved political controversy by agreeing a £370,000 farewell package for the corporation's former director general, Lord Birt.

Greg Dyke's predecessor will get £320,000, a year's salary, plus £50,000 for his pension fund. The package is in line with that offered to other senior executives on their retirement, the corporation said.

Peter Ainsworth, the Tories' culture spokesman, said the deal was an "astonishing act of generosity" for an organisation that complained of a lack of money. Norman Baker, the Liberal Democrat broadcasting spokesman, accused the BBC of a "grotesque waste" of licence-fee payers' money.

Lord Birt's contract has always been controversial: details of the possible retirement payout were first revealed in January, and the deal was signed off at a meeting of the BBC board of governors this week.

The "golden goodbye" was triggered because Lord Birt, 55, agreed to leave the corporation before the end of his contract.

The BBC said yesterday: "John Birt had a contract through to retirement age but he had mutually agreed with the BBC that he would leave before then, so was entitled to a termination payment."

The corporation would not confirm the cost, but it will be reported in its annual report later this year.

Governors have said in the past that they were determined to pay market rates to retain good staff. They aimed to "ensure that the packages offered to executive members enable the BBC to attract, retain and motivate high calibre executives".

Other senior staff, including Will Wyatt, the head of BBC broadcast, and Rod Lynch, the head of BBC resources, have left with similar deals. Ron Neil, former head of BBC production, was paid £170,000, one year's salary, along with £90,000 for his pension fund.

webTitle: Oh Ken - one of them already!

fields.headline: Oh Ken - one of them already!
fields.standfirst:
Mere weeks into his mayoralty, Livingstone has compromised

Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: Mere weeks into his mayoralty, Livingstone has compromised
fields.body:
In a television documentary about the Queen, Neil Kinnock - then Labour leader - was shown in conversation with her at Balmoral in neat black tie and big white smile. The standby caption for such photographs describes the moment as "sharing a joke". But there was no going halves on laughter here: 90% of the giggling was Kinnock's. His beam was obedient.

The scene has stayed with me as an image of the way politics homogenises candidates for high office. Kinnock had come to prominence as a radical, a dangerous orator, a man whose idea of a good time could not possibly be the pre-dinner pleasantries of Queen Elizabeth II. And yet - because glazed-eyed monarchism was considered at Westminster and in the press a defining quality in a potential prime minister - here he was getting ready to say: "Wow! And what did Edward VII say to that, Ma'am?"

The two-party system - in which, because the electorate is seen to favour safety, no quarter in caution can be given to your rivals - has often been blamed for this tyranny of similarity. But the taming process seems to be happening already to the first leading British political figure to be elected without the backing of an established party.

On the front page of yesterday's Daily Telegraph, Mayor Livingstone was pictured grinning alongside the Queen Mother at the opening of the Somerset House art collection. Their shared joke obeyed the Kinnock percentages. The newspaper noted, in the tone of a nanny reporting her unruly charge's sudden marked improvement in table manners, that "Mr Livingstone bowed his head as he met the Queen Mother". If so, it feels like a symbolic ducking under the yoke of establishment reputation. There is a clear glee in the Telegraph's selection of that image. It displays another prisoner captured by the British political system.

A fortnight ago, he was pictured dividing unequal slices of humour with the Queen at the opening of Tate Modern. It may admittedly be bad luck that the independent mayor's first weeks of power happen to coincide with the opening of the huge lottery-funded arts institutions. It isn't Livingstone's fault that established protocol had already decided that the tapes would be snipped by the Windsors.

But does he have to look quite so at ease with the creeping? Wouldn't the Mayor Livingstone who seemed to be promised by his breakaway campaign be giving interviews complaining that these arrangements pre-dated him, but that it would be better if Tate Modern were opened by someone who enjoyed modern art?

His defenders might argue that this is what the left used to call entryism. Mayor Ken diligently enacts the harmless ceremonial - why give the press the pleasure of donkey jacket at the Cenotaph stories? - while the actions that matter will be radical. This, incidentally, is much the line Livingstone offered to journalists about Blair during the 1997 election. Blair would charm the middle classes with his smile and then be radical in office.

But what, on the day of his cheery meeting with the Queen Mother, was Livingstone's main political initiative? He has set up a commission of inquiry, under the journalist Will Hutton, to assess the rival options for future funding of the London tube system. The ruminating panel under a grandee is a classic Westminster delaying tactic: Blair used it to put off and then dilute House of Lords reform.

It's true that, like all independent challengers in politics, Livingstone was supported by a contradictory range of different interests, ranging from mischievous Tories through disaffected Blairites to hopeful members of the old left. But few of them can have suspected that, on a single day in his first month, he would be represented in the media by a pro-royal photo and a canny Blairite political manoeuvre. It's traditional to give leaders 100 days before writing them off, but the trend towards conventionality already looks hard to reverse.

Organisational structures are notoriously hard to reshape. Businesses which reject the traditional pyramid structure eventually founder on the fact that someone has to sign the cheques and give the orders. A string quartet dispenses with the need for a conductor but, in most cases, one of the players will become the leading personality.

In the same way, our political systems are constructed to be run by a leader who is capitalist, monarchistic and desirous of the good opinion of the middle-market press. Whatever your shape on the day of the election, the machine will force you into those contours within weeks.

In 1992, when it briefly seemed that Ross Perot - a weirdo with no policies or established party backing - might claim the American presidency, there was a political talk-show discussion about how dangerous an unschooled incumbent might be. But, amid the apocalyptic commentary, one pundit was relaxed. Even if you ran as an anti-politician, it didn't matter. In the moment of election, you unavoidably became a politician. "It is a very efficient system," he said, "for dealing with dreamers."

It is in England as well, and Ken Livingstone - within a month - looks worryingly like its latest victim. It may, for many of his voters, be a hard joke to share with the establishment.

webTitle: Calm reigns as UN troops patrol Lebanon border

fields.headline: Calm reigns as UN troops patrol Lebanon border
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The Israeli-Lebanese border continued yesterday to enjoy a calm which is already longer - at three days - than it has known for years. The only exchanges, diminishing too, were the taunts and insults that Lebanese visitors continue to hurl at the Israeli soldiers on the other side of the barbed wire.
fields.body:
The Israeli-Lebanese border continued yesterday to enjoy a calm which is already longer - at three days - than it has known for years. The only exchanges, diminishing too, were the taunts and insults that Lebanese visitors continue to hurl at the Israeli soldiers on the other side of the barbed wire.

In other signs of a gathering detente, UN peacekeepers began patrolling areas of south Lebanon recently evacuated by Israel, and Lebanese police moved into predominantly Christian areas of the former "security zone".

The Lebanese government indicated that it would endorse the United Nations terms for confirming that Israel has made a full withdrawal to the international frontier, and Syria reiterated that it would support the deployment of UN peacekeepers.

The only discordant note was Hizbullah's continued insistence that Israel should yield up the so-called Shebaa farms, along with the territory it has already evacuated. That demand came in a triumphant speech by Hassan Nasrallah, Hizbullah's secretary general, on his maiden visit to the territory his men had liberated. "The farms of Shebaa will return to Lebanon," he said. "I advise him [Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak] to get out of them and solve the problem. The days will prove that."

Despite the implied threat, this statement seemed milder in tone than earlier Hizbullah pronouncements.

Patrols of the 4,500-strong Unifil peacekeeping force moved into areas swarming with Hizbullah guerillas. "The idea", said the Unifil commander, General Seth Kofi Obeing, "is to instil confidence in the people and this will continue, ideally, until we are able to implement security council resolution 425," which calls on the UN to assist the Lebanese government to restore its authority up to the frontier.

UN cartographers meanwhile began work on verifying the completeness of the Israeli withdrawal, without which the Lebanese government will not sanction the redeployment of Unifil in the evacuated areas, or that of its own army.

In Beirut, the UN special envoy, Terje Roed-Larsen, came away "very encouraged" from his meeting with Lebanese officials. "The process of liberating south Lebanon, its reunification with the rest of the country, is occurring at a rapid pace," he said. He indicated that, despite Lebanon's continued claim to the Shebaa farms, it would abide by any UN verdict on the Israeli withdrawal. But he warned that all "non-government organisations in the country" - meaning Hizbullah - should do likewise.

There are fears that Hizbullah's insistence on recovering the Shebaa farms will reignite the fighting on a more dangerous scale than before, given Israel's repeatedly announced post-withdrawal strategy of big reprisals against Lebanese targets, and probably Syrian ones too.

There has been no movement of the Lebanese army into the former security zone, but some 600 gendarmes have reportedly gone in. They have deployed mainly in Christian villages, many of whose inhabitants were unnerved by the influx of Muslim guerillas.

In Ein Ibl, a young man conceded: "Hizbullah was very disciplined and did not loot, unlike other groups. But now we feel more secure without all their guns amidst us, and [with] the police arriving in our village."

Syria - accused earlier by Israel of doing its best to sabotage the Israeli withdrawal --expressed its opposition to any "military escalation" in the south, and called the planned deployment of an enlarged Unifil force a "positive factor". Its foreign minister, Farouk Shara'a, congratulated Hizbullah for its "reasonable" attitude, and its avoidance of "any retaliation or act of vengeance, in spite of Israeli fire that had killed six civilians and wounded 25".

"The process of liberating south Lebanon, its reunification with the rest of the country, is occurring at a rapid pace," he said. He indicated that, despite Lebanon's continued claim to the Shebaa farms, it would abide by any UN verdict on the Israeli withdrawal. But he warned that all "non-government organisations in the country" - meaning Hizbullah - should do likewise. Its foreign minister, Farouk Shara'a, congratulated Hizbullah for its "reasonable" attitude, and its avoidance of "any retaliation or act of vengeance, in spite of Israeli fire that had killed six civilians and wounded 25".

fields.headline: UN sanctions'are killing Iraq's children'
fields.trailText: Deaths among babies and children in Iraq have more than doubled in the past 10 years because of the deprivation and malnutrition caused by UN sanctions, according to reports in the Lancet medical journal published yesterday.
fields.body:
Deaths among babies and children in Iraq have more than doubled in the past 10 years because of the deprivation and malnutrition caused by UN sanctions, according to reports in the Lancet medical journal published yesterday.

These soaring child-mortality rates will present the defenders of sanctions with a difficult case to answer, and an editorial in the journal spells out a dire warning. "The courageous policy is to suspend [not abandon] sanctions, lest upcoming generations of Iraqis, out of resentment, suffering and isolation, grow up to be as aggressive as their current leader," it says.

The study, carried out by Mohammed M Ali from the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine and Iqbal Shah from the World Health Organisation, provides the first accurate data on child mortality in Iraq since 1991. The fieldwork was carried out by the United Nations children's organisation Unicef, with the permission of the Iraqi government.

The researchers compared the death rates among babies and children under five years old in the autonomous (northern Kurdish) region with those in the rest of the country. They found a marked difference between the Kurdish area, which is benefiting from the oil-for-food programme, and the rest of Iraq, which is not.

In the Kurdish area, child mortality rates have improved; between 1994 and 1999, infant mortality declined from 64 to 59 per 1,000 live births and the under-five mortality ratio fell from 80 to 72 per 1,000.

In the rest of Iraq, child mortality more than doubled during the sanctions period, rising from 47 per 1,000 live births during 1984-89 to 108 per 1,000 in 1994-99; under-five mortality rose from 56 to 131 per 1,000.

The reports point to many critical factors undermining the health of the Iraqi population - particularly for those who live in rural areas.

Hospitals and health clinics have had little or no maintenance since 1991 and their work has been hampered by shortages of power and water.

Before sanctions, 90% of urban families and 70% of those in rural areas had access to safe water supplies. Now, that can be said of only half those living in towns and a third of those in the countryside.

Dr Ali said yesterday that he and his fellow researcher were not trying to draw conclusions from their work. "We have showed that the increase in child mortality coincides with the start of sanctions," he said.

Since sanctions were imposed, there has also been an increase in malnutrition for mothers and babies - from 3% to 11% of the population - and a rise in endemic diseases such as measles and diarrhoeal diseases. Malaria, eradicated from Iraq in the 1970s, has returned.

Children of educated women traditionally fare better than those from illiterate families - but literacy is not helping in Iraq. "Clearly, education of the mother, suggested to be a determinant of infant-child mortality, has a limited effect in deteriorating socio-economic and health conditions, as seen in the south [and] centre of Iraq," write the authors.

Peter Kandela, a doctor who has just returned from the country, writes of what he calls the tragedy of Iraq in another Lancet article.

"Children who should be at school are scouring rubbish heaps and keeping cool in cesspits, and when they get ill there will be no treatment for them," he writes. "These are the next generation; and who will blame those who survive to adulthood if they react with bitterness and fury against those they deem responsible?"

Two surveys were carried out for the study on child mortality and maternal mortality, the second of which is yet to be published. Between February and March 1999, researchers interviewed 23,105 married women aged 15-49 living in the centre and south of Iraq. Between April and May, 14,035 married women of the same age were interviewed in the autonomous Kurdish region.

One paper notes that Iraq had "spectacular social and economic development" between 1970 and 1990, followed by dramatic decline in the past 10 years. All progress stopped with the start of the Gulf war, the report says.

fields.headline: Rebel leader will be tried
fields.standfirst:
Sierra Leonean president to ask Blair for British troops to stay, and offers assurances on child soldiers
Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: Sierra Leone's president, Ahmed Tejan Kabbah, says he will appeal to Tony Blair to extend the stay of British troops because they are helping to save the country from catastrophe.
fields.body:
Sierra Leone's president, Ahmed Tejan Kabbah, says he will appeal to Tony Blair to extend the stay of British troops because they are helping to save the country from catastrophe.

Mr Kabbah wants the prime minister to permit British troops to remain until the rebel Revolutionary United Front is no longer a threat to the government.

"They [British forces] came in at the right time for the security vacuum that existed, and the confidence on the part of the people which was way down was dramatically lifted. They have really contributed to the security of the country," he said.

"We would like to see the British soldiers staying for longer. My own job is to try and persuade him [Mr Blair], but it's a matter for his judgment to say yes or no."

British marine commandos yesterday took over the defence of Sierra Leone's international airport, Lungi, from British paratroopers.

The president said his government is not trying to win a war but is defending itself from attack while pressuring the RUF to adhere to the peace agreement it signed last year.

Mr Kabbah said the government intends to put the captured rebel leader, Foday Sankoh, on trial. He said that a blanket amnesty granted to the RUF chief and his fighters in last year's peace accords no longer applies because the rebels have gone back to war.

"Sankoh violated the agreement and he can't claim rights any more. We are currently gathering evidence and we hope to put him on trial. We don't want to deny justice or delay it," he said.

The Sierra Leonean president gave damning praise to the United Nations, saying he was pleased it had bolstered its peacekeeping force to more than 11,000 troops but that he was waiting to see how they were used.

Many Sierra Leoneans believe that if it had been left to the UN to defend Freetown, it would now be in rebel hands.

The UN yesterday confirmed that six bodies found earlier this week are those of peacekeepers murdered by rebels who took nearly 500 UN personnel hostage nearly a month ago. More than 200 of the abducted peacekeepers surrendered without a fight to just 20 rebels.

fields.headline: Hugh Hanning
fields.standfirst: The lessons of war taught him to love peace
fields.trailText: Hugh Hanning, who has died aged 75, was a journalist and defence specialist whose determination to direct the world's armies towards humanitarian causes during peacetime overtook his life.
fields.body:
Hugh Hanning, who has died aged 75, was a journalist and defence specialist whose determination to direct the world's armies towards humanitarian causes during peacetime overtook his life.

From his home in Blackheath, south London, he fired off letters to newspapers, masterminded conferences and effected unlikely introductions between the military and charity worlds. His allies were inspired by his moral courage and cheered by his acute sense of humour; his opponents, most of them timorous politicians and recalcitrant bureaucrats, were discomforted.

Hanning took quiet pleasure when his ideas were put into action, as during Nato's Provide Comfort operation at the end of the Gulf war, and in the combined military/ volunteer response to the Rwanda crisis. Manfred Worner, then Nato secretary-general, credited him with laying the groundwork for Nato's historic 1991 decision to assist the republics of the former USSR. Within Whitehall, however, he was fiercely opposed by traditionalists who reasoned that soldiers were trained to kill people, not sustain them.

A solicitor's son, born in Barrow-in-Furness, Cumbria, Hanning grew up in Surrey. He won a scholarship to Winchester, and at 17 joined the Royal Navy. He was at the D-Day landings and was wounded at Walcheren, off the Dutch coast. The carnage he witnessed profoundly influenced his thinking.

After the war, Hanning read history at University College, Oxford, and then took a job as a reporter on the Bradford Telegraph and Argus, where his early attacks on factory pollution gave a clue to the campaigner he would become. Later, he was a distinguished defence correspondent for the Glasgow Herald, the Westminster Press, ITN and the Observer. Between 1967 and 1969 he worked at the Statist, then a rival to the Economist, from where he contributed to the Guardian.

Some wondered if his lack of guile prevented him from rising even further in the profession, but he never saw a career as an end in itself, and by the late 1960s had concluded he could satisfy his twin interests in war prevention and disaster relief more directly.

Hanning had been influenced by a world tour he made in 1964, funded by the World Veterans Federation, where he saw countless examples of military forces carrying out essential civilian work. The next year he launched the concept of Pumf, the peaceful uses of military forces, in the Statist. It was a dream he pursued for 35 years, first as deputy director of the Royal United Service Institution (1968-70) and then as director of the British Atlantic Committee, between 1975 and 1979, and again in 1983.

He had shared his interest in disaster relief with Leonard Cheshire since the early 1960s and, in the 1990s, with a group of retired army officers, he set up the Pathfinders umbrella group of disaster relief workers, although he would later quietly distance himself from some of its old-buffer tendencies in favour of more operational, relief-providing activities. It was through Hanning's encouragement that the founders of Merlin, a British version of Médicins Sans Frontières, saw it expand to an organisation of 600 staff around the world. Latterly, he founded and chaired the Fontmell Group on Disaster Relief.

In 1992 Lord Cheshire, Denis Healey, Field Marshal Bramall and Worner wrote privately in support of a campaign to have Hanning honoured. To their voices was added that of the former Archbishop of Canterbury, Lord Runcie, whom Hanning, a Christian, had advised on international affairs. But it seemed Hanning had irritated too many, and nothing came of it.

During the last dozen years of his life, despite severe ill-health, he continued to work with infectious cheerfulness and unfailing thoughtfulness to others. His books included the highly-praised Peace: The Plain Man's Guide To War Prevention (1988) and Five Wars, One Cause (1996), a polemical history on the dangers of nations failing to indicate clearly their willingness to fight when confronted with an aggressor.

He is survived by his wife Caragh McClure Williams, whom he married in 1954, and his son, James. It was Caragh who made sure that Hanning's last letter reached the Daily Telegraph, a typically coruscating attack on Clare Short's dilly-dallying over aid to Mozambique. He had dictated it five minutes before his death.

Andrew Billen

webTitle: New guns may fall into young hands

fields.headline: New guns may fall into young hands
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: Serious concern was expressed yesterday about the British government's ability to prevent arms supplied to the Sierra Leone army ending up in the hands of child soldiers, despite assurances from the country's president, Ahmed Tejan Kabbah
fields.body:
Serious concern was expressed yesterday about the British government's ability to prevent arms supplied to the Sierra Leone army ending up in the hands of child soldiers, despite assurances from the country's president, Ahmed Tejan Kabbah.

Stung by a prominently published picture of a 14-year-old boy holding a British gun earlier this week, the Ministry of Defence insisted that a new consignment of weapons - including up to 10,000 self-loading rifles - supplied to Mr Kabbah's forces will be subjected to "controlled release under the supervision of British officers" in a 90-strong military training team.

Some 7,500 British rifles were supplied to Mr Kabbah's forces last year as part of a £10m weapons package.

Aid agencies with first-hand knowledge of the situation in the west African country are deeply sceptical about claims that the distribution of the weapons can be controlled effectively.

"I don't think Britain's monitoring system will be sufficient," Antonio Cabral, the Catholic charity Cafod's programme officer for Sierra Leone, said yesterday. He said that children between 13 and 15 from the pro-government Kamajor militia were being integrated in the Sierra Leone army.

"It is almost impossible to police," Mr Cabral said. It would have been much better if Britain had given the weapons to UN forces, he added.

The plight of child combatants - the UN estimates there are about 5,000 in Sierra Leone - was raised by the UN's general assembly on Thursday.

A protocol to the UN convention on the rights of the child calls on governments to take "all feasible measures" to prevent soldiers under 18 from fighting.

According to UN figures, more than 300,000 children under18 - and some as young as seven - are fighting in wars around the world, including in Sudan, Colombia, Angola, Sri Lanka and Afghanistan.

Amnesty yesterday urged the British government to build into its new £20m arms and military training package to Sierra Leone "stringent safeguards" to prevent the further recruitment of child soldiers, and "firm guarantees" from the Kabbah government that British arms would not be provided to pro-government forces that have committed human rights violations.

"In Sierra Leone there are risks and opportunities for the UK government," said Mark Lattimer , the organisation's communications director. He added: "It has an opportunity to prevent child soldiering and guarantee that undisciplined and unaccountable fighters do not end up with British weapons."

The New York-based Human Rights Watch is warning that British weapons may be made available to groups allied to the Sierra Leone government and known to have committed gross human rights abuses.

"There have also been recent, credible reports that child soldiers are being re- recruited and may as such be recipients of some of these arms," it said in a letter to the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon.

Foreign Office officials concede that despite the conditions attached to the new supply of British rifles, there will always be a risk that they will be used by child soldiers.

Iain Duncan Smith, the shadow defence secretary, told the government this week that it had "yet to demonstrate that they will have any overall control over who uses these weapons. They should recognise that their action could backfire with dramatic results - including the possibility of these weapons being used against British soldiers."

Last July's Lome peace accord specifically highlighted the question of child combatants and the Kabbah govern ment has repeatedly committed itself to ending the recruitment of children. Yet there has been no sign of this.

Last November the government's civil defence forces admitted that its soldiers included some 200 children aged 15 to 18 and that there had been no effort to demobilise them.

Meanwhile, the Liberal Democrat foreign affairs spokesman, Menzies Campbell, said that as a member of the UN security council and the former colonial power, Britain had a responsibility to Sierra Leone and UK troops should join the UN force.

"The UN cannot afford to fail in Sierra Leone," he said. "Britain can best ensure success in Sierra Leone by being formally part of the force implementing a UN mandate."

fields.headline: Erich Mielke
fields.standfirst: Pedantic, bureaucratic and humourless, he was East Germany's brilliant, but hated, secret police chief
fields.trailText: Erich Mielke, who has died in Berlin aged 92, was feared and hated more than any other man in communist East Germany. As minister for state security from 1957 until the regime's collapse in November 1989, he commanded a network of 92,000 professional spies and 170,000 voluntary informers and part-time snoops.
fields.body:
Erich Mielke, who has died in Berlin aged 92, was feared and hated more than any other man in communist East Germany. As minister for state security from 1957 until the regime's collapse in November 1989, he commanded a network of 92,000 professional spies and 170,000 voluntary informers and part-time snoops.

Mielke's agents kept such a close watch on East Germany's 16m citizens that organised political opposition was almost impossible. Those identified as critics of the system could face imprisonment and torture, including fatal exposure to radiation. Although he spent five years in prison after German re-unification, he was never called to account for these crimes - or for the murder of hundreds of easterners who tried to escape to the west.

Pedantic, bureaucratic and humourless, Mielke was viewed by many as an unprincipled, heartless party functionary, whose actions were motivated by nothing nobler than a desire to keep himself and his cronies in power. In fact, he was a life-long communist, whose political biography was shaped by his experience in the early decades of the last century.

Born in the working-class Berlin district of Wedding, Mielke had a tough childhood, made grimmer by the early death of his mother. Like many of his neighbours in "red Wedding", his father favoured the communist KPD over the more moderate Social Democrats, and Mielke himself joined a communist youth group at the age of 12.

As a gifted schoolboy, he won a state scholarship to one of Berlin's most prestigious schools but dropped out after only two years when his teachers told him that the educational deficit caused by his underprivileged background could not be overcome. The experience further radicalised the young communist and, when the KPD set up a paramilitary group for "party self-defence", he was among the first to join. Much of the group's time was spent playing a harmless cat-and-mouse game with the police, but it became deadly earnest for Mielke on August 9 1931, when he shot dead a policeman during a demonstration in the centre of Berlin. Aged only 23, he escaped to Belgium using identity papers supplied by the Soviets and, nine years later, went to the Soviet Union.

Trained as a professional revolutionary at the Lenin school, Mielke returned to Germany after the second world war and, with other German communists who had spent the war years in Moscow, helped to establish the German Democratic Republic.

Politically unsophisticated, with a mindset frozen in the prewar years - when communists saw Social Democrats as their worst enemies - Mielke was nonetheless a brilliant secret policeman. From the moment he took charge of the Stasi in 1957, the agency out-performed most of its western rivals.

East Berlin planted an agent in the office of West German chancellor Willy Brandt and, as the German public has discovered in re cent months, its agents knew more about Helmut Kohl's financial misdemeanours than most of the former chancellor's closest aides. When Mielke celebrated his 80th birthday in 1987, the Communist party newspaper was still describing him as a national hero.

Those identified as critics of the system could face imprisonment and torture, including fatal exposure to radiation. In fact, he was a life-long communist, whose political biography was shaped by his experience in the early decades of the last century. webTitle: Brussels glitch for Boeing's satellite buy

fields.headline: Brussels glitch for Boeing's satellite buy
fields.trailText: Boeing was licking its wounds last night after the European Commission disclosed serious reservations about the US air and defence group's plans to buy the world's biggest manufacturer of commercial satellites.
fields.body:
Boeing was licking its wounds last night after the European Commission disclosed serious reservations about the US air and defence group's plans to buy the world's biggest manufacturer of commercial satellites.

Boeing originally hoped to complete its proposed £2.5bn acquisition of the satellite operations of fellow Americans Hughes Electronics by the end of next month. Yesterday's announcement means it is now more likely to be September at the earliest.

The two companies cannot go through with the deal without the blessing of regulators in Brussels and Washington.

In a sign that Brussels is unlikely to allow the deal to go ahead in its present form, the EC said yesterday it would be launching an inquiry into the matter which could take as long as four months. The EC will then give its final ruling on the deal and might demand that the two firms make special concessions before it is willing to give its approval - or decide to block the deal outright.

US regulators are expected to rule on the deal by August and the companies say they remain confident of receiving the go-ahead, despite a recent request from the US federal trade commission for extra information.

The EC is worried that the deal will simply allow Boeing - whose satellite launching rocket, Delta II, is pictured above at Cape Canaveral, Florida - to become too powerful and make it difficult for rivals to compete in the multi- billion dollar market.

webTitle: Vodafone's rights issue by any other name

fields.headline: Vodafone's rights issue by any other name
fields.standfirst: All eyes on Orange's future
fields.trailText: Notebook
fields.body:
Next Tuesday Vodafone Airtouch will unveil its latest results. Attention might be expected to be intense. The company is, by a large margin, the biggest constituent of the FTSE 100.

Yet the figures are likely to be the secondary focus of attention. Real interest will be on what, if anything, chief executive Chris Gent has to say about the future of Orange.

Paradoxically Orange has become a key factor in Vodafone's future strategy even though - for competition reasons - it has to sell it. The issue is money. Like all the big mobile phone players in Europe, Vodafone is trying to acquire as many third generation licences as it sensibly can.

The combination of purchasing a licence and then setting up the subsequent network does not come cheap - even if not all the European governments decide to milk the process for every cent they can get. Nor are finance ministers and equipment suppliers likely to take shares in lieu of cash. Some estimates reckon Vodafone could need £30bn.

At the same time, the City consensus is that Vodafone would struggle to raise more than £8bn from the markets. It is easily overlooked, but even for big companies, recent volatility has put the cost of capital up.

So a trade sale of Orange, rather than the demerger originally planned, could be just the way to foot the third genera tion bill. Mannesmann paid £20bn when it bought Orange last year and since then Orange has bought one of the UK third generation licences for just over £4bn. This time round Orange could fetch £30bn, completing what might be described as the biggest rights issue of all time.

Balancing act
The end of the dollar bull market has been a long time coming but it appears that the wheels are finally starting to fall off the greenback's 61 month-long rally. Last night it reached its lowest level against the euro in a month, losing nearly 3% against the single currency in 24 hours.

If yesterday's move indicates that the markets have decided the dollar is the new 98 pound weakling of the foreign exchanges, the reversal in fortune could be sudden. Look out for the euro getting close to parity next week.

A fall in the dollar is necessary to rebalance global growth imbalances which have seen the American current account deficit soaring to its highest level since the Civil war. But a rapid collapse in the currency could be a disaster, and not just for North America.

The downside risks for the US are easy to spot. The strong dollar has given the Federal Reserve a free ride on inflation for the last five years and has helped attract the capital that has underpinned Wall Street and allowed American consumers to live beyond their means. Falling imported raw material costs have helped keep US price pressures under control.

If the dollar suddenly collapses, leading to a surge in inflation, a market already unnerved by the certain prospect of higher borrowing costs could easily be panicked.

However, the country that could be the first to suffer from a dollar collapse is Japan. It has only just hoisted itself out of recession on the back of exports and it can't afford a stronger yen. Nor can much of developing Asia.

Unwise sage
It must set the nerves a-jangle if, like Paul Walker, the chief executive of accounting software group Sage, you have watched your personal wealth (on paper) move from £25m to £75m, and then back to £50m - all in the space of six months. The temptation to lock in a bit of old-fashioned cash must be irresistible.

But a top director selling does not set a good example to other shareholders. So Mr Walker, regularly described in print as a "friendly Yorkshireman," and investment bankers UBS Warburg have come up with a wheeze to "hedge his exposure to movements in the market price" of just under a fifth of the boss's holding. And a brief statement late yesterday declared solemnly that "the hedging transaction does not commit Mr Walker to sell the shares at a future date".

But the act of "hedging" a stock, or any other financial asset, means forgoing some or all of the future up-side in the price in exchange for limiting the possible downside. On the little information available, this transaction simply says that the chief executive reckons there is a real risk of the share price falling from here and so he is locking in some of his profits.

Mr Walker has done a great job turning Sage into a world class company. He has every right to protect his personal finances. But while he is doing it he should try and avoid misleading other shareholders.

fields.headline: I'm no mastermind, says protester
fields.standfirst:
Pat - not his real name - admits violence during a London riot. But he claims the police are making him a scapegoat. Now he's on the run

May 2K: special report
fields.trailText: Pat is a wanted man. The police believe he was one of the masterminds of the Stop the City riots last June, the Euston demonstrations in November and the May Day riots in the Strand.
fields.body:
Pat is a wanted man. The police believe he was one of the masterminds of the Stop the City riots last June, the Euston demonstrations in November and the May Day riots in the Strand.

His picture has been shown on Crimewatch and under the headline "The General" in the Daily Mail.

Pat is now on the run. He believes he will be caught. He is also adamant he is being set up as a scapegoat. Before detectives catch up with him, he said, he wants to put the record straight.

"They are making out I am some sort of criminal mastermind. It's complete nonsense. I wasn't even at the May Day demonstrations. I can prove it categorically."

He said he watched in disbelief as the publicity around him increased, but insisted he would not give himself up.

Scotland Yard feared there would be trouble on May Day because of the two anti-capitalist riots which took place in London last November and June, and similar violent disturbances earlier this year in Washington and Seattle.

The Metropolitan police cancelled all leave and launched a massive intelligence gathering operation. But the planning did not prevent ugly scenes of violence as activists dug up the grassy area of Parliament Square and daubed paint and graffiti on monuments, including the Cenotaph and a statue of Sir Winston Churchill.

So far, 103 people have been arrested and charged.

Pat, an assumed name, believes he could be number 104.

Pat is from west Belfast and is now in his 30s. He works part time in the tourist industry. He is also a student, reading humanities at university.

He claims to have no criminal record and said his parents, who were "politically involved", moved him to London to get him out of the political scene in Ireland.

After leaving school, he spent a few years travelling, working on cruise ships. He came back "needing some intellectual stimulus".

The 'new enemy'

His history with Reclaim the Streets began, he said, in 1997. But at the start, he stayed mainly on the periphery.

"I did not like what I saw. I did not like elements that were attached to it." He would not expand further.

He thought the police had a fundamental misunderstanding of Reclaim the Streets.

"There's no hierarchy, no real organisation. That scares them and the establishment. They feared the rave movement and the environmental movement, and the police regard RTS as the new enemy.

"This [movement] is very young, very disorganised. There is no method to it. A comprehensive ideology will follow in the next five to 10 years.

"I really believe that we (Reclaim the Streets) are a force of necessity in a democratic society, whether you agree with us or not. It is the cornerstone of any democratic system.

"We are keen and hungry to learn and believe we can make a change in the system, not in a communist way but in a humanistic way. Whether that is idealistic, utopian, I don't know. But I believe that we can make a change. This is the future of domestic protest."

During the J18 demonstration last June, he said, he was one of three people who covered security cameras, carrying a ladder and putting bags over the lenses. He denied that he had anything to do with the damage to the Liffe building or other violence in the City.

"I told people to cover themselves as they went into Tube stations."

Pat insisted that he had nothing to do with the May Day demonstration.

"I can verify that. The idea [stated by the press] that I was there in disguise is nonsense. I knew the police spotters would be out there. I knew they would specifically target me.

"I was working that day. I have my payslip. I have 100% proof of where I was. I was at work from 8am to 11pm."

Although he was not arrested at the Euston riots on November 30 last year, he admits being violent there, overturning a police van. He said he gave a speech in the square outside Euston station which he thinks led the police to believe he is a ringleader.

"I said that the police feared us, and that was why so many police had been sent there. There were people on top of the police van. I'd wrapped a scarf around my face. I told them to get down and they did. It shocked me.

"But the only act of violence that I did - and I'm not proud of it - was push that van over [it was later set fire to].

"The problem caused by the violence is that it can be construed as devaluing the meaning of the protest. It also increases publicity for people in like-minded communities.

"There is a place for violence," he said, citing the suffragette movement.

"It has to be done from within, not from within the establishment, but from within society."

His vision of the future of Britain is bleak. "You're getting classes of people, electronically led, electronically educated, [within] the realms of a privileged class. Do you really think that people are going to accept that?

"All this talk about level playing fields and social inclusion. It's nonsense.

"People at the top of society have no idea about the deprivation at the bottom of society. New Labour has only been tinkering at the edges of society.

"The worst thing is that it does not make economic sense. It is not in our economic interests to have this deprivation in society. You do not have to be an anarchist or hardcore to realise that it's wrong."

He claimed the police used the Daily Mail to build a case against him before he had even been charged or gone to court. "I am resigned to the fact that at some point I will be lifted. They are going out on a limb specifically to target me. They have picked me out."

The police admit their knowledge of Reclaim the Streets is limited. Officers have tried to set up meetings with the movement's leaders, but say they have been rebuffed.

British Transport Police confirmed last night they wanted to question Pat about the disturbances at Euston station last November. Thirty-one people have already been charged.

"We have good video evidence of him. It's pretty clear that he is organising what is going on," said a spokesman. "We never said to the Daily Mail that he was called The General.

"We don't have any evidence that he was at the May Day riots. But we are sure about Euston."

Told of Pat's claims of innocence, another police source said: "Well, he would say that, wouldn't he?"

The following are edited extracts of a diary kept by "Pat" and seen by the Guardian

November 30

I knew for weeks before that I would be attending the demonstrations at Euston. Arrived early ahead of the protest march.

The feeling of strength and self-empowerment derived from being among people who share a widespread vision and belief that we need radically to change society's governing ideals and ethos/status quo, if we are to progress peacefully and meaningfully into the millennium - a country at peace with itself and confident of its place in an ever changing world system.

As the march approached Euston and the square filled, speakers were called for, and for the first time in my life I dared to gamble with myself. I was going to make my "maiden speech". If I recall events correctly (and I'm sure the Met will have a very different take on these events) I mainly spoke of the need for personal responsibility and that if we are to achieve our aims then the concept of DAP (Direct Action Politics) will have to be increased to a more effective and influential level.

I say that what we are telling the CEOs and MDs of London's financial institutions is quite simply that we are putting you on notice - and every action you take is going to entail a counteraction on our part. If we have to isolate you, stigmatise you and make you a social outcast in our society, so be it!

It all ends in violence, and to summarise Rousseau, when the system refuses to see the injustices it inflicts on the citizenry as a whole for the benefit of the minority, then it's time for a change. The direction and methods of that change have yet to be decided.

May 1

Well, it kicked off as to be expected, the minority viewpoint gets all the mention, McDonald's gets trashed, some shit goes off and suddenly everyone's a terrorist! No more protest in the capital, they scream. I wonder if it's just me who sees things the way I do - am I on my own with the shop smashers - maybe they got the right agenda? - think not, heard about the O/B screening everyone on the way out - not there - some of us gotta work!

May 6

Just seen my photo and I guess it's official - I'm now a wanted man! It's quite a shock to turn the pages of the major city paper (the Evening Standard) and find yourself staring back at yourself (crap picture as well!). No bad thing. Shocked, scared and disbelieving - don't even begin to explain the emotions after I read their nonsense - "General" indeed - so out of touch as to be beyond belief. They are setting me up as a fall guy: they messed up J18, N-30 and May Day and of course some "mastermind" has to be behind it all, otherwise wouldn't it show up their incompetence! What are all the resources for, if we can't tell where and when!

Practicalities come first, who will recognise me? Will they squeal or have a laugh about it?

Lisa rings - spotted. Nick rings - spotted (by her mum, no less!). The phone starts to go! Move house.

Try to remember what went on at Euston, made a speech, harassed the Met's undercover surveillance crew. Irish in London making seditious statements - trouble ... Everybody rings tonight.

Go see solicitor. Two choices: Hide & Seek or surrender - no chance!

May 15-16

Just as I was thinking things are going back to normal, big bang, the Mail comes to the Met's rescue - Anarchist general in the area. All the rightwing shit sure to follow!

Old Bill call at door - or so I think (N says I'm being paranoid). Maybe - gotta move. Am I going to be spotted or not? Surprisingly for the amount of people who know me not one has dropped me in it! Will work find out?

May 20

The race is on between me and them - me to hide, them to find. It's interesting that they have to resort to their friends and colleagues in the rightwing press to follow their charges.

May 23

Cops come to door - time to go move out - no one knows my address. No one knows my phone.

So now life revolves around the surefire fact that the knock will come - only a matter of time I guess. However, if they want me they can spend some of their fucking resources in the process! I find it really strange that I can be labelled as a threat to the state, considering the limited violence alone, and its comparisons to the defused violence which is propagated against the weak, poor, disenfranchised and ignorant within our society by the state apparatus.

"We don't have any evidence that he was at the May Day riots. But we are sure about Euston." Told of Pat's claims of innocence, another police source said: "Well, he would say that, wouldn't he?" The following are edited extracts of a diary kept by "Pat" and seen by the Guardian November 30 I knew for weeks before that I would be attending the demonstrations at Euston. Arrived early ahead of the protest march. The feeling of strength and self-empowerment derived from being among people who share a widespread vision and belief that we need radically to change society's governing ideals and ethos/status quo, if we are to progress peacefully and meaningfully into the millennium - a country at peace with itself and confident of its place in an ever changing world system. As the march approached Euston and the square filled, speakers were called for, and for the first time in my life I dared to gamble with myself. I was going to make my "maiden speech". If I recall events correctly (and I'm sure the Met will have a very different take on these events) I mainly spoke of the need for personal responsibility and that if we are to achieve our aims then the concept of DAP (Direct Action Politics) will have to be increased to a more effective and influential level. I say that what we are telling the CEOs and MDs of London's financial institutions is quite simply that we are putting you on notice - and every action you take is going to entail a counteraction on our part. If we have to isolate you, stigmatise you and make you a social outcast in our society, so be it! It all ends in violence, and to summarise Rousseau, when the system refuses to see the injustices it inflicts on the citizenry as a whole for the benefit of the minority, then it's time for a change. The direction and methods of that change have yet to be decided. May 1 Well, it kicked off as to be expected, the minority viewpoint gets all the mention, McDonald's gets trashed, some shit goes off and suddenly everyone's a terrorist! No more protest in the capital, they scream. I wonder if it's just me who sees things the way I do - am I on my own with the shop smashers - maybe they got the right agenda? - think not, heard about the O/B screening everyone on the way out - not there - some of us gotta work! May 6 Just seen my photo and I guess it's official - I'm now a wanted man! It's quite a shock to turn the pages of the major city paper (the Evening Standard) and find yourself staring back at yourself (crap picture as well!). No bad thing. Shocked, scared and disbelieving - don't even begin to explain the emotions after I read their nonsense - "General" indeed - so out of touch as to be beyond belief. They are setting me up as a fall guy: they messed up J18, N-30 and May Day and of course some "mastermind" has to be behind it all, otherwise wouldn't it show up their incompetence! What are all the resources for, if we can't tell where and when! Practicalities come first, who will recognise me? Will they squeal or have a laugh about it? Lisa rings - spotted. Nick rings - spotted (by her mum, no less!). The phone starts to go! Move house. Try to remember what went on at Euston, made a speech, harassed the Met's undercover surveillance crew. Irish in London making seditious statements - trouble ... Everybody rings tonight. Go see solicitor. Two choices: Hide & Seek or surrender - no chance! May 15-16 Just as I was thinking things are going back to normal, big bang, the Mail comes to the Met's rescue - Anarchist general in the area. All the rightwing shit sure to follow! Old Bill call at door - or so I think (N says I'm being paranoid). Maybe - gotta move. Am I going to be spotted or not? Surprisingly for the amount of people who know me not one has dropped me in it! Will work find out? May 20 The race is on between me and them - me to hide, them to find. It's interesting that they have to resort to their friends and colleagues in the rightwing press to follow their charges. May 23 Cops come to door - time to go move out - no one knows my address. No one knows my phone. So now life revolves around the surefire fact that the knock will come - only a matter of time I guess. However, if they want me they can spend some of their fucking resources in the process! I find it really strange that I can be labelled as a threat to the state, considering the limited violence alone, and its comparisons to the defused violence which is propagated against the weak, poor, disenfranchised and ignorant within our society by the state apparatus.

webTitle: France Telecom 'pretty close' to £30bn deal for Orange

fields.headline: France Telecom 'pretty close' to £30bn deal for Orange
fields.trailText: Shares in France Telecom climbed sharply yesterday amid rising expectations that it is close to a £30bn deal to buy mobile phone operator Orange from Vodafone Airtouch.
fields.body:
Shares in France Telecom climbed sharply yesterday amid rising expectations that it is close to a £30bn deal to buy mobile phone operator Orange from Vodafone Airtouch.

Some reports suggest that Vodafone could announce the sale of Orange to the French group early next week.

"I think it's pretty much a done deal now - both parties seem keen to do it," according to one banker close to the deal.

Orange has attracted attention from telecoms companies around the world. As well as France Telecom, the Dutch group KPN - backed by Japan's NTT DoCoMo - Finland's Sonera and America's MCI Worldcom have all been tipped as possible bidders.

France Telecom is regarded as having stolen a march on any rival bidder by putting together a £20bn loan facility to help finance the deal.

Vodafone must demerge Orange, which it acquired when it took over Mannesmann of Germany, to satisfy the European Union's competition authorities. Until recently it had been expected to comply with the competition ruling by returning Orange to the stock market.

Last week Vodafone's chief executive, Chris Gent, admitted the group was prepared to look at a trade sale.

The cash injection from a trade sale would be extremely helpful to Vodafone which is heavily involved in the competition for third-generation mobile phone licences across Europe. But it is unlikely to want to be rushed and might be prepared to dust off the flotation plan - the option preferred by Orange's top management - if it feels that it is not being offered the right price.

"The fundamental respect in which the world has changed in the last four or five weeks is the price for [third generation] licences," said one analyst.

"As a means of raising capital to fund that, an Orange sale clearly makes a lot of sense but only if the price is right."

Orange's value means that any trade sale is almost certain to involve a mixture of cash and shares.

"It is unlikely the French could afford the price in cash. I think that is true of any potential buyer. Therefore it is quite likely that an offer would contain a significant amount of stock," said one industry observer.

European regulators have already made it clear that they will scrutinise any trade sale closely to ensure that it does not limit competition.

Yesterday France Telecom shares rose more than 4%, despite a fall in technology stocks on the Paris market, while in London shares in Vodafone were down 7p at 280.25p.
