webTitle: Core values but few spending pledges in Labour policy papers

fields.headline: Core values but few spending pledges in Labour policy papers
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Leaked Labour documents setting out plans for a second term have revealed a party determined not to steer from its fundamental course.
fields.body:
Leaked Labour documents setting out plans for a second term have revealed a party determined not to steer from its fundamental course.

The papers, obtained by the Guardian, show how Tony Blair and his ministers are set on standing firm on their core concerns - despite the recent populist onslaught by William Hague.

The papers, due to go to the policy forum in the summer, cover education, the economy, Britain in the world, the environment, industry and modern democracy. And despite holding out few spending promises, they provide an insight into the direction which Labour intends to take if it is given another five years.

Democracy and the citizen

Labour will keep to the referendum pledge on electoral reform made in the last mainifesto. But in order to allow existing reforms to take root it holds off from calling for referendums on regional assemblies. The paper does acknowledge a crisis in democracy and holds out the prospect of sweeping reforms of the electoral system. It said: "There is no concensus on controversial changes such as compulsory voting." It acknowledges the need to look at internet voting. On Lords reform, the paper promises to accept an elected element in the upper house "to ensure that there is a voice in the parliament for the regions and nations of the UK".

Nationalisation

The papers reject recent conference calls to renationalise the railways and the Post Office. On railways, it promises instead: "Refranchising will bring in tens of billions of investment over the next decade and will give passengers a better deal from train operators."

They reject full public ownership of the Post Office being written into the next general election manifesto but insist it will be a publicly owned PLC, and any sales of shares will require an affirmitive vote in both houses of parliament. The papers also holds out the prospect of "an independent body to oversee transport safety across a range of travel needs".

The environment

The documents call for further tax breaks for environmentally friendly technologies, more offshore wind farms and custodial sentences for wildlife criminals, including a requirement for landowners to restore damaged sites at their own cost. Ministers are proposing an anti-noise strategy, including new action against graffiti.

Society and crime

Tougher penalties are promised on drink and drug drivers.

The papers hint at reforms to housing benefit first by making changes to rents. They propose comparable rents for comparable properties, and rents that take account of the size and quality of homes on offer. They propose modernising social housing allocation, removing the antiquated points system.

Europe and the world

A separate paper adopts a strong pro-European tone welcoming enlargement of the EU, saying Britian is willing to give up its veto on the council of ministers in some areas, notably transport and the European court of justice. It insists the veto will be maintained in defence.

It also promises an autumn white paper examining how globalisation can work for the poor. The document promises "an increase in Britain's development budget year on year as a proportion of GDP".

Ministers want an increase in the amount of EU aid going to poorest countries to 70% by 2006, up from 50% today. The paper promises to seek an international agreement to prevent further debt by ensuring that export credits are not given for excessive military spending.

The paper also calls for a shake-up of the UN, including reform of the security council with expansion of the permanent membership to include Germany and Japan.

Education

The tone of the papers suggests a government willing to break more taboos if it believes this will raise standards. On the future of comprehensive schools it says: "We want to see schools which focus on what works and [to] abandon any residual dogmatic attachment to mixed ability teaching." A green paper on school funding will be published in the summer.

The paper will add fuel to the renewed controversy over Oxbridge admissions. "Only 17% of young people from lower socio-economic groups enter higher education , compared to 45% of those from non-manual groups. Some universities take less than 5% of their students from areas with historically low levels of participation in higher education".

Work

The papers reveal ministers considering whether Sure Start can be expanded beyond 250 schemes. They also promise to make the New Deal for the unemployed a permanent deal lasting the whole of the next parliament. With some unions threatening a row at the policy forum over economic and industrial policy, the papers stress further increases in the minimum wage and movement on parental leave.

fields.headline: Turbulence:  Branson's short-haul losses grow
fields.trailText: Virgin Express, the short-haul airline, yesterday said it was likely to suffer a fall in earnings following the rise of the dollar against the euro, and continued rises in fuel prices.
fields.body:
Virgin Express, the short-haul airline, yesterday said it was likely to suffer a fall in earnings following the rise of the dollar against the euro, and continued rises in fuel prices.

The comments came as the Brussels-based airline, part of the Virgin empire run by Sir Richard Branson reported sharply higher first-quarter losses of €13.8m (£8.6m) on sales of €59.8m. In the same period last year the company lost €3m on sales of €54.m.

A spokesman for the company said that while revenues continued to rise strongly, the airline's costs going forward were a major problem. The 23% increase in first-quarter costs to €73.6m was due to an unfavourable movement in the dollar-euro exchange rate of 14%, an increase in unit fuel prices of 74%, and a rise of 15% in hours flown, he said.

The airline has been squeezed between other low-cost operators and renewed aggression from established players on the continent.

The spokesman said restructuring had continued to eliminate structurally unprofitable routes, noting the end to flights between Rome and Madrid, Rome and Barcelona, and Brussels and Stansted. A bus shuttle between Brussels and Rotterdam had also been stopped, it said.

He said passenger volumes continued to grow, though bookings were closer to the day of departure, and load factors were down, while yields were up.

webTitle: Brewery jobs at risk as W&D reviews operations

fields.headline: Brewery jobs at risk as W&D reviews operations
fields.trailText: Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries has launched a review into its regional brewing operations in a move which could see the Midlands-based group wind down or close some its four breweries.
fields.body:
Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries has launched a review into its regional brewing operations in a move which could see the Midlands-based group wind down or close some its four breweries.

The decision to undertake the review will come as a further blow to the UK brewing industry, which is already in a state of upheaval. Earlier this week Whitbread finalised the sale of its breweries to Belgium's Interbrew, and Bass is believed to be in the closing stages of selling its six breweries, which make the popular Carling and Tennent's lagers.

W&D employs 1,000 workers in its four regional breweries - Banks's in Wolverhampton, Cameron's in Hartlepool, the Pedigree brewery in Burton-on-Trent and the newly-acquired Mansfield operation. Some of these jobs may be at risk. The company is unlikely to quit brewing altogether and it is understood to want to stay in regional brewing.

Last year, W&D bought both the Marston and Mansfield breweries in two multi-million-pound takeovers.

At the time of the £250m Mansfield deal, W&D said it would remain "committed" to that operation for "at least" two years. Around 200 jobs have already been lost at Mansfield.

The decision to press ahead with the review followed a warning in January that intense competition within the sector and higher operating costs were squeezing margins.

Yesterday the company announced that the acquisitions of both Marstons and Mansfield had boosted brewing profits from £6m to £9.1m during the half year, while total volumes brewed across the group were up 82%.

Pre-tax profits of £25m before goodwill, exceptional and accountancy charges, surged past the previous year's £19m, but disappointed analysts, who had expected profits of at least £27m.

Overall turnover was up 66.5% at £277m, reflecting acquisitions made in the period, though like-for-like retail sales rose just 1.1%.

webTitle: GWR plans brand extension into pay-TV

fields.headline: GWR plans brand extension into pay-TV
fields.standfirst: Leading radio group negotiates joint ventures with Daily Mail & General Trust
fields.trailText: GWR, one of Britain's leading radio groups, is planning the launch of a pay-television channel using its popular Classic FM brand.
fields.body:
GWR, one of Britain's leading radio groups, is planning the launch of a pay-television channel using its popular Classic FM brand.

The group is in talks with Daily Mail & General Trust (DMGT) that are likely to result in the rebranding of the newspaper group's arts TV station, the Performance Channel.

The talks demonstrate a deepening relationship between the companies which is likely to see a series of new joint ventures launched this year. DMGT owns an 18.8% stake in GWR.

The pair have also agreed to develop local net portals in areas where GWR has stations or DMGT owns local papers. As well as Classic FM, GWR has 38 local licences as well as an overseas radio business.

The local portals would exploit the companies' combined content, promotion and advertising sales.

They are also attempting to use as leverage the readership of the Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday and the 6.3m Classic FM weekly listeners in new media - in the past year GWR has invested £46m in growing its net and digital businesses.

The radio group reported a 37.5% leap in pre-tax profits for the year to April and said trading in the past few months had been "very encouraging".

Chief executive Ralph Bernard said the strong performance had been driven by a boom in the advertising market. Group profits were up from £18.1m to £24.9m in the year to April. Revenues were 22% higher at £102m.

He said Classic FM had also consolidated its position as Britain's largest commercial radio station, with 12% growth in listening hours over the year according to Rajar.

GWR chairman Henry Meakin paid tribute to the "strengthening of our brands", which he said was attracting both higher audience figures and revenues.

In November, Digital One, which is 63% owned by GWR and 37% by cable company NTL, launched the commercial national digital network.

GWR operates three of the new national digital stations: Classic FM, Core and Planet Rock. Sceptics have doubted the speed at which services will be taken up, but the company said that momentum behind the adoption of digital radio was growing "at an encouraging rate".

GWR's net ventures have been parked in another firm, Ecast Ventures. It aims to launch a radio entertainment website under Musicradio.com.

webTitle: Criminal justice goes online in crown courts

fields.headline: Criminal justice goes online in crown courts
fields.trailText: Crown courts will go hi-tech in a £32m modernisation programme to speed up criminal justice and make it easier for jurors to understand complex evidence.
fields.body:
Crown courts will go hi-tech in a £32m modernisation programme to speed up criminal justice and make it easier for jurors to understand complex evidence.

The lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, announced the measures yesterday in Court 12 at the Old Bailey in central London, and said they would save money and help victims, witnesses and jurors.

In a pilot scheme at 10 crown courts, displays on computer screens will replace the traditional hefty bundles of documents to be perused by jurors as well as judges and lawyers. Documents, diagrams and photographs will be called up on the screen in seconds; jurors will be able, for example, to compare signatures on two documents side by side, while prosecutors can highlight relevant passages on screen.

The changes promise to revolutionise serious fraud cases, in which the time taken to locate documents and hand them round to the jury prolongs what are already lengthy trials.

In an earlier pilot study a saving equivalent to one court day per week was attained. The savings should be substantial, as it costs £8,800 a day to run a courtroom, on top of which come barristers' and solicitors' fees, charged by the day. In one case £8,000 was saved in photocopying costs.

The computers can also be used in internet prosecutions to show jurors how the alleged offence was committed.

Lord Irvine said that he was "fired up with enthusiasm" when he had a demonstration in Singapore last September of how the system worked there.

"Introducing modern technology and working practices will revolutionise the crown court - helping bring about speedier administration of justice, reduced costs, and a better service to victims, witnesses and jurors," he said.

Details of cases, hearings and general court procedures will also be posted on the internet, while hearings will be arranged by email instead of by separate phone calls to police, defence and the crown prosecution service.

Inside court buildings, electronic display boards and information kiosks will let those waiting know what is going on in each court.

Court proceedings will be digitally recorded, allowing replays in court and transcriptions for appeals.

Court clerks will be able to email information such as bail notices and imprisonment orders to criminal justice agencies and the defence. They will also be able to set dates for short hearings from the courtroom, so everyone will know immediately instead of having to go away and wait to be notified.

Details of cases, hearings and general court procedures will also be posted on the internet, while hearings will be arranged by email instead of by separate phone calls to police, defence and the crown prosecution service. Inside court buildings, electronic display boards and information kiosks will let those waiting know what is going on in each court. Court proceedings will be digitally recorded, allowing replays in court and transcriptions for appeals. Court clerks will be able to email information such as bail notices and imprisonment orders to criminal justice agencies and the defence. They will also be able to set dates for short hearings from the courtroom, so everyone will know immediately instead of having to go away and wait to be notified.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: With a long weekend ahead, the City was taking things easy. The FTSE 100 eased 14.2 to 6,216.9, but few traders seemed to be active and little more than one billion shares changed hands, poor volume by recent standards.
fields.body:
With a long weekend ahead, the City was taking things easy. The FTSE 100 eased 14.2 to 6,216.9, but few traders seemed to be active and little more than one billion shares changed hands, poor volume by recent standards.

The drags on the market included merger partners, Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham , which shed 52p to £19.31 and 16.5p to 863.5p, respectively.

Invensys , the old BTR Siebe conglomerate, fell from 290p to 268p after reports that it was in talks to buy troubled Dutch software group Baan. The British firm declined to comment on the reports.

On the Amsterdam stock market, Baan has been flying all over the place during recent days as rumours of a rescue takeover have swirled. Before Invensys was linked to the company, continental traders had assumed that Oracle would buy this firm.

In London, against the generally bearish trend, there was some relatively fast action among insurance merger partners CGU and Norwich Union . Next week sees the formation of the new entity, CGNU, and news that it will be included in the FTSE life assurance index (which carries a higher rating than the general insurance index where CGU had to sit), sparked a quick flurry of buying. The grey market price for CGNU added 47.5p to £10.40p.

Elsewhere, Semple Cochrane, a facilities management firm, crashed 42.5p to 80p after being warned that an independent review of the firm was likely to show a "material" reduction in assets. Dividend payments have been put on hold, new management has been appointed and the company is now looking at its "strategic options" - as well as talking to its bankers.

Industrial materials group Morgan Crucible warned shareholders attending its annual meeting that first-half growth had been slower than anticipated, blaming exchange rates and margin pressures. The shares fell 23p to 219.5p.

Antisoma , the biotech play, saw its shares bounce 29p to 100.5p after an independent committee overseeing study of its Theragyn ovarian cancer remedy said the recruitment of trial patients should be restarted. The stock plunged by 40% at the beginning of the week when the Phase III trials were halted after a study by a PhD student showed adverse effects from using a similar product.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: 201,250 notes for Beethoven
fields.body:
201,250 notes for Beethoven

Two unpublished pages of Ludwig van Beethoven's score for the Pastoral Symphony, complete with alterations, were sold for £201,250 at Sotheby's in London yesterday. They contain the principal themes for the fifth and final movement of the Sixth Symphony, used in Walt Disney's film Fantasia.

17m Britons have internet access

More than 1m Britons went online in April, according to Nielsen/NetRatings, raising the total to 17m, of whom 8m are active users. Average use is 5 hours 11 minutes a week, compared with 9 hours in the United States.

All change for Radio1 DJs

DJ Clive Warren is to leave Radio 1 after six years. He and Andy Kershaw, who is also leaving, will be re placed by Vicky Marsden, from Napa FM, Cyprus, and Nemone Metaxas from Galaxy 102.

Virgin raises train prices

Virgin trains today raises the price of a Manchester to London weekday return from £48 to £90, while a return leaving before 9.30am costs £150. A £25 return from Liverpool to Luton is offered by easyJet.
Angelique Chrisafis

Jailed solicitor loses aid cash

Newcastle crown court yesterday ordered that a solicitor repay £170,000 obtained illegally from legal aid, and that proceedings be taken to seize a large part of his £2.5m assets. Bernard Ridsdale-Tombling, 45, from Normanby in Middlesbrough, was also jailed for four years, having admitted deception and fraud.

Suntan lotion safety alert

Superdrug has removed bottles of Looney Tunes Safe Sun Lotions for children from shelves after its rival, Boots, warned it may offer half the level of protection marked on the label with a Boots safety star-rating that was revoked in 1999.

fields.headline: Victim statement scheme expanded
fields.trailText: Victims of even the most minor crimes will be able to give a statement about the impact that the offence has had on their lives under a national scheme announced yesterday by the home secretary, Jack Straw.
fields.body:
Victims of even the most minor crimes will be able to give a statement about the impact that the offence has had on their lives under a national scheme announced yesterday by the home secretary, Jack Straw.

But they will not be asked for their views on what punishment the court should impose on the convicted offender. An appeal court ruling only last month warned judges and magistrates that they must treat such "victim impact statements" with caution, and they should not give the victim a say in what punishment should be imposed.

The use of victim impact statements was first proposed in the victim's charter in 1990 and they have been used as a matter of routine in cases of violent crime for many years. Pilot schemes to encourage victims in all kinds of cases to describe how the crime has affected them were initiated in six police force areas three years ago.

Mr Straw said yesterday that the scheme would go nationwide from next year. It would "give victims a voice in a way that they have not had before. It will be a real opportunity to make their views known more formally to the police, crown prosecution service and the courts and to know they will be taken into account in the case. I want victims to feel they are at the heart of the criminal justice system."

It is yet another government "announcement" this week on law and order in the face of the renewed Conservative offensive on the issue. On Monday the cabinet office minister, Mo Mowlam, "announced" plans for a national confiscation agency, to seize the assets of convicted criminals, which were first detailed in a Home Office consultation paper in November 1998.

This was followed by a plan for a new offence of corporate killing, which was put forward by the law commission in 1996, to give the prosecution the right to appeal against judge-directed acquittals, and by the reissue of advice to treat children under 18 involved in prostitution as victims.

Although the introduction of victim impact statements was treated in some quarters as if Britain were adopting the American and Saudi Arabian practice of allowing the views of victims to determine the punishment, the Home Office made clear yesterday that judges and magistrates were not being asked to go down the road of "victim-led justice".

The appeal court ruling on April 19 also warned the courts about limitations of victim impact statements, which it said were already a common feature of the sentencing process. "A sentencer must not make assumptions, unsupported by evidence, about the effects of an offence on the victim."

It went on to rule out asking the victim what sentence he or she thought should be passed but did add that "if an offence had a particularly damaging or distressing effect upon a victim, that should be known to, and taken into account by, the court when passing sentence".

Mr Straw said yesterday that the national scheme would see victim impact statements produced in minor cases as well as the more serious ones and would ensure that the impact on the victim was taken into account of by police and crown prosecutors at a much earlier stage in their investigations.

But the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, said the scheme risked jeopardising the courts' impartiality. "This is a cynical tactic aimed at masking the reality of Jack Straw's failure to get a grip of law and order," she said.

However, Dame Helen Reeves, chief executive of Victim Support, said: "For the first time victims will be able to communicate directly with all the people dealing with their case. They will be able to have their own interests considered by asking for the compensation, support or protection they need."

George Pothecary, assistant chief constable for Dorset and spokesman on crime victims for the Association of Chief Police Officers, said: "The police service is committed to improving its support for the victims of crime, and Acpo fully supports this initiative."

fields.headline: Ex-minister damns government spin
fields.standfirst:
Downing Street 'arrogant and out of touch'
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The former arts minister Mark Fisher has launched a damning broadside against Downing Street, saying that the gilt has come off an arrogant and out of touch government.
fields.body:
The former arts minister Mark Fisher has launched a damning broadside against Downing Street, saying that the gilt has come off an arrogant and out of touch government.

In probably the strongest backbench attack on the government since the resignation of Peter Kilfoyle as junior defence minister, Mr Fisher said the government was perceived to be "London-based, centralised and arrogant. Disillusionment and disgruntlement abound".

In a letter to his Stoke-on-Trent Central constituency party, Mr Fisher claimed: "Ministers want to control the details of every new initiative, many of which are in themselves welcome and excellent. They are going too fast and too uncritically with modernisation without thinking through the changes."

Mr Fisher, who saw the collapse of Labour's base in Stoke in the local elections this month, also attacked "the nauseating spin campaign against Mo Mowlam", saying it "suggests Downing Street is still in the grip of southern modernising spin doctors".

He added: "Tony Blair manages to give the impression that he does not like trade unions, local authorities and the Labour party. People have sensed this, and they don't like it.

"They look at the glitz surrounding Downing Street and spin doctors like Alastair Campbell, and they feel that this government is not on the side of those who are not entrepreneurs or executives surfing the net."

Downing Street "does not seem to worry about those on low incomes in cities like ours. It has not worried about the traditional Labour vote."

In the next year "we need less Mandelsonian theory about modernisation and more practical iniatives which show that we do care for the pensioners and for the poor _ but I am not confident we are going to get it.

"Some policies, like pensions and abolition of the married couples allowance, were not popular. Some are not working: the child support agency and disability welfare reform, the reduction in hospital waiting lists."

Calling for a brainstorming session locally to put matters right, he said the government had some time, but not a lot.

Last night Mr Campbell, the prime minister's spokesman, refused to respond directly, but he let it be known that he regarded himself as "a northern technophobe who does not know what the net is, let alone surf it".

He did say that Mr Fisher's comments were not an accurate reflection of the government. There was anger in Downing Street that Mr Fisher "continued to peddle this media lie about the campaign against Mo Mowlam".

webTitle: Softbank decline hits Japanese net sector

fields.headline: Softbank decline hits Japanese net sector
fields.standfirst:
Asset sales halt largest web investor's slide into red
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Asset sales halt largest web investor's slide into red
fields.body:
Japan's nascent love affair with the internet suffered a blow yesterday with the announcement of a sharp profit decline by Softbank, the country's largest investor in the web.

The vast holding company, run by internet tycoon Masayoshi Son, posted net income of ¥8.4bn (£670m) for the year ending March 31. This was 77% down on the company's performance last year.

According to analysts Softbank was only able to stay in the black thanks to a one-off ¥220bn sale of some of its prime internet assets, including anti-virus software developer Trend Micro and the e-commerce system provider Softbank Technology.

With major holdings in Yahoo!, E*Trade and more than 300 other internet firms, Softbank is one of the world's biggest e-investors. But this has made it particularly vulnerable to the ups and downs of dot.com share prices.

After rising more than twentyfold in the year to February, Softbank's stock price has plunged by 75% as investors have turned their backs on internet shares.

The shift back towards the old economy of more estab lished Japanese firms has been accelerated by the latest corporate results, which have shown many big manufacturers returning to the black after years in the doldrums. According to one survey, Japan's listed companies racked up an average profit growth of more than 90% in 1999.

Despite Softbank's slide in the opposite direction Mr Son was unrepentant, and vowed to focus even more closely on web-related businesses. He said the company's decision to sell holdings in Kingston Technology, a US motherboard manufacturer, and Ziff Davis, a media group, were proof of the company's intentions.

"We are now closer to becoming a pure internet company," he said. "With our pool of investments we will catch on to the fast growth that is the internet."

In an effort to regain in vestor interest, Mr Son announced that the Softbank group will float several of its group companies - including the financial unit Softbank Finance, which racked up some of the group's most impressive growth. Reports about the plan helped to push up Softbank's share price yesterday by the maximum daily limit of 12.4% - suggesting that Mr Son may succeed in recovering from this latest setback.

webTitle: Breaking point: Hostages in the Philippines 'becoming suicidal'

fields.headline: Breaking point: Hostages in the Philippines 'becoming suicidal'
fields.trailText: As the guerrillas holding 21 mostly foreign hostages in the Philippine jungle yesterday cancelled negotiations for their release, concern was growing in Germany for their physical - and, above all - mental wellbeing. According to one of the captives, some are close to suicide.
fields.body:
As the guerrillas holding 21 mostly foreign hostages in the Philippine jungle yesterday cancelled negotiations for their release, concern was growing in Germany for their physical - and, above all - mental wellbeing. According to one of the captives, some are close to suicide.

Nine Malaysians, three Germans, two Finns, a French couple, two South Africans, a young Lebanese woman and two Filipinos will enter their sixth week in captivity on the island of Jolo tomorrow. They were snatched by Muslim separatists on April 23 from a Malaysian holiday resort.

Two developments have prompted fears for the victims, who were either on holiday or at work in the resort when the terrorists struck.

On Wednesday the German tabloid Bild published a photograph showing the leader of the rebels, Galib Andang, also known as "Commander Robot", with his arms around two of his captives - Werner and Renate Wallert from Göttingen. All three were smiling.

The paper asked what sort of pressure had been put on the Wallerts to agree to be photographed in this way. Mrs Wallert, 56, was giving a particularly unconvincing smile. She suffers from high blood pressure and had earlier been seen in video footage rocking to and fro with a fixed gaze and having her head held up as one of the other hostages poured water into her mouth.

Though medication has since reached her, the images of her suffering have made a profound impact in Germany and put her release at the top of the negotiators' agenda.

Interviews conducted by German and Filipino journalists at the kidnappers' hide-out have highlighted the less visible plight of some of the other captives. Mirko Johannen Risto from Finland said: "There are those among the hostages who are suffering acute nervous exhaustion. They have nightmares and some are seriously considering suicide."

A French hostage, Sonia Wendling, hinted at disputes over food. "Now we have new rations," she said. "We talked over this problem and now it is again OK within the group. Now it is better."

However one of the other hostages said: "We are still weak, tired and hungry."

They were seized by the smaller and more radical of two guerrilla movements fighting for an independent Islamic state in the impoverished southern Philippines.

Though the Abu Sayyaf (father of the sword) group claims political motivation, opponents say it is on the wrong side the line between guerrilla warfare and banditry.

Its formal demands include the setting up of an independent Islamic state. Informally, Abu Sayyaf has asked for up to $2m (£1.3m) just to free Mrs Wallert.

Changes to the government's negotiating team and skirmishes between rebels and troops have combined to delay the talks. But Manila's chief negotiator, Robert Aventajado, was optimistic.

"I think the conditions are right. Abu Sayyaf trusts that the military will not attack, and the military is cooperating," he said.

The government's spokesman meanwhile signalled a readiness to discuss ransom terms. "We have to look at things realistically," said Ricardo Puno. "I believe that, in the case of ransom money being demanded, we ought to discuss it."

But the Philippines' foreign minister earlier cautioned against hopes of an early outcome. Domingo Siazon told envoys from Germany, France and Finland that previous kidnappings by Abu Sayyaf had lasted three to six months.

At the guerrillas' hide-out Sonia Wendling explained how the hostages kept their spirits up by singing together. "If we didn't do that," she added, "we couldn't stand it any more."

webTitle: Masayoshi Son: bringing back the cash

fields.headline: Masayoshi Son: bringing back the cash
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Softbank yesterday announced a new strategy to procure capital through the public listing of several of its group companies. Chairman Masayoshi Son said the flotations would provide more opportunities for investment in the ¥6 trillion Softbank group - criticised for being inaccessible because only a fraction of its shares are traded.
fields.body:
Softbank yesterday announced a new strategy to procure capital through the public listing of several of its group companies. Chairman Masayoshi Son said the flotations would provide more opportunities for investment in the ¥6 trillion Softbank group - criticised for being inaccessible because only a fraction of its shares are traded.

"By listing the holding companies we can promote disclosure standards and improve the transparency of our group businesses," Mr Son said. But he did not reveal any details about the IPOs. According to industry observers five companies, including Softbank Finance , will be listed. Softbank has announced a three-for-one share split in the parent on June 23.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Mugabe ally shot by police
fields.body:
Mugabe ally shot by police

Police shot dead a supporter of President Robert Mugabe's ruling party after he and others stormed a police station 90 miles north of Harare, an official said yesterday.

In the first reported shooting of a Mugabe supporter since February's constitutional referendum, the unidentified man was fatally wounded when police tried to disperse a mob in Mvurmi attempting to free 19 members of the ruling Zanu-PF party, who had been arrested for attacking political opponents.
AP Harare

Marley cancels Austrian show

The reggae star Ziggy Marley has cancelled a performance in Austria to show his opposition to the participation of a far-right party in its federal government, concert organisers said yesterday. Marley cancelled his June 17 date in Wiesen, in the eastern province of Burgenland, to protest at the presence of "a Nazi in government", his promoters said.
AP, Vienna

Afghans apply to stay in Iran

Some 55,000 Afghan refugees in Iran have appealed against being sent back to their country, forcing the office of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees to speed up its claims process, the UNHCR said yesterday. Fewer than 1,500 appeals have been dealt with so far.
AP, Geneva

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Rover runs short of models
The sudden surge in sales of Rover cars has left the company with a new problem - shortage of models. Diesel versions of the company's flagship car, the Rover 75, have run out as have a number of four-door versions of the Rover 45.
fields.body:
Rover runs short of models
The sudden surge in sales of Rover cars has left the company with a new problem - shortage of models. Diesel versions of the company's flagship car, the Rover 75, have run out as have a number of four-door versions of the Rover 45.

Some Rover 25 models are also unavailable, according to Glass's Guide. "This makes a change from reports of unsold cars piling up in some field," said a spokesman. "However, the switch of production of the 75 from Cowley in Oxford to Longbridge in Birmingham may lead to continuing unavailability of the model for a while."

Rover sales rocketed in April. The company took a 13.48% share of the new car market last month, second only to Ford. The Rover 25 topped the April 2000 best-sellers' list.

BP buys out Bayer stake

BP Amoco agreed on Friday to buy out its 50:50 German petrochemicals joint venture partner Bayer in a deal analysts said was worth around $500m (£336m). BP and Bayer said in separate statements they expected to reach a final agreement on BP's acquisition of Bayer's stake in Cologne-based Erdoelchemie early in 2001. Neither would comment on the price. Bayer said the whole business had annual sales of €1.3bn, and BP said that when wholly owned, it would account for 10% of its worldwide petrochemical capacity and make BP Amoco Chemicals one of the top three European olefins producers.

Insurance sales fall by 2%
Insurance firms sold products worth £13.1bn in the first quarter of this year, down 2% on last year, according to figures from the Association of British Insurers yesterday.

The value of life insurance policies rose from last year while sales of pensions and collective investment products fell. Life insurance sales rose to £6.4bn in the first quarter from £5.8bn in 1999.

The value of new pension premiums fell 14% to £2.1bn, with a 5% drop in sales. Separately sales of investment products, such as unit trusts, fell in value by 11% to £2.8bn.

Poll boost for Standard Life

Standard Life claimed mounting opposition against demutualisation yesterday citing a Mori poll which showed support for the campaign led by carpetbagger Ken Woollard had fallen from 32% two weeks ago to 18%. The poll of 500 voting members showed that 43% were against demutualisation and 39% undecided.

Sega shake-up after big loss
Sega president Shoichirou Irimajiri is resigning after the company posted a loss of ¥42.9bn for the year to March. Poor sales of Sega's Dreamcast games console are to blame, say officials.

Chairman Isao Ohkawa, who is also chairman of Sega's biggest shareholder, CSK, will replace Irimajiri and take charge of restructuring. Mr Irimajiri will become vice-chairman and focus on developing a successor to Dreamcast.

fields.headline: Worth the wait
fields.standfirst:
Iran's new parliament is finally here

More about Iran
fields.trailText: Those who were appalled by the delay in counting the votes for this month's London mayoral election - the final result was not declared until lunchtime the following day - should spare a thought for the people of Iran. They voted in their parliamentary elections in February, and yet the results were not formally announced until last Saturday.
fields.body:
Those who were appalled by the delay in counting the votes for this month's London mayoral election - the final result was not declared until lunchtime the following day - should spare a thought for the people of Iran. They voted in their parliamentary elections in February, and yet the results were not formally announced until last Saturday. Wrangling over dodgy ballot boxes had dragged on for three months. Still, when the outcome was finally confirmed it could not have been clearer: reformers had swept the board. Today they will take their seats in the 290-member body, the first time they have been in command since the 1979 revolution.

As if to symbolise the completeness of the rout, the conservatives' best-known candidate, the former president Hashemi Rafsanjani, has now announced that he will not even take up his seat. Apparently Mr Rafsanjani, who some had tipped to become the new speaker, was disheartened at his abysmal personal showing in the election. In the battle to represent the capital, Tehran, which has 30 seats, the former president scraped through - in 30th place.

This is all very good news for Iran. It means that the reform-minded president, Mohammad Khatami, will have a partner of clout: he and the parliament can now counterbalance both the ultras on the Council of Guardians and Iran's supreme leader, the fundamentalist Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. Better still, the reformers have momentum on their side. The average age in the new chamber will be 15 years younger than in the outgoing body, with many fewer clerics on the benches. Most important is the fact that the new body is assembling at all. The last three months were tense: there were real fears that the conservatives might simply ignore the people's will, annul the elections and stay in power. Instead they have stuck to their constitution - and the grip of Islamic dictatorship has weakened just a little bit more.

fields.headline: A question of attribution
fields.trailText: Michael Daley (Case of restored panel, May 22) is entitled to whatever views he chooses to hold on the attribution of of the Samson and Delilah painted by Rubensnow hanging in the National Gallery. What he is not entitled to do is to make untrue and unsubstantiated allegations.
fields.body:
Michael Daley (Case of restored panel, May 22) is entitled to whatever views he chooses to hold on the attribution of of the Samson and Delilah painted by Rubensnow hanging in the National Gallery; even though they are shared by none of the leading Rubens experts, for whom this is not only a work by Rubens, but among the greatest of his early career.

What he is not entitled to do is to make untrue and unsubstantiated allegations. The clear implication of his remarks is that senior members of National Gallery staff tampered with the picture by planing down the panel, perhaps to remove evidence of attribution, and that the gallery has dishonestly denied that this has happened.

May I state that the wooden support on the panel was not planed down while the picture was in the possession of the gallery, and the implication that the gallery has behaved as he suggested is quite absurd.
Neil MacGregor
Director, National Gallery

I do not claim in the Art Review as fact that the National Gallery altered the back of Rubens's Samson and Delilah to conceal its inauthenticity. I draw attention to the gallery's failure to identify the circumstances of a radical intervention which served no conservation need and of which no record has been produced. This lapse of accountability disturbs because, as the gallery admits, the treatment may have destroyed evidence with direct bearing on the picture's weak provenance.
Michael Daley
East Barnet, Herts

fields.headline: Why our screens are dim
fields.trailText: Jacques Peretti claims Brit-flicks are "shit-flicks" (Shame of a Nation, Friday Review, May 26) because British producers are arrogant idiots. Alan Parker blames the scripts. They're both right but missing the big picture.
fields.body:
Jacques Peretti claims Brit-flicks are "shit-flicks" (Shame of a Nation, Friday Review, May 26) because British producers are arrogant idiots. Alan Parker blames the scripts. They're both right but missing the big picture.

When my new novel was grabbed by a pre-emptive bid from Tom Cruise's production company, I was thrilled but concerned that the book went directly to Hollywood and no British producer ever got a peek at it. Since the Hollywood agency involved struck a cherry-picking pact with the publishers Bloomsbury, we're looking at organised cream-skimming.

But after 11 years in development hell with earlier books, I have to agree with Peretti's judgment on British producers. And add that investment in our writers, and education to prepare them to work in a global culture, has been culpably neglected.
Celia Brayfield
London

The French New Wave of 40 years ago left behind not only masterpieces but the lesson that they can only be made by dedicated craftsman. Godard spent weeks experimenting with film stock before he achieved that unique look that is as much a star of Breathless as Belmondo.
Chris Jones
Luton

Giving people free money to make films is likely to result in bad films. Art should be almost impossible to do. That weeds out the chancers. Countries which subsidise film-making make poor films. For instance France. (Or us.)
Peter Howell
London

webTitle: My film is not biased against Palestinians

fields.headline: My film is not biased against Palestinians
fields.trailText: Kevin MacDonald writes: I would like to respond to Edward Said's inaccurate and innuendo-ridden attack on my film One Day in September (Saturday Review, May 20).
fields.body:
I would like to respond to Edward Said's inaccurate and innuendo-ridden attack on my film One Day in September (Saturday Review, May 20). His article follows similar attacks in Israel and Germany. In Israel I was accused of justifying or glamourising terrorism and castigated for "humanising" a terrorist. The families of the dead Israelis have been outraged because the Palestinian voice in the film has significantly more screen time than they do.

Said is correct that many atrocities have been carried out by the Israeli government which could also be the subject of a film: but they are not the subject of this film. This film deals with a single event: one day in September not 50 years of Arab-Israeli conflict.

Most audiences (and critics) emerge from the film not praising Zionism nor hating Palestinians, but shocked by German incompetence and the needless waste of lives, both Palestinian and Israeli. The events of Munich are presented as part of a wasteful, tragic cycle of Palestinian-Israeli violence.

The film is humanist not political. We tried to make it to attract a wide audience, including people who would not usually watch a film on a serious historical subject, and we have succeeded. Said could have argued this was not the way to deal with such a difficult subject. However, if he read the book accompanying the film (written by Simon Reeve and published by Faber ) he would find the story in historical context, including interviews with numerous people who were not in the film for reasons of structure and space, among them families of three of the dead Palestinians. The book was undertaken because we realised there were many aspects of the story we could not include in a 90-minute film.

Said insinuates that I show the surviving Palestinian in shadow so that I can represent him as a dehumanised person. I would have loved to have shown his face clearly and interviewed his family, but due to understandable concerns about their safety they would not let me.

Said asserts that the film contains no new information and serves no purpose except as "Zionist propaganda". The film is packed with revelations, some explosive, to do with the extraordinary level of German incompetence during rescue attempts. So new were some of these that they were on the front page of the Observer. He also asserts no Palestinians were involved in the film, and that no Palestinian name is listed in the credits. Near the top of the credits is a list of researchers, one Israeli, two Germans and Khalil Abbed Rabbo, who is identified as a "Palestinian journalist" (he is one of the most respected journalists in the region).

Said only sees what he wants to see; your readers have the opportunity to make up their own minds by seeing the film.
Kevin Macdonald
Director,
One Day In September

fields.headline: A rubbish policy
fields.standfirst: Meacher thwarted by luke-warm cabinet
fields.trailText: Britain has a lamentable record on what it does with its rubbish. We have buried far more of the stuff in the ground than any other country in Europe and have earned for our dirty habits a position near the bottom of the EU league for recycling - only Greece is worse.
fields.body:
Britain has a lamentable record on what it does with its rubbish. We have buried far more of the stuff in the ground than any other country in Europe and have earned for our dirty habits a position near the bottom of the EU league for recycling - only Greece is worse.

So Michael Meacher's white paper on waste this week is a praiseworthy start to turning round our "dustbin culture". He has managed to convince sceptical Whitehall colleagues that the recycling target of 25% by 2005 should be statutory. This is a significant victory; aspirational targets simply do not deliver. We miserably failed the Tories' 1990 recycling target of 25% by 2000.

Having given Mr Meacher credit, now we come to the fudges. Firstly, the statutory recycling target will be expensive - start up costs of around £200m a year - and while Mr Meacher was upbeat that the Treasury would find the money in July's comprehensive spending review, there is a danger of that slipping and hard-pressed councils finding themselves landed with a large bill.

Secondly, Mr Meacher was equivocal about the thorny issue of incinerators. What is clear is that given the tough EU directive restricting landfill by 2020, there is a gap in the government's waste strategy which can only be filled by increasing our reliance on incinerators. Mr Meacher was reluctant to give a figure, but with our rubbish increasing at 3% a year, we could need between 40 and 130 new incinerators. That will not be popular and Mr Meacher runs the risk of landing this government in a string of planning disputes. With uncanny timing, the story of Newcastle's Byker allotments emerged as Mr Meacher was unveiling his plans. With Byker's allotment gardeners warned not to eat products from their vegetable patches for at least a year because of contamination from incinerator ash, anxieties about dioxins will not have been eased.

This was probably as good a white paper as Mr Meacher was able to get. His dogged persistence is admirable, the shame is that this government is so lukewarm on environmental issues. It deprived Mr Meacher of the chance to develop a 20-year strategy which would put Britain ahead in Europe. That would mean restrictions on incinerator emissions and size, as well as investment in researching good practice and new technologies, and supporting the market in recycled products.

fields.headline: More tales from scheming spires
fields.trailText: Ten years ago my local comprehensive sixth-form pushed me to apply for Oxford (Letters, May 26). I wanted to go to Sussex, but they, with their own state school kind of snobbery, wanted the kudos of seeing me at least accepted at Oxford.
fields.body:
Ten years ago my local comprehensive sixth-form pushed me to apply for Oxford (Letters, May 26). I wanted to go to Sussex, but they, with their own state school kind of snobbery, wanted the kudos of seeing me at least accepted at Oxford. I passed the exam and was called for interview. In common with every other state-schooler I met, I was interviewed by a young tutor and a postgraduate student - all the public schoolers we met were interviewed by the dean of the college.

It was the first interview I had ever had; I was overawed and on my best behaviour. Not so the postgraduate, who took delight in making me blush by asking if I thought TS Eliot's line "testimony of summer nights" referred to used condoms. I refused to be daunted. To their evident distaste, I queried aspects of the course, comparing it unfavourably to the Sussex prospectus and was told that if I wanted to be "a radical feminist marxist lesbian" then I should go to Sussex.

Nonetheless, they interviewed me a second time and I finally passed to the dean. The dean arrived 10 minutes late and informed me he could only see me for five minutes. After three days of being treated like a second-class citizen who should be desperate to win a place, all I wanted was to get away.

The dean sent me the expected rejection letter, which I didn't care about, but with a sting which stuck for years - based on his five-minute interview, he informed me that "English wasn't my subject". Having been rejected by Oxford, I then found myself rejected out of hand by all but two of the other places I had applied to; a victim of another kind of Oxbridge snobbery. Happily for me, Sussex accepted me, and so, when I got my three As at A-level, I won the place I wanted. My only regret is that I allowed myself to be pushed through a process which was stacked against me and did nothing but leave my confidence in my own abilities unpleasantly, and unnecessarily, shaken.
Cathy Savage
Brighton

Gordon Brown is talking rubbish (Brown scorns Oxford elitism, May 26). My daughter comes from an ordinary background, went to a middle-of-the-road state comprehensive (45% A-C grades) and was encouraged to apply to Oxford. She was accepted after a two-day interview, but failed to achieve the required grades (nerves, illness, panic). On results day the university phoned her school and after discussing this with her teacher, confirmed her place. I assume they had recognised her potential at the interview and stuck by their belief in her potential.
Ann Thomas
Bristol

The answer to Alan and Lesley Fowler's question (Letters, May 25): why so few candidates from northern comprehensives get places at Oxford is that not many apply. The success rate of applicants once they've applied is, in most subjects, much the same across schools, sexes and regions. The reason why private schools take 10% of the whole secondary population and get 50% of Oxbridge places is that they produce 35% of the straight-A students, and supply 50% of the applicants to Oxbridge. The really deep inequity is a matter of social class; 80% of the children with the best results at GCSE - whatever sort of school they attend - come from social classes one and two, and you can't change that by tinkering with Oxbridge admissions. But if anyone has a recipe for taking undeveloped talent, and catching up 12 years of lost attainment in the three or four years we have our students for, I'd like to know it.
Alan Ryan
Warden, New College, Oxford alan.ryan@new.oxford.ac.uk

Alan Ryan must be aware of Halsey and McCrum's study of 6,000 straight-A students who applied to Oxford in 1994-98. Candidates from private schools were found to be 1.2 times more likely to be offered a place than state school students. Since the study was conducted by Oxford professors, I assume Mr Ryan will not attempt to dismiss it as silly "myth making". Admissions tutors need to equalise acceptance rates for students who do apply before lecturing others about their preconceptions of Oxford.
Nicholas Shaw
London

Laura Spence may well discover her gain is greater than her loss. I toyed with the idea of applying for Oxford, but as not one of its colleges had either the expertise or the facilities to offer the courses I wanted to follow, I decided against it. The University of Wales did. I was not disappointed.
Paul Bryant-Quinn
Aberystwyth

Why does Gordon Brown find it so shocking Laura Spence won a Harvard scholarship but not a place at Oxford? Harvard is an elite institution which aims to take the best students. The typical UK comprehensive is a more successful academic environment than its US counterpart, so it is unsurprising a student from our state system would compete well. We should celebrate the success of comprehensive schools and expect to see more of our brightest young people go on to study abroad.
David Firth
Kidlington, Oxfordshire

A simple solution for Oxbridge admissions tutors faced with all those A grade candidates. Make offers to those whose schools are lowest in the national league tables. They are bound to be more independent and persistent.
Paula Casson
Leicester
fields.bodyText: Ten years ago my local comprehensive sixth-form pushed me to apply for Oxford (Letters, May 26). I wanted to go to Sussex, but they, with their own state school kind of snobbery, wanted the kudos of seeing me at least accepted at Oxford. I passed the exam and was called for interview. In common with every other state-schooler I met, I was interviewed by a young tutor and a postgraduate student - all the public schoolers we met were interviewed by the dean of the college. It was the first interview I had ever had; I was overawed and on my best behaviour. Not so the postgraduate, who took delight in making me blush by asking if I thought TS Eliot's line "testimony of summer nights" referred to used condoms. I refused to be daunted. To their evident distaste, I queried aspects of the course, comparing it unfavourably to the Sussex prospectus and was told that if I wanted to be "a radical feminist marxist lesbian" then I should go to Sussex. Nonetheless, they interviewed me a second time and I finally passed to the dean. The dean arrived 10 minutes late and informed me he could only see me for five minutes. After three days of being treated like a second-class citizen who should be desperate to win a place, all I wanted was to get away. The dean sent me the expected rejection letter, which I didn't care about, but with a sting which stuck for years - based on his five-minute interview, he informed me that "English wasn't my subject". Having been rejected by Oxford, I then found myself rejected out of hand by all but two of the other places I had applied to; a victim of another kind of Oxbridge snobbery. Happily for me, Sussex accepted me, and so, when I got my three As at A-level, I won the place I wanted. My only regret is that I allowed myself to be pushed through a process which was stacked against me and did nothing but leave my confidence in my own abilities unpleasantly, and unnecessarily, shaken. Cathy Savage Brighton Gordon Brown is talking rubbish (Brown scorns Oxford elitism, May 26). My daughter comes from an ordinary background, went to a middle-of-the-road state comprehensive (45% A-C grades) and was encouraged to apply to Oxford. She was accepted after a two-day interview, but failed to achieve the required grades (nerves, illness, panic). On results day the university phoned her school and after discussing this with her teacher, confirmed her place. I assume they had recognised her potential at the interview and stuck by their belief in her potential. Ann Thomas Bristol The answer to Alan and Lesley Fowler's question (Letters, May 25): why so few candidates from northern comprehensives get places at Oxford is that not many apply. The success rate of applicants once they've applied is, in most subjects, much the same across schools, sexes and regions. The reason why private schools take 10% of the whole secondary population and get 50% of Oxbridge places is that they produce 35% of the straight-A students, and supply 50% of the applicants to Oxbridge. The really deep inequity is a matter of social class; 80% of the children with the best results at GCSE - whatever sort of school they attend - come from social classes one and two, and you can't change that by tinkering with Oxbridge admissions. fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: South Yorkshire
fields.trailText: One of the bonuses of wetter than average weather in April and May is the extended wetness of wetlands. Not simply that they are staying wetter, longer, but that they are often much larger in extent. There are a couple of wet grasslands on the southern edge of South Yorkshire,    almost in Derbyshire really, that currently have standing water on an area roughly 50% greater than is usual for this time of year. In both cases, the outer, drier areas are heavily grazed, so they lack the diversity of the wetter centre.
fields.body:
One of the bonuses of wetter than average weather in April and May is the extended wetness of wetlands. Not simply that they are staying wetter, longer, but that they are often much larger in extent. There are a couple of wet grasslands on the southern edge of South Yorkshire, almost in Derbyshire really, that currently have standing water on an area roughly 50% greater than is usual for this time of year. In both cases, the outer, drier areas are heavily grazed, so they lack the diversity of the wetter centre.

This current inundation, whilst restricting the area available for grazing, to some extent is allowing wetland plants to expand. Elsewhere, wetlands, which by now would be becoming quite dry, are still good and squelchy. At Harthill, three small reservoirs have extensive wetlands surrounding them.

Early this morning I stood enthralled at the edge of a wet flash of reedmace, water horsetail, marsh marigold and watercress. In the willow fringed edges, three male sedge warblers were counter-singing at each other in a triangular musical contest. Desperate to reinforce their territory boundaries, each was flitting and hopping about the top of a separate willow shrub in agitated frenzy, seeking the best vantage point from which to hurl out its rasping warble at its rivals.

More sedately, newly emerged damselflies clung upside down to the lower growing vegetation, as alderflies and caddis flies sat quietly soaking up the weak early morning sun. On the open reservoir water birds were out and about with their families, but most seem to have only one or two chicks left with them. There are probably some very fat pike and mink about. The resident mute swan pair has just one cygnet left and no coot family numbers more than four young. Even four can be too many to watch. Plaintive cries from the edge of the dam drew my attention to a coot chick calling, panic-stricken for its parents, but swimming away in the opposite direction to them. It took several minutes of marshalling by the parents and calls to come hither, before calm was restored.

fields.headline: The devil in the detail
fields.trailText: Keith Thomas (Letters, May 26) is right about the echo of the Lord's prayer in the warden of New College's use of the phrase "them that".
fields.body:
Keith Thomas (Letters, May 26) is right about the echo of the Lord's prayer in the warden of New College's use of the phrase "them that". However, "they" in that instance are correctly "them", as the objects of our forgiveness, while Alan Ryan's admissions tutors are the subjects of "it wasn't them that refused". The slightly curious combination in his phrase of the demotic with the archaic echo of the 1662 Prayer Book perhaps reflects the warden's unease with the issues.
Jane Armstrong
London

Keith Thomas makes a nice point about the Lord's prayer (May 26) in his response to my letter, but 1662 was a long time ago. Some of us have moved on.
Dr John Baker
Cambridge

Can someone please explain how Railtrack can be said to make a profit of £300m when they receive a government subsidy of £2bn?
John Reade
Manchester

So Barbara Cartland is to be buried in a cardboard coffin in an attempt to save trees. Her hundreds of novels have probably already accounted for a couple of forests.
Prof Bill Ollier
Goostrey, Cheshire Bill.Ollier@fs1.ser.man.ac.uk

"They kept him [nine-year-old stowaway discovered in mid-flight] on the plane until it reached the Canary Isles" (Report, May 26). As opposed to...?
Stephen Jessel
Paris, France stephenj@cybercable.fr

Re the initial letters of the Blair children spelling Ken L (Letters, May 25). Hells bells! Does this mean we can look forward to 10 more Blair babies: Iris, Violet, Ian, Nigel, Gerald, Simon, Trevor, Oliver, Nathan, Edward.
Peter Woodcock
Sheffield

fields.headline: The Rap Trap
fields.standfirst:
Dr Dre helped pioneer hardcore hip-hop: violence against ÔbitchesÕ, the love of guns and fast cars. Now a millionaire father-of-two, he says heÕs turned over a new leaf Ñ all that gangsta stuff was just about marketing, pleasing the fans. So who is the Dre of today? And has he really managed 
to break free from his past?
fields.trailText:
Dr Dre helped pioneer hardcore hip-hop: violence against ÔbitchesÕ, the love of guns and fast cars. Now a millionaire father-of-two, he says heÕs turned over a new leaf Ñ all that gangsta stuff was just about marketing, pleasing the fans. So who is the Dre of today? And has he really managed 
to break free from his past?
fields.body:
IÕm on my way to meet Dr Dre, and I have a song in my head. ItÕs called Fuck You, and in it Dre explains, in some detail, how he just wants Òto fuck bad bitchesÓ. The streets of Los Angeles glare white in the midday sun. I struggle into the plush recording studio where Dre is working. We talk for a while about his latest album, Dr Dre 2001.

He recorded it, he tells me, because he felt misunderstood. ÒPeople definitely had the wrong idea about me. A lot of people were saying I was a mean cat, I disrespected women, a lotta bullshit, a lotta nonsense.Ó

Can you blame them, I suggest, given your history of violence, an arrest record that makes for long, grim reading and a six-month prison sentence for parole violation. He reflects for a moment. ÒOf course I canÕt blame them, but IÕm a different person today. I canÕt blame them, and thatÕs why I wanted to do this album and present myself in a new light Ñ the Dre of today.Ó

For the record, then, the Dre of today is a relaxed, good-humoured, 35-year-old husband and father of two. He would like very much to put the misdemeanours of youth behind him, and make songs that highlight his maturity and sensitivity. Songs such as Fuck You. Strangely, there is less contradiction here than might seem apparent.

It was while serving a six-month sentence in a Pasadena jail that Dre realised heÕd had enough of hardcore hip-hop. As a producer and performer, he helped create the violent, invective-filled genre of gangsta rap, selling around 40 million records in the process. But along the way Ñ amid the parties and women and fast cars that also came with being Dr Dre Ñ heÕd lost touch with himself, Andre Young. And he was tired. ÒI just said, let me do a whole 180 with my life. I donÕt want to do any more negative hip-hop music, I canÕt be talking about bitches and hoÕs.Ó

After prison, he got married and recorded a compilation album, Dr Dre Presents . . . The Aftermath, by unknown artists and producers. His contribution was a single track, Been There, Done That. In the wake of his jailhouse conversion, he now mocked rappers Òwho talk that hardcore shit coz thatÕs all they worthÓ. The album promised much. A fresh start for Dre and a career launch for the artists involved. It delivered neither. By commercial standards, the record sold acceptably. By DreÕs measure, it was a woeful failure. ÒPeople were expecting 7-Up and they got water,Ó he conceded. ÒI wasnÕt getting compliments from my fans.Ó Rap critics began to suggest heÕd lost his edge. He felt directionless and insecure. Finally, his wife gave him some advice. ÒShe used to play my music before we even met, so she was like, ÔYou need to get back in there and get back on that hardcore shit.Õ It felt funny going in the studio talking about Ôthis bitchÕ and Ôthis hoÕ and how ÔI fucked this girlÕ with a wife at home. But then, I have to look at it like entertainment, and I have a set fanbase, and thereÕs certain things they want to hear. They wanna hear Dre be Dre.Ó

So Dr Dre 2001 delivers a well-established formula of hardcore rap to its audience. There are songs that fetishise guns and objectify women. Songs that celebrate marijuana use and low-rider cars. Despite this, itÕs not simply a return to DreÕs gangsta past. ItÕs a more complex, reflective album. Where most hardcore rap affects a stony-faced emotional detachment, 2001 is at its strongest when Dre shows himself to be vulnerable. ÒReal gangstas donÕt cry,Ó he states on one song, Òif thatÕs the truth then IÕm realising I ainÕt no gangsta.Ó This is most notably so on The Message, a ballad that features the plaintive vocals of R&B queen Mary J Blige and on which Dre mourns the death of his younger brother, Tyree, whose neck was broken in a fight three years ago.

ÒBack in the day, I would never have made a song about my brother, but it was a very big part of my life, so I finally decided to give people that much more of me.Ó Having tried unsuccessfully to divorce himself from what Dr Dre was, it seems he has chosen instead to broaden the possibilities of who Dr Dre can be. So much so that he gives me an indignant look when I refer to him as a gangsta rap artist, complaining that he doesnÕt Òeven know where the term gangsta rap came from. I think the media invented it. We never came out and said, ÔYo, what we do is gangsta rapÕ. What I make is hardcore hip-hop.Ó

ItÕs easy to see why he insists on the distinction. Creatively, the music form never progressed far beyond an adolescent glee at its own ability to shock. Yet itÕs ironic, too. Because, as part of the rap group NWA, Dre helped create gangsta rap and watched its impact spread across the globe. And, as a consequence of that breakthrough, he became lauded as the finest producer in rap. Newsweek called him Òthe Phil Spector of hip-hopÓ, and he won a Grammy award after his first solo album, The Chronic.

But the timbre of our conversation has changed. Dre is progressively less relaxed the more we talk about those years of high acclaim. His broad 6ft 2in frame folds into itself, his knee bobs up and down nervily. Finally, it occurs to me that what heÕs uncomfortable about has nothing to do with music. Rather, heÕs edgy about where his success led. And how money and fame threatened to consume him as thoroughly, and fatally, as it did to so many of those around him.

In the 60s, before it became famous through an NWA record, Compton was regarded as a neighbourhood of hope. With the phasing out of the cityÕs racist housing policies, black families fled the ghettos of Watts and headed en masse for ComptonÕs palm-tree-lined streets. Today, it has become a battleground in the vicious feud between LAÕs two main black street gangs, the Bloods and the Crips. It was Andre YoungÕs love of music that kept him out of trouble in the neighbourhood. The last of his divorced motherÕs three children, he was playing records from her extensive collection from as early as three years old. ÒIÕd put on a record at my motherÕs card parties, and people would scream out or get up and dance. I just loved stirring people up.Ó

During high school, he deejayed at parties and clubs, and won a college scholarship to study mechanical drawing. Instead, though, he left school at 16 to join one of LAÕs earliest rap groups, the World Class WreckinÕ Kru. It was an inauspicious start to his career. Inspired by the extravagant stage-gear of acts such as Parliament and Earth Wind & Fire, the group wore flamboyant costumes that brought together the previously unconnected fields of hip-hop and high camp. Spandex jumpsuits, lace ruffs, off-the-shoulder capes and mascara featured heavily. Dre skulked at the back wearing eyeliner and, in a weak pun on his name, a surgeonÕs gown and mask. He was determined that his next group would use rap as a vehicle for reality, not fantasy.

Indeed, at the height of their notoriety, when the FBI was calling for their heads and police forces went on alert in advance of the groupÕs arrival in their town, NWA had a simple response to criticism: they were just reporters, telling the facts as they saw them. It was a seductive argument. But reportage follows principles of objectivity. And Niggaz With Attitude, the five-piece Dre founded with Eric ÒEazy-EÓ Wright and OÕShea ÒIce CubeÓ Jackson in 1986 were anything but dispassionate in their work.

In the mid-80s, hip-hop was dominated by sober New York-based rap groups such as Public Enemy, the standard bearers for a black nationalist agenda subscribed to, at least in name, by most acts on the East Coast. Over on the West Coast, NWA had other ideas. Instead of Malcolm X or the Nation Of Islam, they turned for inspiration to the ghetto fiction of pimp-turned-novelist Iceberg Slim and the bawdy humour of Richard Pryor, Dolemite and Red Foxx. Like them, the group spun tales from the less salubrious aspects of black life. They rapped about drug deals gone wrong and drive-by shootings, gang warfare and police confrontations, grasping, materialist women (hoÕs) and unfaithful lovers (bitches), all of which was set to an exhilarating, cinematic soundtrack produced by Dre. And they were delighted when the moral panic stirred by their debut album, Straight Outta Compton, released on Eazy-EÕs Ruthless records in 1988, turned them into the most famous, and infamous, rappers in America.

Outraged by songs such as Fuck Tha Police, politicians, civic leaders and, most spectacularly, the FBI accused the group of glorifying violence to sell records. Ultimately, however, NWAÕs success was based on their shrewd understanding of modern media. Courting notoriety meant that they could bypass both radio and MTV, which anyway refused to play them. Instead, newspaper headlines, debates on CNN and Home Office raids on their record companyÕs UK HQ brought them worldwide attention.

ÒAfter we started getting flak from FBI agents and people of that nature, we said, ÔOkay, weÕre going to really fuck with you now,ÕÓ says Dre gleefully. ÒSo we started making the music even heavier.Ó The strategy worked. Straight Outta Compton went gold in six weeks (600,000 record sales) then platinum (one million record sales), and after that double platinum. Niggaz 4 Life, the follow-up, went straight to number one in the US charts. Barely out of his teens, Dre was rich and famous. It was the start of his troubles.

Estranged from Eazy-EÕs Ruthless label following a dispute over management and finances, Dre began work on The Chronic, the solo album that would come to consolidate his reputation at the forefront of hip-hop. As in-house producer at Ruthless, he had already been responsible for a string of million-selling albums. In return, he rewarded himself with a lavish lifestyle that included an enormous French colonial-style house, numerous high-grade sports cars and a ceaseless round of parties. ÒMy house was full of people all the time. You could come over on Sunday morning and thereÕs just people laying out on the floor asleep. Girls all over the place. I was spending money on a lot of cars, jewellery, apartments all over town. I probably bought somewhere between eight to 10 cars. Ferraris, I donÕt know how many Mercedes, Corvettes . . . it was just dumb shit. I blew a lot of money. I was letting people in my life that were straight up there totally to see what they can get out of my pocket, and I wasnÕt seeing this. It was just about the party to me, and you gotta have people around to have a party.Ó

Insulated from criticism by his retinue of hangers-on, and with a reputation as a hardcore rapper to maintain, Dre began reacting to criticism with sudden, petulant rage. At a music-industry party in 1991, he attacked TV show host Dee Barnes after an uncomplimentary report about NWA had aired on her programme. ÒDre picks me up by my hair and my ear,Ó Barnes told the writer Ronin Ro, in his gangsta rap expos, Have Gun Will Travel. In terror, she dashed into the ladiesÕ washroom. Dre pursued her. ÒHe grabs my hair again, throws me to the front of the bathroom. I just duck down and just . . . take my ass-whipping, you know what I mean? ThereÕs nobody helping me and thereÕs no way in hell I could throw a punch at him.Ó In response to the attack, Barnes filed a $20-million lawsuit, although the case was eventually settled out of court. Dre muttered to Rolling Stone, ÒI was in the wrong, but itÕs not like I broke the bitchÕs arm.Ó

The Dee Barnes affair was only the prelude to a catalogue of misdemeanours during 1992. In June that year, Dre was fined $10,000 and placed under electronic house arrest for 90 days with a tagging device around his ankle. He had been found guilty of breaking the jaw of an aspirant rap producer, Damon Thomas. In October, he served another 30 days after pleading guilty to the battery of a police officer during a large brawl that took place in the lobby of a New Orleans hotel. Some events were beyond his control, though. He was shot in the legs after gunfire broke out at a party he was attending. And, following a raucous party of his own, the producer was forced to stand by and watch his grand house go up in flames. ÒWeÕd had a party at my house the night before. We had a barbecue, and the next day the coals from the barbecue were dumped in a trash can which was pushed up against the house,Ó says Dre. ÒThey set the house on fire. And boom, there you have it. House going up in smoke!Ó

Post-NWA, Dre was now living the life heÕd once only rapped about. And it was proving too much. ÒI was out of control,Ó he admits. ÒI was wildinÕ out, partying, women . . . I think the business, and all the fame and fortune, just sucked me in and I had to step back and see that I was ruining everything that I had worked so hard at building.Ó

Frustrated by continued wrangling with Eazy-E, Dre co-founded a new label in 1992, Death Row. Within four years, it would be worth an estimated $200 million, becoming one of the most successful black-owned labels of all time. But before then, it became clear that the company had a major liability: Death RowÕs other owner. Marion ÒSugeÓ Knight was a 300lb, 6ft 3in former professional footballer-turned-businessman. He was also a convicted felon with gangster connections, whom ABC television described in 1996 as Òthe most dangerous man in musicÓ. While Dre was the production brains of Death Row, Knight was its public face. At its inception, he talked of creating a label as successful and culturally important as Motown. In its early days, this didnÕt seem like an idle boast.

Death RowÕs first release was The Chronic. Hailed as a masterpiece by critics, it marked DreÕs maturing as a producer and performer. True, there were an obligatory number of weapons brandished and insults hurled (although most of the latter were issued at Eazy-E), but there was also love. The album introduced the Death Row ÒfamilyÓ of new artists who shared a spirit of friendly collaboration on many of its tracks. They were to be the stars of the new Motown. Chief among them was DreÕs protg, a tall, fine-featured rapper, whose laidback manner and hangdog expression had earned him the childhood nickname Snoopy. As Snoop Doggy Dogg, he became the labelÕs first home-grown star, with a debut album, Doggystyle, that outsold DreÕs. By 1996, The Chronic and Doggystyle had earned an estimated $50 million and $63 million in retail sales, respectively.

None of this was enough for Suge Knight, though. As Death Row grew in strength, so too did his greed. Knight took to holding unconventional business meetings with rivals. To resolve DreÕs long-running feud with Eazy-E, he allegedly threatened the latter at gunpoint, forcing him to relinquish RuthlessÕs rights to DreÕs work. Other record company executives shared similar tales of intimidation, and even outright assault. In 1992, Knight faced assault charges after the pistol-whipping of two brothers, George and Lynwood Stanley, in the offices of Death Row. Catching them using the office payphone, Knight beat them, ordered them to strip naked and then robbed them. They deserved their punishment, insisted the Death Row boss. He was waiting for a phone call.

A climate of terror settled over the labelÕs Wilshire Boulevard offices. Members of the Piru Blood gang, an arm of the feared Bloods street gang that was friendly with Knight, took to hanging out there, swapping prison stories and shaking down staff for cash. They were also there to mete out summary justice on behalf of Knight.
