The chaos within Death Row seemed indicative of deeper stresses in the hardcore hip-hop world. Gangsta rap was reaching critical mass. The once close-knit Death Row family fell into rivalrous camps. ÒIt became, ÔWhat kinda car does this person have. I gotta get a better car than thatÕ; ÔMy house has to look better than this personÕs houseÕ,Ó says Dre. ÒWhen the money started coming into play from Death Row, thatÕs when the problems just went haywire.Ó

Worse followed. In 1995, the notoriously promiscuous Eazy-E died after contracting Aids. In 1996, Snoop Doggy Dogg stood trial for murder. He was acquitted. But that same year, Tupac Shakur, a recent signing to Death Row and one of rapÕs brightest stars, was killed in a drive-by shooting. Sitting beside him in the same car, Suge Knight escaped largely unhurt. There was speculation that the shots were never intended for Shakur, but rather Knight. Two weeks later, the Death Row boss was behind bars after being caught on security camera taking part in the group beating of a member of the Crips street gang, sworn enemies of KnightÕs associates, the Bloods. A serial offender with eight previous convictions, he had violated the terms of his probation received for assaulting the Stanley brothers. Knight was sentenced to nine years in jail. The FBI, IRS, DEA and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms immediately began joint investigations into Death Row on possible racketeering charges related to KnightÕs alleged business links with the drug-dealing Piru Blood gang. Death RowÕs grand dreams had melted into air.

ÒIn the beginning, it was all about Niggers coming up,Ó commented Dre in the hip-hop magazine Blaze. ÒThen it turned into a fucking Don Corleone thing. It was like a movie. You come into his [KnightÕs] office and canÕt step on the carpetÕs Death Row emblem and all that crazy shit. It didnÕt need to escalate like that . . . I got tired of seeing engineers get they ass beat for rewinding a tape too far.Ó

Dre says he decided to leave Death Row after going to jail. Arrested on a drunk-driving charge, he was found guilty of violating the parole he received for breaking Damon ThomasÕs jaw. ÒTo be honest, prison was probably the best thing that could have happened to me in my life,Ó he says earnestly. ÒEverything was happening so fast, the success I was having, all the money coming in, all the girls, all the partying. I never had a chance to say, ÔYo, what do I want my life to hold?Õ I had to find myself. And it was crazy. I saw a confused individual. A guy that wasnÕt sure what he really wanted out of life. It made me say, ÔYo, man, fuck those streets, fuck everything thatÕs going on out there on those streets. Is this the life I wanna lead, or do I wanna be a businessman, be able to take care of my family, chill out, have fun and make money while IÕm sleeping?ÕÓ

Dre now lives with his wife, Nicole, and their two young sons on a $4.9-million estate in a gated community in the San Fernando Valley. He abandoned his stake in Death Row while it was still a force in the music industry, trading income for Òpeace of mindÓ. Ultimately, he believes his Òreal talentÓ lies in producing, directing and scoring films. He has already written a screenplay based on his own life, called Please Listen To My Demo. Yet although heÕs now a 20-year veteran of the music business, his career is far from over. In fact, itÕs just enjoying its third swell.

In 1996, Dre started his own label, Aftermath, backed by Interscope records, part of the entertainment conglomerate, Universal. AftermathÕs contract is due for renogotiation, and industry observers predict that it will net Dre a nine-figure sum. Following the disappointment of its first release, Dr Dre Presents . . . The Aftermath, the label is now thriving. Dr Dre 2001 has sold five million copies since November 1999 and, in 26-year-old white rapper Eminem, it also has a major new star. A skilled, darkly-comic performer from Detroit (born Marshall Mathers), EminemÕs records have sparked controversy for their warped reflections on sex, drugs and teen life. The response is an echo of the furore that surrounded NWA more than a decade earlier. Dre, who produced the rapperÕs debut album, The Slim Shady LP, is amused. ItÕs easy to see why.

In the years since Straight Outta Compton, real life, with its celebrity scandals and high-school shoot-outs, has worked hard to outgun even the most lurid fantasies of hardcore rap. Entertainment culture has responded by becoming more provocative and more sexualised, from Reservoir Dogs and Boogie Nights in the US to Gail PorterÕs bare bottom projected on to the House of Commons in Britain. Under the circumstances, itÕs difficult to argue that hardcore hip-hop, in particular, deserves to be excoriated. But it does raise a question. NWA are currently in the studio, recording a comeback album called Not These Niggaz Again, with Snoop Dogg replacing the late Eazy-E. But just what is there left for them to rebel against? ÒI know people are gonna be, like, ÔNWA started this whole genre of hardcore hip-hop or gangsta rap music Ñ what else are they gonna talk about?Õ Ó nods Dre. ÒBut once we deliver the record and itÕs hot, and itÕs a record that you can buy and bump and just roll out and wild out to, what the album is about wonÕt matter.Ó Besides, he counters, ÒI donÕt think itÕs easy to sell records when youÕre just trying to shock and inflame. ItÕs been done a thousand times after NWA came, and nobodyÕs reached the success that we had.Ó

Perhaps DreÕs real art is not in shock, then, but seduction. Like his heroes, Pryor, Iceberg Slim, Tarantino and Scorsese, he has remade the brute antagonisms of street life as beautiful, dissonant poetry. While critics of hardcore rap have concentrated on its lyrics, Dre has been more concerned with what it should feel like; with how it bumps and rolls. Knowing all the while that art shouldnÕt aim simply to imitate life. But to outdo it

fields.bodyText: IÕm on my way to meet Dr Dre, and I have a song in my head. ItÕs called Fuck You, and in it Dre explains, in some detail, how he just wants Òto fuck bad bitchesÓ. The streets of Los Angeles glare white in the midday sun. I struggle into the plush recording studio where Dre is working. We talk for a while about his latest album, Dr Dre 2001. He recorded it, he tells me, because he felt misunderstood. ÒPeople definitely had the wrong idea about me. A lot of people were saying I was a mean cat, I disrespected women, a lotta bullshit, a lotta nonsense.Ó Can you blame them, I suggest, given your history of violence, an arrest record that makes for long, grim reading and a six-month prison sentence for parole violation. He reflects for a moment. ÒOf course I canÕt blame them, but IÕm a different person today. I canÕt blame them, and thatÕs why I wanted to do this album and present myself in a new light Ñ the Dre of today.Ó For the record, then, the Dre of today is a relaxed, good-humoured, 35-year-old husband and father of two. He would like very much to put the misdemeanours of youth behind him, and make songs that highlight his maturity and sensitivity. Songs such as Fuck You. Strangely, there is less contradiction here than might seem apparent. It was while serving a six-month sentence in a Pasadena jail that Dre realised heÕd had enough of hardcore hip-hop. As a producer and performer, he helped create the violent, invective-filled genre of gangsta rap, selling around 40 million records in the process. But along the way Ñ amid the parties and women and fast cars that also came with being Dr Dre Ñ heÕd lost touch with himself, Andre Young. And he was tired. ÒI just said, let me do a whole 180 with my life. I donÕt want to do any more negative hip-hop music, I canÕt be talking about bitches and hoÕs.Ó After prison, he got married and recorded a compilation album, Dr Dre Presents . . . The Aftermath, by unknown artists and producers. His contribution was a single track, Been There, Done That. In the wake of his jailhouse conversion, he now mocked rappers Òwho talk that hardcore shit coz thatÕs all they worthÓ. The album promised much. A fresh start for Dre and a career launch for the artists involved. It delivered neither. By commercial standards, the record sold acceptably. By DreÕs measure, it was a woeful failure. ÒPeople were expecting 7-Up and they got water,Ó he conceded. ÒI wasnÕt getting compliments from my fans.Ó Rap critics began to suggest heÕd lost his edge. He felt directionless and insecure. Finally, his wife gave him some advice. ÒShe used to play my music before we even met, so she was like, ÔYou need to get back in there and get back on that hardcore shit.Õ It felt funny going in the studio talking about Ôthis bitchÕ and Ôthis hoÕ and how ÔI fucked this girlÕ with a wife at home. But then, I have to look at it like entertainment, and I have a set fanbase, and thereÕs certain things they want to hear. They wanna hear Dre be Dre.Ó So Dr Dre 2001 delivers a well-established formula of hardcore rap to its audience. There are songs that fetishise guns and objectify women. Songs that celebrate marijuana use and low-rider cars. Despite this, itÕs not simply a return to DreÕs gangsta past. ItÕs a more complex, reflective album. Where most hardcore rap affects a stony-faced emotional detachment, 2001 is at its strongest when Dre shows himself to be vulnerable. ÒReal gangstas donÕt cry,Ó he states on one song, Òif thatÕs the truth then IÕm realising I ainÕt no gangsta.Ó This is most notably so on The Message, a ballad that features the plaintive vocals of R&B queen Mary J Blige and on which Dre mourns the death of his younger brother, Tyree, whose neck was broken in a fight three years ago. ÒBack in the day, I would never have made a song about my brother, but it was a very big part of my life, so I finally decided to give people that much more of me.Ó Having tried unsuccessfully to divorce himself from what Dr Dre was, it seems he has chosen instead to broaden the possibilities of who Dr Dre can be. So much so that he gives me an indignant look when I refer to him as a gangsta rap artist, complaining that he doesnÕt Òeven know where the term gangsta rap came from. I think the media invented it. We never came out and said, ÔYo, what we do is gangsta rapÕ. What I make is hardcore hip-hop.Ó ItÕs easy to see why he insists on the distinction. Creatively, the music form never progressed far beyond an adolescent glee at its own ability to shock. Yet itÕs ironic, too. Because, as part of the rap group NWA, Dre helped create gangsta rap and watched its impact spread across the globe. And, as a consequence of that breakthrough, he became lauded as the finest producer in rap. Newsweek called him Òthe Phil Spector of hip-hopÓ, and he won a Grammy award after his first solo album, The Chronic. But the timbre of our conversation has changed. Dre is progressively less relaxed the more we talk about those years of high acclaim. His broad 6ft 2in frame folds into itself, his knee bobs up and down nervily. Finally, it occurs to me that what heÕs uncomfortable about has nothing to do with music. Rather, heÕs edgy about where his success led. And how money and fame threatened to consume him as thoroughly, and fatally, as it did to so many of those around him. In the 60s, before it became famous through an NWA record, Compton was regarded as a neighbourhood of hope. With the phasing out of the cityÕs racist housing policies, black families fled the ghettos of Watts and headed en masse for ComptonÕs palm-tree-lined streets. Today, it has become a battleground in the vicious feud between LAÕs two main black street gangs, the Bloods and the Crips. It was Andre YoungÕs love of music that kept him out of trouble in the neighbourhood. The last of his divorced motherÕs three children, he was playing records from her extensive collection from as early as three years old. ÒIÕd put on a record at my motherÕs card parties, and people would scream out or get up and dance. I just loved stirring people up.Ó During high school, he deejayed at parties and clubs, and won a college scholarship to study mechanical drawing. Instead, though, he left school at 16 to join one of LAÕs earliest rap groups, the World Class WreckinÕ Kru. It was an inauspicious start to his career. Inspired by the extravagant stage-gear of acts such as Parliament and Earth Wind & Fire, the group wore flamboyant costumes that brought together the previously unconnected fields of hip-hop and high camp. He was determined that his next group would use rap as a vehicle for reality, not fantasy. Indeed, at the height of their notoriety, when the FBI was calling for their heads and police forces went on alert in advance of the groupÕs arrival in their town, NWA had a simple response to criticism: they were just reporters, telling the facts as they saw them. It was a seductive argument. But reportage follows principles of objectivity. And Niggaz With Attitude, the five-piece Dre founded with Eric ÒEazy-EÓ Wright and OÕShea ÒIce CubeÓ Jackson in 1986 were anything but dispassionate in their work. Over on the West Coast, NWA had other ideas. Instead of Malcolm X or the Nation Of Islam, they turned for inspiration to the ghetto fiction of pimp-turned-novelist Iceberg Slim and the bawdy humour of Richard Pryor, Dolemite and Red Foxx. Like them, the group spun tales from the less salubrious aspects of black life. They rapped about drug deals gone wrong and drive-by shootings, gang warfare and police confrontations, grasping, materialist women (hoÕs) and unfaithful lovers (bitches), all of which was set to an exhilarating, cinematic soundtrack produced by Dre. And they were delighted when the moral panic stirred by their debut album, Straight Outta Compton, released on Eazy-EÕs Ruthless records in 1988, turned them into the most famous, and infamous, rappers in America. ÒSo we started making the music even heavier.Ó The strategy worked. In return, he rewarded himself with a lavish lifestyle that included an enormous French colonial-style house, numerous high-grade sports cars and a ceaseless round of parties. ÒMy house was full of people all the time. You could come over on Sunday morning and thereÕs just people laying out on the floor asleep. Girls all over the place. Ferraris, I donÕt know how many Mercedes, Corvettes . . . it was just dumb shit. I blew a lot of money. I was letting people in my life that were straight up there totally to see what they can get out of my pocket, and I wasnÕt seeing this. It was just about the party to me, and you gotta have people around to have a party.Ó Insulated from criticism by his retinue of hangers-on, and with a reputation as a hardcore rapper to maintain, Dre began reacting to criticism with sudden, petulant rage. ÒHe grabs my hair again, throws me to the front of the bathroom. I just duck down and just . . . take my ass-whipping, you know what I mean? Knowing all the while that art shouldnÕt aim simply to imitate life. But to outdo it Forgot About Dre, by Dr Dre featuring Emimem, is released on Interscope on May 27.

fields.headline: God and us
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor with... part two of our religious coverage
fields.trailText: The readers' editor with... part two of our religious coverage
fields.body:
There was a robust response to my column last week about the Guardian's coverage of religious affairs. Several of the letters were dismissive of the idea that such matters should have any place in the paper at all, not because the writers thought it, to use Herman Melville's words, "but vain to popularise profundities", but because they liked their Guardian to be fundamentally secular. They liked to be able to move around in it freely - they seemed to be suggesting - without stumbling over people on their knees.

A couple of readers thought that I must have come under "concerted pressure from religionists", as one of them put it, to bother airing the subject. "The Guardian already has a Face to Faith column and a correspondent devoted entirely to the doings of believers. If the faithful want more, why don't they get the Church Times and let the rest of us get on with real life?"

Another wrote, "It seems that a concerted campaign is being waged against you, much like the one that was recently launched against the BBC." Not at all, and in any case, the point is being missed. The complaints about the Guardian's coverage that I was discussing last week - gathered from letters to the paper over a period of months and certainly not amounting to a campaign - were more about quality and tone than quantity.

One correspondent, a Methodist lay preacher, commenting on the column, says, "sometimes the most ridiculous caricatures of Christian belief and practice are allowed to pass. Why is this? Why is it assumed . . . that everyone of any sense and maturity has long since discarded any religious belief?"

She continues, "It is a paradox that this 'irreligious' paper is actually a prime resource for Christians who take their faith seriously and want to pray in an informed manner about the needs of the world and to know how to take useful action. The Guardian leads the way in promoting humanitarian causes such as Jubilee 2000, Oxfam's Education Now campaign, and in promoting fair treatment and respect for refugees and asylum seekers . . . It also provides the best coverage and comment on international affairs. This is why no amount of negative comment about the church will ever put me off buying it."

An Anglican priest writes to say that the Guardian through many years of reading has become one of the institutions that has shaped his life. He wants and expects constructive criticism of the church and religion as of everything else and not what he feels too often stands in its place. "This is perhaps why what people such as me now feel amounts to little less than betrayal." He adds, "I hope this discussion will run, and that we Christians of the left, who, a bit like Old Labour, have nowhere else to go, will be able to recover the sense of identity with the Guardian we used to have."

One correspondent said he had been taking the Guardian for 40 years and would not like to contemplate life without it, yet on a number of occasions lately he had been on the point of giving it up because of its apparent attitude towards the minority group to which he belonged, the Christians.

He was not impressed by the argument that editorials on Christian values were eschewed in deference to the paper's multicultural or non-Christian, or non-believing readership. "My own conclusion is that you are more frightened of your non-believing readers - who can indeed write acerbically - than your believing ones."

A theologian took up the editor's point that there was no reason why the scepticism applied in other areas of reporting should not be applied to religious affairs. "That would be a fair point if the Guardian were indiscriminate in its scepticism; but I have yet to see it turn its sceptical eye on to the limitations, inconsistencies and failings of the secularism that it privileges . . . Besides, relentless, programmatic scepticism is really too easy and self-complacent a stance to take to anything. Braver, more honest, and more intelligent is the discriminate criticism that is willing to give its object credit where credit is due."

Finally, a note from a reader who says, "it is true, scorn is what comes through all over the place, where religion (particularly Catholic) is concerned". In the course of a long and interesting letter he makes the following point, one that many other readers have made: "believing in God and spirituality, honouring and respecting religious traditions - irrespective of which one we're talking about - is not incompatible with commitment to so called 'progressive' social causes . . . For me and a lot of other people it is a matter of principle and good education in every sense of the word."

By the way, copies of all your letters on this subject have been passed to the editor and the religious affairs correspondent. Thanks for writing.

webTitle: Now you too can have your back licked

fields.headline: Now you too can have your back licked
fields.trailText: Stamp Show 2000 | The Dome | That Grant-Hurley split
fields.body:
I popped into the Stamp Show 2000 at Earl's Court this week. It seemed more crowded than the Dome, though nobody I know seems to collect stamps any more. There were hardly any young persons, but plenty of middle-aged men in windcheaters and mud-coloured sports coats, plus a far higher percentage of beards than you'd find in the population as a whole. But it was still intensely nostalgic.

When I was a teenage nerd, I too used to stand over some particularly choice stamp, moistening my lips with repressed desire, though I don't think I would ever have held a book of 10 current second-class stamps up to the light as if seeking imperfections, like some of these chaps at the Royal Mail display. There are still people in this country who get anxious about whether half a dozen 44p stamps come in a column block, or with guttering.

But there are some great attractions. The wonderful Royal Collection, on show this week, reveals that George V must have been the most highly-ranked anorak in British history. You can alarm your friends by having a sheet of stamps printed up with your face attached - see mine above; it's perfectly good for postage, and will make people think for one appalling moment that you've inherited the throne.

I liked the letter posted in May 1840 to a "Miss Jones" in Camberwell, possibly the first time a Penny Black was ever used. "What a pity that they should make Victoria gummy!", Miss Jones's swain wrote. He mailed the letter one day before stamps became legally usable, and some early Jobsworth with an eye on history surcharged her an extra penny.

 So the Dome has more or less had it. Yes, it should have been better, and yes, it exemplified the Mandelson tenet that reality is the mere raw material for what you make it; all that matters is the spin. (Do you recall his star Dome attraction, "Surfball - the game for a new millennium", which didn't exist and was pure invention? It was cynical beyond belief). But, as I said at the time, my family and I enjoyed our visit, found plenty to engage us, and thought it good value. The kids didn't want to leave.

But nothing could survive the stereophonic abuse from rightwing papers which couldn't stand the idea of a massive communal project paid from public funds, and the snobbery of the bien- pensant leftish elite, which thought it should be more like Tate Modern, with food supplied by Granita. Much of the comment was grotes- quely unfair, but it was so relentless that few would have wanted to make the effort.

 The most poignant detail of the Grant-Hurley split is that Madame Tussauds wax museum has dropped plans to make one of her to go next to him, so depriving customers of the pleasure of hearing tourists say: "I think I recognise Mick Hucknall, but why have they put him next to Ann Widdecombe?"

My agent phoned the other day to ask if I'd be considered for the voice-over in a new Hovis commercial. I won't do ads, for the obvious reason that as a journalist all you have to offer is your judgment, and who's going to believe that if it's for sale to the highest bidder? And why me? I suppose it's because I still have a Yorkshire inflection in the voice, which could easily be hammed up. "Aye, when ah'm wi' mates in sum fancy pants west end restaurant eating foie gras for me snap, ah allus insists on a pint of mild and a thick slice of Hovis ter go wi'it. That's reet champion, that is!"

I wanted to find out how much I'd turned down - I know that when some actors get a voice-over, they often nip out and order a new Saab - but my agent couldn't discover. "They found someone else," he told me. Brian Sewell, perhaps.

 No, I didn't say all Welsh people are offensive. I'm not an idiot, and I had a very pleasant 24 hours in Cardiff the other day, meeting nothing but courtesy and warmth. I merely pointed out that some people use Welsh to talk about English-speakers behind their backs. It's the most obvious statement of fact. Alice Payal of Wimbledon had a similar experience on the island of Islay. Entering a cosy pub with friends, she found all heads turned to the invaders. "Then conversation resumed, but, deliberately we felt, in Gaelic... we had the brilliant idea of continuing our conversation in French. You'd have thought we'd dropped a bomb! Outrage on every face. 'How dare they?' written on each one."

Roger Protz, whose excellent book on British pubs I mentioned last week, wrote to tell me about a pub in West Wales which Camra hopes to include in the next edition of the Good Beer Guide. "The problem is, the owners are English and don't hide their antipathy to the Welsh, which takes some chutzpah in that part of the world. But the pub sells cracking beer. After much soul-searching, they've decided to include it, but to print the description in Welsh!"

 I went to a curious event in Chelsea the other day, the launch of a new shop selling women's clothes made by Thomas Pink, the ineffably upper-class tailors. The shirts (£55 and up) all shimmered on the shelves, being made from fabrics as lustrous as the pubic hair of angora rabbits. There was limitless pink champagne. The guests were impeccably clad in silk and cashmere.

Gorgeous women looked at me with the blank stare of the beauty who knows not to make eye contact with dirty old men, though this time because they'd probably never seen anyone as ill-dressed who wasn't selling the Big Issue. A poodle, dyed pink, was thrust into various arms and photographed. A woman said to her friend: "Timmy can't come. He got a big spot on his forehead during tap-dancing class. He's so sorry."

As I was leaving, I met the managing director, Des Swan, who told me to my amazement that these fabulous garments were made in Portadown, famous as the bigotry capital of Northern Ireland. I pondered briefly what it would be like to march down the Garvaghy Rd with a pink poodle in my arms, and wondered who would eviscerate me first: the Prods, the IRA or the British army.

fields.headline: The indestructible power of belief
fields.standfirst: Are the 2,000-year-old Dead Sea Scrolls a key to the origins of Christianity and the state of Israel?  Justin Cartwright on an enduring controversy
fields.trailText: Are the 2,000-year-old Dead Sea Scrolls a key to the origins of Christianity and the state of Israel? Justin Cartwright on an enduring controversy
fields.body:
Professor Eleazar Sukenik was the first Israeli to see a fragment of the Dead Sea Scrolls, through a security gate in divided Jerusalem as the war of 1947 broke out. Then he travelled to Bethlehem to see two scrolls, brought by an Arab dealer who had acquired them from a Bedouin shepherd. Sukenik's hands "shook as I started to unwrap one. I read a few sentences. It was written in beautiful Biblical Hebrew. The language was like that of the Psalms."

One of these was the Isaiah scroll, which I saw recently in the Rockefeller Museum in East Jerusalem: sections of goat-skin parchment, sewn together, 27 feet long. I felt in the presence of something numinous, although I have been a convinced atheist since boyhood. But this document is a testament to the inexplicable persistence of the human mind, in the face of all the evidence, in believing that we are on earth for a divine purpose. Its words were familiar to me from years of tedious school church services; poetic phrases, urging the children of Israel to make straight in the desert a highway for God.

The first scroll was found in 1947 in a cave looking down to the Dead Sea above a place called Qumran. It is one of a great library of documents discovered there. Until these were found, barely a scrap of papyrus existed from the two centuries immediately preceding the birth of Christ. The scrolls are the documents of the Essene sect, who lived near Qumran about 250 BC, insisting on a communal life, devoted to strict observance of the law and ascetic piety as they waited for the end of days.

Some scholars believe that they were the early model for Christian monastic life because only men were admitted to their settlements. Their documents were copies of the Bible, by 500 years the earliest known Hebrew copies. There are also pesharim , or Bible commentaries, rules of the community, laws for admission, orders of service and hymns, a (probably) allegorical guide to hidden treasures, and an account of the war between the sons of light and darkness. There are 50,000 fragments and many have phrases which resonate through the New Testament, which led to rumours that these were early Christian documents and that the sect leader, the "Teacher of Righteousness", was Jesus.

Commentators, including Edmund Wilson, persuaded themselves that the sect was the forerunner of Christianity. Wilson said: "The Monastery (at Qumran) is perhaps the cradle of Christianity." The Essenes embodied the qualities which came to be thought of as Christian. It has now been shown, however, that the sect had been flourishing for 250 years before the birth of Christ. That does not mean that the Essenes did not influence others, including, two and a half centuries later, Jesus of Nazareth. But the scrolls reveal a more complex and modern society than my C of E education ever disclosed.

For Jews, too, the picture of an ancient, eternal homeland is revealed to be an oversimplification. The land of Israel, the Roman province of Judea, was at the time of Christ in religious and political flux. The Temple at Jerusalem, rebuilt by Herod, was the appointed place of worship for Jews: there were no synagogues. But Jews had spread out around the Mediterranean and many had become Hellenised. Greek was the language of the educated classes, and Alexandria an important centre of Jewish intellectual life.

Control of the Jerusalem Temple's revenues and its doctrinal output was the central issue among factions of high priests and sects. The Essenes, who regarded themselves as the true sons of Israel, lost the battle, and retreated from Jerusalem to Qumran.

The Aramaic-speaking Galileans, of whom Jesus was one, were also often in dispute with Jewish authorities in Jerusalem. Jesus's crucifixion, if historical, was a by-product of disputes between the religious factions and the appointees of the Roman authority; by 73 AD the Romans had destroyed the Temple - its Western Wall is its only surviving section, today the focus of Jewish longing, just as it was for the Essenes in Qumran.

The Essenes had been chronicled by Pliny, Philo and Josephus, a Hellenised Jew who retired to Rome, writing only a few years after the destruction of the Temple: he described their habits in detail and with admiration. The rules of the community in the Qumran scrolls were identical to those described by Josephus. The Essenes had come to life, and a whole branch of Judaism had been disinterred.

Excavations at Qumran, then a part of Jordan, by Father Roland de Vaux of the école Biblique in Jerusalem, built up a picture of an all-male community, farming, transcribing the scrolls, eating ritual meals. The members wore linen robes and bathed frequently in 11 ritual baths- the irrigation system to feed them is visible.

Pliny describes the location of the Essene settlement (and mentions the unpleasant smell of the Dead Sea), and Josephus seems to make Qumran prime candidate for the sect's headquarters. Inkwells were found there and rooms which might have been a library and a refectory were excavated. Not far away, scrolls and leather workshops were found in caves.

But some doubt has been cast on Qumran as the location of the Essene settlement: if the Essenes were a male-only sect, why were skeletons of women and children found in one cemetery? No excavations are now possible in Jewish cemeteries, but a German academic had recovered bones sent abroad in the 50s and a physical anthropologist from Jerusalem has identified them as Arab, of a much later date: jewellery found in the graves was identified as Arab, 12th century. Analysis of the clays of the jars in which the scrolls were found proved they did not come from Jerusalem, so the scrolls were not part of the library of the Temple, hidden to avoid destruction by the Romans.

I had already asked myself why so many scrolls were concerned with the rules of a sect opposing the high priesthood if they were part of the library of the Temple. This is one of many contemporary academic debates about the documents. There are also less academic attempts to find the treasures of the Temple, and loopy fundamentalist Christian enterprises to find the lost ark of the covenant.

Because many of the scrolls and fragments had been in the École Biblique in Arab- controlled Jerusalem, and because of the reluctance of non-Jewish scholars to give up their privileged position, rumours flourished. The most fanciful is that the documents contained secrets damaging to Christianity, suppressed by the Vatican. The noted scholar, Fr Emile Puech, says that he has never heard of any interference by the Vatican.

The original scholars, a volatile group, could not cope with their task, and foolishly refused to allow access to outside scholars, releasing only what they saw fit when they had completed their translations and commentaries. But in 1991, the Israeli government declared that the scrolls would be open to all.

The single most important fact emerging from them is that there were a number of Jewish sects, including the Essenes, which, far from preparing the way for Christianity, were struggling for dominance. Some Jews wanted to free themselves from Rome, others wanted to continue Hellenisation, some wanted to live in this world, some to withdraw. Christianity was originally no more than a Jewish sect, turning to the scriptures for justification, looking for a Messiah, hopeful of a new order.

But it is not Christianity which makes the scrolls significant, nor do they make modern Israel authentic. The scrolls may illuminate the origins of Christianity and modern Judaism; but they also show us that ideas do not spring out of nothingness, that they can persist and become universal. This is the heroic impulse to make sense of the human predicament - full of pathos - made more powerful by the knowledge that the Essenes vanished, but their beautiful testaments survived.

 Justin Cartwright has just directed a documentary on the Dead Sea Scrolls. His Whitbread prize-winning novel, Leading the Cheers, is published by Sceptre, £6.99

The Aramaic-speaking Galileans, of whom Jesus was one, were also often in dispute with Jewish authorities in Jerusalem. Jesus's crucifixion, if historical, was a by-product of disputes between the religious factions and the appointees of the Roman authority; by 73 AD the Romans had destroyed the Temple - its Western Wall is its only surviving section, today the focus of Jewish longing, just as it was for the Essenes in Qumran. The Essenes had been chronicled by Pliny, Philo and Josephus, a Hellenised Jew who retired to Rome, writing only a few years after the destruction of the Temple: he described their habits in detail and with admiration. The rules of the community in the Qumran scrolls were identical to those described by Josephus. The Essenes had come to life, and a whole branch of Judaism had been disinterred. Excavations at Qumran, then a part of Jordan, by Father Roland de Vaux of the école Biblique in Jerusalem, built up a picture of an all-male community, farming, transcribing the scrolls, eating ritual meals. The members wore linen robes and bathed frequently in 11 ritual baths- the irrigation system to feed them is visible. Pliny describes the location of the Essene settlement (and mentions the unpleasant smell of the Dead Sea), and Josephus seems to make Qumran prime candidate for the sect's headquarters. Inkwells were found there and rooms which might have been a library and a refectory were excavated. Not far away, scrolls and leather workshops were found in caves. But some doubt has been cast on Qumran as the location of the Essene settlement: if the Essenes were a male-only sect, why were skeletons of women and children found in one cemetery? No excavations are now possible in Jewish cemeteries, but a German academic had recovered bones sent abroad in the 50s and a physical anthropologist from Jerusalem has identified them as Arab, of a much later date: jewellery found in the graves was identified as Arab, 12th century. Analysis of the clays of the jars in which the scrolls were found proved they did not come from Jerusalem, so the scrolls were not part of the library of the Temple, hidden to avoid destruction by the Romans. I had already asked myself why so many scrolls were concerned with the rules of a sect opposing the high priesthood if they were part of the library of the Temple. This is one of many contemporary academic debates about the documents. There are also less academic attempts to find the treasures of the Temple, and loopy fundamentalist Christian enterprises to find the lost ark of the covenant. Because many of the scrolls and fragments had been in the École Biblique in Arab- controlled Jerusalem, and because of the reluctance of non-Jewish scholars to give up their privileged position, rumours flourished. The most fanciful is that the documents contained secrets damaging to Christianity, suppressed by the Vatican. The noted scholar, Fr Emile Puech, says that he has never heard of any interference by the Vatican. The original scholars, a volatile group, could not cope with their task, and foolishly refused to allow access to outside scholars, releasing only what they saw fit when they had completed their translations and commentaries. But in 1991, the Israeli government declared that the scrolls would be open to all. The single most important fact emerging from them is that there were a number of Jewish sects, including the Essenes, which, far from preparing the way for Christianity, were struggling for dominance. Some Jews wanted to free themselves from Rome, others wanted to continue Hellenisation, some wanted to live in this world, some to withdraw. Christianity was originally no more than a Jewish sect, turning to the scriptures for justification, looking for a Messiah, hopeful of a new order. But it is not Christianity which makes the scrolls significant, nor do they make modern Israel authentic. The scrolls may illuminate the origins of Christianity and modern Judaism; but they also show us that ideas do not spring out of nothingness, that they can persist and become universal. This is the heroic impulse to make sense of the human predicament - full of pathos - made more powerful by the knowledge that the Essenes vanished, but their beautiful testaments survived.  Justin Cartwright has just directed a documentary on the Dead Sea Scrolls. His Whitbread prize-winning novel, Leading the Cheers, is published by Sceptre, £6.99

webTitle: Net stations? We've got thousands of 'em

fields.headline: Net stations? We've got thousands of 'em
fields.trailText: Wave riding
fields.body:
You didn't know you needed this - but trust me, you'll love it: on Radio Finland you can hear the news in Latin.

Not on the tranny but on the internet (www.yle.fi/fbc/latini/). And the internet is how radio is increasingly going to be heard. This isn't futuristic hype, it's the abundant present. At a Radio Academy conference on radio and the web last week the figure of 20,000 stations was bandied about, though many of these are terrestrial stations simultaneously broadcasting on the web, rather than bespoke net stations.

It has been estimated that 70% of American twentysomethings, when they use their computer, simultaneously listen to a CD or a radio station on it. The 40s British radio programme Music While You Work was meant to raise the spirits of factory workers. Now we can raise our own.

Net radio listening can be problematic if the server is down or there's net congestion, but it is the place to hear exciting radio. www.radioqualia.va.com.au offers sound art made from the glitches that other radio stations have thrown away. Last week it also ran a strange tale about Mary, a colour scientist imprisoned in a black and white room by unidentified captors as an experiment. That's what it sometimes feels like listening to net radio, where there's no pretentiousness filter.

But there's wit too. www.hearingvoices.com bills itself as where journalism meets John Cage, while on Chicago's www.thislife.org I heard Take A Negro Home Tonight, a scam to drive rednecks demented.

We bring to our net listening a BBC ear, and discover how many other ways there are of doing radio. Berkeley station's www.kpfa.org was the first listener-sponsored radio in the world and, despite repeated cash crises and manage ment follies, still sounds fresh, if sometimes achingly West Coast.

While traditional, formatted radio admits innovation only reluctantly, net radio embraces it. On www.gaialive.co.uk , DJs pay to host a show and play underground London music.

It is easy to get overwhelmed. In the number and variety of radio stations we hear in Britain, we've gone, thanks to the web, from paucity to excess without passing enough. It's a radiophonic Babel, but guiding sites like www.live-radio.net help, offering dozens of stations in virtually every country. Or there's the excellent World Radio Network (www.wrn.org ) re-broadcasting hundreds of public radio news services in English, Lao, Khmer, Burmese, Esperanto and more.

Sure, there's dross. In The Legend of Castle Bodner, a half-hour award-winning drama from www.shoestrong.org about a romance in a haunted castle, the doors aren't the only thing to creak. And many net stations are just a branch of e-commerce, vehicles for the sale of CDs.

But after surfing net radio, even cable and satellite TV looks restricted. And pirate radio - who needs it? The net is the audio equivalent of desktop publishing, allowing the small to compete with the big, without need of licence, dosh, or the constraints of regulation. Anthropologist Jo Tacchi suggests net radio will enfranchise black people traditionally excluded from mainstream radio, while also enabling local sounds to reach a global audience.

The phone will make net radio mobile. Last week independent radio production house Somethin' Else signed deals with Ericsson to deliver interactive broadcast content for mobile phones, and with BT launched the XY Network broadcast entertainment service specially for Wap phones (www.xynetwork.com ).

As for the BBC, the net allows expats to hear The Archers; but given the thousands of identical formatted stations out there, creating original quality programmes becomes even more imperative.

So will net radio rival traditional stations? Will we ever listen to net radio while doing the washing-up? Don't expect an answer from me, for this is my last column as this paper's radio critic.

fields.headline: The last word on acting
fields.trailText: Good actors are good because of the things they can tell us without talking. - Cedric Hardwicke
fields.body:
Good actors are good because of the things they can tell us without talking. - Cedric Hardwicke

It seems to be a human need, because it is a human universal, to tell - or more tellingly, to enact - stories about human experience. There are many reasons for this, apart from the entertainment value. We watch or read tales about lives like our own, and lives unlike our own, to understand ourselves better, to understand other possibilities better, and sometimes to escape both. A potent way of doing so is through performance, especially in film and theatre, which reprise one of the most ancient of arts. One easily imagines humanity's remote ancestors gathered round the fire at night to recapitulate legends about gods, heroes and the hunt, either dancing and singing them, or watching poets recount them in the footlight of the flames under a proscenium of stars, gesticulating and changing voices to suit the story, encouraged by a firelit ring of spellbound eyes.

With very little change, this describes what the late John Gielgud did in a career of consummate acting in which, occasionally, there was almost - but never quite - the flavour of ham. He had beautiful diction and an even more beautiful control of the meaning of his lines, and he easily passed the test implied in Cedric Hardwicke's dictum that "when actors are talking, they are the servants of the dramatist. It is what they can show the audience when they are not talking that reveals the fine actor."

As this shows, actors are not merely playwrights' mouthpieces. They have the same relation to the text of a play as a musician does to a composer's score. They must grasp its possibilities of meaning, and they must know what an audience understands by another's ways of saying and seeming, moving and doing. The least of their craft thus demands skills of interpretation and representation. By connecting them an actor mirrors the world, and makes audiences believe they see truth in the reflection.

Shakespeare was fond of the convertible insights that the stage is a microcosm of the world, and the world a macrocosm of the stage. When the world's a stage, he famously said, all its inhabi tants are players, their lives a series of parts from the infant "mewling and puking in its nurse's arms" to the superannuate entering "second childishness and mere oblivion."

But people are actors in more than this. We talk of the roles we play, many of them simultaneously, as children and parents, colleagues and friends, customers and consumers, spectators and participants. We adjust our behaviour according to the company or circumstances we find ourselves in. As a result we may play a variety of parts in a single day, some very different from the others - and yet all of them are ourselves, all express facets of our identities, which are therefore more multiple, protean and evolving than we tend to think, even if the sum of their interactions yields a personality that is, within a range of variability, stable in its appearance to the outside world - like the sound of a chord made up of many notes.

The acting of roles comes naturally in ordinary life, because ordinary life demands it; but it helps to know this latter fact, so that one can be prepared not just to play one's part when required, but to act a part if required. The words "acting" and "action" have the same root in the Latin verb ago, agere, egi, actum - to do, to drive, to lead. To play one's part, to have a role, is therefore to be active rather than passive; it is to take charge of oneself, and to make a difference of one's own choosing.

Thinking of a person as a troupe of actors explains much. It explains the difficulty each individual has in defining a sense of self, at least until the members of the troupe have each had their turn on life's stage.

It explains the mistake in thinking that there is a route - for example, psychotherapy - which could help one to find the truth about oneself, for it shows that there are many routes to many truths about oneself, and at least several of them have to be travelled before the relation between those truths can be understood. And it explains why, when instructed to "be yourself," it is so hard to comply; unless what comes closest to a central self is the one you are when you are unaware of yourself, and when you are happy without knowing it.

webTitle: Last of the great songwriter satirists

fields.headline: Last of the great songwriter satirists
fields.standfirst: Warren Zevon sounds gruffer and more despairing than ever - which suits  Bob Flynn
fields.trailText: Warren Zevon sounds gruffer and more despairing than ever - which suits Bob Flynn
fields.body:
Warren Zevon has admitted he was drunk for 27 years. I imagined him like a rock Howard Hughes, festering in some seedy Caribbean hide-out with the bottles and the paranoia, demanding lawyers, guns and money, fading into his own iconography. But the Tarantino of pop is back, as if the body on the slab has just sat up and started singing his wry, venomous numbers from one of the darkest and funniest American songbooks.

It was the perfect, packed-out opener to Billy Kelly's adventurous Big Big Country Festival of non-mainstream American music. An excitable audience filled Glasgow's all-smoking, all-drinking Old Fruitmarket with shouted requests to Zevon who, at 53, looks a little mashed up by life. But the voice is a deep sonorous thing that crackles like dry leather, and he can still draw blood with one deadpan line.

Zevon, though, was recovering from a throat infection and he moved from a sluggish start - as if he was still unsure about the whole damn business - into a growling caustic cascade of dystopian American visions, switching between guitar and keyboards, mixing old favourites with songs from his new album, Life'll Kill Ya.

Marching through The Detox Mansion into My Shit's Fucked Up, the songs tumble out of his battered suitcase of jokey despair. Succinct tales of fracture and failure, and thumbnail sketches of lonely desperation, positively revelling in the flotsam of American life are all set to jaunty rock and ragtime rhythms.

The new songs, like the wistful, shuddering plea of Don't Let Us Get Sick, are all about the terror of ageing and hardly pop-chart compatible. But it is surprising how contemporary it all sounds.

By the end he's into a pounding resurrection of Werewolves of London, the throat holding up through the howling choruses, and, of all startling things, a fiery version of Robert Burns song of national betrayal A Parcel of Rogues in a Nation somehow segueing into the savage irony of Lawyers, Guns and Money. Extraordinary.

He's unmissable because he's still the sharpest pitch-black joker in the pack. Hurry on down and catch the last of the American songwriter satirists playing from the belly of the rock beast. Billy Joel from hell.

 The Big Big Country festival continues until June 4. Warren Zevon plays Warwick Arts Centre, Coventry, tomorrow, the Custom House, South Shields, on Monday and Shepherd's Bush Empire on Tuesday.

fields.headline: Call me Laurie
fields.standfirst: The hi-tech, multimedia Moby Dick contains a little bit of Melville and a lot of Laurie Anderson, writes  Andrew Clements
fields.trailText: The hi-tech, multimedia Moby Dick contains a little bit of Melville and a lot of Laurie Anderson, writes Andrew Clements
fields.body:
Moby Dick may be the Great American Novel, but it is also a book, like A La Recherche du Temps Perdu, that everybody means to read one day, but just hasn't got down to yet. Yet anyone planning to see Laurie Anderson's latest hi-tech, multimedia extravaganza Songs and Stories from Moby Dick, which has arrived in Britain for five performances at the Barbican Theatre this week, ought to do as much homework as they can before they go, for Anderson's take on this teeming, discursive narrative is an oblique one.

This is the first of her performance pieces to be based upon an existing text. All the previous shows, from the eight-hour United States of the early 80s onwards, have been built out of her own reminiscences and wry observations on American life. Anderson has said that the new piece is "10% Melville, 90 per cent Laurie", and that is how it seems, with themes from the book sparking anecdotes of her own, and the musical numbers using her words rather than the novelist's.

There is no narrative thread running through the Songs and Stories, though the work does end with Ahab's death, the destruction of his ship the Pequod and the survival of the storyteller - "Call me Ishmael". The novel's major characters (though not Ishmael himself, nor the harpooner Queequeg) do appear, portrayed by a group of four singing actors in a mixture of set-piece musical numbers and rather archly choreographed stage pictures - another departure for Anderson, who has previously operated as a one-woman band, singing and playing everything.

The attempt to broaden the theatrical canvas seems to me the major weakness in the piece. Anderson is at her best in anecdotal/confessional mode, one-to- one with the audience either singing her naggingly memorable songs or unfolding little stories over gently pulsating soundtracks. In Moby Dick those moments are the strong points of the show. There are mini-lectures on how whales communicate and how the sperm whale got its name, an engaging little anecdote about going to the Natural History Museum in South Kensington to talk to the head of the whale section, who turned out to be an expert on worms instead; but there are too few of them, especially musical ones.

Her writing for the rest of the cast is unmemorable, apart from some striking numbers for Ahab - virtuosically played by Tom Nelis, complete with stovepipe hat and some pirouetting manoeuvres on his crutches. A mawkish MOR ballad for the Second Mate (Price Waldman) belongs in a second-rate musical rather than here - it is sentimental guff of a kind I thought Anderson was too discriminating to write - while some of the stage routines would not have embarrassed the Four Tops or the Platters in the early 60s. I can only hope they were meant to be tongue-in-cheek.

The technology is slick and inventive, as you would expect from someone who has been pushing at the boundaries of the possible for 20 years now. Anderson's latest digital creation, the "talking stick", creates some extraordinary continuums of sampled sounds; the harmoniser, which allows her to deepen her voice or to sing in duet with herself, makes another appearance; and the ambient music, with its haloes of creaking ships and whale song, is strikingly atmospheric. The visuals are sometimes striking too - seascapes and underwater life, the pages of the novel flicking across the back wall, letters from them spinning through space, the actors using real-time video cameras to project their own likenesses around them.

What the show needs most of all is a backbone. Too much is taken (literally) as read; there are too many tangential ideas. The words, of course, are crucial, but for all the sophistication of her electronic hardware, Anderson has failed to solve the problem of audibility. In the Barbican - a space designed to project unenhanced speech - amplification blurs the syllables. You cannot hang on every word of the Songs and Stories, because you cannot hear them, and in a piece written around one of the greatest prose works, that is a real problem.

 Until tomorrow (returns only). Box office: 020-7638 8891

webTitle: She said 'I do', so he said 'Sorry, she doesn't'

fields.headline: She said 'I do', so he said 'Sorry, she doesn't'
fields.standfirst: Nancy Banks-Smith on another wedding-day disaster in soapland, this time at Brookside
fields.trailText: Nancy Banks-Smith on another wedding-day disaster in soapland, this time at Brookside
fields.body:
Who can forget the wedding of Amanda Carrington and Crown Prince Michael of Moldavia in Dynasty, when the Popular Front came crashing through the windows, firing from the hip, and the King of Moldavia, seizing opportunity by the forelock, threw himself firmly on Joan Collins.

American soaps, unlike ours, tend to be about the rich. As the Rev Spooner once said to his stunned congregation, "All of you have horny hands and most of you are mothers," which nicely encapsulates the cast of the average British soap.

Recently, for no apparent reason, Channel 4's Brookside, the Scouser's soap, has been infested with nobs. Nathan, in particular, turned out to be the son of a big nob, Viscount Cuddington of stately Cuddington Hall. You know what they're like, these people. Before you can say "Gerroff back to Cheshire!" they are taking your jobs and marrying your women, and yesterday Nathan married Jacqui Dixon of this parish. Well, almost.

The wedding was held in Cuddington Hall. A string quartet gave Congratulations plenty of welly. The bride's father, known to his few friends as Dicko, was wearing his best wig, the one with the wave in it. And who should turn up but Jill from Crossroads, purporting to be the richest woman in the world. ("She started very modestly with a motel in the Midlands, invested wisely and... hey presto!") Gaiety was jolly well unconfined, in a subdued sort of way.

Soap weddings are like standing on the Lux in the bath, a sudden whirl of limbs, bad language and occasional concussion. At best the groom's middle name will turn out to be Shostakovich. At worst there will be a woman with a baby in the back row. The Vicar of Dibley had a nice variation on this. A woman at the back cried "Stop! The groom is married to me!" then, as the happy couple turned towards her like dead men swinging from a gibbet, "Oops, sorry! Wrong church!"

This was a double wedding and both brides were in two minds about getting married. Rachel, the daughter of the body buried under the patio, suddenly went off all men in spades. As her groom was a man, this initially proved a difficulty ("I'm going to look a right plank!') but the perfectly circular Sinbad talked her round.

Jacqui was also having twinges, realising belatedly that, if she married Nathan and lived in London, she would be giving up "me friends and me family and me life in Liverpool". To many this would have seemed a positive plus. Many Liverpudlians leave with all speed, as if on the toe of a boot. My parents for two. But this whole saga turned on the siren song of Liverpool, which goes something like this:

I wish I was back in Liverpool

Liverpool Town where I was born

Where there ain't no trees

No scented breeze

No fields of waving corn.

But there's lots of girls

With peroxide curls

And the black and tans flow free.

There's six in a bed

By the old pierhead

And it's Liverpool Town for me.

Nathan's face was set and white, like a hardboiled egg. When Jacqui said doubtfully, "I do," he said, "No, I'm sorry but I don't think she does," and the registrar quickly revised his idea that marriage gives a new gladness to the sunshine and new fragrance to the flowers.

I think a great opportunity was missed here. Brookside people are well used to living in each other's spare rooms and back pockets. Nathan's grand house in Holland Park has eight bedrooms. Ample room for the whole boiling: Jimmy Corkhill, who is in the throes of clinical depression; Dave, the shifty drug dealer, whose eyes are set so close you could fire them down his nostrils; Susannah and her current bit of rough; Jacqui's surrogate baby; Ron Dixon and his collection of rare rugs; Emily and Tinhead, the Bonnie and Clyde of Merseyside; and that new kid who wants to be Pope when he grows up. Not one of them intelligible for more than five seconds together. They could do the show right here.

webTitle: The old ones are the best

fields.headline: The old ones are the best
fields.standfirst: Elliott Carter in his 90s is better than ever, says  Tom Service
fields.trailText: Elliott Carter in his 90s is better than ever, says Tom Service
fields.body:
To talk of a composer's "late period" is often to suggest an otherworldly concentration on the ineffable, eternal questions. But in his 90s Elliott Carter has produced a miraculously prolific series of works that, far from displaying a removal from worldly affairs, contain some of the freshest, most invigorating - in short, youthful - music of his career.

The London Sinfonietta under Oliver Knussen, one of the most eloquent and impassioned champions of Carter's recent music, presented two Carter premieres at the Queen Elizabeth Hall in London this week: the first complete performance of his song cycle, Tempo e Tempi, and the British debut of the ASKO Concerto.

The concerto is, in a sense, a homage to the baroque concerto grosso form, where a brief ritornello punctuates a succession of solo sections. But Carter has transformed the entire ensemble into a collection of individuals, as the 16-piece line-up is split into concertino-like groups of duos, trios, a quintet and a solo.

Each soloistic section has a precisely defined character, from the quiescent, almost lamenting dialogue between bass clarinet, trombone and cello, to the rapturous andvolcanic duet between violin and trumpet. However, the most spectacular individual performance was from John Orford, whose bassoon solo was mercurial in its playfulness.

Like so much of Carter's latest music, the ASKO Concerto speaks with the freedom and confidence of a composer who, as he said in a pre-concert talk, "knows what he's doing" after a seven-decade-long career. If that implies that composition has become easier for Carter, there is no hint of production-line monotony in his newest pieces.

Where the ASKO Concerto found its form through the special qualities of the ASKO Ensemble, who commissioned the piece, so too the collection of Italian settings, Tempo e Tempi, creates its own highly characterised structures. Carter conjures striking musical images from an ensemble of soprano, oboe, clarinet, violin and cello to complement poems of cruel rivers, sunken oboes and the incessant march of time.

At the end of the nightscape of the final song, Carter sets the last word, " luce ", to the most serene music of the set: as if time itself had stopped in this tranquil and ecstatic sequence of chords. Lucy Shelton and the Sinfonietta players matched Carter's demands with a crystalline expressiveness. Carter's own creativity shows no sign of abating, with a cello concerto on the way and another opera on the cards.

fields.headline: A mad, mad world
fields.standfirst: London's new Salvador Dali Universe is more baroque souvenir shop than museum: the old surrealist would have approved, writes  Jonathan Jones
fields.trailText: London's new Salvador Dali Universe is more baroque souvenir shop than museum: the old surrealist would have approved, writes Jonathan Jones
fields.body:
The toxic stench, jagged metal and dangerous drops that greet the press inside the new Salvador Dali Universe create a spectacular surrealist experience but, unfortunately, will not be permanent parts of the exhibition. Work on the new museum is a little slow and this bizarre addition to County Hall's post-GLC attractions, sandwiched between the London Aquarium and the millennium wheel, will not open until next weekend, a week later than planned. Shame they can't leave it as it is. The whiff of chemicals might have appealed to Dali, who claimed he courted his wife Gala by covering himself in goat manure and laughing maniacally.

A good laugh, Dali, but he has had a bad press ever since he was cast out of the surrealist movement. "Dali's venture," fumed the group's leader, André Breton, was "discredited by a cynical indifference regarding ways of imposing himself on the public."

The Salvador Dali Universe won't correct that impression. It contains mostly late prints and sculptures - some suspiciously late, dating from the mid-80s when he was confined to bed and rumours abounded, as they still do, about who was sanctioning multiples of his works. It mixes up early relics with awesomely vacuous pseudo-art nouveau bronzes of icons like the floppy watch. It is more baroque souvenir shop than museum, with trinkets shown off in dark, cavernous spaces. I enjoyed it. I like the Salvador Dali Theatre-Museum in Figueras, too. This is a bargain-basement version.

It is easy to take the Breton position on Dali - that he began as an authentic surrealist, putting the Freudian theory of revolution into practice with the sliced eyeball, donkey-dragging priest and dismembered hand in Un Chien Andalou, his 1929 film with Luis Buñuel, and then betrayed the movement, turning into "Avida Dollars", the anagram Breton uncovered in his name. One might agree that where his early art is a revelation of the unconscious, his later work is a posturing theatre of surrealist cliches - "Zeez are symbolic feesh" as he told Russell Harty in a classic TV encounter.

Fortunately, because you won't learn much about early Dali from this exhibition, you can supplement it with a trip downriver, where some of his greatest paintings are on show at Tate Modern; this Thameside Dalinian odyssey recalls his visit to Britain in 1936 when he gave a lecture in a deep-sea diving suit. Looking from early to late Dali, the falling off is undeniable, but something links his most compelling paintings with the bronze unicorns, tarot cards and rococo tableware that constitute The Dali Universe: his poisonous mixture of traditional technique with a rejection of the values that technique was meant to uphold.

Drawing was supposed to give structure to the world; Dali used it to create bodies with no solidity. His wispy people are sick. Where Ernst or Magritte created allusive images of the psyche, Dali painted people masturbating or defecating. He was the biggest pervert in modern art, and this runs through his paintings' textures - the shiny surfaces, the soft bodies. Ugh. That's how George Orwell responded, throwing down Dali's autobiography with the judgment that its author was "a dirty little scoundrel".

What could be in worse taste, finally, than to sign your name to blank sheets and let publishers decide what to print on them? That attack on the signature of the artist has been done more respectably by other artists.

But it is the grotesque excess of Dali that still disturbs. His most provocative gestures were made in the gap between fine art and mass culture. The Dali Universe may not have much in the way of classic early works, but it does have one rare souvenir - the painted backcloth of wide-open eyes with spiny eyelashes that Dali designed for Hitchcock's 1945 movie Spellbound.

Hitchcock claimed Dali wanted Ingrid Bergman to be covered with ants, but that "just wasn't possible". Instead, for the dream at the heart of this Freudian romance, Dali created that forest of eyes snipped by giant scissors. It was pure Hollywood, and yet a direct translation of the avant-garde aesthetic of Un Chien Andalou into popular cinema. To borrow a couple of Dali's favourite words, this is a putrid and cretinous museum - but who doesn't like looking at symbolic feesh?

 The Dali Universe opens on June 3 at County Hall, London SE1 (020-7620 2720).

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText: So, BNP leader Nick Griffin would be opposed to immigration if, and I quote, 'it meant they were going to take over the country and change it so we do not have a homeland - which every people needs if it's going to survive.' (Race To The Right, May 20.)
fields.body:
So, BNP leader Nick Griffin would be opposed to immigration if, and I quote, 'it meant they were going to take over the country and change it so we do not have a homeland - which every people needs if it's going to survive.' (Race To The Right, May 20.)

It's a pity the British ancestors of Griffin, and others like him, didn't think the same way when they invaded nearly every country outside of Europe all those centuries ago, acting as if it was their God-given right to take over other peoples' land and slaughter them out of existence. The Native Americans barely survived, and the Aborigines are now shadows of their former selves. What homeland do these people have now?

I suspect the reason the British far right has never managed to re-invent itself as a legitimate political movement is because Britain has, for centuries, been made up of immigrants. Look deep enough into the history of many British people and you will see that they are descended from foreigners. And for all Griffin's race hatred, it didn't stop him from going to Libya to beg for money.
Joyce Cope
Address supplied

Until last Saturday, I was blissfully unaware that the BNP had a new leader, or of the fledgling Führer's name. So why is the Guardian giving free publicity to right-wing fantasists that no one has ever heard of? Shame on you.
John Beardsmore
Leicester

Andrea Dworkin's views were fascinating (Take No Prisoners, May 13), once I was able to read them. My problem was not illiteracy but my (male) partner's preoccupation with the photographs of Ms Dworkin, which he found so repellent that he refused to read the article or to let me near the Weekend section.

I know the feminist arguments about womens' appearance but, even so, one must wonder what was the purpose of so many photographs, some in close-up, of Ms Dworkin. I am sure that the photographer, and maybe the editor, were well aware of their likely impact upon readers, particularly men, and wonder whether they were included with the perhaps unconscious purpose of detracting from, and thus undermining, the disturbing substance of the excellent article, by producing a debate on Ms Dworkin's appearence.
Dr Tanya Garrett
Stafford

As a lifelong purveyor of crisp sandwiches, I must categorically disagree with Mathew Fort (Love At First Bite, May 20). Not only is peanut butter a superb additive, but combined with strong cheddar cheese on a proper northern cob, with (Walkers) cheese-and-onion crisps, the result is sublime (especially when pregnant).
Emma Byne
London SW9

Has anyone got a spare copy of Lost Consonants, number 144, I could swap for a duplicate of number 507?
Julian Dunn
eisendora@compuserve.com
Oxford

Last week's Dear Weekend contained no mention whatsoever of Julie Burchill. Isn't it time you replaced her with someone more controversial?
Richard Saunders
Alton, Hants

webTitle: A matter of life and death

fields.headline: A matter of life and death
fields.standfirst: Catherine Chalmers takes photographs of animals at their most beastly: quasi-gladiatorial images of insects, reptiles and amphibians mating, killing and devouring each other (in one case, all three). What makes her work all the more unnerving, however, is that she captures these deadly embraces in a wholly unnatural environment. In doing so, argues Libby Brooks - and irrespective of our response to them, be that intrigued, horrified, even repulsed - Chalmers questions our own sense of morality
fields.trailText: Catherine Chalmers takes photographs of animals at their most beastly: quasi-gladiatorial images of insects, reptiles and amphibians mating, killing and devouring each other (in one case, all three). What makes her work all the more unnerving, however, is that she captures these deadly embraces in a wholly unnatural environment. In doing so, argues Libby Brooks - and irrespective of our response to them, be that intrigued, horrified, even repulsed - Chalmers questions our own sense of morality
fields.body:
The taut skin of a plump red tomato buckles and rips, then oozes flesh, as a caterpillar begins to feed. A praying mantis clamps the candy-striped larva between its front legs. It tears into the turquoise underbelly, and a viscous bulb of tomato pulp erupts. Two mantises meet, dance, mount. They hold each other intensely, then suddenly her jaws are on his neck. Another mantis hops nervously around a slick, petrol-coloured tree frog. The frog yawns and gapes. Its puckered pink tongue flashes and the mantis is gone.

Welcome to the food chain. Death nourishes. Sex kills. Hunger is brutal. It is these fundamentals of existence - eating, mating, dying - that are explored at their nexus in artist Catherine Chalmers' vivid photography of insects, amphibians and reptiles. Capturing small deaths in huge detail, her magnified prints allow a dignity and authority to species normally left under the carpet. Because size matters, not only in relationships between animals but in mediating our typically human responses to them. "If it's smaller than your foot and you can step on it, then it seems okay that you do so," says Chalmers. "Because it's small, you can step on an ant and walk away. If the ant were the size of a hippopotamus, our relationship with it would be entirely different.

"We have this idea that a lion is the predator and the zebra a prey, but a zebra can also kill a lion with one kick. The predator/prey scenario can very quickly reverse if the size proportion is wrong. So one of my praying mantises got attacked by a caterpillar that grew too big and they rolled around the set. When I put the tarantula and a full-grown mantis together, I realised it could have done some damage to the spider."

Her exhibition prints deliberately confound perspective. The praying mantis is large enough to eat the viewer. Baby mice, fed to snakes and frogs, are the size of human newborns. The deaths of these "pinkies" - blind, hairless, vulnerable - are particularly chilling. The baby strains vainly, then relaxes into submission as the snake wraps itself around her tiny form, first caressing then gobbling.

But is empathy genus-specific? Do we care about the fate of a mouse more than that of a caterpillar? Ambiguity is Chalmers' lexicon. "As humans, we tend to root for the underdog," she says. "There is one kill, but it depends on how you present the information. What animal you want to live and die is entirely subjective, from person to person and day to day."

Raising her subjects from birth in her New York loft, Chalmers found her own relationship to them swinging between the maternal and the functional. "I had lots of caterpillars and they bit me every time I picked them up. They also had this spectacularly beautiful death when they were ripped open, so when I fed them to the mantis I always looked forward to it.

"But the mantises were so difficult to keep: it took a mini-ecosystem to raise them. I had to give them live food, fruit flies when they're babies, then houseflies, then crickets, and they were all housed individually because they're cannibalistic. It would take me four hours to feed the brood, fly by fly. They have a head that moves on a neck much like ours, unlike most insects, where the head and body are fused. They look back at you with two big eyes. I got to really like them. When I first put one up on set with a tarantula, I procrastinated. I was attached to them and it really touched me."

Her tarantula, however, was a docile creature. "So the longer it didn't eat, the more I wanted it to, and I then began to worry about why the spider was rejecting food."

Some of her series of photographs are published in a book, Food Chain: Encounters Between Mates, Predators, And Prey, and an exhibition of her photographs of roaches is currently on show in London.
