Houseflies interested me because they essentially live their lives with us. They live indoors in a house like humans, and have a parallel life of their own."

We take these species seriously only in our desperation to eliminate them, she argues, pointing to the billions of dollars spent each year on pesticides. We despise the abundant, unaware that the way we live tends to increase the species we hate most, the ones that live off us. "One of the things we don't like about insects is that they work on numbers. You can kill one fly, or 10, you can kill 100 roaches, but you're never going to get them all. There's always another one coming. It's that lack of control, and their ability to insert themselves into our lives whenever they want to, that bothers us. They live lives that seem to be the most opposite of ours - they eat their young, females eat males - and do all sorts of things that, to our mammalian code of ethics, are outrageous."

Chalmers aims to confront our separation from the natural and the base instinctual. It's one thing to observe a food chain, she says, and another to be part of it. "It's possible, in the west, to go through life without seeing any of the basic mechanisms of the natural world. We don't see the bird eat too many worms. It's easy to eat a hamburger and never have killed a cow."

So she recreates in her studio that which exists in a world from which we are removed. "I wanted to find out what it was like to see something so true to the functions of the earth but so removed from us as humans. It's very easy to have a connection with nature in the form of a cute little puppy. It's much more difficult to be in touch with the parts of nature from which we have worked throughout time to separate ourselves."

But where does natural begin and unnatural end? Nowadays, natural means make-up, muesli, mineral water. "It's one of those words whose definition changes throughout time. We would call a nature reserve natural because there are no buildings or roads there. But that reserve has been completely modified and managed by human beings."

While her photographs portray the most natural of impulses, her subjects are pictured against a stark white background more reminiscent of a fashion shoot than traditional nature photography. "I wanted a neutral place that was away from nature and away from us. The tree frogs are originally from Australia, the mantises from China. The caterpillars and the tomato were the only things indigenous to the US. They would never have met were it not for humans and, more specifically, me. I didn't come across them in the wild, so putting them back there was beside the point."

But that neutral space was the locus of extreme events. "At first, I was horrified that I was raising animals to eat each other. I felt that was beyond what someone should do. I'd never killed an animal before in my life, and throughout this project I never did, myself," she qualifies. Was there a sense that she was playing God among her glass cases? "Every time I reached into the cage of mice, there would be a pile of little pinkies. They all looked the same and I could reach for one or, in a half-inch, reach for another. That was unsettling. I didn't like being the one to choose. Part of me felt bad playing God, and the other part felt I was doing a good job raising my snake."

She takes a pragmatic view of the inevitable animal-rights concerns, arguing that she cares for her animals painstakingly well and simply feeds them what they require. We are all involved in a little bit of God-playing, she says. "We have zoos all over the world that are used now for conservation and breeding programmes. We have got ourselves into a position where, in the natural world, things are so out of balance that there is a need for intervention on our part, trying to put it right, or to what we believe is supposed to be right.

"Should we have pets at all? Look what we've done to dogs. You buy a beagle, which has been entirely manipulated for our pleasure to look like that. Then we have a whole industry that takes cows and grinds them up into little dog pellets. At what point do you start interjecting a morality?"

And whose morality? The predator and the prey bring their own survival imperatives to the kill. We add a third human eye. We are both fascinated and repelled by violence among animals, but do we impose our own ethics upon them? "That's certainly bound up in which animals we like and dislike. We tend to like other mammals, enjoy the ones that are soft, with big eyes, and tend not to like the ones with glassy eyes and scales. "But saving the ecosystem of a certain species of worm may be more important because it preserves the forest in its entirety - the world could ecologically function very well without humans and function pretty well without mammals, but get rid of the insects and things would fall apart very quickly."

What separates us from the subjects of these photographs: an accident of biology, the superiority of civilisation, a distrust of instinct? And whose side are we on? Perhaps it is because these creatures are most different from us that we like them least. But out of context and perspective, their stories resonate. It is Chalmers' art to make the ugly beautiful, and the unknowable accessible.

fields.headline: Toasty-Whitey aggro
fields.standfirst: 'Back when I lived in Cairo, colour was not something hidden under an itchy blanket of pretended equality: it was in your face'
fields.trailText: 'Back when I lived in Cairo, colour was not something hidden under an itchy blanket of pretended equality: it was in your face'
fields.body:
When the chap from the water company backed into Nayra's car in the office driveway some weeks ago, we should have rushed to lock the gates, call the police, file a report... But it was five o'clock, and we each had somewhere else we needed to be. He seemed okay. He said, "Accidents happen, love, what can I say? The company'll take care of it."

So even though Nayra narrowed her eyes and said he seemed like a bad lot and she didn't trust him, I put it down to a snooty, centuries-old suspicion of the working classes and came on all liberal: "No, no, you heard what the man said. He's admitted responsibility. What else can he do?"

Well, plenty. The water company's insurers wrote to say that Nayra had backed into their car and that they'd be looking to us for their expenses. "But the driver said..." "He's been fired." So we have a battle on our hands. Pam says she believes it's a "Toasty" versus "Whitey" thing. Nayra and I being the Toasties and the driver and - presumably - the water company being the Whiteys.

The Toasty thing comes from a joke about how, when God made Man, He'd left the first batch in the oven too long and, seeing it was burned, He'd tucked it into a corner of Africa. With the second batch, He was over-careful, snatching it out before it was done, and He'd hidden the doughy result in northern Europe. The third time He got it just right, and the people of toasted complexion who'd come out He'd placed in His choice spot: the centre of the earth, the Mediterranean.

Racist? Back when I lived at home, in Cairo, it had seemed harmless enough. Colour was not something hidden under an itchy blanket of pretended equality; it was in your face. Two teachers at Cairo University who shared the same name and department but not complexion, were referred to as "Black Khalafallah" and "White Khalafallah" when it was necessary to distinguish between them. And the description was just that: descriptive. I know, because when a phrase was reckoned to describe an area in which a person was "challenged", it was transmuted into something else. So my nanny, for example, whose right eye had been spectacularly ruined in childhood, was referred to in our street as "She of the honoured eye".

What that may or may not tell us about "labyrinthine" eastern minds or manners is beside this particular point: Egyptians come in every shade, from the burnt chocolate of Aswan and Nuba, to the green eyes and golden hair of the Bedu of Sinai and the Western desert. Partly it's geography, partly history: the waves of varying races that over 7,000 years have been swept on to Egypt's shores have left their mark. But the majority is what you might call, well, "toasty".

"Toasty" was what was printed on the baseball cap of a little dog-doll that my son acquired when he was two. Soon enough, a game evolved. Whenever anything went wrong, we asked, "Who-o-o did that? It wasn't me it wasn't you - it must have been . . . TOASTY!" Toasty could carry the wrongdoings of the world, for he came equipped with boxing gloves and a bungee-line, and could always dodge away and spring back punching.

Oddly, just the other day, I found Toasty wedged behind the back of a sofa as I tried to return some order to the house after my son's first teenage "party". There he was, apprehensive, defensive, expecting no doubt to be blamed for the beer bottles in the bushes, the cigarette ends trodden into the lawn, the mud on the curtains - on the curtains! Was the Can-Can back in fashion? - the chewing-gum stuck to the cushions, the door-frame torn from the wall, the broken chairs . . . I shan't go on. I looked at him for a moment, but I knew it wasn't him. To give him his due, my son had spent what was left of the night before disinfecting the basins, cleaning the floor, piling every towel in the house into the washing machine and had only stopped hammering at the chairs when yelled at that it was past two o'clock and were we NEVER to get any sleep?

Sleep? Perchance to dream, of parties as I thought they were meant to be. Events to be looked forward to for weeks, dressed up for, discussed. There was food and soft drinks and conversation and dancing. And the life of the house seemed to carry on uninterrupted.

Now, I was banished upstairs, and as I looked out at the garden from my bedroom window I realised that this wasn't a party at all. It was just some kids getting together and lacking a natural venue. I don't mean to harp on about Cairo, but you only go by what you know. If this were there, they'd have met at their club or at one of the countless sandwich and juice bars where the young congregate. Here, they have nowhere to go. Once they're 16, the pubs will suck them in and spew them out at midnight - reeling.

Meanwhile, they bide their time. I should have realised it wasn't a party by both the preparation and the lack of it. On Thursday, my son asked if he could have "some people" round. My consent was all that was required. Offers of pizza, fruit, even crisps were turned down. "You don't offer food," he said. Friday at 7pm, the house was on full alert: cabinets turned round to face the wall, carpets rolled up, mantelpieces cleared, drinks hidden, books and papers stashed away. Two young heavies were detailed to the door to intercept gate-crashers. I even had to move my car out of the drive in case it was sat on. Not that I'd have minded particularly, as it's old and battered, anyway, but being a Citroën it is very sensitive around the suspension. That graceful rise on to its forelegs at the turn of the ignition followed by the pert thrust of its bottom into the air is no longer performed with the same insouciance, but rather like my beloved oldest aunt casting around for something that will bear the weight of her leaning on it as she rises hesitantly on to legs whose knees she cannot be sure will hold.

Which brings me back to where I started: I wish it had been my car that had got bashed, for I truly wouldn't have minded an extra bump on the boot. But it was Nayra's and it's new and she'd put all her savings into it and it's going to ruin her no-claims bonus and its going to be one more straw in the substantial bale of Toasty-Whitey aggro and another in that of inter-class distrust.

 Ahdaf Souief's Booker-shortlisted novel, The Map Of Love, is published in paperback by Bloomsbury, priced £6.99. Julie Burchill is away.

fields.headline: Mesomorphosis
fields.standfirst: 'This suit that once made me look mildly foolish now looks as if it is bullying me. It has more personality than me, a bad personality'
fields.trailText: 'This suit that once made me look mildly foolish now looks as if it is bullying me. It has more personality than me, a bad personality'
fields.body:
The best thing about working from home is that you can earn a living dressed in flip-flops, underpants and a 15-year-old sweatshirt. Over the phone, no one has any idea how you look. You can compose demanding emails in a state of florid BO, send outraged faxes without getting out of your dressing gown and negotiate arcane contractual details with your scrotum peeping out from under that Italia '90 T-shirt you never quite got around to throwing away. The downside to this sartorial freedom is that you end up with a distinctly odd wardrobe: thousands of T-shirts, EU food-surplus-sized mountains of underwear, a fair old heap of jeans and . . . one suit.

It's this suit that constitutes my problem. I feel about as much affection for it as I do for Phil Collins. This suit is my nemesis. I bought it four or five years ago on the grounds that, if you want to pass yourself off as an adult, you should at least possess one item of smart clothing. In an attempt to cling to a shred of dignity, I must conceal the name of the shop. All you need to know is, it was a bad choice . I was young, I was naïve, I knew nothing about suits, so I just went into a high-street shop and bought one. I thought that was how it worked with suits. Only now, with a few more years of experience behind me, is it clear how wrong I was.

It was a wedding invitation that prompted me to get mine out and dust it off again. I was prepared for a mildly unpleasant moment. But not for this. A quiet voice in the back of my head had been defying all logic, telling me that this time it would look good. Then I looked in the mirror. Swathes of grey cloth hung everywhere in giant folds. My armpits were held in a vice while every other part of my body disappeared behind a loose curtain of curiously bobbly cotton. Suddenly, I looked 1ft shorter and 1ft wider.

The fact is, I have never looked good in suits. Sorry. Understatement. When I put on a suit, I look like a builder. If I'm lucky, I may just manage to look like a waiter. Usually, though, putting on any form of smart clothes strips 16 years of education off me in an instant. I'm not, as a rule, paranoid about my body. All the relevant parts of my anatomy are still in roughly the right places without too much unsightly shrinkage, swelling or sagging. My body, naked, is okay. My body half-naked in an Italia '90 T-shirt is okay. Even the flip-flops, underpants and sweatshirt thing doesn't look too bad. But when I put on a suit, I can hear Darwin pissing himself laughing at the things evolution does to people.

The technical term is mesomorph. An ectomorph has a tall, bone-dominated physique; a mesomorph is the opposite - our bodies would still stand up if you took all the bones out. Stocky, I believe, is how lanky people describe us. A friend of mine, whose chest looks like a xylophone and who, when he wears a T-shirt, resembles a de-shelled tortoise, becomes a physical god the second he dons a suit. Even cheap suits give him an air of authority. In an expensive suit, he looks like he owns half of Switzerland. The direct result of being a mesomorph is that wedding invitations make you quake with fear. If a suit is required, and it almost always is, you are going to have to spend a whole day looking like your girlfriend's chauffeur.

This suit that once made me look mildly foolish now looks as if it is bullying me. It has more personality than me, a distinctly bad personality. Inside it, I simply disappear as a credible human being. Now, if I'm lucky , I could pass myself off as a builder in this suit. Without fortune on my side, I'll look like I'm in fancy dress.

The situation has to be rectified. If I buy another cheap suit, my position won't be improved. But if I buy an expensive suit, I risk even greater humiliation, because I know I will still look an idiot. To look an idiot in a suit from Burtons (no, that's not where I got mine) is the suit's fault. But imagine the humiliation if you put on some top-notch Paul Smith schmutter and still looked like a builder. If you can't look good in a designer suit, there is no debating who is to blame. You are like the tennis duffer with the £200 racket. Everyone who has spent less and looks better (ie, all those lanky bastard ectomorphs) can justly laugh at you and request a quotation for a spot of plastering.

Which leaves me with a simple choice. I can either look cheap and stupid by going in the Phil Collins, or vain and laughable by heading for Bond Street. Or perhaps I can concoct some excuse for wearing an Italia '90 T-shirt to a wedding. It looks good. Really. Especially with heavily-stained combat shorts and a pair of grey socks. If you could see me now, you'd believe me.

 William Sutcliffe's latest novel, The Love Hexagon, is published by Hamish Hamilton, at £9.99. Alexander Chancellor is away.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck celebrates Ken's election with a bottle of sparkling wine
fields.body:
The perfect way belatedly to celebrate Ken Livingstone's election to the London mayoral seat is to spend £3.99 on a bottle of sparkling wine. I did not vote for him, though I am, curiously, not entirely displeased that he got in, since he will at least sympathetically chew his Greens, whose opinion of London's air and streets I share. (That's Greens, by the way, not Greeks. I am sensitive about these matters, as there was a time when what I wrote was not always what you read - eight years ago, before the brilliant sub-editors who currently handle my copy, I was horrifed to discover, upon opening my copy of Weekend, that by the simple transposition of 'Sp' into 'D , I had become the first wine writer to discover Danish wine.)

The celebratory wine is at Sainsbury, and it's at the price quoted above until June 3. It's a classic bubbly: crisp, clean, fresh, dry without austerity, gently fruity without fullness. A more elegant performer than hundreds of champagnes, it is the own-label Cava, and it rates 16.5 points out of 20.

Sainsbury has several more bargains until June 3. Alteza 640 Oaked Viura (15.5 points, on offer at £2.99), from Spain, offers an interesting range of dry flavours, from almonds to under-ripe melon and a hint of apple, but the texture of this white wine is very polished and gently plump. D'Istinto Sangiovese Merlot 1998 (14 points, on offer at £2.99), from Sicily, is one of the tasty exceptions in the curate's egg that is the D Istinto wine range. It has fruit, tannins and acidity all in good working order. Sainsbury s Jumilla (15.5 points, on offer at £2.99), from Spain, is very soft and sticky but unabashedly luxurious and flavoursome as it finishes. It's a terrific barbecue red. More so is Alteza 600 Old Vines Garnacha (16 points, on offer at £3.49), from Spain. It parades burnt leaves and ripe plums, dry tannins, handsome acidity and very good fruit balance. It is a vivacious wine of more than passing quaffing interest.

At Safeway, there is a splendid pair of red, own-label Bulgars. The Young Vatted Merlot 1999 (14.5 points, £3.49) is all-embracingly fruity and delightfuly forward. The Bulgarian Country Red Merlot/Gamza 1999 (15.5 points, £2.99) is joyously unpretentious and it veritably melts in the mouth. (From which the attentive reader will deduce little tannin attack.)

At Tesco, there is a South American extravaganza going until June 6, which wipes 20% off the prices of all the following wines. Anubis Tempranillo 1999 (16 points, £5.99), from Argentina, has a most individual approach to the old Spanish grape. It flaunts a quirky soft/hard fruit edge, a dry yet soft texture and a lilting finish - 100 selected Tescos have it (call 0800 505555 for details). Isla Negra Merlot 1999 (16.5 points, £5.49), from Chile, presents deeply committed and sunnily-dispositioned fruit of gallant texture and great depth. There is a beautiful generosity to this wine and it s at 220 Tescos. 'Q' Cabernet Sauvignon 1998 (17 points, £9.99), from Argentina, is exotically warm and gently spicy and very stylishly tannic. The cabernet cliché, blackcurrant, is given a new and exciting metaphoric definition here and, though you may say that a wine at a tenner ought to be exciting (and this one is), there are far too many wines that do demand this price of admission but which reveal a hackneyed plot. It, too, is at 100 Tescos.

A superb red at Waitrose is Errazuriz Merlot 1999 (16 points, £5.99), from Chile. Controlled to begin with, it gets ripe and rampant as it finishes with a marvellous surge of soft leathery fruit. Waitrose also has a mail-order side, the so-called Waitrose Direct (0800 188881), and one utterly scrumptious South African wine only available from there is Spice Route Flagship Merlot 1998. True, the Flagship notation jars, since this status is more elegant if conferred unstated, but this does not detract from the fruity colossus in the bottle which, upon opening, crushes the palate under a tsunami of flavours. It is a special-occasion merlot of massive depth, unwavering tannins and huge food compatibility. It costs, ouch, £11.95 a bottle, but it s well worth 17 points.

fields.headline: Dough nuts
fields.standfirst: Pizza is cheap and easy, right? Not at the Dyer home, it isn't. Who better than the Kitchen Doctor, Rosie Sykes, to help them past first base, says Bob Granleese
fields.trailText: Pizza is cheap and easy, right? Not at the Dyer home, it isn't. Who better than the Kitchen Doctor, Rosie Sykes, to help them past first base, says Bob Granleese
fields.body:
Peter wasn't really interested. Still, when you're eight, there are more important things than learning how to make pizza - winding up your sister, for one. Not that Peter doesn't like pizza; he just couldn't see why mum Angela wanted to master the finer points of dough-making and toppings. Why couldn't they get a take-out like everyone else?

So, when Rosie Sykes, Kitchen Doctor, descended on the Dyers' Cambridge home, Peter did what young boys do best: he turned on the telly and pretended she wasn't there. Angela, 16-year-old Nan and lodger, Simeon, however, were tickled pink to see the KD crew. "When I make pizza, there are a couple of disaster areas," Angela had pleaded. "The dough is all sticky, and the more I knead the stickier it gets. As for toppings, I lack ideas." Being vegetarians, there was to be none of that prosciutto or salami, thank you. Just good, honest veg and cheese.

No sooner had Rosie arrived, therefore, than she was off out the door again, to the health-food store, deli and grocers on nearby Mill Road. Once back at the Dyer homestead, she ordered this chopped and that sliced before commencing her dough masterclass. "I'm going to show you two doughs," she said, "a basic one, and a rich one, for calzone."

Angela's expression suddenly switched from that of keen apprentice to terrified examinee, her fear becoming even more pronounced when Rosie began tipping out flour and yeast with reckless abandonment. "Don't worry," said Rosie disarmingly, "the measurements are all in the recipes. They're only an approximate guide, anyway. You only know a dough is right when it feels right. See, get your hands into this."

Angela prodded the unfamiliar matter gingerly, then, realising that it wasn't going to bite, got well stuck in. "It's lovely," she said. "Not at all like my efforts. It's so . . . smooth."

Time to leave the yeast to do its thing, exclaimed Rosie, and to get to grips with the vegetables. Midway through the ensuing maelstrom of frying, boiling and roasting, Dad David arrived home for his lunch. He didn't seem to notice the massed ranks in his usually peaceful kitchen, but that was because he was transfixed by the sight of Rosie holding a red pepper over an angry-looking gas flame. "Is there an official term for that?" he asked tentatively.

"Erm, charring?" said Rosie, not altogether convincingly.

Fortunately, David didn't press her on the matter, for his interest had switched to the myriad bowls of cooked and raw ingredients adorning the table. "Am I allowed to nibble this?" he asked, eying the courgettes, then shovelled a handful into his mouth before anyone could respond.

Roused from his viewing by the sound of lips smacking, Peter piped up, "Is it ready?" Rosie's eyes gleamed - so he had been paying attention, after all. Then she smiled knowingly: "Would you like to help me get the first pizza ready?" she asked. "Let's do a spring vegetable one." She had the poor boy hooked. Peter watched Rosie's every move as she rolled out a hunk of dough into a vague round ("I don't believe in perfect circles at home," she said. "It's a place to be natural"), and then, following her instructions with an attentiveness that would have made his teachers weep with envy, he laid the pesto and veg on top. "What next?" he gasped.

"It's Nan's turn," said Angela.

"Then Mum's," said Nan, the Dyers being a democratic household.

"Can I make one, too?" said Peter.

Soon, Nan was up to her elbows in aubergine, courgette and garlic, while Angela filled the calzones as if she'd been doing it all her life. No sooner had one pizza been sent to the oven than it was time to start on the next, but no one minded, least of all Peter. An hour later, they'd made - and eaten - each of Rosie's creations twice over, yet there was still plenty of dough and toppings left over. "Tell you what," said Rosie, "why don't Peter and Nan devise their own?"

Talk about red rag to a bull. While Nan placed a pinch of this and a teaspoon of that on her base, Peter piled a glistening mound of sweated onion on a slab of dough, topped it with a great smear of pesto, then chucked on hummocks of potato, mozzarella and mushroom, before capping the lot with a storm of Parmesan. "We've gone a bit excessive here," said Rosie as he presented his creation. Ten minutes later, a leaning tower of pizza emerged from the oven, but no one made a move towards it: two doughs, six toppings and 12 pizzas later, they could eat no more.

All except Peter, that is. "That means I get a big bit," he said. "And Mum, can we have pizza for dinner?"

To get your pizza going at once, give it plenty of bottom heat: preheat a baking tray and place the prepared pizza on top.

Plain pizza dough

Makes six to eight pizzas.

20g fresh yeast

500g strong white four

15g salt

2 tbsp olive oil

Around 350ml warm water

Sift the dry ingredients into a large, warm bowl, and mix with your hands, distributing the yeast evenly. Add the oil, then slowly add water - it may or may not take all the water. You want a workable yet still-moist dough - if it's too moist, add a little more flour. Turn the dough on to a floured surface and knead for 10 minutes, until smooth and elastic. Place in an oiled bowl, cover with oiled clingfilm and leave in a warm place to prove and double in size. Knock it back a little with your fist, and it's ready for use.

Enriched dough

Makes six to eight pizzas.

15g fresh yeast

2 tsp sugar

35ml warm milk

500g strong white flour

60g softened butter

2 eggs

1 tsp salt

35ml warm water

Mix the yeast with the sugar until it dissolves, then add to the warm milk. Sift flour into a warm bowl. Make a well in the centre and add the butter, eggs, salt, water and yeast mixture. Bring together and knead to a smooth dough. Place in a clean bowl, cover with oiled clingfilm, and put in a warm place to prove and double in size (allow up to two hours). Knock back, and you're ready to go.

Pissaladière

Not really a pizza, I know, but this classic French tart topping is ideal with the rich dough. Serves three to four.

450g white onions, finely sliced

200g red onions, finely sliced

3 tbsp olive oil

2 large red peppers

1 handful pitted black olives

In a covered pot, carefully sweat the onions in the oil. Stir from time to time, and remove the lid when they are nearly ready, to cook off any excess moisture - they should be pulpy and slightly sweet. When the onions are done, season and set aside. Hold the peppers over an open flame (use a skewer), char them all over, then put in a plastic bag to cool. Peel off the skins (they will come off easily), deseed and cut into strips.

Preheat the oven to 225C/425F/ gas mark 7. Lightly oil a Swiss-roll-sized baking tray, take half the enriched dough and shape into a rectangle. Roll out to fit the tray and no more than cm thick, and lay it on the baking tray.

Spread with a thick layer of onion, leaving a 1cm border all around. Lay the pepper on top in a diagonal grid, and put an olive in each 'square' (classic pissaladière uses anchovies.) Place on a preheated baking sheet, and cook for 15-20 minutes, until the base is crisp.

Spring vegetable and pesto pizza

For the simple dough. Serves four. For the pesto

1 big bunch fresh basil, picked

Five sprigs fresh mint, picked

2 cloves garlic, peeled and crushed

Olive oil

125g fresh Parmesan, grated

For the topping

1 bunch fresh asparagus, trimmed

1 handful fresh peas, podded

1 handful fresh broad beans, podded

1 tbsp pecorino, coarsely grated

Preheat the oven to 200C/400F/gas mark 6. Make the pesto: blitz the garlic with seasoning and olive oil, add the herbs, whizz again, add Parmesan and season to taste. Blanch the veg until al dente, and slip off the bean skins.

Take half the basic dough, split into four pieces and roll into rounds. Spread a layer of pesto on top of each, then over the vegetables. Sprinkle with pecorino, and season, remembering that the cheese is already pretty salty. Slide on to a preheated tray and bake until crisp, about 15-20 minutes.

Roast aubergine, courgette and garlic pizza

Also for the rich dough. Serves four.

1 whole head of garlic, unpeeled

Salt and fresh-milled black pepper

1 sprig fresh thyme

Olive oil

3 courgettes, sliced on a diagonal

2 aubergines, cut into cm rings

1 bunch fresh basil

Preheat the oven to 150C/300F/gas mark 2. Toss the head of garlic in a little olive oil, salt and pepper, pop in a pan with the thyme and a large tablespoon of water, cover and roast for 40 minutes, until completely soft. Toss the courgettes and aubergines in oil, seasoning and torn basil, place in a single layer on an oven tray and bake for 10 minutes.

Turn up the oven to 225C/425F/ gas mark 7. Take half the dough, split it into four and roll into rounds. Squeeze the softened garlic cloves out of their papery coats and spread over the bases. Sprinkle with basil, cover with alternate pieces of courgette and aubergine, season, drizzle with oil and place on a preheated baking tray. Bake until crisp, around 15-20 minutes.

Leek, mushroom and new potato pizza

Use either dough for this. Serves four.

2 cloves garlic, peeled and crushed

1 bunch parsley, picked and chopped

55g butter, softened

Olive oil

450g leeks, washed and cut thin

450g mushrooms (wild, cultivated or mixed)

200g new potatoes, boiled

200g goats' cheese

Thyme

Preheat the oven to 225C/425F/gas mark 7. First, mix the garlic, parsley and butter together, and set aside.

Heat a little oil in a pan and sauté the leeks until al dente. Clean the mushrooms with a damp cloth, slice and sauté in a little oil. Towards the end of the frying, add a knob of garlic and parsley butter, and season. Cut the potatoes into slices as thick as a £1 coin.

Take half the dough, split into four and roll into rounds. Place leeks on top of each base, dot with garlic and parsley butter, and sprinkle with thyme. Scatter over the potato and mushrooms, then crumble the cheese over the top. Slide on to a preheated baking sheet and bake for 15-20 minutes, until the base is crisp.

Butternut squash, mozzeralla and romesco calzone

For the rich dough. This Catalan sauce is usually served with grilled fish or veg, but is ideal pizza material. The quantities for the sauce will make more than you need, so you can try it the traditional way, too. Serves two. For the romesco sauce

25g almonds

25g hazelnuts

90ml olive oil

1 chunk of stale white bread, crusts removed and cut into cubes

2 cloves garlic, crushed

200g tinned tomatoes, chopped

1 fresh red chilli, finely chopped

1 pinch cayenne

Sea salt and black pepper

1 tsp sugar

2 tsp vinegar

4 tbsp fino or manzanilla sherry

Preheat the oven to 150C/300F/gas mark 2. Roast the nuts until lightly browned, then set aside to cool. Heat three tablespoons of oil in a pan, and sauté the garlic and bread until golden. Remove from the pan, add two tablespoons of oil (the bread will have soaked up the first lot) and fry off the tomatoes, chilli, cayenne, salt, pepper and sugar.

Turn up the oven to 225C/435F/ gas mark 7. Grind the nuts in a blender or pestle, add the bread and garlic, then gradually pour in the vinegar and sherry. Add this mixture to the tomato sauce when most of the tomato juice liquid has reduced. Reduce the liquid in the pan a little more and season.

For the calzone

8 tbsp romesco sauce

250g butternut squash, peeled and cut into 1cm thick pieces

1 mozzarella (preferably buffalo)

Olive oil

Preheat the oven to 200C/400F/gas mark 6. Sprinkle some olive oil and seasoning over the squash, and pop it into the oven while it is heating up, which will make it less firm to the bite. Break the cheese into chunks.

Roll out a third of the enriched dough into two rounds, and spread romesco sauce over one half of each, leaving a 2cm border at the edge.

Top with a generous layer of squash followed by an ample one of mozzarella. Cover with more sauce, and finish with a final layer of squash. Fold over as above, and bake until golden and crisp.

Broccoli, spinach and blue cheese calzone

Serves four.

450g broccoli, trimmed

450g spinach, washed

225g roquefort or other blue cheese

Olive oil

2 tbsp raisins

2 tbsp pinenuts

Preheat the oven to 150C/300F/gas mark 2. Toast the pinenuts. Turn up the oven to 200C/400F/gas mark 6. Blanch the broccoli (stalks as well as florets) in boiling, salted water until al dente. Heat some oil in a pan, wilt the spinach for no more than two minutes, then squeeze between two plates to remove any excess moisture.

Roll out half the dough into four largish circles. Leaving an edge of 2cm or so, layer half of each round with first spinach, then cheese, then broccoli, scattering the raisins and pinenuts as you go. Fold over the other half of the dough circle, thereby forming a half-moon shape, and press down the edges. Place on a preheated baking tray and bake until the dough is crisp and lightly golden, 15 minutes or so

 Do you have a culinary dilemma? Flummoxed by fish, say, or just fed up with eating the same old stuff week in week out? If you would like the Kitchen Doctor's expert treatment, write with details of your problem, along with a brief description of your domestic set-up, to Kitchen Doctor, Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Email: weekend@theguardian.com

So, when Rosie Sykes, Kitchen Doctor, descended on the Dyers' Cambridge home, Peter did what young boys do best: he turned on the telly and pretended she wasn't there. Angela, 16-year-old Nan and lodger, Simeon, however, were tickled pink to see the KD crew. "When I make pizza, there are a couple of disaster areas," Angela had pleaded. "The dough is all sticky, and the more I knead the stickier it gets. As for toppings, I lack ideas." Being vegetarians, there was to be none of that prosciutto or salami, thank you. Just good, honest veg and cheese. No sooner had Rosie arrived, therefore, than she was off out the door again, to the health-food store, deli and grocers on nearby Mill Road. Once back at the Dyer homestead, she ordered this chopped and that sliced before commencing her dough masterclass. "I'm going to show you two doughs," she said, "a basic one, and a rich one, for calzone." Angela's expression suddenly switched from that of keen apprentice to terrified examinee, her fear becoming even more pronounced when Rosie began tipping out flour and yeast with reckless abandonment. "Don't worry," said Rosie disarmingly, "the measurements are all in the recipes. They're only an approximate guide, anyway. You only know a dough is right when it feels right. See, get your hands into this." Angela prodded the unfamiliar matter gingerly, then, realising that it wasn't going to bite, got well stuck in. "It's lovely," she said. "Not at all like my efforts. It's so . . . smooth." Time to leave the yeast to do its thing, exclaimed Rosie, and to get to grips with the vegetables. Midway through the ensuing maelstrom of frying, boiling and roasting, Dad David arrived home for his lunch. He didn't seem to notice the massed ranks in his usually peaceful kitchen, but that was because he was transfixed by the sight of Rosie holding a red pepper over an angry-looking gas flame. "Is there an official term for that?" he asked tentatively. "Erm, charring?" said Rosie, not altogether convincingly. Fortunately, David didn't press her on the matter, for his interest had switched to the myriad bowls of cooked and raw ingredients adorning the table. "Am I allowed to nibble this?" he asked, eying the courgettes, then shovelled a handful into his mouth before anyone could respond. Roused from his viewing by the sound of lips smacking, Peter piped up, "Is it ready?" Rosie's eyes gleamed - so he had been paying attention, after all. Then she smiled knowingly: "Would you like to help me get the first pizza ready?" she asked. "Let's do a spring vegetable one." She had the poor boy hooked. Peter watched Rosie's every move as she rolled out a hunk of dough into a vague round ("I don't believe in perfect circles at home," she said. "It's a place to be natural"), and then, following her instructions with an attentiveness that would have made his teachers weep with envy, he laid the pesto and veg on top. "What next?" he gasped. "It's Nan's turn," said Angela. "Then Mum's," said Nan, the Dyers being a democratic household. "Can I make one, too?" said Peter. Soon, Nan was up to her elbows in aubergine, courgette and garlic, while Angela filled the calzones as if she'd been doing it all her life. No sooner had one pizza been sent to the oven than it was time to start on the next, but no one minded, least of all Peter. An hour later, they'd made - and eaten - each of Rosie's creations twice over, yet there was still plenty of dough and toppings left over. "Tell you what," said Rosie, "why don't Peter and Nan devise their own?" Talk about red rag to a bull. While Nan placed a pinch of this and a teaspoon of that on her base, Peter piled a glistening mound of sweated onion on a slab of dough, topped it with a great smear of pesto, then chucked on hummocks of potato, mozzarella and mushroom, before capping the lot with a storm of Parmesan. "We've gone a bit excessive here," said Rosie as he presented his creation. Ten minutes later, a leaning tower of pizza emerged from the oven, but no one made a move towards it: two doughs, six toppings and 12 pizzas later, they could eat no more. All except Peter, that is. "That means I get a big bit," he said. "And Mum, can we have pizza for dinner?" To get your pizza going at once, give it plenty of bottom heat: preheat a baking tray and place the prepared pizza on top. Plain pizza dough Makes six to eight pizzas. 20g fresh yeast 500g strong white four 15g salt 2 tbsp olive oil Around 350ml warm water Sift the dry ingredients into a large, warm bowl, and mix with your hands, distributing the yeast evenly. Add the oil, then slowly add water - it may or may not take all the water. You want a workable yet still-moist dough - if it's too moist, add a little more flour. Turn the dough on to a floured surface and knead for 10 minutes, until smooth and elastic. Place in an oiled bowl, cover with oiled clingfilm and leave in a warm place to prove and double in size. Knock it back a little with your fist, and it's ready for use. Enriched dough Makes six to eight pizzas. 15g fresh yeast 2 tsp sugar 35ml warm milk 500g strong white flour 60g softened butter 2 eggs 1 tsp salt 35ml warm water Mix the yeast with the sugar until it dissolves, then add to the warm milk. Sift flour into a warm bowl. Make a well in the centre and add the butter, eggs, salt, water and yeast mixture. Bring together and knead to a smooth dough. Place in a clean bowl, cover with oiled clingfilm, and put in a warm place to prove and double in size (allow up to two hours). Knock back, and you're ready to go. Pissaladière Not really a pizza, I know, but this classic French tart topping is ideal with the rich dough. Serves three to four. 450g white onions, finely sliced 200g red onions, finely sliced 3 tbsp olive oil 2 large red peppers 1 handful pitted black olives In a covered pot, carefully sweat the onions in the oil. Stir from time to time, and remove the lid when they are nearly ready, to cook off any excess moisture - they should be pulpy and slightly sweet. When the onions are done, season and set aside. Hold the peppers over an open flame (use a skewer), char them all over, then put in a plastic bag to cool. Peel off the skins (they will come off easily), deseed and cut into strips. Preheat the oven to 225C/425F/ gas mark 7. Lightly oil a Swiss-roll-sized baking tray, take half the enriched dough and shape into a rectangle. Roll out to fit the tray and no more than cm thick, and lay it on the baking tray. Spread with a thick layer of onion, leaving a 1cm border all around. Lay the pepper on top in a diagonal grid, and put an olive in each 'square' (classic pissaladière uses anchovies.) Place on a preheated baking sheet, and cook for 15-20 minutes, until the base is crisp. Spring vegetable and pesto pizza For the simple dough. Serves four. For the pesto 1 big bunch fresh basil, picked Five sprigs fresh mint, picked 2 cloves garlic, peeled and crushed Olive oil 125g fresh Parmesan, grated For the topping 1 bunch fresh asparagus, trimmed 1 handful fresh peas, podded 1 handful fresh broad beans, podded 1 tbsp pecorino, coarsely grated Preheat the oven to 200C/400F/gas mark 6. Make the pesto: blitz the garlic with seasoning and olive oil, add the herbs, whizz again, add Parmesan and season to taste. Blanch the veg until al dente, and slip off the bean skins. Take half the basic dough, split into four pieces and roll into rounds. Spread a layer of pesto on top of each, then over the vegetables. Sprinkle with pecorino, and season, remembering that the cheese is already pretty salty. Slide on to a preheated tray and bake until crisp, about 15-20 minutes. Roast aubergine, courgette and garlic pizza Also for the rich dough. Serves four. 1 whole head of garlic, unpeeled Salt and fresh-milled black pepper 1 sprig fresh thyme Olive oil 3 courgettes, sliced on a diagonal 2 aubergines, cut into cm rings 1 bunch fresh basil Preheat the oven to 150C/300F/gas mark 2. Toss the head of garlic in a little olive oil, salt and pepper, pop in a pan with the thyme and a large tablespoon of water, cover and roast for 40 minutes, until completely soft. Toss the courgettes and aubergines in oil, seasoning and torn basil, place in a single layer on an oven tray and bake for 10 minutes. Turn up the oven to 225C/425F/ gas mark 7. Take half the dough, split it into four and roll into rounds. Squeeze the softened garlic cloves out of their papery coats and spread over the bases. Sprinkle with basil, cover with alternate pieces of courgette and aubergine, season, drizzle with oil and place on a preheated baking tray. Bake until crisp, around 15-20 minutes. Leek, mushroom and new potato pizza Use either dough for this. Serves four. 2 cloves garlic, peeled and crushed 1 bunch parsley, picked and chopped 55g butter, softened Olive oil 450g leeks, washed and cut thin 450g mushrooms (wild, cultivated or mixed) 200g new potatoes, boiled 200g goats' cheese Thyme Preheat the oven to 225C/425F/gas mark 7. First, mix the garlic, parsley and butter together, and set aside. Heat a little oil in a pan and sauté the leeks until al dente. Clean the mushrooms with a damp cloth, slice and sauté in a little oil. Towards the end of the frying, add a knob of garlic and parsley butter, and season. Cut the potatoes into slices as thick as a £1 coin. Take half the dough, split into four and roll into rounds. Place leeks on top of each base, dot with garlic and parsley butter, and sprinkle with thyme. Scatter over the potato and mushrooms, then crumble the cheese over the top. Slide on to a preheated baking sheet and bake for 15-20 minutes, until the base is crisp. Butternut squash, mozzeralla and romesco calzone For the rich dough. This Catalan sauce is usually served with grilled fish or veg, but is ideal pizza material. The quantities for the sauce will make more than you need, so you can try it the traditional way, too. Serves two. For the romesco sauce 25g almonds 25g hazelnuts 90ml olive oil 1 chunk of stale white bread, crusts removed and cut into cubes 2 cloves garlic, crushed 200g tinned tomatoes, chopped 1 fresh red chilli, finely chopped 1 pinch cayenne Sea salt and black pepper 1 tsp sugar 2 tsp vinegar 4 tbsp fino or manzanilla sherry Preheat the oven to 150C/300F/gas mark 2. Roast the nuts until lightly browned, then set aside to cool. Heat three tablespoons of oil in a pan, and sauté the garlic and bread until golden. Remove from the pan, add two tablespoons of oil (the bread will have soaked up the first lot) and fry off the tomatoes, chilli, cayenne, salt, pepper and sugar. Turn up the oven to 225C/435F/ gas mark 7. Grind the nuts in a blender or pestle, add the bread and garlic, then gradually pour in the vinegar and sherry. Add this mixture to the tomato sauce when most of the tomato juice liquid has reduced. Reduce the liquid in the pan a little more and season. For the calzone 8 tbsp romesco sauce 250g butternut squash, peeled and cut into 1cm thick pieces 1 mozzarella (preferably buffalo) Olive oil Preheat the oven to 200C/400F/gas mark 6. Sprinkle some olive oil and seasoning over the squash, and pop it into the oven while it is heating up, which will make it less firm to the bite. Break the cheese into chunks. Roll out a third of the enriched dough into two rounds, and spread romesco sauce over one half of each, leaving a 2cm border at the edge. Top with a generous layer of squash followed by an ample one of mozzarella. Cover with more sauce, and finish with a final layer of squash. Fold over as above, and bake until golden and crisp. Broccoli, spinach and blue cheese calzone Serves four. 450g broccoli, trimmed 450g spinach, washed 225g roquefort or other blue cheese Olive oil 2 tbsp raisins 2 tbsp pinenuts Preheat the oven to 150C/300F/gas mark 2. Toast the pinenuts. Turn up the oven to 200C/400F/gas mark 6. Blanch the broccoli (stalks as well as florets) in boiling, salted water until al dente. Heat some oil in a pan, wilt the spinach for no more than two minutes, then squeeze between two plates to remove any excess moisture. Roll out half the dough into four largish circles. Leaving an edge of 2cm or so, layer half of each round with first spinach, then cheese, then broccoli, scattering the raisins and pinenuts as you go. Fold over the other half of the dough circle, thereby forming a half-moon shape, and press down the edges. Place on a preheated baking tray and bake until the dough is crisp and lightly golden, 15 minutes or so  Do you have a culinary dilemma? Flummoxed by fish, say, or just fed up with eating the same old stuff week in week out? If you would like the Kitchen Doctor's expert treatment, write with details of your problem, along with a brief description of your domestic set-up, to Kitchen Doctor, Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. fields.headline: A swift pint
fields.standfirst: Yella Belly Bitter
fields.trailText: Yella Belly Bitter
fields.body:
Batemans, a family-owned brewery in Wainfleet, Lincolnshire, has joined the swelling ranks of organic beers with Yella Belly Bitter, 4.2% on draught and in bottle, and brewed with organic Chariot pale malt, from Simpsons of Yorkshire, and Hallertau hops from New Zealand. I had my first taste of Yella Belly at a party to celebrate George Bateman's 50 years in brewing, and found it wonderfully refreshing, with juicy malt balanced by aromatic hops and citrus fruit. But even as I drank, the beer was changing. Batemans has responded to those who sampled the first brew and said it was too bitter. Organic hops are higher in the alpha acids that give bitterness, and head brewer Martin Cullimore has now reduced the amount of Hallertau.

The bottled version (£1.55, 50ml) will be in selected supermarkets, the draught in Bateman's pubs (01754 880317) and Wetherspoon's.

NB Wychwood's Corn Circle, featured in my last piece, has changed its name to Corn Dolly to avoid confusion with Hop Back's Crop Circle.

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Top seed: sesame
fields.trailText: Top seed: sesame
fields.body:
The subject
Sesamum indicum . As in 'Open, sesame!' Adornment of dishes both sweet and savoury. One of the cook's smallest but most head-turning helpers.

The basics
They really are seeds, and they have a tendency to split their pod suddenly - thus, perhaps, the origin of the 40 thieves' command. Origin: probably Iran. Modern sources: China, Middle East, India, etc. Chockablock with oil, which can go rancid if the seeds are kept too long. All the more reason to use them liberally when you have a supply on hand. Open, sesame jar!

The details
Sesame seeds can be white, brown and black; white's most common and versatile. To attain greatness, they need heat-treatment - namely, put them in a non-nonstick pan over a moderate flame. Heat until medium-deep brown and nuttily fragrant, stir constantly and watch like a hawk - they burn faster than you can say 'smoke alarm.' If not used immediately, they can be stored in a covered jar for 1-2 weeks. Formula 1 vehicles for a drive down sesame street: Asian noodles, green veg, stir-fries, chicken. Ultimate sesame-friendly zones: Japan, China, bakeries. Seedless alternative number, and wonderful: Chinese sesame oil from roasted seeds. Colour: pale through deep brown. Uses: innumerable.; Flavour: indescribable. Seedless alternative, and less wonderful: sesame paste (tahini). Cement-like consistency, and useful mostly in hummus.

Where to buy
In shops catering for so-called ethnic groups: Indian, Chinese, Middle Eastern. In a supermarket, a jar will cost around £1 for 30g or so; a bag from a small shop may work out at less than half that price. Ditto for sesame oil, but buy the most expensive bottle on offer, wherever you're shopping.

The easy way out
Sesame oil (in moderation) makes any dish taste better.

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum:  Radio daze
fields.standfirst: 'Harriet is horrified by the sight of my socks with the word Umbro on them'
fields.trailText: 'Harriet is horrified by the sight of my socks with the word Umbro on them'
fields.body:
Invited to participate in Book Quiz on radio. Can only assume someone must have died at short notice. "But you haven't read a book for 20 years!" frowns Ex-Spouse. Protest that I have read Bill Bryson. But then, even people who can't read have read Bill Bryson. Friendly producer assures me that it will be fine and, in tone of voice suggesting that everybody knows those like the back of their hand, that the special subjects this week are Dickens and TS Eliot.

Glance affectionately at the back of my hand, and am alarmed to discover raised red patch where none existed before. Rush to computer and ransack cancer websites. A particularly helpful hospital in Illinois encourages me to suspect it is either a basal thingie or a squamous thingie. Recoil in horror at electronic images of appalling skin conditions. Halfway through a ghastly outbreak of pustules on an Australian thigh, Harriet comes in and announces, "Mum, I'm not, like, a Christian any more. But I believe in reincarnation, okay?"

Inform her that religious freedom will always be respected in this house, while trying to rid screen of skin-cancer imagery, and replace with something mild and inoffensive. The Society for the Protection of Spam, perhaps. The trouble is, once you've had your cancerphobia, you can't delete it. Possibly same may be said of cancer itself. It lurks in the delete box of your body, but a skilful T-cell, or whatever, could probably conjure it up again in no time by hacking into your slipped disks.

Great Aunt approaches, looking glum, and confides she thinks she may be in the early stages of dementia, as she can't remember the name of that nice man who used to lead the Liberal Party before the one who left under a cloud. Assure her that I can't, either. However, inform Ex-Spouse that I've just remembered another book I've read, though I can't remember the actual title, yet. I remember the author's name, though: Annie Proulx. Her life must be a silent "L".

Distracted by secret, almost libidinous, urge to view more hospital websites when I should be trying to refresh my memory of TS Eliot and What'shisname Dickens.

"You must wash your hair and get some longer trousers before you go on the radio, Mum!" scolds Harriet, horrified by the appearance of my socks with the word Umbro written on them. Umbria would have been more pleasant, certainly.

Rush out and buy baggy trousers and wash hair almost on way to station. On train, have sound business idea: hairdressing salons, shoe-repair booths, bookshops, etc, should be provided on trains - nay, perhaps cyber-cafes, too, where one could scrutinise the tumours of those lucky enough to be ill in Illinois. Should have been thinking about TS Eliot, but must know it backwards, surely.

Arrive at recording venue and am introduced to my fellow-panellists, all professional literary journalists of youthful ferocity, wit and badinage. We are wheeled in and the questions start to fly. I am invited to recollect the opening sentence of Great Expectations. Mind goes worse than blank - blunk. Cannot distinguish between Great Expectations and David Copperfield. Something to do with a little boy who runs away to found a circus. At the height of the humiliation - or, perhaps, at its depth - my memory banks inform me that Jo Grimond used to be the leader of the Liberal Party, and how like a liberal it was for him to have the feminine form of the Jo.

When it comes to TS Eliot, I am distracted by another complete non sequitur: an inability to distinguish between Germaine Greer and Jan Morris. All I know is I would like to see them playing badminton before I die.

Glance furtively at the back of my hand - where, if I had any sense, I would have written a crib about publication dates of Dickens's novels - and observe that the sinister spot has started to grow a crust. Assume this is the beginning of the end, but am comforted by the thought that, owing to the epic quality of my ignorant silence, were I to die quietly during the second half of the quiz, none of the listeners would even notice.

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Gloria Gaynor
fields.trailText: Gloria Gaynor
fields.body:
Gloria Gaynor was born Gloria Fowles in 1949, in Newark, US. Her father was a singer, her mother a seamstress. Gaynor quit her job in a department store after a neighbour heard her sing and asked her to perform at his nightclub. In 1979, she had a massive hit with I Will Survive. Her new single, Last Night, is released on Monday.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Being in love with someone who is in love with you, in a union blessed by God, coupled with peace, good health and physical comfort.

What is your greatest fear?
Fear itself.

With which historical figure do you most identify?
Christ, because my greatest desire in life is to please and glorify God.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
Being critical of myself and others.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?
Deceit.

What is your greatest extravagance?
My car (a Jaguar).

Should the Royal Family be scrapped?
No, they bring a sense of civility and order to an otherwise chaotic land.

What objects do you always carry with you?
Bible, make-up, pen, credit cards.

What makes you depressed?
Man's inhumanity to man.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?
My weight.

What is your favourite fantasy?
Where I am built like Vanity and my husband is built like Muhammad Ali, and we are turning heads as we walk down the beach.

Do you believe in monogamy?
Absolutely.

Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it?
Yes.

What is your greatest regret?
That I never got a chance to share my financial success with my mother.

When and where were you happiest?
On the day that I was crowned 'Queen of Disco'.

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?
Structure.

What would your motto be?
Practise what you preach.

Do you believe in life after death?
Yes, I believe I'll go to heaven.

How would you like to be remembered?
As a person who tried to please God and was truthful, compassionate and generous to others.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
That God's opinion is the only one that matters.

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: Prince Michael of Kent and www.adhesives.com
fields.body:
Mum sent me the GM smoked salmon she'd ordered for treacherous Mike. It was delicious, and I was amazed to discover the following morning that my hair had grown back a bit. Goodbye to my wig!

Not a minute too soon: that evening I was going out with Ricky, and I didn't want to lose my head in that particular way. I had checked www.adhesives.com: my options to secure the wretched wig firmly in place ranged from Superglue (too brutal on my budding follicles) to milder products such as Blu-Tac, which would not stand the ardour of a lusty Brit male brought up on hormone-enriched BSE beef.

You must be dying to know what happened, to ask me the kind of questions Ali G puts to his female guests; all I'll say is: 'Fabulous.' I'm level-headed enough to take things one step at the time, but only fools live just for the present; I visited www.weddingguide.co.uk as a precaution, and asked them to email me its Mensa compatibility test.

The apotheosis of Ken Livingstone has made me wonder whether Tony's reign could be nothing more than a mirage, an Indian summer for affluent-yet-compassionate consumers such as myself. As we all do in uncertain times, I longed for guidance from our tribal elders, so I visited www.princemichael.org.uk, the site of HRH Prince Michael of Kent. I was delighted to find that the Kents are not bankrupt and that his consultancy business is thriving. The Prince says he is prepared to answer a few email questions from us every month - probably not if they are in Ali G mode, but give it a try. His views on Ken, perhaps?

fields.headline: Match of the day
fields.standfirst: Never think of plants in isolation, says Christopher Lloyd. Experiment with different colour combinations - and learn by trial and error
fields.trailText: Never think of plants in isolation, says Christopher Lloyd. Experiment with different colour combinations - and learn by trial and error
fields.body:
There are all sorts of little dodges for gaining the best effect from the plants we grow. About now, we are sowing wallflowers for next spring's display. They join the brassicas in their seed bed outside and are subsequently lined out, some 25cm apart, to make fat plants. Don't grow mixtures; they include too many colours and, visually, cancel each other out. Choose which colours you want to juxtapose (two or three will probably be enough in any one year), grow them separately, then combine them when bedding out in autumn.

If the colours are of comparable strength, such as orange and lemon yellow, I usually make adjacent, informal patches side by side. But if one colour is dark, and the other bright and light, I make single-plant splashes of the bright colour (it might be 'Cloth Of Gold') in a matrix of the dark, which might be purple or brown. That would entail three plants of the dark colour to one of the bright.

Here at Great Dixter, I like tulips with my wallflowers, but in separate patches, among or behind them. This is because wallflowers are basically scrawny plants, easily blown sideways in the wind. If massed, they hold one another up and become a single, undulating carpet.

Another scrawny plant, which I yet like to grow, is the summer-flowering annual, Helenium amarum (30cm). It has masses of small yellow daisies over a long period, supported by very bright, light-green, linear leaves. That loses its scrawniness if massed. It combines well with the substantial bronze red Gaillardia 'Red Plume' - one plant of that to two of the helenium, in adjacent blocks. I should warn that you don't get much seed of the gaillardia in a packet, so two packets of that to one of the helenium.

Ladybird poppies, Papaver commutatum, have great appeal, with their crimson flowers, each petal with a large black basal blotch. Never think of plants in isolation; always think of how to combine them effectively with something else In this case, you might use the annual or biennial (according to when you sow it) Cynoglossum amabile, in one of its pure blue- flowered strains. But in a mixed planting I should have two plants of the cynoglossum to one of the poppy (both are roughly 0.5m high), as the poppy's flower is much the larger and makes the stronger impact.

On the other hand, you might combine it with Omphalodes linifolia, which is a little shorter and has small, dead-white flowers above grey leaves. White stares, so in this case I should bed with the same number of each component, mixing them evenly. We raise both poppy and omphalodes in modules, then pots, so as to be sure of strong plants for bedding out. Experiments of this kind are fascinating and can be changed annually, which is a way of prolonging your own life in terms of experience.

A piece of bedding out that I admired in the Logan Botanic Gardens at the south-west tip of Scotland, and have since imitated, was a mixture of the tender perennial, grey-leaved Helichrysum petiolare with the bright yellow, coreopsis-like Bidens ferulifolia - this is also tender, so now is just the time to get such a scheme planted.

Both plants have a sprawling, widely spreading habit and the units can be planted almost 1m apart; they will soon be interlocking. As the bidens is such a bright yellow, you need far less of it than of the helichrysum. One plant to three would be enough. This is an easy and effective way to cover a wide area of ground. It will not give you any height to speak of, however, so you may need to think of a taller background: blue agapanthus, perhaps.

I love red "geraniums", not in mindless, solid blocks, but in touches to liven the scene. So, perched above my sunk garden, I have four large terracotta pots planted up about now for the summer, the ingredients varying but always including a Helichrysum petiolare (again) and a red or orange "geranium". One loses the names (meaning that I have lost the name), but we keep it going from autumn-struck cuttings over-wintered under glass.

A combination that we found most satisfying, but which needs planning (sowing seed now to flower, as biennials, in a year's time), was of Canterbury bells ( Campanula medium - a single-flowered strain) with the scarlet Lychnis x haageana. The latter is half the height of the campanula but of a very strong personality, so that roughly equal numbers of each worked out right, planting the Canterburys first, rather widely spaced, and then interplanting the lychnis.

You can still buy Canterburys in separate colours - pink, white, mauve (called blue) or purple, but in practice we used a mixture of the four and it worked admirably. All this, I have to say, was totally unorthodox, so we (Fergus and I) were overjoyed by the result.

This year, we have combined the lychnis with Campanula primulifolia, which is campanula blue. I have not grown it before. Flowering will be in June. Come and see what you think

 Christopher Lloyd's Garden Flowers is published by Cassell & Co, priced £30. To order a copy for £25 (plus 99p UK p&p) phone Guardian CultureShop on 0800 3166102. Great Dixter, tel 01797 252878.

webTitle: How to be an airline pilot

fields.headline: How to be an airline pilot
fields.trailText: Airline pilots are modern-day Moseses, in that they're the ones most likely to lead us to the promised land (and bring us back after two weeks when the promises in the brochure are wearing a bit thin).
fields.body:
Airline pilots are modern-day Moseses, in that they're the ones most likely to lead us to the promised land (and bring us back after two weeks when the promises in the brochure are wearing a bit thin). To be a pilot, you need to have a voice like the sound of a Bentley on gravel, so that even when you're asking people to remain seated the clear subtext is that you've got a big throttle and you know how to handle it. Women pilots should give the impression that the plane is nothing but an overgrown schoolboy who will get a good spanking if it doesn't get its flaps down.

Many pilots do their initial training in the RAF. This is very similar to being a commercial pilot, except for the fact that, with an airline, the people who are getting bombed are in the seats behind the pilot, and that you can't do a victory roll after a successful mission. Airline pilots need to have a certain lack of imagination, so that when you're landing in thick fog using instruments only, you can forget the fact that all the onboard systems were built by the lowest-cost supplier. Similarly, in the many hours of long-haul tedium, you must have the strength of character to be polite to the millionth visitor in the cockpit who asks what that switch is for, who accidentally turns off the autopilot with their bottom and then attempts to steal the black box as a souvenir. An artistic side is also a great help for pilots, so you can enjoy the pretty holding patterns you'll be creating on every flight into Heathrow airport.

Flying is really a very small part of the job; far more important is how you walk through the terminal building - you must do this at the head of a gaggle of cabin crew with your first officer walking slightly behind you. Make sure you have more gold braid on your arm than Engelbert Humperdink, albeit arranged slightly more tastefully. Never, ever acknowledge a passenger in the terminal building. Instead, keep your gaze fixed somewhere on the far horizon, as if constantly alert for dangerously convergent mountains/Lufthansa flights.

Above all, you must give no sign that you actually enjoy flying and that your overwhelming preoccupation is passenger safety. At the end of a long flight, no one likes to hear the captain announcing that we've started our descent but before we touch down we're going to buzz the tower. Remember, in civil aviation there are no prizes for cutting up a Cathay Pacific jumbo just before touchdown, however much fun that might be in pure flying terms.
