fields.headline: Finding fact from fiction
fields.standfirst: In returning to novel-writing, Susan Sontag has been able to escape from what she calls the 'insufferable moralism' of her essays and lectures. She has also discovered a new desire for the truth about herself that would finally free her from the burden of being labelled America's most intelligent woman
fields.trailText: In returning to novel-writing, Susan Sontag has been able to escape from what she calls the 'insufferable moralism' of her essays and lectures. She has also discovered a new desire for the truth about herself that would finally free her from the burden of being labelled America's most intelligent woman
fields.body:
It seems peculiar, looking back now, to recall that my first impression of Susan Sontag was distinctly antipathetic, even hostile. Now I have come to think of her as one of the warmest, funniest, most generous and silliest people I have ever met - silly in the sense of playful, spontaneous, alive. But that first day in Prague, at the literary festival, listening to her talk - effusively and not always interestingly; watching her interact with the other writers - bossily, even selfishly hogging the limelight; observing her deal with the audience - peremptory at times to the point of insult.

One young man's question, convoluted but nonetheless heartfelt, dismissed as "making no sense". A young Czech woman, whose request for an autograph for her album was greeted with, "I don't do that. I only sign books." Sontag herself, remonstrating about being introduced on the platform as an intellectual, as in "one of America's leading intellectuals" - using the mantle of authority her fame has given her to repudiate that authority - though you'd think after almost 40 years she must be used to it by now.

Indeed, the most quoted line about Sontag is Jonathan Miller's "probably the most intelligent woman in America". Anyway, the immediate impression was of someone haughty, humourless, disregarding of others' feelings and self-regarding to the verge of narcissism. Wrong. Though on the narcissism front there may be something small to answer.

Every time you meet someone, you have to ask yourself, Is it the person I am meeting or the part that they are playing? With Sontag, I think I met both. The role, "the intellectual" is extant - there in the essays: Against Interpretation, Styles Of Radical Will, On Photography. In her monographs - on, among others, Godard, Barthes, Simone Weil - leading intellectual and cultural figures of the 20th century. "Concealing myself behind my admiration," she says now, though borrowing a voice might be closer.

But since Sontag herself now repudiates the part - "I think I had some moralistic idea about enlightenment and elevating people. Where there was darkness then there was light, that kind of thing. Or maybe it was the only thing I knew how to do," - I am not going to deal with it overmuch. She has changed, she says: "Change is my speciality." Though you could equally say that what she has done is to go back, to find the person she would have been, before life, experience intervened.

Hannah Arendt, the German Jewish political theorist and philosopher, and herself a writer of some wonderful monographs - on friends such as the poet Randall Jarrell, on writers she admired such as Isak Dinesen - used to refer to what she called "the specifically human quality of greatness", which she defined in this way: "True greatness, even in works of art . . . appears only where we sense behind... a being that remains greater and more mysterious because the work itself points to a person whose essence can be neither exhausted nor fully revealed by whatever he may have the power to do." This desire to "sense behind", to delight in the greatness of a person, to accept that you can't know it all, to refuse to view the person as the work, Arendt sometimes summed up in the word "friendship".

It's not an easy quality to come by, this friendship, it requires a certain openness of character, an intrepidity of spirit. You read Sontag's early work, and it lies flat and lifeless on the page. Insightful, analytically intelligent it may be. But there is no friendship in it. She knows it, and it makes her sad, or anyway rueful. "What did I think I was doing?" But the past 10 years she has begun writing fiction, or rather returned to fiction - her first book, The Benefactor, was a novel. In this 10 years, she has written two books: The Volcano Lover, published in 1992, based on the triangular relationship between Emma Hamilton, her husband William Hamilton and her lover, Lord Nelson, which became a worldwide best seller; and her latest novel, In America, again based on a true story, that of the actress Maryna Zalewska who, in 1876, emigrated from Poland to California to set up a commune and later wowed America as a performer.

Fiction has released her, Sontag says. "I am so much freer. I can write more expansively, more expressively. It's like the doors have been flung open and there's a view." She says she doesn't understand how it happened, it's a mystery, she just regrets that it didn't happen sooner. "I know you shouldn't regret things. But it's a bit like having only one child. I would have loved more and I regret that. I can't help it."

She talks now frankly and unguardedly, and she laughs, all the time, like someone who has just discovered laughter. When she gets excited, her voice rises and rises so that sentences end almost in song. It's very funny and engaging. She loves being teased, she's a great flirt and quite a flatterer. She is also surprising. We were talking at one point about transformation, about inventing a self. Listen, she said, "I have this to say about self-invention. If I use those words it's because I have had to produce a kind of language of what I do. I don't start with those words, I'd be crazy. If you want to know what it feels like to be me, it is someone mooching along trying to work out how to make a sentence that's not ugly."

And, if I hadn't liked her so much already, at what she said next I would have thrown myself at her feet. "If I hadn't allowed my insufferable moralism to kidnap me, if I'd stuck with fiction . . . " But she couldn't resist the attention. "The essays got so much attention." It's no wonder she mistrusts the media. Has a love-hate relationship with attention. The media gave her an image, as a sort of pr t-à-porter cultural guru, and she became fixed in it. But she was complicit with it, you say. Well, yes and no. She was young, as she says, naive. She didn't see until too late what was being made of her.

It's hard to think back to the early 60s, to that eager early feminism, how desperate we all were for a female face. Face being the operative word. Sontag was, and remains, at 67, a beauty. "Yes, I always knew it. I was pretty and smart, and that drew attention to me. But what I've always felt is that I didn't ask either for these prejudices or for those benefits."

And what happened, I suspect, is that as the gap between how she saw herself (intelligent, but nonetheless a moocher) and how she was seen ("a tastemaker, a producer of opinions") widened, she began to perceive herself as a fraud. Or anyway to feel fraudulent. And that's a huge weight to carry. The mystery, then, is not how she released herself, but that she was able to do it at all. What she is saying, of course, is that the non-fiction, the essays, were in fact a fiction. And the fiction, the novels, are real. But it takes immense courage to pull away the mask. To insist that you are seen in friendship, or not at all.

She sets her novels in the past, in history. "Because the past is a way of looking at the present, though I am moving slowly towards the 21st century. My next novel will be set in 30s Japan." Her instinct is probably right - to start from a distance and work gradually forward. She tells me that the first time she ever talked about her own past, her "personal life", was when she was being interviewed in 1992 for The Volcano Lover. Prior to this, she'd always held tenaciously to TS Eliot's line that great writing is impersonal. "That biography is trivia." It was her lifeline.

"I remember that time saying that my mother had been an alcoholic." Her mother had died six years earlier, in 1986, from lung cancer. "And after, I rang my sister Judith and said, 'I've just thrown mother to the wolves.' And Judith said, 'Good.'" It's strange. So much rage, and yet in life she said nothing to her mother at all. Even on her death-bed, in hospital in Hawaii, where her mother lived, Sontag was unable to put out her hand to her. "She was the sort of woman who flinched if you touched her." Her mother's last words to her were, "Why don't you go back to the hotel?" To which Susan replied, "Oh, you know, mother, I love hospitals." And her mother smiled and closed her eyes. "She liked that, you see. She thought it witty and sarcastic. I couldn't say, 'I've come here because I love you. I've come because you are mortally ill.'"

Of course she couldn't. Not after a lifetime of not saying. Imagine the depth of sadness, of waste, that could reveal. "I adored her," Susan says, "but in that way you adore someone you can't have. I hardly saw her as a child. She was always away." And the father? Absent also. A wealthy furrier, living and working in China, in the British concession in Tiensin, he died from tuberculosis, in 1939, when Susan was five. The two children were brought up by nannies and servants in the big house on Long Island, where they lived. So she hardly knew him. "Though I cried for him every day of my childhood."

Her mother lied to her. Lied about his death, said he was coming home. Lied later about the cause of his death, said he died from pneumonia. "There was a stigma at that time surrounding TB." Lied even about where he was buried. "Said it was Brooklyn, when in fact it was Queens."

Just two years ago she employed a researcher to track down his grave and went to visit it. And suddenly there was his headstone: Jack Rosenblatt. "There's knowing and really knowing. I don't think I had believed he was dead until then."

Susan was 12 when she changed her name from Rosenblatt to Sontag. Her mother had remarried, "A foolish man, a war hero, a harmless, inept, fatuous guy." They skipped off to Mexico, got wed, and didn't tell the girls until their return. He never legally adopted them. So he was never their father. But he was there, a present figure of authority, substituting for an absent figure of authority, and, as you can see from her description of him, she despised him.

So what do you do as a bright young girl who, in her early teens, finds herself in the wrong place, and misunderstood. Because how could this fatuous, inept guy ever understand her? Or, indeed, her mother - the "cold, cruel woman" she describes. I think two things happen. You grow up early, too early. You bypass adolescence - though you'll probably have to make a detour back there later. And you find yourself a new authority. An authority that challenges the ineptitude of this poor substitute.

She found it in academia. She says herself that books became her refuge. That she'd spend her evenings in the library, away from home. Comforting herself with knowledge, learning things by rote - she has always had a prodigious memory, as well as a prodigious curiosity. Learning became her unassailable identity. Or so she thought. And the irony is that it could have worked. If she had been less clever, less curious, more easily satisfied.

Probably it did work for a while. She told me that she'd never understood why her sister rejected learning - never did well at school. "I always thought that I had made a really good choice. I couldn't see why Judith didn't make it, too. She was an under-achiever, bright but anti-ambitious." She couldn't see it because her own need was blocking her view. She became "an intellectual" - let's give it that name - out of insecurity, out of need. Judith, presumably, had other needs.

Why did she take her mother's husband's name? More to the point, why did she keep it? I asked her, and she said this: "I think I liked Sontag. It sounded less funny, less Jewish, than Rosenblatt. More American." And, in post-war America, anti-Semitism was again rife. Germany was being resurrected as an ally. "I was used, at school, to being called a dirty kike. I think I was relieved to change my name."

It's an answer but it may not be enough. She felt betrayed by her father, she says. "He didn't come back." Changing her name was not a reciprocal betrayal. It was something else. A constant reminder. As if keeping a name that wasn't real pointed always to the reality behind it. That whoever she may have been was obliterated. She was 16 when she left home. Why did she marry at 17? And a man, Philip Reiff, whom she scarcely knew. Reiff, 10 years older than she, was an academic at Chicago University, where she was studying. He met her one day, took her out for dinner, a cheeseburger, took her out the next day for breakfast, and then for lunch, another cheeseburger. And that evening he proposed. He told her that the moment he heard her voice he knew she was the woman he was going to marry.

"I'd never been called a woman before. I thought it was fantastic. I said yes. Isn't that crazy?" When she suggested they should sleep together, he said, we'll marry first. "I thought, 'He's even purer than I am.' We were married the next week."

Of course she left him. Nine years later, when their son David was seven. She left him, she says, to become another person. "I had longings. I didn't know what they were, but they weren't to be in the academic world." This must be right. She was bored. "I felt as if all the oxygen was going out of me." In her new book, In America, in the first chapter, Chapter Zero, written in the person of the narrator, she describes how, at 18, she read Middlemarch. ". . . And a third of the way through the book I burst into tears because I realised that not only was I Dorothea but that, a few months earlier, I had married Mr Casubon." Casubon being the representation of all that is dull and stale about academia.

She writes, also in this chapter, about her main character, the actress Maryna, ". . . she would never be seduced into forgetting herself". It's an interesting word here, seduction. Success, fame, applause, attention came to Sontag like a lover, and she couldn't resist it. I asked her if she had loved her husband. "Oh yes," she said, she loved him, it was a real marriage. And I asked her if he had loved her. "I can't say that," she replied. "I can't say that someone loved me. No. I just can't." As though being loved, allowing yourself to be beloved, becomes another form of forgetting.

So began her impersonation on the public stage. In private, of course, she'd been doing it since she was 12. Putting on what she calls "her essay voice". She kept herself at a distance from what she wrote, forgot herself, as she says. Loved the work, but didn't expect much back. "I think very early on I developed a way of dealing with painful information, which was to say, that's interesting. Instead of allowing myself to be hurt by it."

So she went through the world kind of inured by her interest in things. Things because it was not the person, it was always the work. And says she was surprised that the world seemed to confuse her with what she was writing about - all these male authority figures such as Barthes and Godard, et al. And also loved it. "You know, like the child who wants the attention and then is embarrassed by it." But didn't trust it. "Always felt the applause is simply that they've never seen anything better. So it was meaningless. They just didn't have the imagination to imagine anything else."

Small wonder she is fascinated by actors. Their psychology. "The debate about whether an actor feels what he or she is incarnating, the sincerity of the actor, is a real debate, don't you think? I've always been moved by the anxiety of actors." And: "I think it's a sign of professionalism to be afraid." It is also an instinct for survival to be afraid. Though first you have to identify the danger.

Both her recent novels, The Volcano Lover and In America, focus on strong, fearless women who strike poses. Emma Hamilton, whose husband used to display her in Greek "attitudes", like a living sculpture and who dies a penniless victim. And Maryna, the professional actress who doesn't die, who becomes a star, one of the dubious rewards that America can endow, and so traduces her talent. A different sort of death. I think we assume that in both cases the audience that matters is male. That both are women who function to please men and who, one way or the other, get lost. There's a line in The Volcano Lover: ". . . emotional women who don't have power, real power, usually end up being victims." How not to be a victim, of your success, viz Maryna, of your beauty, viz Emma. Of yourself and your own story, viz Sontag, has become Sontag's embracing subject.

There's no answer, or rather there's a whole panoply of answers - one of which may be to free yourself from the trap of others' expectations. Sacrifice your audience, or find a new, sympathetic audience. Maybe this becomes easier as you get older, I say, there's less above you to weigh down on you, the spectre of authority becomes lighter.

S hall I tell you about getting older, she says, and she is laughing. "When you get older, 45 plus, men stop fancying you. Or put it another way, the men I fancy don't fancy me. I want a young man. I love beauty. So what's new?" She says she has been in love seven times in her life, which seems quite a lot. "No, hang on," she says. "Actually, it's nine. Five women, four men."

She will talk about her bisexuality quite openly now. It's simple, she says. "As I've become less attractive to men, so I've found myself more with women. It's what happens. Ask any woman my age. More women come on to you than men. And women are fantastic. Around 40, women blossom. Women are a work-in-progress. Men burn out." She doesn't have a lover now, she lives alone. The rumours about her and the photographer Annie Leibovitz are, she says, without foundation. They are close friends.

Maybe it sounds foolish, she says. "Maybe everyone will think I have an aberrant life, or a low sex drive. Maybe I am consigning myself to the asexual here. But speaking candidly, and only for myself, there are so many things in my life now that are more important to me than my sexuality. My relationship with my son, David. My writing. Even my moral passions seem to me to be far more defining than my erotic life. People can conclude from this what they want."

She talks with this same clarity about cancer, from which she has suffered twice. Metastatic breast cancer in 1976. Uterine cancer in 1998. It was after she had breast cancer that she wrote her book, Illness As Metaphor. "To try to help dispel the stigma of that disease. To demystify illness. In the 70s, people still referred to it as the Big C. They were superstitious even about naming it." But, as she says, the origins of that book lay with her father's death. She doesn't think of illness as imparting knowledge, she says. She thinks of illness as illness, requiring treatment. In her case, with the breast cancer, a mastectomy followed by three years of chemotherapy. And with the uterine cancer, a total hysterectomy. And what the experience has left her with, she says, is a dual feeling. "That I may soon be dead. And simultaneously, an elation that I am not."

Her life, she says, has been a progress from austerity to something more expressive. "You know I used to want to be Simone Weil, die on an ant-hill, sacrifice myself." She used to throw herself at these ideals, she says. "I've always been a great faller-in-love. A great adorer. My abiding image of her will be of her running down the street, in pain, because the chemotherapy has left her with nerve damage to her legs so bad that some days she can hardly bear to walk. But oblivious. And laughing because it's funny and she is having fun. And shouting. "We are friends."

Friendship, as Arendt said. The desire to delight in other people. And also, inevitably, in oneself

fields.bodyText: It seems peculiar, looking back now, to recall that my first impression of Susan Sontag was distinctly antipathetic, even hostile. Now I have come to think of her as one of the warmest, funniest, most generous and silliest people I have ever met - silly in the sense of playful, spontaneous, alive. But that first day in Prague, at the literary festival, listening to her talk - effusively and not always interestingly; watching her interact with the other writers - bossily, even selfishly hogging the limelight; observing her deal with the audience - peremptory at times to the point of insult. One young man's question, convoluted but nonetheless heartfelt, dismissed as "making no sense". A young Czech woman, whose request for an autograph for her album was greeted with, "I don't do that. I only sign books." Sontag herself, remonstrating about being introduced on the platform as an intellectual, as in "one of America's leading intellectuals" - using the mantle of authority her fame has given her to repudiate that authority - though you'd think after almost 40 years she must be used to it by now. Indeed, the most quoted line about Sontag is Jonathan Miller's "probably the most intelligent woman in America". Anyway, the immediate impression was of someone haughty, humourless, disregarding of others' feelings and self-regarding to the verge of narcissism. Wrong. Though on the narcissism front there may be something small to answer. Every time you meet someone, you have to ask yourself, Is it the person I am meeting or the part that they are playing? With Sontag, I think I met both. The role, "the intellectual" is extant - there in the essays: Against Interpretation, Styles Of Radical Will, On Photography. In her monographs - on, among others, Godard, Barthes, Simone Weil - leading intellectual and cultural figures of the 20th century. "Concealing myself behind my admiration," she says now, though borrowing a voice might be closer. But since Sontag herself now repudiates the part - "I think I had some moralistic idea about enlightenment and elevating people. Where there was darkness then there was light, that kind of thing. Or maybe it was the only thing I knew how to do," - I am not going to deal with it overmuch. She has changed, she says: "Change is my speciality." Though you could equally say that what she has done is to go back, to find the person she would have been, before life, experience intervened. Hannah Arendt, the German Jewish political theorist and philosopher, and herself a writer of some wonderful monographs - on friends such as the poet Randall Jarrell, on writers she admired such as Isak Dinesen - used to refer to what she called "the specifically human quality of greatness", which she defined in this way: "True greatness, even in works of art . . . appears only where we sense behind... a being that remains greater and more mysterious because the work itself points to a person whose essence can be neither exhausted nor fully revealed by whatever he may have the power to do." This desire to "sense behind", to delight in the greatness of a person, to accept that you can't know it all, to refuse to view the person as the work, Arendt sometimes summed up in the word "friendship". It's not an easy quality to come by, this friendship, it requires a certain openness of character, an intrepidity of spirit. You read Sontag's early work, and it lies flat and lifeless on the page. Insightful, analytically intelligent it may be. But there is no friendship in it. She knows it, and it makes her sad, or anyway rueful. "What did I think I was doing?" But the past 10 years she has begun writing fiction, or rather returned to fiction - her first book, The Benefactor, was a novel. In this 10 years, she has written two books: The Volcano Lover, published in 1992, based on the triangular relationship between Emma Hamilton, her husband William Hamilton and her lover, Lord Nelson, which became a worldwide best seller; and her latest novel, In America, again based on a true story, that of the actress Maryna Zalewska who, in 1876, emigrated from Poland to California to set up a commune and later wowed America as a performer. Fiction has released her, Sontag says. "I am so much freer. I can write more expansively, more expressively. It's like the doors have been flung open and there's a view." She says she doesn't understand how it happened, it's a mystery, she just regrets that it didn't happen sooner. "I know you shouldn't regret things. But it's a bit like having only one child. I would have loved more and I regret that. I can't help it." She talks now frankly and unguardedly, and she laughs, all the time, like someone who has just discovered laughter. When she gets excited, her voice rises and rises so that sentences end almost in song. It's very funny and engaging. She loves being teased, she's a great flirt and quite a flatterer. She is also surprising. We were talking at one point about transformation, about inventing a self. Listen, she said, "I have this to say about self-invention. If I use those words it's because I have had to produce a kind of language of what I do. I don't start with those words, I'd be crazy. If you want to know what it feels like to be me, it is someone mooching along trying to work out how to make a sentence that's not ugly." And, if I hadn't liked her so much already, at what she said next I would have thrown myself at her feet. "If I hadn't allowed my insufferable moralism to kidnap me, if I'd stuck with fiction . . . " But she couldn't resist the attention. "The essays got so much attention." It's no wonder she mistrusts the media. Has a love-hate relationship with attention. The media gave her an image, as a sort of pr t-à-porter cultural guru, and she became fixed in it. But she was complicit with it, you say. Well, yes and no. She was young, as she says, naive. She didn't see until too late what was being made of her. It's hard to think back to the early 60s, to that eager early feminism, how desperate we all were for a female face. Face being the operative word. Sontag was, and remains, at 67, a beauty. "Yes, I always knew it. I was pretty and smart, and that drew attention to me. But what I've always felt is that I didn't ask either for these prejudices or for those benefits." And what happened, I suspect, is that as the gap between how she saw herself (intelligent, but nonetheless a moocher) and how she was seen ("a tastemaker, a producer of opinions") widened, she began to perceive herself as a fraud. Or anyway to feel fraudulent. And that's a huge weight to carry. The mystery, then, is not how she released herself, but that she was able to do it at all. What she is saying, of course, is that the non-fiction, the essays, were in fact a fiction. And the fiction, the novels, are real. But it takes immense courage to pull away the mask. To insist that you are seen in friendship, or not at all. She sets her novels in the past, in history. "Because the past is a way of looking at the present, though I am moving slowly towards the 21st century. My next novel will be set in 30s Japan." Her instinct is probably right - to start from a distance and work gradually forward. She tells me that the first time she ever talked about her own past, her "personal life", was when she was being interviewed in 1992 for The Volcano Lover. Prior to this, she'd always held tenaciously to TS Eliot's line that great writing is impersonal. "That biography is trivia." It was her lifeline. "I remember that time saying that my mother had been an alcoholic." Her mother had died six years earlier, in 1986, from lung cancer. "And after, I rang my sister Judith and said, 'I've just thrown mother to the wolves.' And Judith said, 'Good.'" It's strange. So much rage, and yet in life she said nothing to her mother at all. Even on her death-bed, in hospital in Hawaii, where her mother lived, Sontag was unable to put out her hand to her. "She was the sort of woman who flinched if you touched her." Her mother's last words to her were, "Why don't you go back to the hotel?" To which Susan replied, "Oh, you know, mother, I love hospitals." And her mother smiled and closed her eyes. "She liked that, you see. She thought it witty and sarcastic. I couldn't say, 'I've come here because I love you. I've come because you are mortally ill.'" Of course she couldn't. Not after a lifetime of not saying. Imagine the depth of sadness, of waste, that could reveal. "I adored her," Susan says, "but in that way you adore someone you can't have. I hardly saw her as a child. She was always away." And the father? Absent also. A wealthy furrier, living and working in China, in the British concession in Tiensin, he died from tuberculosis, in 1939, when Susan was five. The two children were brought up by nannies and servants in the big house on Long Island, where they lived. So she hardly knew him. "Though I cried for him every day of my childhood." Her mother lied to her. Lied about his death, said he was coming home. Lied later about the cause of his death, said he died from pneumonia. "There was a stigma at that time surrounding TB." Lied even about where he was buried. "Said it was Brooklyn, when in fact it was Queens." Just two years ago she employed a researcher to track down his grave and went to visit it. And suddenly there was his headstone: Jack Rosenblatt. "There's knowing and really knowing. I don't think I had believed he was dead until then." Susan was 12 when she changed her name from Rosenblatt to Sontag. Her mother had remarried, "A foolish man, a war hero, a harmless, inept, fatuous guy." They skipped off to Mexico, got wed, and didn't tell the girls until their return. He never legally adopted them. So he was never their father. But he was there, a present figure of authority, substituting for an absent figure of authority, and, as you can see from her description of him, she despised him. So what do you do as a bright young girl who, in her early teens, finds herself in the wrong place, and misunderstood. Because how could this fatuous, inept guy ever understand her? Or, indeed, her mother - the "cold, cruel woman" she describes. I think two things happen. You grow up early, too early. You bypass adolescence - though you'll probably have to make a detour back there later. And you find yourself a new authority. An authority that challenges the ineptitude of this poor substitute. She found it in academia. She says herself that books became her refuge. That she'd spend her evenings in the library, away from home. Comforting herself with knowledge, learning things by rote - she has always had a prodigious memory, as well as a prodigious curiosity. Learning became her unassailable identity. Or so she thought. And the irony is that it could have worked. If she had been less clever, less curious, more easily satisfied. Probably it did work for a while. She told me that she'd never understood why her sister rejected learning - never did well at school. "I always thought that I had made a really good choice. I couldn't see why Judith didn't make it, too. She was an under-achiever, bright but anti-ambitious." She couldn't see it because her own need was blocking her view. She became "an intellectual" - let's give it that name - out of insecurity, out of need. Judith, presumably, had other needs. Why did she take her mother's husband's name? More to the point, why did she keep it? I asked her, and she said this: "I think I liked Sontag. It sounded less funny, less Jewish, than Rosenblatt. More American." And, in post-war America, anti-Semitism was again rife. Germany was being resurrected as an ally. "I was used, at school, to being called a dirty kike. I think I was relieved to change my name." It's an answer but it may not be enough. She felt betrayed by her father, she says. "He didn't come back." Changing her name was not a reciprocal betrayal. It was something else. A constant reminder. As if keeping a name that wasn't real pointed always to the reality behind it. That whoever she may have been was obliterated. She was 16 when she left home. Why did she marry at 17? And a man, Philip Reiff, whom she scarcely knew. Reiff, 10 years older than she, was an academic at Chicago University, where she was studying. He met her one day, took her out for dinner, a cheeseburger, took her out the next day for breakfast, and then for lunch, another cheeseburger. And that evening he proposed. He told her that the moment he heard her voice he knew she was the woman he was going to marry. "I'd never been called a woman before. I thought it was fantastic. I said yes. Isn't that crazy?" When she suggested they should sleep together, he said, we'll marry first. "I thought, 'He's even purer than I am.' We were married the next week." Of course she left him. webTitle: How to... ask your boss for more

fields.headline: How to... ask your boss for more
fields.standfirst: You never know, you might even get what you're looking for
fields.trailText: It might not feel like it sometimes, but the workplace pendulum is slowly swinging in favour of the employee. The old deal where job security was offered in exchange for employee loyalty has been replaced by a new one where employers, especially the good ones, now realise that attracting and retaining the best workers is their number one issue.
fields.body:
It might not feel like it sometimes, but the workplace pendulum is slowly swinging in favour of the employee. The old deal where job security was offered in exchange for employee loyalty has been replaced by a new one where employers, especially the good ones, now realise that attracting and retaining the best workers is their number one issue.

For companies, it's no longer a matter of finding capital (there seems to be no shortage of money in the current boom). And it's no longer the lack of great ideas (there's a bunch of those, too). Put simply, there are just not enough good people to fill the positions being created.

So what's the problem? There isn't one for the workers. In fact, there has never been a better time to be a worker. So, go ahead, ask your boss for more. You'll probably get it. But what should you ask for?

Here are a few ideas:

 Ask for more money. But don't just ask for a base salary increase. Also ask for a share in the outcome. In other words, if the company does well or your department does well, you'll get a piece of the action. "Achieving success is key in allowing you to pursue your more personal intentions from a position of strength," says Patrick Forsyth, author of Understanding Office Politics (Hodder & Stoughton). "If you are responsible for others, for a team of people or department, then the potential scale of success is greater than what you might achieve alone."

 Ask for more time off. With the advent of telecommuting, you could ask for more flexitime in your day. For example, if you want to take the afternoon off to pick up a friend at the airport, then you can do it. You may have to spend some time on the computer that night, but at least you set your own schedule.

Ask for more say in company decisions. Easier to pull off in smaller companies, admittedly, but even some of the larger companies are starting to listen to their employees' ideas on new products, services, processes, or how things can get done more quickly and with better results.

Ask for more assignments. Be proactive in your quest to be noticed and get promotions for more interesting work.

Ask for more fun. Yes, that's right. Fun. Good employers understand that people have to have balance in their lives to be great employees. And fun is a key part of balance. There are companies who have games rooms, activity weekends or evenings when they put their credit card behind the bar - some don't even mind the occasional food fight in the canteen.

Ask for a sense of purpose. OK, this one's a little ethereal. But many of us want to feel like we are actually contributing something or making a difference. Who knows, maybe the boss has an idea or two on this request.

Timing is absolutely paramount when asking for more, and there are certain times which are more effective than others.

Here are seven suggestions:

1. Ask during an interview. It's a great time to start to get a sense of how your prospective employer operates.

2. Ask at scheduled times. We're not just talking about the annual review. Suggest to your boss that you meet at a regularly scheduled time, say once a month, to see how things are going, how you can improve and so on.

3. Ask when you have a need. The key here is to ask in a business-like manner, not an emotional manner. Having a baby or moving house, for example are legitimate. But tie your request to how you are going to bring more to the business, not from the standpoint of the company 'owing you'.

4. Ask when someone else gets more. You can't go running to the boss every time a colleague gets a pay rise. But it is an indication the company is in that mode. So plan your timing and present your idea on how you can justify your request.

5. Ask when you have a good idea. There's never a bad time for a great idea that will help the company increase its value. Just make that the primary issue and somehow tie your request for more to the idea.

6. Ask when you are in a good mood. Never give an ultimatum. Although that approach can work in the short run, long term it won't. You'll be seen as someone the company doesn't want or need.

Put simply, there are just not enough good people to fill the positions being created. So what's the problem? There isn't one for the workers. In fact, there has never been a better time to be a worker. So, go ahead, ask your boss for more. You'll probably get it. But what should you ask for? Here are a few ideas:  Ask for more money. But don't just ask for a base salary increase. Also ask for a share in the outcome. In other words, if the company does well or your department does well, you'll get a piece of the action. "Achieving success is key in allowing you to pursue your more personal intentions from a position of strength," says Patrick Forsyth, author of Understanding Office Politics (Hodder & Stoughton). "If you are responsible for others, for a team of people or department, then the potential scale of success is greater than what you might achieve alone."  Ask for more time off. With the advent of telecommuting, you could ask for more flexitime in your day. For example, if you want to take the afternoon off to pick up a friend at the airport, then you can do it. You may have to spend some time on the computer that night, but at least you set your own schedule. Ask for more say in company decisions. Be proactive in your quest to be noticed and get promotions for more interesting work. Ask for more fun. Yes, that's right. Fun. Good employers understand that people have to have balance in their lives to be great employees. And fun is a key part of balance. There are companies who have games rooms, activity weekends or evenings when they put their credit card behind the bar - some don't even mind the occasional food fight in the canteen. Ask for a sense of purpose. fields.headline: Humble beginnings
fields.standfirst: If you really want to be a high flier, lower yourself
fields.trailText: That well-known biblical mantra "whoever exalts himself will be humbled and whoever humbles himself will be exalted", can certainly ring true for graduates.
fields.body:
That well-known biblical mantra "whoever exalts himself will be humbled and whoever humbles himself will be exalted", can certainly ring true for graduates.

Those who want to get ahead are often happy to accept they may have to enter their chosen field at a much lower level than initially hoped. It's a growing trend, borne out by research published recently by the Careers Service Unit (CSU), which shows that nearly 40% of employed graduates land jobs where they are not using their degree. However, after three years only 10% are in non-graduate jobs.

"People who are humble are more likely to succeed than people who say, 'I've got my degree, I demand a degree-level job and I'm going to wait for it'," says Carl Gilleard, chief executive of the Association of Graduate Recruiters.

Research shows that waiting for a dream job could seriously damage your career prospects. The CSU report found that graduates still unemployed six months after graduating spend on average 30% - or 13 months - of the first three and a half years unemployed, compared with less than one month for graduates employed 6 months after graduation. Furthermore, graduates unemployed after six months are less likely to be employed in a graduate job in the future than those who got a job within six months.

Gill Mills was keen to get into TV as a director when she left Glasgow University with a degree in film, TV and theatre studies. But she was unable to find an entry level position and so ended up as a £50-a-week runner on a Scottish TV programme. Today she commands hundreds of pounds a day as a presenter for Radio 1 and digital channel ITV2.

"I wouldn't be presenting now, if I hadn't been prepared to have patience," says Gill. "There were people on my degree course saying they were going straight to the BBC and five years later they're still saying that."

Gill whose portfolio of presenting work also includes careers show Hot Pursuits on digital channel BBC Knowledge, continues: "You have to be realistic and not think you're going to get the job of your dreams straight away. You've got to be prepared to start at the bottom."

Careers today are not necessarily structured onwards and upwards. Some people may have to move sideways or backwards to achieve their dreams. So the eventual winners are the ones who are prepared to be flexible.

Of course, it's only natural to want to land a well-paid degree-level job after spending years in academia with very little money. But imagine how much more you will have to offer as a manager in the future if you have worked in the same jobs as those who report to you.

IT, advertising, charity and the media are just some of the sectors where you're unlikely to land the job of your dreams straight away.

But not everyone has to settle for a first job they would rather not do. "Some people are going to be identified as high fliers and trained and promoted quickly. Those who don't have the good fortune are likely to be successful, but will get there a different way," says Gilleard.

For a fast-track career look out for graduate training schemes. Though a significant number will have been filled already, many blue chip companies still have opportunities. It's important to note that in many major companies if you start off in a non-graduate position it is very difficult to progress to a graduate job. "The idea of being employed as, say, a secretary and moving into a graduate development programme will not work," says Martin Birchall, survey director of High-Fliers Research.

"But small employers who are keen to get someone of graduate calibre, will give you something menial and once you've proved yourself you can progress quite quickly."

fields.headline: Tip of the week
fields.standfirst: Hack down hecklers
fields.trailText: Chairing or presenting to meetings full of big noises can be daunting for novices. Author Bob Rosner has two pieces of advice: distribute the agenda at least a day in advance and have a plan to handle difficult people. "Comics have hecklers, companies have hoggers," he says. "Be kind, but firm in keeping a few people from dominating the discussion. Reach out to people who are quiet so that everyone gets a chance to contribute. Monitor tension in the room. It's tough enough for most of us to juggle the agenda and the clock without having to worry about how people are feeling. But it's important. Try to be aware of body language. If you notice the tension level rising or if people are drifting away, bring it to the group's attention."

fields.headline: Sixty seconds in... Theatre costumes
fields.standfirst: Liz Walsh, costume and furniture hire manager at London's National Theatre, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.trailText: Liz Walsh, costume and furniture hire manager at London's National Theatre, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.body:
Contrary to popular belief we don't spend our time dressing up; most of the time it's too busy. I manage two giant warehouses in Brixton where the National stores 60,000 costumes, most of which have been in previous productions. There's everything from ostrich outfits to Tudor peasant costumes. We hold them to be reused in subsequent National productions but also to be hired out to various organisations, from professional companies to schools.

When the National puts on a new play, most of the costumes for the leading actors are usually made by the theatre's costume department. However, it's uneconomic to make the costumes for the lesser parts and that's where we come in.

It might seem odd, but the costumes are all stored according to their period rather than the production in which they appeared, apart from two shows - Guys and Dolls and The Wind in the Willows. All day, designers and hirers visit us by appointment. One of the areas in which we specialise is distressed costumes. People wandering around often look at the bundles of rags hanging up and wonder who in their right mind would want to hire these. But if you have a chorus line of street urchins, they're perfect.

Because of the sheer number of garments, a good deal of the job involves learning about the stock. If a client needs help we'll show them round and it's not unusual for them to bring the actors along for a fitting. Equally, once they've seen what's available they are just as likely to leave having decided to bring the production's period forward by 20 years.

Once the decision has been made, we book it out and deal with all the paperwork. We do allow alterations if they are done by a proper seamstress and they are restored afterwards. Things like dry cleaning and repairs all need attending to.

It might seem amazing but until recently, none of the stock was on a database - but that's being changed. We are currently giving every piece a computer entry and barcode which will eventually save us writing out a detailed description of the garment every time it goes out on hire.

There's no doubt that one of the attractions of the job is the fabulous costumes we hold and the fact that every year, the costumes from 30 more productions arrive.

One problem we do have is finding enough big costumes for women. When I'm at the first night of the latest production and it has a large actress playing the lead, the thing I immediately think of is - oh good, another large costume.

webTitle: Moving on up: An ABC guide to making a good drama out of a small crisis

fields.headline: Moving on up: An ABC guide to making a good drama out of a small crisis
fields.trailText: A. Promotion prospects
fields.body:
A. Promotion prospects

Crises are great. They bring people together, provide a bit of excitement and allow those who've been working on their leadership skills to put them to use. There's something for everyone in a good crisis. Use it to make yourself look important or to provide an excuse for being irrational, moody and difficult. Whilst talented slackers melt into the confusion, the ambitious can exploit the opportunity to raise their profile. Get a reputation for being able to cope in a crisis and any faults you have will be overlooked, making you a front runner for promotion.

B. Increased productivity

Once in a managerial role you're in the best position to keep generating situations that show you at your troubleshooting best. Maintain a steady supply of emergencies by making sure everyone has workloads beyond their capacity, too few resources and little information. If they're stoic about all this, keep changing your mind over what's wanted, cancel all training and outlaw life-friendly working practices. Your staff turnover and crisis count will soar.

C. The smell of success

Above all, avoid thinking ahead. It's a boring activity that will not make you feel powerful or important. Just concentrate on urgent tasks and don't worry about trying to prioritise work. Keep telling yourself you can only work to tight deadlines, persist in the belief that cure is better than prevention and smell the burnout.

webTitle: Have you come to a fork in your career?

fields.headline: Have you come to a fork in your career?
fields.standfirst: We road test three of the best sources of advice
fields.trailText: Ok, so you've admitted you need help. But where do you find the best advice when deciding which career path to follow or whether to change direction? To help you choose, Rise road-tested three different models in the current range of services.
fields.body:
Ok, so you've admitted you need help. But where do you find the best advice when deciding which career path to follow or whether to change direction? To help you choose, Rise road-tested three different models in the current range of services.

A. Going back to university

Your old university is a good place to start if you are still living nearby. But through the Association of Graduate Careers Advisory Services' (AGCAS) mutual aid agreement, you can actually walk into most university careers services and receive help. So, for example while I could have gone back to Humberside University, I saved myself the train fare and opted instead for City University, round the corner from where I work.

There were plenty of resources on offer - staff were helpful and friendly and pointed me in the direction of PCs which I could use to write my CV (and print it out for a small fee) and analyse the career options open to me. There was a huge selection of books, leaflets and brochures on career planning in the library - and much of the infor-mation was free for me to take away.

The university also offers one-to-one career guidance, although this needs to be arranged in advance. In City's case, this service is available only to people who graduated no more than two years ago, but this rule doesn't apply at all universities. These consultations are free at City, but some universities will make you pay if you are already in a job.

If you can't get to a university campus, AGCAS also runs a graduate career phone line which is staffed by experienced university careers advisers. They can help you create a job-search strategy, evaluate the pros and cons of postgraduate study and discuss other issues where face-to-face contact is not essential. You pay for your call, but the advice itself is free.

B. Going private

You can, of course, pay for advice if you want to. For example, I tested C2 - the Graduate Career Shop - which is part-funded by the Department for Education and Employment. It is aimed at graduates of all ages who want advice on a career change, CV analysis, creative job searching and interview techniques.

C2 offers group sessions as well as personal consultations in most of these areas. One-to-ones are more expensive, so I opted for a group session about changing direction. After introducing ourselves, we found that we were facing a variety of career dilemmas which ranged from boredom to cravings for more money or fresh challenges.

During the session we looked at why we wanted to change career, how to find a path which suited us, and then how to go about it. The workshop was thorough - it gave us plenty of ideas on how to assess our current situations in a realistic manner, order our priorities and take control of our careers. The session was interactive and we were free to suggest ideas or ask questions at any time.

A group session costs £15 for 90 minutes (or you can buy four for £55). However, a follow-up 30-minute private consultation costs £40, while a one-hour chat will set you back £70. Yet personal consultations are popular and you may have to book two or three weeks ahead - not very helpful if you require urgent advice.

However, you can visit C2's library of books and software for a charge of £4 a day.

C2 also offers psychometric testing. The Myers Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI), for example will help you identify your personality type. This will enable you to understand your preferred way of working - essential when choosing a career that fits.

The one-hour MBTI test costs £80 at C2 but it is also available at other university career libraries and can cost as little as £6 per session, a fiver of which is a deposit - if you turn up for the session you get your money back.

C. Going online

If you're too lazy to leave the house, there is an increasing number of websites which offer general career advice, and I tested one of the best-known, ProspectsWeb which is run by the Higher Education Central Services Unit.

The site gives masses of contact information on occupations, employers, postgraduate education, job vacancies and career libraries. Its Quick Match gets you thinking about the most important things you want from work and then matches these with the characteristics of different jobs.

Prospects Direct, meanwhile will email you information on relevant job vacancies and opportunities. There is an interactive software package too called Prospects Planner which includes self-analysis and help with preparing applications.

webTitle: Help: I'm working for a moron!

fields.headline: Help: I'm working for a moron!
fields.trailText: My boss is unbearably arrogant, and although I enjoy my job and the company of others at work, his attitude is driving me to consider looking for another job. Katrice T, surveyor, Luton
fields.body:
My boss is unbearably arrogant, and although I enjoy my job and the company of others at work, his attitude is driving me to consider looking for another job. Katrice T, surveyor, Luton

Shame to leave a job you enjoy for a reason like this. Have a go at developing some survival strategies first. Arrogant behaviour, that unpleasant combination of rudeness and bullying, is often accepted with resignation as inevitable from those in a position of power.

This reinforces their can't-be-wrong feeling, which feeds and promotes healthy growth of self admiration. Such inflated egos are protected by a thick lack of subtlety and layers of disregard for the opinions of others.

To puncture them takes a long, sharp pin. Tempting as it is to wound characters like this, there's limited satisfaction to be gained from destroying someone, and little point in attacking the virtually indestructible. The healthiest way to make your working life more pleasant is to minimise him. Whereas most people make an effort to relate to others and take account of their point of view, consideration is wasted on those totally lacking basic social skills. So switch off. Don't let what he does or says be important.

Keep all contact as brief and business-like as possible. Physically remove yourself whenever you feel angry, cowed, argumentative or upset - these all serve to intensify an arrogant individual's feeling of superiority. Don't worry about appearing impolite - he's probably too self-absorbed to notice.

And if you feel like laughing at some of the more ridiculous things he says, do. An ego starved of suitable reaction might in time wither.

Whereas most people make an effort to relate to others and take account of their point of view, consideration is wasted on those totally lacking basic social skills. So switch off. Don't let what he does or says be important. Keep all contact as brief and business-like as possible. Physically remove yourself whenever you feel angry, cowed, argumentative or upset - these all serve to intensify an arrogant individual's feeling of superiority. Don't worry about appearing impolite - he's probably too self-absorbed to notice. And if you feel like laughing at some of the more ridiculous things he says, do. An ego starved of suitable reaction might in time wither. mailto:ijk@excite.com

fields.headline: Top rung/ Bottom rung
fields.body:
Top rung

Malcolm Wall
Aged 43
Chief executive, broadcasting interests
United News & Media

Former Harlequins rugby player Malcolm Wall wanted to be a journalist when he left the University of Kent with an English degree. "I wanted to be a James Cameron or John Pilger," he admits.

But when he finally got his chance in broadcasting with Southern Television he made his mark on the commercial side. By1987 he had become senior sales exec with Anglia, later Granada, and he went on to join Meridian as deputy chief exec in 1992. Two years on he became Anglia's MD and took up his present position in 1997.

Screen role: Running TV businesses for United News & Media, which has 2,200 staff and a £60m turnover. His responsibilities include broadcasting, programme-making (such as ITV's Hearts and Bones ), sales, broadband and the consumer internet. "My task is to give strategic direction while maintaining good business disciplines."

Coming soon: Malcolm is CEO designate of the TV businesses arising from the merger with Carlton. "This will mean £250m worth of programme-making. I aim to give the creative talent the freedom to prosper."

The buzz: "Being in an industry where you always face a new challenge - creative, technological and corporate."

Bottom rung

Kathryn Shannon
Aged 25
Sales executive, television
United News & Media

Kathryn Shannon fancied being anything from a pop star to a footballer. And when she graduated in electronic engineering (York University) she still didn't have a firm career planned, so decided on a gap year.

"When I returned from travelling in Australia and south-east Asia I knew I wanted to get into the media," she says.

Sales pitch: Kathryn searched the newspapers, internet and agencies and finally landed a job in strategic planning with United News & Media. But after four months she realised it was a sales role she wanted. "So, I approached the MD and, after three interviews and a presentation, I made it," she smiles.

Current role: She works with 12 agencies on media solutions and campaigns - for example, Euro 2000 sponsorship for ITV football.

Training? "In such a fast-moving business as new media, training is very hands-on. We also have reviews every quarter during which our targets are set."

Ambitions? "I would love to see this business go global and be in charge of an operation abroad."

Tip for graduates: "Do anything you want to do and go out and enjoy it."

 For more details visit www.unm.com

fields.headline: VIP sweet
fields.trailText: Name: Sonia Kapur
fields.body:
Name: Sonia Kapur

Status: Guest relations manager at Crowne Plaza, London

Past:Graduated from University of Surrey with BSc in hotel and catering management. Joined Crowne Plaza London as guest relations officer and just 18 months later was promoted to manager.

Present: Looks after VIPs such as diplomats or soon-to-be sirs and dames visiting nearby Buckingham Palace.

Future: "I hope it will involve some sort of hospitality, perhaps PR in a large company, so long as it's one that regards customer service as a top priority."

Strengths: "This job comes naturally to me. I have an ability to talk to people no matter who they are and I enjoy being nice to people - there's no hidden agenda."

Weaknesses: "I find it difficult to switch off - I end up thinking about my work a lot and taking on too much."

Wisdom: "Go for a job you really love. Work hard, take pride in what you do and be prepared to sacrifice time and energy."

References: www.basshotels.com/crowneplaza

fields.trailText:
• What's the big idea?
Are you a budding entrepreneur? The right idea could win you a two-week placement in the British Virgin Islands courtesy of adviser BDO Stoy Hayward. Open to any full-time first or second year student, the challenge is to come up with the most original business plan that has the best chance of success. See www.bdo.co.uk/bigidea2000

 What's the big idea?
Are you a budding entrepreneur? The right idea could win you a two-week placement in the British Virgin Islands courtesy of adviser BDO Stoy Hayward. Open to any full-time first or second year student, the challenge is to come up with the most original business plan that has the best chance of success. See www.bdo.co.uk/bigidea2000

 Book of the week:
Graduate job-hunters need to be well informed to get to the front of the queue and Shirley Kenner's Graduate Career Handbook (FT Prentice Hall) is a timely web- referenced guide which provides inside information on the recruitment process. To order your copy at the special price of £16.99 (plus p&p), call our Cultureshop on 0800-316-6102.

 They are what they eat:
If you're trying to suss out a new colleague, take note of what they snack on. Researchers at the Smell and Taste Treatment Foundation in Chicago tested 800 volunteers and concluded that people who prefer crisps are more likely to be high achievers while cracker lovers tend to be shy and contemplative.

 Spark detector:
Job candidates could soon be facing a new style of psychometric test. Oxford Psychologists Press has come up with the Innovation Potential Indicator, which can help determine who has the potential to be an innovator. Crucially, the test examines the big difference between the ability to have ideas and the ability to see those ideas through.

 Run up a tab:
Scientists at Bristol University have identified a chemical which they think causes stress - the second-biggest workplace health problem, with 5m British sufferers - and reckon they could cure it with a simple tablet. The research has also established links between stress and problems such as backache, heavy drinking and poor mental health.

 Dressing down:
The trend for letting people go casual at work is making more work for personnel departments. A survey by the Society for Human Resource Management found that the number of US firms adopting a casual dress policy grew from 76% in 1996 to 95% last year.

fields.headline: Word power
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  on Jonathon Green' s Herculean exercise in lexicography, Cassell's Dictionary of Slang
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard on Jonathon Green' s Herculean exercise in lexicography, Cassell's Dictionary of Slang
fields.body:
Cassell's Dictionary of Slang
Jonathon Green
(£15.99)
Buy it at BOL

My word-processing program puts a row of fussy little red dashes under every word it thinks might be in some way wrong. Which is fine when you type "fewkgjitr" but not when you use the word "ass". It would appear my programmers think that Jesus rode into Jerusalem on a bottom. The guardians of our morals are the most dirty-minded of us all.

But I can hardly imagine anyone, except the most eyeball-swivelling Festival of Lighter, objecting to the appearance of this book, which contains not only all the words that give Corel WordPerfect the heebie-jeebies (probably "a nonce coinage by the US cartoonist Billy Derbeck", 26 October 1923) but is done so on a scholarly basis. This is a real, functioning dictionary, an astonishingly impressive work of reference and research, however you look at it. It is incredible to think that it is the work of one man over only five years.

In fact, it seems hardly possible. Slang is almost by definition undefinable, deliberately outside the dictionary. Eric Partridge of course had the idea in 1937; but this is a worthy successor to Partridge, supplanting it in almost every respect. It's Johnsonian in scope; and indeed it carries its own Johnsonian resonances, not only in its solitary authority, but in our memories of the time he was congratulated by a couple of goody-goody ladies for not putting any rude words in, only for the good doctor to ask them what they thought they were doing looking them up in the first place.

Apart from the lack of "Destroyer's Breakast" - a fag and a cup of tea (yet "Drover's Breakfast", a cough and a look around, is in) - the only omission I can charge him with is a salute to Viz's "Roger's Profanisaurus", an ongoing lexicon of base language whose regular updates alone justify the price of the magazine. I am disappointed, for instance, that "the turtle's head" is not in Green.

But you can't expect him to keep on top of everything, and as he acknowledges in his preface, this is a book that he hopes to update with contributions from the floor. He has done his damnedest to supply the etymologies whenever he can, and they all ring true. You can tell this by the way that he has to acknowledge defeat from time to time: "Caledonia", a black term for a socially ambitious black woman, used in America (note the precision) from the 1920s to the 1950s, has as its etymology the despairing but hopeful "[? a book ? play ? song ?]". Well? Any ideas?

What is really great about it is that it tacitly acknowledges the idea - that some stupid people can't get their heads around - that a dictionary is only alive if it contains plenty of dead words or phrases. Slang, the most democratic of languages, further widens its inclusion if it includes the extinct. "Dog-dram": "the act of spitting in someone's mouth and hitting them on the back." From mid-18th to early 19th century: Jesus, what would the Daily Mail think of that if it started up again? Did Dr Johnson ever do it? Probably not, but Dr Johnson survives (from Partridge) as yet another term for the penis, for "there was no one Dr Johnson was not prepared to stand up to". We stand up and salute Mr Green.

fields.headline: Tunnel vision
fields.standfirst: Steven Poole  delves into Haruki Murakami's masterpieces
fields.trailText: Steven Poole delves into Haruki Murakami's masterpieces
fields.body:
Norwegian Wood
Haruki Murakami, translated by Jay Rubin
Harvill, £15, 594pp
Buy it at BOL

Underground
Haruki Murakami, translated by Alfred Birnbaum and Philip Gabriel
Harvill, £20, 309pp

The men who narrate Haruki Murakami's novels repeatedly claim to be utterly ordinary. They live blameless lives, keep their heads down, indulge moderately in jazz and beer, hope things will stay the same. And yet something happens: the ordinary man is catapulted into deranged circumstances. He might be forced to hunt down an evil sheep that wants to take over the world, or to investigate his wife's spectral disappearance.

Norwegian Wood, first published in Japan 13 years ago but only now translated for a western audience, might therefore puzzle the reader who has grown to love Murakami's haunting, melancholy surrealism: its action is resolutely realistic. And yet the narrator, Toru Watanabe, is just as baffled by life. At one point he writes: "I have never lied to anyone, and I have taken care over the years not to hurt other people. And yet I find myself tossed into this labyrinth." There is no moral justice in Murakami's world; there is only the duty - both epistemological and moral - to try to understand.

This duty also informs his first non-fiction volume, Underground. Murakami became obsessed with the 1995 Tokyo subway attack, in which Aum cult members released Sarin nerve gas on five separate trains. The book consists largely of edited transcripts of interviews conducted with survivors or relatives of victims. "How on earth did this happen to us?" one woman asks. "That 'How on earth...?' ", Murakami comments, "stuck in my head like a big question mark." No wonder: it is also the cry of pain that fires the depths of his fiction.

Norwegian Wood is a love story. The Beatles song of the title, heard by the 37-year-old Toru Watanabe, is an aural Proustian madeleine that transports him back to his student days. Watanabe has started at university in Tokyo the year after his best friend, Kizuki, killed himself. Kizuki's girlfriend Naoko and Watanabe have grown romantically close since their friend's death, but their love is complicated by Naoko's depression. Naoko enrols at a sanatorium, and the lonely Watanabe meets another woman, the flirtatiously vulnerable Midori. Thus is his "labyrinth" woven: a choice between idealised love and eternally sworn loyalty or flesh-and-blood happiness in the present.

The first chapter dreamily foreshadows the entire novel. Watanabe and Naoko, in the saturated colours and hyperreal detail of burned-in memory, are walking in a field, and Naoko playfully relates the local legend of the field well. No one knows where it is, and there is no encircling wall. You could fall down it at any time, and you would never get out.

Finding oneself down a well, or otherwise underground, is an oddly charged possibility in Murakami. The well can furnish a kind of metaphysical holiday - the narrator of Murakami's masterpiece to date, The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle, seeks out a well bottom in order to "think about reality". Alternatively, as Naoko fears in Norwegian Wood, being down a well might mean suffering in despair, being swallowed up by madness, inexorably dying. The horror of the Tokyo subway shares this motif with Murakami's fiction: as one survivor tells him: "The fear of going underground in a metal box and something bad happening is overpowering."

Norwegian Wood, simply told on the surface, slowly reveals its own subterranean currents. Chatting to Midori's dying father in hospital, for example, Watanabe mentions that he prefers Sophocles to Euripides. The implication is that conflicts will not be solved by an interfering deus ex machina, but can only unravel in tragic violence. Subtle allusions to Thomas Mann and The Great Gatsby contribute further eddies.

Such is the exquisite, gossamer construction of Murakami's writing that everything he chooses to describe trembles with symbolic possibility: a shirt on a washing-line, a string of paper cut-outs, a butterfly hairslide. Three times in the novel Watanabe reaches out to clutch light: first a sparkling mote of dust, next a firefly disappearing into the night. The third time he is strolling in the sanatorium gardens and becomes transfixed by Naoko's lit window in the distance, "like the final pulse of a soul's dying embers". You cannot retain the fleeting after-image of a firefly - similarly, perhaps, you cannot keep such embers alight by force of will. Maybe this bird, as John Lennon sang, has flown.

For all its metaphysical gloom, however, Norwegian Wood also flutters with sympathetic comedy. What on first glance appear to be bathetic lapses into jovial innuendo or irrelevant cookery chat between characters make the point that people in real life do not react to alarming or tragic situations in consistent or appropriate ways. Underground 's testimonies reflect the same truth - some survivors are angry, some scared, others calm or even lighthearted.

Underground is largely made up of the voices of others because, as a novelist, Murakami is "less interested in the 'big picture', as it were, than in the concrete, irreducible humanity of each individual". Norwegian Wood glows with this same interest, as its injured but hopeful characters hungrily seek happiness in odd places. Amazed by the overdubbed slurping and sucking of a porn-cinema soundtrack, Watanabe muses: "I felt strangely moved to think that I was living out my life on this bizarre planet of ours." The novel comes in two volumes, and just as the second jacket replaces blood red with spring green, so the ending is one of heavily battered, qualified optimism.

The Aum attack, meanwhile, eventually seems to Murakami to pose a challenge that is explicitly novelistic. Shoko Asahara, the cult leader, must have been a "master storyteller" in order to seduce so many intelligent individuals to his seemingly crazed version of Buddhism. In Murakami's view, the worst response to the massacre would be to view it as an aberration, a one-off evil perpetrated by spaced-out psychos. For his imaginative sympathy extends to the cult members, interviewed in the latter third of Underground, as well as to its victims.

Through Murakami's sensitive yet relentless questioning, it emerges that the people who joined Aum felt just as adrift in the world as Murakami's own characters do. One hyper-rational member describes his youthful frustration: "I couldn't find a single person who wanted to talk about the things that I cared about." But when he met Asahara, "It was like he saw the real me at a glance." In Murakami's fiction, too, people are tempted by eccentric, comforting myths: Naoko in Norwegian Wood becomes obsessed by the idea of a posthumous reunion with her first boyfriend; in the searingly brilliant A Wild Sheep Chase (also now published by Harvill), the megalomaniac ovine seduces its most powerful servant with a narrative: a malign logic that seems preferable to the impotent mess of daily life.

So before we dismiss the Aum cult as "utter nonsense", Murakami argues in Underground, we'd better make sure we have a narrative that is "potent" enough to chase it away. "It's something I'm going to have to deal with much more seriously from here on," he writes. As a statement of intent from a man who must already rank among the world's greatest living novelists, this is nothing less than thrilling.

"It's something I'm going to have to deal with much more seriously from here on," he writes. As a statement of intent from a man who must already rank among the world's greatest living novelists, this is nothing less than thrilling.

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.trailText: The perfect read after Ridley Scott's Gladiator, plus Classical Cookbook
fields.body:
The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire
Edward Gibbon
(Penguin, £9.99)
Buy it at BOL

Portable Gibbon, abbreviated even from an abridgement and printed with Penguin measliness of typesize and paper, but retaining interjected square crossheads, footnotes with unexpected, expansive adverbs and the most relishable of rolling passages. An Augustan book, both physically and linguistically, written from Gibbon's bottom, guts and heart, all under the management of a wise and compassionate head, for no ruin of a palace affected him more than the "conflagration of a cottage". Essential for shutting up those office speculations about Rome based on a dim viewing of Ridley Scott's movie commercial for Nike, Gladiator.

Classical Cookbook
Andrew Dalby and Sally Grainger
(British Museum, £8.99)
Buy it at BOL

The writers have shrewdly understood that the weird ideas we hold of Greek/Roman food (honey-roasted dormice rolled in poppy seeds, etc) are based on literary descriptions that were at least as pretentious as menu prose is now. The reality, as near as they can recreate it from manuals by Apicius and others - with Vietnamese fish sauce for Roman garum, with dill, cumin, mint, coriander and pungent asafoetida (still fearfully present in India's spice mixes) - is like Claudia Roden's Levantine recipes, or London's latest restaurant, Leban. Ave, Caesar, and may we recommend Cato's hot cheesecake?

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.trailText: Annie Proulx squeezes the epic into her short stories of America's horizonless middle lands, plus Comfort Woman, My Grandmother's Erotic Folktales and King
fields.body:
Close Range
Annie Proulx
(Fourth Estate, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

The disclaimer in Proulx's introduction, "short stories are very difficult for me", is false modesty. True, the 11 pieces here deal in epic squeezed into miniature - with small insignificances that do not ring with the usual short-story writer's stock in trade of epiphany - but with Proulx, the sense of place and the narrative voice are all. Set among ranchers and small-town folk of America's horizonless middle lands, the sentences are ripped in quick, laconic bursts as if the Wyoming wind had carried off their endings. "She could make you smell the smoke from an unlit fire," as Proulx describes one of her characters; it is an apt description for Proulx herself.

Comfort Woman
Nora Okja Keller
(Virago, £9.99)
Buy it at BOL

Mothers are always embarrassing in the eyes of their teenage daughters, and Beccah has good cause to blush at her mom's behaviour. Sewing charms into underwear and chasing every scrap of red from their home is not normal, even in Hawaii; nor can it be explained simply by the fact that Mom started life in a Korean village. What begins as a seemingly didactic rendering of a second-world-war atrocity takes flight into a delicately realised land of ghosts, demons and dubious salvation by an American preacher. Keller brushes lightly against history and pain in this essentially optimistic story of the unbreakable bonds between mother and daughter.

My Grandmother's Erotic Folktales
Robert Antoni
(Faber, £6.99)

"With stories of adventure and occasional orgies in her boarding house for American soldiers during the war, including her confrontations with the Kentucky colonel, the Tanzanian devil and the king of Chacahacari" - the subtitle makes clear to the reader that these are to be no ordinary reminiscences. The arrival of an American base on the Caribbean island of Corpus Christi turns life upside down, but Grandmother, determined to keep pizzas and prostitution out of her boarding house, entertains the troops with stories. The tales are bawdy, hilarious and magical - if only all grannies could be like this.

King
John Berger
(Bloomsbury, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

A story of humanity that thrives in a wasteland of broken televisions and scrap metal, told by a dog? It could have pulled too strongly on the heartstrings to be taken seriously, but with Berger you know that there is a fierce conscience and a dedication to stretching the possibilities of prose that prevent King from being an anthropomorphic weepie. Saint Valéry is a patch of land beside a motorway - or, in King's eyes, a coat laid on hard ground. He lives with Vico and Vica in the cuff of the right sleeve, their confidant, guard and equal. A dog narrator is a perspectival device, but the view from the end of King's nose is dazzlingly refreshing.

fields.headline: The Legacy: Emmer Green, 1956
fields.trailText:
Let the boy try. The chisel's edge is slid
into the crack. A few businesslike knocks
should do it. Gently now. The blistered lid
resists, resists. He levers at the box...
fields.body:
Let the boy try. The chisel's edge is slid
into the crack. A few businesslike knocks
should do it. Gently now. The blistered lid
resists, resists. He levers at the box,

I hold it steady. (All day long they've worked
to sort Miss Mary's things. A magpie-nest
of clothes, toys, jewellery, papers, bills, that lurked
in bags, chests, cupboards, clocks; and with the rest

I'm told, the poet's letters, stuffed in absurd odd corners.
They asked us to have a go
at these old trunks and crates. Why she left word
the Scouts should open this, I'll never know.)

A splintering crack. It gives. A musty cover
of cloth, and under it the dull green
nubbed bulk of a fully-loaded revolver.
Army issue. Nineteen-seventeen.

Thirty corroded live rounds in a pouch
of mouldy leather. Gasping, the lads crowd in.
Treasure-trove! No. No: better not touch.
Steadying my hands, I pack the things again.

In mildewed lint and sour buttery tarnish
the huge unwieldy ghost of war is laid.
My fingers nearly slip on the dull varnish.
Lifting the box, I learn that I'm afraid.
