fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: A book that stimulates more than just the ears...
fields.body:
The Kitchen Congregation
Nora Seton
(Orion, £8.99, 200mn)
Hear a RealAudio clip

A fine audiobook should be an aural treat, and here the reader Lorelei King truly ravishes the ear. But within words of the start of Nora Seton's account of the kitchen's central role in her and her family's lives, your nose should be twitching too. What is that smell? Not cassette combustion, which would be truly nasty, but the olfactory impression conjured by her description of her mother's virtuosity with food.

Seton serves a moving and insightful account of events joyful, traumatic and commonplace from the perspective of the kitchen, where her novelist mother busily presided and other key figures in her life have passed through. Somehow the warmth and solidity of this room, probably more crucial to the American homestead than the typical British semi, assuages the pain in Seton's narration of her mum's slow death from cancer and the stillbirth of her own first child. But it is the magical combination of Seton's writing and King's sensual delivery that conquers any repressed British feelings about the importance of good food and its production. We don't stand a chance.

fields.headline: Mister Godam
fields.standfirst: Paul Langford sees English life through foreign eyes in Englishness Identified
fields.trailText: Paul Langford sees English life through foreign eyes in Englishness Identified
fields.body:
Englishness Identified: Manners and Character 1650-1850
Paul Langford
Oxford, £25, 389pp
Buy it at BOL

Tourists to England are nowadays likely to come for aspects of its past: castles and cathedrals, royalty and Shakespeare. Yet in the 18th and 19th centuries, travellers came from Europe and America to find what they thought, or even hoped, would be their future: most of the foreign witnesses to England and Englishness gathered in Paul Langford's learned yet amusing study came "to view tomorrow in the making, not yesterday".

"I have seen the country in the world which is most worthy of our curiosity - I mean England," wrote Montesquieu in the 1730s. His curiosity was becoming common. In the 17th century the English were Europe's mavericks, notorious for their history of violence, turbulence and instability. By the middle of the 18th century, England seemed to many educated Europeans to be the world's most advanced civilisation: commercially successful, politically tolerant and culturally confident. Many people came in search of the secret of this transformation.

So this book has a double fascination. On the one hand, it is a history of national characteristics, from eccentricity and clubbability to xenophobia and conversational inadequacy, showing how these were first invented or discovered: it is an archaeology of myths. On the other, it is a history of how others have seen the English (or the British, many being unable to distinguish between the two). Its interest, and its comedy, lie in the way that "natural" behaviour looks thoroughly odd through the eyes of an outsider, especially an outsider seeing a trait in the early stages of development.

Take walking and running. Visitors found a metaphor for Britain's economic and military energy in its inhabitants' weird pleasure in locomotion. Bizarrely, going for a walk was a leisure activity. Stranger still, men, and even women, ran races against each other. Surely these were examples of a national restlessness - what the French historian Michelet called "this terrible concentration of power, this desperate acceleration in a straight line, found everywhere in England". The case seemed proven when French foxes were imported into England because of a shortage of home-bred quarry. It was reported that les renards were too short-winded to give English huntsmen a decent chase.

This story also illustrates the combination of fairness and violence that perplexed outsiders. The puzzlement runs through Langford's account of that notorious myth, English "fair play". The English loved wrestling, boxing and football - the latter but an excuse, said one Swiss tourist, for street disorder and the smashing of windows. "Anything that looks like Fighting is delicious to an Englishman," commented a Frenchman living in London in the 1690s.

Yet the anglophile Voltaire persuaded many that English pugilism was "a species of honour not known in any other part of the world". By the end of the 18th century, travellers sought out boxing matches. Such violence was supposed to reveal, through its unwritten rules, the essence of English "fair play", and it had become "received wisdom that it was a superior form of lower-class duelling, wise, humane, philosophical".

Langford catches the way English writers had already formed many of the standards by which foreigners were to judge England. He has always been one of the few historians of the 18th century to credit the power of imaginative literature, and here he shows how English literature shaped the expectations of non-English visitors, not least by generating waves of anglomania on the continent. The English novel, he says, was "the single most potent agent of English culture" outside England.

Samuel Richardson's Pamela and Clarissa persuaded many that behind English reserve was a wealth of sensibility. Henry Fielding, thinks Langford, was largely responsible for establishing a national reputation for eccentric amiability - celebrated in his fiction and elaborated as a stereotype "from the Vicar of Wakefield to Mr Pickwick". Equally, it is telling that the most powerful influence forming a specifically Scottish identity in the minds of Europeans and Americans was to be the writing of poet and novelist Sir Walter Scott.

It is clear that, as German teenagers nowadays expect their English hoteliers to pass for Basil Fawlty, French intellectuals once thought they recognised the innkeepers on the Dover road from Tom Jones or Roderick Random. Melancholy - "The English Malady", as the title of an 18th-century bestselling book of popular medicine had it - was also a settled reputation, owing much to literature.

Shakespearean tragedy became fashionable throughout Europe from the 1760s and was taken to represent the gloomy spirit of the nation. Meanwhile, Garrick performing Shakespeare, one of the great tourist attractions of late 18th-century London, convinced observers by his naturalism that the English were honest and unstudied in their self-expression.

Anglophile foreigners contorted themselves to find the qualities that explained the country's commercial and cultural success. In the 1820s, supposing that English bluntness was particularly enviable, fashionable young Frenchmen and Italians laced after-dinner conversation with phrases such as "Damn my eyes" and "God damn": "Mr Godam" was a standard French characterisation of an Englishman. Langford is especially good on the percolations of language. As he notes, "In 1700, no educated continental European would have thought it necessary to speak or read English, whereas by 1800 it would have been considered essential."

His history of words and attitudes teaches sharp little lessons. Post-war planners of public housing, for instance, did not notice what travellers had remarked over two centuries: that even the labouring classes in England strived to avoid communal living. The very words for spaces in shared buildings were foreign, "flat" being Scottish and "apartment" French. The English, noted a surprised German observer, "prefer the most miserable cottage hired in their own name, to more convenient apartments in another house. The national character is discovered in this very circumstance."

Equally, foreigners were as shocked by the scandal-mongering of the London press two centuries ago as they affect to be now. By 1800, newspapers were reliably serving up what one disapproving witness called "private distresses for the breakfast and entertainment of the public" (fruitiest on Sundays, under the guise of censorious moral comment).

There is special pleasure in the echoes of what is still familiar. Over and over again, visitors identify the peculiarities of English privacy: houses are hidden behind thick hedges; taverns and railway carriages are divided into small compartments. Uncommunicativeness appears a national achievement, what Talleyrand dubbed "une taciturnité toute anglaise". Today's tourists often find the crowded silence of the London tube strange. Two centuries ago, visitors from other European cities noted that London, commercially the most dynamic city in the world, was thronged with speechlessly busy men and women.

And then there was always English straitlacedness, which women's dress made literal to foreigners. "Stays were one of the most characteristic features of English civilisation" until "in the mid-19th century they conquered the west as a whole and thereby ceased to be English." Before this happened, visitors were fascinated by the whalebone à l'anglaise, the "absolute breast-plates", as a French observer put it, of national virtue. These confirmed the frigidity of English women, taken for granted throughout Europe, and a national "delicacy in matters of physical love". Englanderei, by the early 1800s, was a German word for prudishness.

This wonderful book brings such detail and generalisation together by being organised not chronologically but by "six major supposed traits of Englishness": Energy, Candour, Decency, Taciturnity, Reserve, Eccentricity. This has its drawbacks; occasionally you can hear the author flicking through his card index, collecting his quotes from centuries apart. Yet this is a petty cavil, for therein lies the book's richness: Langford has read widely and unpredictably, especially in accounts that have never been translated into English. This has allowed him to produce a book that is, in one respect, brilliantly un-English: it is fascinated by what foreigners have thought.

fields.headline: Classical music
fields.trailText: 'Tis nearly the season to be packing your Thermos and your clingfilmed ciabatta to spend a few hours nosing someone else's odorous backpack and feeling your legs go to sleep - or, as it's otherwise known, Promming.
fields.body:
'Tis nearly the season to be packing your Thermos and your clingfilmed ciabatta to spend a few hours nosing someone else's odorous backpack and feeling your legs go to sleep - or, as it's otherwise known, Promming.

Those hardy souls, as well as the wimps who take seats, are clearly planning rigorously with the official guide for the Albert Hall season. Howard Goodall's overview of musical paradigm shifts and Wolff's magisterial Bach will presumably soon be joined by David Cairns's prizewinning second volume of Berlioz biog.

Elsewhere, guides are still where it's at, with two books of opera self-help. Shame that opera, once a pleasant occasion for gossip and bitching, is now something we feel we ought to do homework for, grimly ticking off dramaturgical apercus rather than indulging sensuously - luckily, we have the estimable Lesley Garrett to put the fun back in.

Howard Goodall's overview of musical paradigm shifts and Wolff's magisterial Bach will presumably soon be joined by David Cairns's prizewinning second volume of Berlioz biog. Elsewhere, guides are still where it's at, with two books of opera self-help. Shame that opera, once a pleasant occasion for gossip and bitching, is now something we feel we ought to do homework for, grimly ticking off dramaturgical apercus rather than indulging sensuously - luckily, we have the estimable Lesley Garrett to put the fun back in. 1 The BBC Proms Guide 2000 (BBC, £4.50) 2 Note from a Small Soprano Lesley Garrett (Hodder & Stoughton, £17.99) Buy it at BOL 3 Big Bangs Howard Goodall (Chatto and Windus, £16.99) Buy it at BOL 4 Penguin Guide to Compact Discs ed Ivan March (Penguin, £19.99) Buy it at BOL 5 Johann Sebastian Bach: The Learned Musician Christoph Wolff (Oxford, £25) Buy it at BOL 6 Vaughan Williams Simon Heffer (Weidenfeld, £12.99) Buy it at BOL 7 Opera for Dummies D Pogue, Scott Speck (IDG Books, £14.99) Buy it at BOL 8 Performing Rites Simon Frith (Oxford, £9.99) Buy it at BOL 9 Herbert von Karajan Richard Osborne (Pimlico, £15) Buy it at BOL 10 Penguin Opera Guide Amanda Holden et al (Penguin, £12.99) Buy it at BOL

fields.headline: New faces in Wonderland
fields.standfirst: Illustrator Helen Oxenbury tells Julia Eccleshare about redefining Alice
fields.trailText: Illustrator Helen Oxenbury tells Julia Eccleshare about redefining Alice
fields.body:
" 'Zany' and 'funky'. I hate it when people use words like that about children's books. It doesn't really mean anything and it's patronising."

Well, Helen Oxenbury's work is never funky, or zany. Its classic status comes from its combination of lightly observed humour and bold line drawing full of exquisite detail. The children she draws are real children, not surprisingly since the original inspiration for her picture books came from her own children, and her kindly eye and delight in them gives them a timeless appeal.

Her most recent work, which has already won the Kurt Maschler Prize and has just been shortlisted for the prestigious Greenaway Medal, has been the massive one of re-illustrating Alice's Adventures in Wonderland. Her young Alice is less sophisticated than many previous representations, though flashes of her knickers show her to be less innocent than she looks; the often terrifying Red Queen is more bad-tempered than mad and Alice looks like more than a match for her. It certainly fulfils Oxenbury's intention of creating an edition of Alice that is more accessible to children.

The original commission for Alice came from Thames TV, who were planning an animated version. Along with a number of other illustrators, Oxenbury was asked to submit some illustrations. Hers were chosen but, after many months of work, the project fell through and Helen took it instead to her publisher, Walker Books.

"The trouble with Alice ," she says, "is that it comes with its own illustrations - Tenniel most obviously, but also Rackham, and Mervyn Peake did a version. I had to think, 'How do I see this?' I tried to clear my mind and think how I felt about the book as a child."

Like Carroll himself, Oxenbury based her Alice on a child she saw when visiting a friend. "You just see something in a face, something just right," she says. Some of the other characters were easy - the white rabbit and the Queen. "The Mad Hatter's easy, too, because you have such a strong vision from Tenniel. Others were much harder. But, once I'd got them, I wanted to open up the backgrounds, which Tenniel never really illustrated in detail. I have tried to give it a very English feel."

Oxenbury has illustrated more than 70 books - both classic texts and original stories, and has won all the major prizes. She is a perfectionist, whose pile of roughs is a tribute to the care she takes. Her first critic is her husband John Burningham, himself a prize-winning author and illustrator. "John and I show each other our work. I think we do it when we know something's wrong. We're critical of each other - no holds barred - but we're also very supportive."

The couple met at the Central School of Art where she was doing a course on theatre design. "After I'd finished, I worked in repertory theatre, putting new sets up every Saturday night. It was terribly hard work and I was paid £7 a week but it was very good training - a kind of square-bashing. Then John went to Israel to work on an animated film and I followed him out and got work at the Habimah Theatre in Tel Aviv. I started out painting huge great backdrops with a giant paintbrush."

It seems very different from the small scale of picture books, but she is not alone in taking this route. Maurice Sendak, author of Where The Wild Things Are, went on to design sets for The Cunning Little Vixen. "With illustration, as with set design," Oxenbury explains, "you are interpreting the ideas of an author, and where possible, you are adding - but most of all, you don't want to detract from the words, or from the actors or actresses. You can't just put up a pillar because you think it looks nice."

Oxenbury only thought of turning to illustrations when her first child was born. "I'd seen John working, so I knew about the process and I wanted to do something at home." She started with a simple counting book and an ABC, and then moved on to illustrating other people's texts. "I've no idea what influenced me at the time, but I had drawn a lot as a child and I did masses of life drawing at art school."

She is dismayed and horrified at the loss of life drawing from schools and art schools and its replacement by computer-generated art. "Illustration is all about the characters' relationship to each other or with an animal, or whatever. It's about that contact. How can that be shown by googly-eyed creatures?"

Working with publisher Sebastian Walker has been one of the strongest influences on her work. They had met when Walker worked for Random House, and when he set up his own company, he called Helen, who had then just had her third child, and persuaded her to do a book for his new list. The result was her series of classic board books, such as Shopping and The Dancing Class, in which her skill at capturing the exact poses and features of children is shown at its best - the illustrations were closely modelled on observation of her own daughter, Emily. "I love the look of very young children, and I loved being around them when my children were small." Now a grandmother, she once again has her own models on at hand.

She is offered hundreds of stories to illustrate, but turns most of them down, confining herself to about one picture book a year. "I'm slower than I used to be and more critical of my work,"she says.

"It's difficult to put your finger on what it is that attracts me in a story. I don't like ones that are kissy and soppy. I think they have to have humour - subtle humour, preferably. Mostly, I suppose, it has to be a bloody good story."

fields.headline: Big in crime
fields.trailText: Maxim Jakubowski rounds up the latest releases
fields.body:
There is a distinct paucity of black writers in British crime fiction: apart from the school of X-Press "Yardie" entertainers, the only one who comes to mind is Mike Phillips. Phillips is one of those rare mystery mavens who insist on using the thriller form to question social reality. A Shadow of Myself (HarperCollins, £16.99) is his most accomplished performance yet, subverting genre to pose questions about race, history and identity.

A black British filmmaker visiting Prague meets his hitherto unknown half-brother and is pulled into a violent maelstrom of intrigue. The opposition between western-educated and Iron Curtain-bred brothers proves a compelling background for a fast-paced meditation on how politics shape personal lives. Hugely ambitious - albeit at times a touch heavy going - this is also a splendid love story and a lesson in making crime fiction relevant.

Another of our most vibrant mystery authors is Val McDermid, who improves from book to book. Her new thriller Killing the Shadows (HarperCollins, £16.99) is as compelling as her last, A Place of Execution (HarperCollins, £6.99), just out in paperback. McDermid has become our leading pathologist of everyday evil, and she both thrills and scares in this tale of celebrity stalking with a difference, in which the new technologies take on a most sinister colouring. The subtle orchestration of terror is masterful, and puts American experts such as the much-overrated Patricia Cornwell to shame.

Mary Scott is the author of the award-winning literary novel Not In Newbury. Her debut crime novel, Murder on Wheels (Allison & Busby, £16.99), sees her tackling genre fiction with gusto. Bryan Greyshott was a high-flying executive, now paralysed and confined to a home where he and his fellow wheelchair-users are patronised by the staff. When a spate of murders disrupts the place's routine, Bryan decides to investigate.The sleuth in a chair is a new spin on conventions and the results are black, comic and provocative.

For over a decade Lindsey Davis has been regaling readers with the tales of Marcus Didius Falco, an Imperial Rome sleuth whose style mirrors the romantic side of Philip Marlow. Ode to a Banker (Century, £16.99) is the 12th Falco romp, and a witty satire of publishing and banking with striking contemporary resonance. All the usual suspects are here: Falco, his beloved, his rascally father, Nux his dog. Rome is brought to uproarious life: hot, noisy, smelly and full of unforgettable characters.


Buy A Place of Execution at BOL
Buy Murder on Wheels at BOL

fields.headline: Samuel Johnson Prize
fields.trailText: Stephen Fry on Inigo Jones, a tribute to Barabara Cartland and Berlioz triumphant
fields.body:
 To the swanky Banqueting House in Whitehall for some upper-crust bib and tucker in celebration of the Samuel Johnson Prize for Non-fiction. No sign of former judge and local resident Cherie Blair, who was presumably busy wringing out a bucketful of terry nappies and expressing milk.

In charge of proceedings was Chair of the Judges Nigella Lawson, elegantly bedecked in pink in honour of the late lamented Dame Barbara Cartland. Indeed, she had her work cut out for her, with each judge speaking about each shortlisted book before John Sessions read an extract - a rather convoluted process that lasted well into the night. However, it threw up some nice moments, as Stephen Fry (described as the Henry Fonda of the judging panel) commented on the boom and echo of the room: "Inigo - marvellous architect. Doesn't really know anything about acoustic engineering, does he?".

 The Loafer had a jolly time sitting at shortlisted author Brenda Maddox's table. A tense moment occurred as Timothy Garton Ash began his address on her book - a biography of Yeats - with the idea that "even if you're reading a not very good non-fiction book, you can still learn something". To which Maddox, with a horrified look on her face, mouthed the words "Does he mean me?".

 The prize eventually went to David Cairns for the second volume of his biography of Berlioz, at which there was much rejoicing in the Penguin camp. What might he do with the £30,000 prize money? Bribe the LSO to allow him to conduct them, of course. Meanwhile, Fourth Estate, with both Matt Ridley and Francis Wheen on the shortlist, were less than overjoyed, MD Victoria Barnsley departing with her eyes fixed firmly on the heavens - and before the Loafer had time to quiz her on rumours that Fourth Estate is about to be bought by HarperCollins, with Barnsley herself mooted as a possible successor to Eddie Bell.

 Signs of the times: The Poetry Society announce that Lever Brothers (they probably make your fabric conditioner) have appointed Jackie Wills as their official poet in residence. She, we are told, will "encourage the team to approach product development from a new angle" in a programme designed to foster the links between business and poetry. Expect an ode or two to accompany your fresh, soft towels from now on.

fields.headline: The gripes of Roth
fields.standfirst: Philip Roth's anti-heroes in The Human Stain are steamrollered by the zeitgeist
fields.trailText: Philip Roth's anti-heroes in The Human Stain are steamrollered by the zeitgeist
fields.body:
The Human Stain
Philip Roth
Jonathan Cape, £16.99, 361pp

After dissecting the secret torment of Swede Levov in American Pastoral and documenting the public humiliation of Ira Ringold in I Married A Communist, Philip Roth consummates his trilogy of investigations into the post-war American psyche with another surge of bold, dense prose, fusing a tragedy of rare intelligence and emotional power from the fragments of truncated lives.

As Levov was undermined by his daughter's revolt over the Vietnam war and Ringold was broken by his wife's complicity in the McCarthy witch-hunts, so, in The Human Stain, Coleman Silk falls victim to the resurgent puritanism that put Clinton on trial for a series of banal sexual indiscretions, inflated by the media into the rapacious progress of a Grand Guignol. In each novel, successful men are scuppered by historical forces beyond their control: zonked by the zeitgeist. The trilogy is given consistency by this tragic structure, refracted through the narrative voice of Roth's fictional alter ego, Nathan Zuckerman, although each is self-contained.

Zuckerman, living in retreat in rural Massachusetts, befriends Coleman Silk, a professor of classics who has resigned his position after being accused of racism by two black students. The charge against Silk revolves around a single word: spooks. "Does anybody know them or are they spooks?" Silk asks his class of a couple of absentees. He means "ghosts", of course, but the two students assume that he spoke the word with its secondary, barbed and racist meaning of "negroes". His colleagues either stay neutral or are swayed by Delphine Roux, the new feminist head of faculty, to side with the students.

Through the story of Silk's disgrace, Roth captures the hysteria and absurdity characteristic of the era of political correctness. When the speaker's intention is disregarded and replaced by prurient suspicion, freedom of expression is sacrificed to the overwrought sensitivities of special-interest groups who, like Dostoyevsky's Underground Man, will pretend to find malice in the most innocuous words. Roth implies that PC abrogates the First Amendment.

The stupendous irony in the charge against Coleman Silk is that he is himself black. Silk is an adventurer in self-identity, a man who has revolted against the inclusive "we" of the ethnic group, staking his existence on "the raw I" and its protean ability to change shape and migrate through chosen identities.

Silk lives behind a screen of self-invention, occluding his black roots behind the meticulously maintained persona of an olive-skinned Jew. Only three times is his disguise seen through: by a black woman whom he dated as a young man; by Nathan Zuckerman, when he meets Silk's sister Ernestine at her brother's funeral; and by Faunia Fairly, the cleaner who was Silk's lover in the Viagra-fuelled libido-fest through which he managed to salve some of the pain of his fall from grace. To the society which exiles Silk, he is permanently unknown.

Silk's relationship with Faunia, his "Voluptas" who conceals her middle-class education behind the pretence that she cannot read, is steeped in fatality. Raped by her step-father, abused by her husband and - after the death of their two children - compulsively stalked by him, she is as much a victim as Silk of the aggressive tendencies in American life.

As the hyper-literate professor and the fake illiterate are double victims, so the moralising Delphine Roux becomes twinned in nemesis with the resentful husband, Les Fairly. A veteran of two tours of Vietnam, he is America's bad conscience coming back to haunt it, a return of its darkest repressions. When the narrative becomes infused with Fairly's voice, it snarls with recrimination and anger. The description of his failure to reconcile himself to the wounds gouged in his life is one of the novel's highest achievements.

Equally powerful is the contrapuntal voice of Faunia, as she rhapsodises about becoming a wild crow and washing off "the human stain". She will arrive at the insight that the stain is indelible: "We leave a stain, we leave a trail, we leave our imprint. Impurity, cruelty, abuse, error, excrement, semen - there's no other way to be here. Nothing to do with disobedience. Nothing to do with grace or redemption. It's in everyone. Indwelling. Inherent. Defining... It's why all the cleansing is a joke. A barbaric joke at that. The fantasy of purity is appalling. It's insane. What is the quest to purify, if not more impurity?"

Like Salman Rushdie, like the Greek tragic poets, Roth depicts a world in which humans are mixed-up beings, scrambled out of the odds and ends of inherited traits and acquired experience, animal propensities and spiritual aspirations.

Sartre argued in Existentialism and Humanism that "existence precedes essence". Roth might retort that existence precludes essence, that human beings can never arrive at stable self-definition through their conscious activity. He maintains that this is not because we fail to recognise what we truly are, or because we have deserted God, but because human beings are the ultimate hybrid. Faunia, the crow-woman, lover of the veiled Silk, becomes "reconciled to the horrible, elemental imperfection" in us all. The Human Stain invites its readers to do likewise as it unfolds its resounding plea for tolerance.

The Human Stain invites its readers to do likewise as it unfolds its resounding plea for tolerance.

fields.headline: The stuff of the world
fields.standfirst: Paul Strathern reveals how one man's obsession built the periodic table in Mendeleyev's Dream
fields.trailText: Paul Strathern reveals how one man's obsession built the periodic table in Mendeleyev's Dream
fields.body:
Mendeleyev's Dream: The Quest for the Elements
Paul Strathern
Hamish Hamilton, £12.99, 308pp

The Periodic Table is one of the great summary statements of how things are. Its neat rows and columns of elements adorn the walls of labs and lecture theatres throughout the world. It is the modern answer to the question that defines chemistry: what kinds of stuff is the world made of, and what can you do with them?

And it did not come easy. By the second half of the 19th century, the catalogue of ur-substances went way beyond the earth, air, fire and water of the ancients. There were dozens of them, each supposed to have its own kind of indivisible atoms. And their temperaments were hugely diverse. They were variously solids, liquids or gases, heavy or light, shiny or dull. Some had almost no chemistry, some were explosively reactive. But so what? How could a chemistry textbook ever be more than a whole lot of lists?

Paul Strathern takes the long way round to the answer. After giving a tantalising glimpse of the shaggy, bearded obsessive Dmitri Mendeleyev about to crack the problem on a snowy February afternoon in St Petersburg in 1869, he traces a path through the entire history of science. Before we finally get to see Mendeleyev call the elements to order, we are treated to a lengthy narrative that moves from Greek science through to the establishment of chemistry as a discipline in its own right. It is mostly a well-told tale, focusing on remarkable individuals such as the itinerant medieval physician Paracelsus, an inspired egomaniac who hawked his remedies from town to town, staying in each one just long enough to fall out with the authorities.

Strathern's treatment of Paracelsus, and everyone else, only grates when he insists on giving them brownie points for what we now regard as scientific thinking and black marks for anything else. In a history of chemistry this causes particular problems with alchemy, to which virtually everyone he writes about in the first half of the book was deeply committed.

Strathern seems to find this irritating and puzzling by turns. Writing of the great theologian and philosopher Thomas Aquinas's attachment to alchemy, he confesses: "It is difficult to imagine how the woolly ramblings of hermetic philosophy could have co-existed with the theological rigour of scholastic philosophy in the mind of Aquinas." Others who let him down include Isaac Newton and Newton's contemporary Robert Boyle, who looked like a scientist but "sadly" also believed in alchemy. This whiggishness, which sees alchemy as mere metaphysical contagion or mumbo-jumbo, is always a temptation in a popular narrative, but it is lousy history.

Things get better, and the pace brisker, once we get past the scientific revolution. There is then a clearer track through a recognisably modern enterprise, pursued by scientists such as Dalton, Priestley, Lavoisier and the monumentally eccentric Henry Cavendish. And, finally, back to Mendeleyev.

Whiggish or not, it is fair to see his inauguration of a new chemical order as the culmination of a lengthy quest. Armed with an encyclopaedic knowledge of chemistry, fierce concentration and a penchant for playing patience, he succeeded in creating the array that everyone else was hoping to find but couldn't quite see.

The principle was simple: place the elements in columns in order of their atomic weights, and in rows which contain groups with similar properties. The reality was more complex. Not all the rows or columns turned out to be the same length. Some elements appeared out of sequence. And there were the gaps. Never mind, said Mendeleyev, with a conviction in the power of his pattern which remains awesome even now all the facts are in. If the sequence looks awry, measure those weights again. And the gaps? Go and look for new elements. I'll tell you the properties they will have. A nail-biting decade followed, but the next two elements discovered fitted his predictions exactly. Chemistry had a new backbone.

In a way, Mendeleyev's startling insight was just the start of a more satisfying story. One reason the periodic table endures is that it has been able to find spaces for nearly double the number of elements it started with. The more compelling reason is that, not too long after that afternoon in St Petersburg, sub-atomic physics was able to explain exactly why each element behaves as it does. Linus Pauling, the greatest chemist of the next century, used the language of quantum mechanics to show exactly how orbiting electrons bind atoms together. The fact that the structure of Mendeleyev's table stayed the same through the several scientific revolutions that stand between him and Pauling is some measure of the Russian's achievement. And it makes his fabulously successful card game a fitting end to Strathern's brisk tour of the history of his science.

 Jon Turney teaches science communication at University College London.

fields.headline: Home run
fields.standfirst: Gary Younge  follows Caryl Phillips' voyage around black history in The Atlantic Sound
fields.trailText: Gary Younge follows Caryl Phillips' voyage around black history in The Atlantic Sound
fields.body:
The Atlantic Sound
Caryl Phillips
Faber, £16.99, 240pp
Buy it at BOL

Going on holiday with Caryl Phillips would be a curious experience. His intellectual curiosity leads him to fascinating parts of the world, often in interesting ways - across the Atlantic in a banana boat, for example. But his socially conservative nature denies him all sorts of adventurous possibilities when he gets there. He avoids verbal contact with strangers (if it were not for the interviews he set up before he left, you wonder whether he would speak to anyone at all), frets about air conditioning and bans music from the car for fear that it will distract his driver.

A fortnight of such fastidiousness in foreign parts would drive you insane. You imagine a sweaty standoff in a sun-baked street: Phillips pleading for a return to the hotel for a poolside nap, you screaming: "If I'd known you were going to be like this we would have gone to Tenerife."

For all that, The Atlantic Sound is, for the most part, impressive. The writing is clear and elegant, the pace varied and the thesis underpinning the project engaging. At its heart lies an exploration of various notions of "home" through a series of visits to pivotal points in what has become known as the Black Atlantic - the once financially lucrative and still culturally resonant triangle that linked Africa, the Americas and Britain in the trade of slaves and other goods. It starts with Phillips retracing the journey he made as an infant in his mother's arms by boat from the Caribbean to Britain, then moves to Liverpool, Ghana and South Carolina; a peculiar and incongruous trip to Israel is added as an epilogue that feels like an afterthought.

Phillips is at his strongest when narrating other people's stories. He relates with compelling style the life of Mohammed Mansour Nassirudeen, a Ghanaian who was arrested, imprisoned and deported from England for being an illegal immigrant after a string of poorly paid dead-end jobs and aborted attempts to study. He approaches with sensitivity Mansour's frustrations at the drifting life of unemployment in Ghana, but remains critical of his determination to flee his native land again in search of illegal life in America.

Similarly engaging is his depiction of the white South Carolinian judge J Waties Waring and his wife Elizabeth, who risked and lost both their social and political standing in Charleston's high society when they made their stand against segregation. Through the political self-exile of the Americans and the partially self-inflicted economic displacement of the Ghanaian, we begin to understand the complex relationship that individuals have to negotiate - between where they are from geographically and where they are going intellectually.

Phillips is at his weakest when telling his own story. He recites his actions in what feels like real time, so that what looks like attention to detail reads as a laborious account of the banal. He tells us when he is opening books, consulting maps and supping inconsequential pints. A four-page account of waiting for a delayed plane followed by a non-conversation with a drunk fellow passenger is rarely the stuff of which good travel writing is made.

In common with most literature of this genre, the book is deliberately disjointed in sequence and style - like the collective consciousness of the black diaspora itself, it shifts between the past and present, the personal and polemical. It is a style which Phillips has mastered in his fiction, particularly The Nature of Blood and The Final Passage, but in The Atlantic Sound it occasionally jars. The account of an African trader's stay in Liverpool, where he attempted to recoup money swindled from his father by a corrupt Liverpudlian, begins as abruptly as it ends, making Phillips's account of his own time in the city feel like an adjunct rather than a complement to the 19th-century story.

Yet when humour emerges - as in a visit to a festival in Ghana centred around the "return" of westerners of African descent to "Mother Africa" - the writing throws up comic scenes that expose the tensions within the diaspora: a row between Ghanaians and African-Americans about who should be responsible for the slave fortresses on the coast; the Jamaicans who give an African concierge a patronising lecture on the benefits of ensuite facilities and are finally ejected from the hotel because they want to smoke marijuana in their rooms. To add insult to injury, they have picked the lemon grass planted to keep mosquitoes away and made tea out of it.

The Ghanaian festival is a gathering of people for whom Africa has become a psychological crutch - the practitioners of "quick ethnic fixes and cheap pseudo-solidarities" that Paul Gilroy, in his recent book, refers to as "an inadequate salve for real pain". The reader is left in no doubt as to what Caryl Phillips makes of these confected identities. What is not clear, however, is what impact these travels have had on Phillips's own sense of self. As a journey around the globe the book is intriguing; but as a voyage of self-discovery it never quite arrives.

 Gary Younge is the author of No Place Like Home: A Black Briton's Journey Through the American South, published by Picador (£16).

fields.headline: Race for sale
fields.standfirst: Andy Beckett  admires Paul Gilroy's polemic on black identity, Between Camps
fields.trailText: Andy Beckett admires Paul Gilroy's polemic on black identity, Between Camps
fields.body:
Between Camps: Nations, Cultures and the Allure of Race
Paul Gilroy
Penguin, £22.50, 406pp

In 1937, when Hitler and Mussolini looked a lot like the political future, the black American activist and visionary Marcus Garvey gave a disquieting interview. "We were the first fascists," he boasted of his efforts to establish a separate black nation during the 1920s. "We had disciplined men, women and children in training for the liberation of Africa. The black masses saw that in this extreme nationalism lay their only hope... Mussolini copied fascism from me."

Nowadays, you could see this as just a foolish moment. Plenty of reckless people found themselves enthusing about dictators during the inter-war years. Yet to Paul Gilroy, the author of this brave and unsparing book, Garvey's bragging is more than an embarrassing footnote to the history of black liberation. He asserts that Garvey's emphasis on racial purity, physical prowess and unity of purpose have remained features of worldwide black politics ever since, and he does not like the consequences.

On the one hand he sees blackness being ever more defensively defined: by militant rappers, African despots and uniformed street organisations such as the Nation of Islam. On the other hand, he sees this identity being exploited - and outflanked - by the white-run global economy. Black styles and physiques are increasingly things to be sold by international corporations to mostly non-black consumers.

More benign developments, meanwhile, such as increasing intermarriage and migration and the discrediting of the old pseudo-sciences of racial difference, mean that "the idea of 'race' has lost much of its commonsense credibility". What is needed in its place, Gilroy says, is something more flexible and realistic, a loose multiculturalism that recognises difference and past discrimination but does not fetishise them. By page two, he has already coined a grand phrase for it: "planetary humanism".

Such universal pronouncements require confidence. Gilroy, unusually for a black British academic - in fact, for any British academic - has the international status to publish a work as burstingly over-ambitious as this. He currently teaches African-American studies at Yale, but this book contains little of the race-reverent, introverted stuff sometimes implied by that subject. Gilroy's background is in sociology and cultural studies, and his frame of reference happily encompasses film criticism, theories of fascism and recent events in Africa. The acknowledgments, like those in publications by Umberto Eco or Jean Baudrillard, speak of star turns in lecture halls from Berlin to the University of California.

Unfortunately, such postmodernist polymaths tend to write in riddles. This volume is no exception. Its second sentence reads, in part, as follows: "...this book addresses some of the continuing tensions associated with the constitution of political communities in racialised form." Gilroy says he dislikes exclusivity of all kinds; yet nervous readers may get no further than this roadblock of grey jargon. His arguments circle and subdivide and eddy, obscured by overhanging abstract nouns, slowed by great mudbanks of qualification, definitions of terms, and self-conscious statements of assumptions. You wonder, during the 135-page introduction, whether all this represents a sort of fearfulness - whether Gilroy is actually reluctant to state his heresies.

It is worth persisting, though. Gradually, Gilroy's free association acquires a suggestive logic of its own. He begins in Germany in the 1930s, with the propaganda revolution of the Nazis. He notes its eerie modernity: the use of the swastika as an early corporate logo, the media-age emphasis on sound and symbols and spectacle, the slow, loving gaze of Leni Riefenstahl's cameras - just like a modern ad director's - over the bodies of athletic young males. Then Gilroy shows how precisely these innovations have infiltrated the modern entertainment economy, in particular the parts of it concerned with selling blackness. And who are the middlemen in this process? None other than contemporary black nationalists, Garvey's spiritual descendants, such as the film director Spike Lee and the rapper and film star Ice Cube.

Gilroy is harsh on these "corporate traffickers in black culture". While they "offer a fantasy of segregation" - stern homilies about the oil-and-water properties of black-white relationships, for example - their careers in private involve moving "to and fro freely" across racial divides, collaborating with white-owned ad agencies and entertainment conglomerates to maximum personal advantage.

What is more, the images these separatist celebrities help produce, Gilroy says, do more harm than good to the black "community" they claim to represent. Idealised black athletes, earthy black musicians, horny black film stars - white people are quite capable of admiring such figures while despising their race, or of having their prejudices about "noble savages" confirmed. Riefenstahl spent her post-Nazi career taking heroic photographs of Africans.

Gilroy ventures further. This worship of muscle and melanin to the exclusion of other qualities has become part of black sensibilities too. Gyms and jeeps dominate the black public culture; in this "fortified" world of perpetual feuds and competition for prestige, politics "is reduced to the dimensions of a basketball court". The old battles for equality are glibly remembered on baseball caps, but the need to continue these campaigns is much less of an easy sell.

Instead, as Gilroy describes it, the Nation of Islam, the Military Fruit of Islam and other black paramilitary bodies spend their time practising parade-ground drills like blackshirts and mobilising against fantastical-sounding opponents such as the Illuminati and the New World Order. Black nationalists share this paranoid worldview with the far-right fringe of white politics, with whom some of them are increasingly cosy. Gilroy's sentences rise to eloquence with his indignation at it all.

But some of his contentions seem overstated. The "idea of race" questioned here remains malevolently alive in the minds of many politicians and people of violence. And Gilroy seems too pessimistic about the state of black politics. The campaign for justice for Stephen Lawrence, for example, with its coalition of black, Asian and white Britons, receives only a few passing mentions. In many democracies, black people continue to vote in large numbers - despite the few black candidates offered to them. In Britain, studies of elections show that issues other than race dominate the thoughts of the black electorate.

The evidence here to the contrary is mostly American. Perhaps Gilroy is extrapolating too far from his experiences of a society where, more than elsewhere, gyms and jeeps and tribal allegiances have always trumped politics, in every ethnic group. It is noticeable that the writing on pop culture is American-dominated too; Gilroy finds little space for less identity-fixated black entertainers from Europe, who, in dance music for example, have been openly and easily collaborating with other races for decades.

In the last part of the book, Gilroy promises to move beyond race to describe a "cosmopolitan yet-to-come". Yet, as the vagueness of that phrase suggests, it never quite crystallises. "As we leave the century of the colour line behind," he writes, "we need self-consciously to become more future-oriented." But his long paragraphs keep ducking back into the past, into previous explorations of race and attempts to escape its confines. For a while, Gilroy tries to find the future in the prophecies of space travel and extraterrestrial contact put about by black musicians like Sun Ra and George Clinton in the 1970s. Then he seeks signs of successful multiculturalism in recent action movies such as Men in Black, in black and white blasting aliens together.

All this reads a little too much like weightless cultural-studies speculation. Then again, just because this volume finally fails as prophecy does not devalue it as provocation. The restless, all-absorbing, questioning intelligence of Gilroy's sharpest chapters is his own best argument against the nervous orthodoxies of identity politics. I just wonder what his colleagues will make of it all.

In Britain, studies of elections show that issues other than race dominate the thoughts of the black electorate. The evidence here to the contrary is mostly American. Perhaps Gilroy is extrapolating too far from his experiences of a society where, more than elsewhere, gyms and jeeps and tribal allegiances have always trumped politics, in every ethnic group. It is noticeable that the writing on pop culture is American-dominated too; Gilroy finds little space for less identity-fixated black entertainers from Europe, who, in dance music for example, have been openly and easily collaborating with other races for decades. In the last part of the book, Gilroy promises to move beyond race to describe a "cosmopolitan yet-to-come". Yet, as the vagueness of that phrase suggests, it never quite crystallises. "As we leave the century of the colour line behind," he writes, "we need self-consciously to become more future-oriented." But his long paragraphs keep ducking back into the past, into previous explorations of race and attempts to escape its confines. For a while, Gilroy tries to find the future in the prophecies of space travel and extraterrestrial contact put about by black musicians like Sun Ra and George Clinton in the 1970s. Then he seeks signs of successful multiculturalism in recent action movies such as Men in Black, in black and white blasting aliens together. All this reads a little too much like weightless cultural-studies speculation. Then again, just because this volume finally fails as prophecy does not devalue it as provocation. The restless, all-absorbing, questioning intelligence of Gilroy's sharpest chapters is his own best argument against the nervous orthodoxies of identity politics. I just wonder what his colleagues will make of it all.
